webTitle: Microsoft leads new slide in US tech stocks

fields.headline: Microsoft leads new slide in US tech stocks
fields.standfirst:
Break-up rumours aggravate sell-off
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: US technology stocks suffered a day of heavy losses yesterday in response to disappointing earnings growth by Microsoft and reports that the government is leaning towards a breakup of the software group.
fields.body:
US technology stocks suffered a day of heavy losses yesterday in response to disappointing earnings growth by Microsoft and reports that the government is leaning towards a breakup of the software group.

The Nasdaq composite index fell 208.43 points, or 5.72%, to 3,434.47 in late morning trading as the gloom about Microsoft's prospects spread across the rest of the technology sector.

Intel, the world's largest chip manufacturer, was among the early fallers, losing $2.06 to $113.31 by mid-afternoon. Cisco Systems, which provides much of the hardware that manages data flow across the internet, fell 3 to 62.

Sun Microsystems, one of the big players in the server market, was also on the slide, along with the cellular phone equipment maker Qualcomm, Yahoo!, the online auctioneer eBay and Amazon.com, the internet retailer, which dipped 4 1/16 to 47 11/16.

But Microsoft's difficulties - which were the trigger a few weeks ago for one of Wall Street's worst falls on record - failed to spread to the rest of the market, with the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average registering little change.

After the three-day Easter holiday it was the first day of trading since Thursday night's warning by the company that business demand for PCs was waning. The share price was marked down from the outset in New York.

The damage was compounded by reports that the courts may order the break-up of the Microsoft group for violating anti-trust laws. Sources close to the case said the government would propose splitting it into two, separating its Office software from the Windows operating system.

"There is a feeling that if Microsoft's growth rate is going to be lower then the stock warrants a lower valuation," said Harvey Hirshhorn, chief economist and investment strategist at fund manager Stein Roe and Farnham.

"You also have near term concern about corporate PC growth and you are getting downgrades and talk that the federal government may be pressing to break it up."

Yesterday's losses in the technology sector came at the start of what is likely to be a volatile week for trading, with a plethora of economic data due to be released which could influence share valuations.

Today there will be consumer confidence and homes sales data for the market to digest. Tomorrow brings the latest durable goods orders and on Thursday the government will publish key output and employment costs figures.

Economists say tame wage pressures would help to sooth angst at the US Federal Reserve over March's higher than expected inflation data but are unlikely to prevent further rate rises.

The next Fed meeting on May 16 will probably result in a quarter-point increase, although some analysts fear a half-point rise to guard against the risks of overheating.

fields.headline: Saved by bluegrass
fields.standfirst:
BBC Radio 2 Country Festival
London Arena
Rating: * *
fields.trailText:
BBC Radio 2 Country Festival
London Arena
Rating: * *
fields.body:
Tobacco-chewing old timers might remember the country festivals of yesteryear, held at Wembley Arena. The London Arena is a much nicer venue, except you have to drag yourself to Docklands to find it.

No matter. Cowpokes from Pontefract and Cheam had braved the Easter showers, and were determined to soak up some of that ol' country ambience. However, watching the folks as they rooted and tooted around the merchandising stalls or indulged in lethargic line-dancing in the Arena's Glengall Room, I couldn't fathom why they were all dressed like fast-food attendants from Arkansas.

A 6.30pm start was early enough for me, by which time Jo Dee Messina was cranking it out onstage. A rumbustious redhead in skin-tight pink PVC trousers, Jo Dee fronted a band of journeyman rockers and kept the message simple. Jo Dee was enthusiastic but not great, though she was markedly superior to the awful Grand Ole Opry video clips shown on giant screens between artists. Luckily Ricky Skaggs arrived to rescue us.

Once ridiculed by the style gurus of the Old Grey Whistle Test for his unsuitable haircut, Skaggs is now clean shaven and committed to the cause of playing unadulterated bluegrass. Bluegrass doesn't mean high-speed banjo playing by retarded yokels in Deliverance, but rather a rich and varied palette of acoustic sounds, played on fiddle, guitar, banjo and mandolin. The only thing wrong with Ricky's set was its brevity.

If only the same could be said of Reba McEntire, whose headlining performance set new benchmarks in mawkishness and insincerity. There was the maudlin What Do You Say?, complete with accompanying video in which mom dies of cancer. There was The Greatest Man I Never Knew, a treacly tearjerker about her father. There were glutinous references to her son Shelby, and cloying odes to motherhood. It reminded you why country music remains so stubbornly American.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: 'Realistic' Durlacher begins to retreat from website investment

fields.headline: 'Realistic' Durlacher begins to retreat from website investment
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The golden age of the internet start-up might already be over. Durlacher, one of the most prolific venture capital companies to foster the growth of the British online sector, has decided to pull back from future investments in business-to-consumer websites.
fields.body:
The golden age of the internet start-up might already be over. Durlacher, one of the most prolific venture capital companies to foster the growth of the British online sector, has decided to pull back from future investments in business-to-consumer websites.

David Pannell, a senior consultant with the company, yesterday said the market had become more "realistic" about potential rewards from conventional websites relying on e-commerce and advertising.

The venture capital company has made only one investment in a consumer-based business since the end of last year - a pop music website set up by the Spice Girls' former guru, Simon Fuller.

"We stopped investing in that kind of business around Christmas unless it is a very compelling proposition," Mr Pannell said.

"Lastminute.com demonstrated the top of the boom. E-tailing was at its peak about four months ago and there was a lot of money pouring in on the assumption that there would be a significant shift in sales from the high street to the online environment.

"There are now very few being launched, and most of those around will go out of business or get bought.

"Take-up has not been as rapid as people thought, and the cost of acquiring customers is extremely high."

The market, he added, was suffering from chronic oversupply after the slew of start-ups last year which fuelled the internet boom.

More recent Durlacher investments are focused on underlying technology which allows existing bricks-and-mortar firms to go online.

The shift was demonstrated yesterday by a £300,000 injection in online security business Datamark in return for 5% of the company's equity.

"A few months ago we would say as long as you can get advertising then we can worry about other sources of revenue later on. Now we want a clear source of revenue."

Durlacher's better known investments have included 365 Corporation, the sports content and websites business, and Autonomy, the software company run by Mike Lynch which has been a phenomenal stock market success.

Durlacher also has stakes in software company Zeus Technology, online CD retailer Boxman and Online Travel, which are all understood to be planning flotation.

Mr Pannell said there was still a wealth of investment opportunities. "The economy is shifting, perhaps not as fast some people had thought, and there will be hiccups.

"But the excitement is still there because the internet is one of the few areas where innovative small start-ups can grow very quickly and very profitably. That wouldn't happen in the steel sector."

fields.headline: Banks don't answer in cyberspace
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: High street banks would never make their customers queue for six days in one of their branches, yet according to new research this is precisely what many financial firms expect of customers trying to bank over the internet.
fields.body:
High street banks would never make their customers queue for six days in one of their branches, yet according to new research this is precisely what many financial firms expect of customers trying to bank over the internet.

At a time when many banks are closing branches and trying to lure customers into cyberspace instead, the research shows that 61% of companies may be failing to meet customer expectations.

The research was commissioned by Microsoft and Onyx, an e-business software house.

Samia Rauf, marketing director at Onyx, said that "mystery shopping" of 126 financial firms also showed that many responses consisted of standard information rather than personal replies.

"These results do not speak of an industry preparing itself for revolution.

"Nor do they speak of an industry that knows how to sell to its customers," says the report's author, Paul Gant, from management consultancy Market Elan.

The researchers tried to contact 126 financial firms, including the major high street banks, investment banks and building societies, between January and March over the internet. They found that 31% did not have a website or had one which did not allow them to submit an electronic request for information.

Of those to which a request could be made, 26% failed to respond at all, while a further 17% took six days or longer to reply.

Of the companies which did reply to the request for information, 80% of them did not bother to follow up the "mystery shopper" - by telephoning, for instance.

Ms Rauf said she was surprised by the research. "If you go into a bank branch you are not going to stand there for six days waiting for someone to deal with you," she said.

She said the internet, through which customers could fire off requests for information about products from hundreds of firms, was all about speed. "It's a race for which of the firms responds first," she said.

Ms Rauf suggested that one of the reasons the firms appeared so badly equipped might be a breakdown in communication within their organisation: for instance the marketing department may have set up the website but not consulted with the IT department properly about how to best use it.

fields.headline: One2One faces £2.2bn hurdle
fields.trailText: One2One is expected to push the value of bids in the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences past £22.2bn today, as it reopens the bidding after a five-day break.
fields.body:
One2One is expected to push the value of bids in the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences past £22.2bn today, as it reopens the bidding after a five-day break.

There are six remaining contenders for the five licences on offer. Bidding goes in strict rotation and it is the turn of One2One, owned by Deutsche Telekom, to resume the auction in the first of several rounds expected today.

One2One, the UK's fourth biggest mobile phone operator, yesterday affirmed its commitment to winning a licence. "We have always said we expect to end up with a licence and that is certainly our intention," a company spokeswoman said.

Today's bidding is also likely to see the value of licence B pushed above £6bn as it continues to be battled over by Vodafone and British Telecom. BT last week continued its game of one-upmanship with Vodafone as each operator offered more than the other in the successive bidding rounds.

Licence B is attractive to Vodafone and BT as it offers the most capacity available to the four incumbent operators.

Both these operators' existing networks are fully com mitted and they need to buy as much extra capacity as possible to be able to expand their customer base.

Licence A, the biggest licence, has been reserved for a new entrant. The two remaining contenders in this battle are NTL Mobile, which is being supported by France Tele com, and TIW, a Canadian company which is backed by Hutchison Whampoa.

Some analysts expect the auction to peak this week with the prices being paid for the licences already well in excess of even the government's own conservative estimates. A report by Lombard Street Re search has criticised the auction as "hobbling the new economy to finance government debt paydown, tax cuts and/or spending increases. Whichever it is, it is a major economic blunder".

The report predicts that the expense of the licences will cut third generation mobile phone usage to one third of earlier forecasts.

Coupled with strong competition among the five operators, this could see the new generation of phones being sold at a marginal cost to buy market share.

The report said that the risk in such a strategy is that one of the operators could quickly be forced out of business. However, there are equally grave risks for each of the four existing operators in not winning a licence.

These include the potential for collapse in the operators' stock market values, loss of customers, damage to their international reputation and future business strategy.

fields.headline: Mixing with the best
fields.standfirst:
Twice As Nice
The End, London
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText:
Twice As Nice
The End, London
Rating: * * *
fields.body:
UK garage has certainly taken giant steps forward since Scott Garcia of MC Luck proclaimed: "It's a London thing," a few years back. Since then the country has gradually fostered a collective ear for two-step garage, a synthesis of electro, hip-hop, US garage, reggae and R&B, and sent Craig David to the higher echelons of the charts. Radio 1 sensibly rewarded the genre's premier DJ squad, the Dreem Team, with a show earlier this year; and as part of their Easter Sunday Live Sessions, the station took a leap into the Dreem Team's natural home: Twice As Nice at The End club in London.

Twice As Nice has been serving a primordial soup of hardcore's kinetic energy and reggae basslines to a devoted crowd of dancers for four years. In that time it has been at the forefront of the music's transformation from robotic pitch shifting, divas on helium and wayward sample structure to music that has rapidly transcended its inspirations to produce a sound that is more dynamic, directly expressive and deep.

As befits their party hard reputation, Spoony, Mikee B and Timmi Magic looked as though they were enjoying themselves behind the decks. At the height of their three-hour set, the boys managed to shoehorn 10 years of cutting edge dance music - house, garage, hip-hop beats - into a pretty good mix.

However, across both two-step rooms, the music itself was presented in a cut up fashion with irritating cartoonish samples and MCs who continually ruined the flow of tracks such as Ty Holden's gospel mantra, Heaven, with their incessant chatter.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Shimmering spirituality
fields.standfirst:
Bach's Easter Oratorio
Barbican Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
Bach's Easter Oratorio
Barbican Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.body:
Paul McCreesh's Gabrieli Consort and Players celebrated Easter Day with a moving, exhilarating concert which fleetingly contained the entirety of Christian revelation. Bach's Magnificat was placed alongside his Easter Oratorio: the Virgin Mary's rapturous hymn at the Annunciation was juxtaposed with the ecstasy of the saints and apostles on beholding Christ's empty tomb.

Together, the two works make an illuminating diptych and one is forced, as always, to wonder at Bach's almost miraculous ability to convey the spiritual essence of his chosen texts. The 12 compact sections of the Magnificat are like sudden flashes of anticipatory insight. In the Oratorio, the vast tripartite choruses and arias, accompanied by woodwind obbligati of piercing beauty, give the impression of time standing still as the characters contemplate eternity.

The Gabrieli Consort and Players do both works almost to perfection. McCreesh conducts with a combination of reverence and elation, teasing out the vocal and instrumental lines with great fluency. The woodwind playing, on this occasion, was particularly outstanding, with Katy Bircher's flute wrapping Mary, mother of James, in exquisite tendrils of sound, and Katharina Spreckelsen's oboe sharply mirroring Mary Magdalen's highly charged swivelling between impatience and desire. Both players exchanged their instruments for recorders to spin out the rapt lullaby to which the apostle Peter meditates on the equation between death and sleep.

The few faults were largely those of balance. McCreesh, arguing that the choral writing is inherently "soloistic", allots a maximum of three singers to each line. The resulting gain in polyphonic clarity is offset, however, by some swamping of the singers by the brass at climactic moments. On the other hand, Kimberly McCord's rich soprano shimmered and soared through the elder Mary's mystic colloquy with her own soul (one of the most astonishing moments in Bach's entire output). You can either cope with the idea of a counter-tenor as Mary Magdalen or you can't - but Robin Blaze sang with such conviction, ease and passion that the switch in gender seemed irrelevant.

fields.bodyText: Paul McCreesh's Gabrieli Consort and Players celebrated Easter Day with a moving, exhilarating concert which fleetingly contained the entirety of Christian revelation. Bach's Magnificat was placed alongside his Easter Oratorio: the Virgin Mary's rapturous hymn at the Annunciation was juxtaposed with the ecstasy of the saints and apostles on beholding Christ's empty tomb. webTitle: How to survive a new boss

fields.headline: How to survive a new boss
fields.standfirst: Your current manager is a teddy bear and you've been working harmoniously together for years. But all that's about to change...
fields.trailText: Ever changed bosses? If the answer's yes, and you moved from Attila the Hun to Tweetie Pie the chances are you weren't too traumatised by the experience. But it's the reverse situation that causes us the most problems it seems.
fields.body:
Ever changed bosses? If the answer's yes, and you moved from Attila the Hun to Tweetie Pie the chances are you weren't too traumatised by the experience. But it's the reverse situation that causes us the most problems it seems.

Parting a team from a popular boss can be like wrenching the seven dwarves away from Snow White, with the next manager inheriting Grumpy, Resentful, Cynical, Sullen, Skulking, Obstinate and Over-critical as a result.

Few new bosses come baggage free. Even if he/she has arrived bandbox-fresh from an isolated cave in Peru, someone, somewhere will already have passed on the information that he/she can be a complete bastard first thing in the morning, and that his/her personal grooming habits leave a lot to be desired, not to mention the rumours about them downloading Internet porn during that stint in the Scunthorpe office.

Conflict, prejudice, or even fear and panic can start before the first meeting, making realistic appraisals difficult to the point of impossible.

If you built up a good track record with previous bosses in your company the chances are you'll be 'rewarded' with The One No One Else Can Work With as a result. This character will have decimated half the workforce by eating them up and spitting them out, leaving a trail of staff on stress-related sickies or suicide watch.

Your well-honed skills at bonding with bosses will mean you've earned yourself a place as their next victim. By the time colleagues have finished briefing you on every legendary foible you will feel every bit as motivated as Joan of Arc waiting for that first match to be struck.

If your boss swap is the result of a company takeover, rather than just a departmental move, you'll be coping with a complete change of culture and circumstances. The important factor in both situations is to think positively.

Confidence
Your self-esteem is vital to the success or failure of the transition. If the boss swap is internal, never get paranoid about the reasoning behind it. Some companies like constant movement and change. Perhaps you have been given the more challenging character because you are expected to be able to deal with him/her well.

Make a list of all the things you achieved under your old boss. Remind yourself of all the skills, experiences and abilities you will be bringing to the new one. Never get depressed, imagining all your hard work has vanished down the drain. This is your chance to work with a clean sheet, but it will be your past experiences that will help you manage well.

Be flexible
Watch the pursed lips and folded arms when your new boss tells you how he/she likes things done. You do things your way, but there are many ways that can be right. Keep an open mind. If you feel you know better only ever serve the information up with a big side order of tact.

Absence makes the heart grow fonder
Even if you loathed your last boss you may find time and distance blurring your vision. The same thing happens with divorcees. Somehow the past relationship just doesn't seem so bad any more. Your memory deletes the painful bits, and in the end you are wandering around pining for the old relationship.

Remember the past should never affect the future, except in a positive way. Yearning for what has gone is a waste of emotion and energy. It will also be driving colleagues, who have to put up with all your whingeing about how great your old boss was, to homicidal fantasies. Move forward. The past is another country.

Book time to talk
Bosses are busy and so are you. But neither of you will bond while you're second-guessing his/her needs or style of working. Book an appointment to talk. Be assertive and avoid nervous waffle or serious attempts at brown-nosing. Be specific with your questions and ask him/ her how they like to operate. If they're good they will even divulge any foibles and quirks, which is always supremely helpful. Work from this list when you are dealing with him/her, rather than the 'urban legend' variety that will have been passed down to you from colleagues.

Speak for yourself
Hopefully, the relationship will be two-way. Use the session to tell your boss how you like to work as well. This should be seen as a flexible negotiation, although you need to be clear about what is and isn't negotiable, if asked. If you can't work late or you won't do certain kinds of jobs, like making tea and personal chores, then this is the best time to bring it up.

Quick tips:
 Never harp on about how your last boss did it better
 Keep an open mind. Never judge before you have met
 and then reserve judgment for a while. People need a long 'breaking in' period before the real relationship starts to form
 Lower your expectations. Don't expect a friend, mentor, advisor and mother/father figure who has the wisdom of Solomon and personality of a saint. Bosses are human. Your objective is to work well together, even if you dislike one another
 Make it your job to keep the communication lines open
 Be honest and assertive
 You're not clairvoyant and neither is your boss. If you don't know something - ask.

fields.headline: A dream of Donegal
fields.standfirst:
Translations
Palace Theatre, Watford
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
Translations
Palace Theatre, Watford
Rating: * * * *
fields.body:
There is a wonderful scene in Brian Friel's play when an English lieutenant, George, part of an ordnance survey mapping operation being conducted in a remote area of Donegal in 1833, tells local Irish girl Maire of his love for her. The two lovers cannot speak each other's language, yet their ability to communicate the joy of love is totally unimpaired.

The beautiful thing about this scene, indeed the whole of Friel's magnificent 1980 play, is its subtle irony. George has fallen in love with Ireland and the Irish and yet he is actively engaged in sweeping away an ancient culture, replacing the old names for villages and features of the landscape with anglicised versions.

Friel piles on the salt by setting the play in a hedge-school, where after a day in the fields bringing in the harvest, the Gaelic-speaking community learn Latin and Greek. The incoming English soldiers despise them as illiterate peasants because they cannot speak English, but unlike the English these "peasants" can quote Homer and Virgil. English, suggests one, is a language without poetry, best suited for the purposes of commerce. But it is also the language of the conquerors, of what is set to become the dominant culture. The greatest irony of all, perhaps, is the fact that the play is written in English. Its cleverness is in convincing the audience that the English speak only English and the Irish converse in their language.

There have been plenty of plays written about England's Ireland in the past 30 years, but none as perceptive and moving as Friel's. Lawrence Till, Watford's new artistic director, treats this play with the quiet respect it deserves, delivering an intelligent and beautifully acted production that is like a long slow burn. Searing stuff.

 Until May 6. Box office: 01923 225671. Then touring to Salisbury Playhouse and the Belgrade Theatre, Coventry

webTitle: Computer sales slow as mobiles and TV email erode market share

fields.headline: Computer sales slow as mobiles and TV email erode market share
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Global personal computer sales have failed to show the acceleration expected once millennium bug problems were out of the way. Figures from Dataquest, part of the Gartner information group, show that first-quarter PC shipments rose by 15%.
fields.body:
Global personal computer sales have failed to show the acceleration expected once millennium bug problems were out of the way. Figures from Dataquest, part of the Gartner information group, show that first-quarter PC shipments rose by 15%.

This compares to industry estimates of growth between 17% and 19% made during the last quarter of last year.

Customers had been expected to postpone their PC purchases until after the turn of the year, when Y2K software problems had been resolved.

However, fresh worries have begun to unsettle the PC market, with consumers wondering whether new mobile phone or television email services will meet their needs. Others have decided to wait until the new Microsoft 2000 operating system has proved itself before buying.

Two weeks ago a leading US broker warned that the slowdown in PC sales would hit Microsoft's revenues this year.

The reduction in the PC sales growth rate could make some of the forecasts for the volume of internet shopping begin to look a little suspect.

The Dataquest figures show that Compaq has managed to maintain its position as market leader ahead of Dell.

Compaq's first-quarter sales rose 11.4% to 3.75m units, giving it 12.5% of the world market.

Dell's PC sales rose 10% to 3m, giving it 10% of the market. The company, run by the billionaire Michael Dell, is closing the gap on Compaq, mainly on internet sales.

Compaq only recently committed itself to large-scale selling over the internet while Dell is widely regarded as having the most sophisticated web-based sales strategy and highest ratio of net sales among its main rivals.

The two leaders were followed by Hewlett-Packard, IBM and NEC - with 8%, 5.9% and 4.8% of the PC market respectively.

Sluggish PC sales in Europe and the US were offset by rapid growth in Latin America, Asia and Japan.

Charles Smulders, PC analyst at Dataquest, said: "The Asia-Pacific region continues to recover economically - and with it, demand for technology is strengthening."

He said the industry needed to produce a new generation of more powerful, stylish machines to persuade businesses and consumers to replace their personal computers more frequently.

"The industry faces the challenge of finding a way to persuade existing users to replace their PCs every two to three years instead of every four to five years," he added.

The Dataquest survey showed that years of declining prices for home PCs in the US had been checked by industry consolidation after IBM and Packard-Bell decided to pull out of the retail market for these.

However computer manufacturers are trying to increase the size of the overall market by offering low price entry-level machines equipped to access the internet.

fields.headline: Börse struggles to meet deadline
fields.trailText: High-level talks between the London stock exchange and Deutsche Börse are expected to intensify this morning as pressure mounts for an agreement before a crucial German deadline next week.
fields.body:
High-level talks between the London stock exchange and Deutsche Börse are expected to intensify this morning as pressure mounts for an agreement before a crucial German deadline next week.

The Börse is anxious to clinch terms of a tie-up - which might include the Nasdaq US technology market - by May 4, when it is due to produce details of an initial public offering of its own shares.

While informal talks continued over Easter, many issues still need to resolved. The London exchange is anxious to prevent any merger being interpreted as a takeover by its German rival and headway is said to have been made on this issue over the weekend.

However, the longer the talks continue behind the scenes, the greater the speculation that merger talks will fail. Exchange sources have indicated that the terms of a deal are near to being agreed now but insist that discussions are so delicate that they could easily fall apart.

The German exchange is said to be prepared to make concessions to appease officials in London, such as basing the administrative hub of a combined exchange in the City.

But speculation about the future of Gavin Casey, chief executive of the London exchange, continues to intensify amid suggestions that his counterpart in Germany, Werner Seifer, will be offered the role. Don Cruickshank, the newly appointed chairman of the London exchange, is expected to retain the post.

fields.headline: Funds seek windfall boost
fields.standfirst: Queries raised over Barclays' role as Standard Life faces fresh assault
fields.trailText: The Barclays-run funds supporting a fresh demutualisation assault on the insurer Standard Life are among the the worst performers in their sector. This leaves the bank's investment management arm open to criticism that it is resorting to desperate measures in order to boost returns.
fields.body:
The Barclays-run funds supporting a fresh demutualisation assault on the insurer Standard Life are among the the worst performers in their sector. This leaves the bank's investment management arm open to criticism that it is resorting to desperate measures in order to boost returns.

The £80m funds stand to receive a multimillion-pound cash injection if Standard Life is forced to demutualise. A conversion resolution is due at the insurer's management this morning, just hours before its annual meeting. The three funds - which operate under the Barclays Global Investors banner - own £17m of Standard Life policies.

They are supporting a new attempt by the Standard Life Members Action Group to force the mutual insurer to float on the stock market.

The funds are also bankrolling the Monoco-run rebel group to support the demutualisation bid.

Support from BGI, which last night refused to comment, has been cited as significant boost to the campaign initiated by Australian Fred Woollard, a fund manager who personally stands to make £150,000.The action group calculates each Standard Life policyholder could receive a £6,500 windfall.

The rebel group failed to force a demutualisation vote earlier this year but this morning will make a new "requisition" to the mutual insurer, which is Europe's largest. While Standard Life, whose investment arm owns a stake in Barclays, will not put the call to its annual meeting in Edinburgh today, it must respond to SLMAG within 21 days.

Of the three BGI funds supporting the demutualisation move, two are languishing at the bottom of highly respected Micropal performance league tables over the past year.

BGI Endowment Fund III had produced a negative return of 15.08% over the year to the end of March, while fund II also turned in a negative performance, putting it in penultimate place in a sector which produced an average of 2.62% for the eight funds in the category.

Barclays' best endowment fund beat the sector average and was in fourth place but still producing half of the returns provided by the top fund. Mr Woollard insisted yesterday that Barclays was the only group prepared to publicise its support. He has als discussed his plans with Scottish Value and Dresdner RCM, two other groups with large policyholdings.

The funds work by buying endowment policies from individuals who want to cash them in, usually because of unemployment or divorce. The buyer of the policy - the investment trust - gives the individual a better price than is achievable by surrendering to the life office, and hopes to make a profit by picking up the valuable "terminal bonus", worth up 30% of the final payout. Although they are managed by investment groups such as BGI, they do have independent boards.

A spokesman for Standard Life said the insurer would adopt tough tactics at today's meeting, at which Mr Woollard is expected to push the issue of demutualisation.

The demutualisation calls met opposition from Joe Egerton of the group Justice in Financial Services, who wrote to Howard Davies, the chairman of the Financial Services Authority, urging him to remind the investors that by voting for "dosh" they would be receiving money from their own policies.

webTitle: Best yet to come from United

fields.headline: Best yet to come from United
fields.trailText: Southampton 1 - 3 Man Utd
fields.body:
Six Premier League championships in eight seasons is a remarkable feat of consistency even in a competition custom-made for plutocrats and Manchester United deserve the superlatives showered on them after they strolled to another title in the Southampton sunshine on Saturday.

Not since Liverpool won the league with 26 days to spare in 1983 has the championship been settled so early. United now have three weeks to milk the applause starting with Chelsea's visit to Old Trafford at lunchtime today, when memories of a 5-0 drubbing at Stamford Bridge last October will surely motivate Sir Alex Ferguson's players to produce something more meaningful than a lap of honour.

The principal reason for Ferguson wanting the domestic chores completed over Easter vanished last Wednesday when Real Madrid, shrugging aside their own indifferent season in the Spanish league, caught United on a bad night, played the better football and knocked them out of the Champions League in the quarter-finals.

Now, instead of contemplating the semi-finals and final in Europe unburdened by the need for Premiership points, United will be playing only for records in terms of winning margins and goals scored. Having won the European Cup last season, they have surely reached a point when success at Old Trafford is judged less by what is won at home than how far the team progress abroad.

Milan, Juventus, Real Madrid and Barcelona have all gone through this phase. Whatever happens in the Premiership next season United know that, having joined the biggest spenders in Europe with their readiness to pay £19m for Ruud van Nistelrooy, they will be regarded as successful only if they go further in the next Champions League than they have done this time.

Ferguson's declaration, after this victory at the Dell, that "this is the best United side ever" needed qualifying. If he meant the team which has emerged over the five seasons since the best of the class of '92 - the FA Youth Cup-winning side which included David Beckham, Nicky Butt and Gary Neville - followed Ryan Giggs into the first team, few would give the United manager an argument, even if the biggest single influences on the revival at Old Trafford, Eric Cantona and Peter Schmeichel, are no longer present.

Matt Busby's successful 1960s team carried more individual appeal in the shape of George Best, Denis Law and Bobby Charlton, Munich robbed his Babes of their destiny and Busby's post-war side played the outstanding football of its day. webTitle: Town tumble as Peacock does Peacock proud

fields.headline: Town tumble as Peacock does Peacock proud
fields.trailText: QPR 3 - 1 Ipswich
fields.body:
Gavin Peacock took a phone call on the morning of this match which promised him hero status in SE7 if he could come up with a decisive goal and minutes after the final whistle the QPR captain took another from the same delighted caller.

On the line was his father Keith, 17 years a Charlton player and now their assistant manager, thanking his lad for helping to secure promotion for the Addicks by denying Ipswich three points.

Peacock the younger had opened the scoring seconds after the interval when Jamie Clapham, who had dropped back from midfield to replace the substituted Gary Croft, was dispossessed by Richard Langley. The midfielder advanced and saw his low shot loop off the goalkeeper but the captain was there to meet it with a well-placed header.

The Dutchman Sammy Koejoe then profited from a slip by the rickety Tony Mowbray and fired in a shot from the edge of the box, and though Jim Magilton scored from spot after being brought down by Langley, Ipswich's play became increasingly frenetic as they pounded away for an equaliser.

In the dying seconds Chris Kiwomya, a member of the last Ipswich promotion-winning squad in 1992, added a third goal with a shot into the bottom corner and there was only time for Town to contemplate tomorrow's visit of Crystal Palace and hope that Pompey can do them a favour against second-placed Manchester City tonight.

Nevertheless Ipswich, four points adrift of City who have a much better goal difference, look bound for the play-offs for the fourth successive season. "I feel a bit for them," Peacock said. "I thought they were the best team we played last year. I hope they do it in the play-offs."

The Ipswich manager George Burley, a team-mate of Peacock at Gillingham in the late 80s, was visibly disappointed but refused to contemplate the prospect of missing out on automatic promotion.

He maintained that his team had approached the game in their usual fashion, was annoyed that they conceded two "bad goals" and added that Croft was replaced to increase attacking options on the left.

"I feel for George," said QPR's manager Gerry Francis. "They've been a very consistent side for the past two years, shown great ability and can probably still be in the Premiership next season. I would like to be in his position."

And a word for Charlton? "I think it's going to be very hard for them to stay up," he added. "There's an amazing gap. It's not impossible but it's very, very difficult. They deserve their reward but the real hard times are on the way."

fields.headline: Ternent toasts Clarets' courage
fields.trailText: Burnley 4 - 3 Millwall
fields.body:
Stan Ternent, Burnley's battle-hardened manager, carries the hang-dog look of a man who has been involved in one too many end-of-season scrapes for his own good.

Twelve months ago he steered the club to safety, avoiding relegation in the final days of the season with a spirited run. Now, despite their best efforts to throw away a 4-0 lead against Millwall on Saturday, Burnley are a matter of hours away from promotion to the First Division.

Ternent's achievements in improving fortunes at Turf Moor have been remarkable. Burnley barely had a senior playing staff in the summer of 1998 when he picked up the pieces of Chris Waddle's disastrous reign, which itself had almost ended in relegation.

Within weeks Ternent had offered to resign following an embarrassing Worthington Cup defeat at Darlington. The few surviving players of that period recall visiting places such as Maine Road with a side filled with reserve team youngsters and Norwegian triallists fresh off the plane.

Now Ian Wright cannot even earn a starting position for the Clarets and, barring a late disaster even more spectacular than the one they almost pulled off on Saturday, Burnley will at least take their place in the play-offs.

"The sort of pressure on the players now is a lot better than what they had last year," said Ternent. "We've got nine points to play for and 79 already, which is a long way in excess of what we finished with last season.

"We lost 3-0 at home to Gillingham in midweek, so this was a real test of character for the players and they reacted extremely well. They showed resilience and courage."

So, too, did Millwall after an Ian Cox header, Andy Cooke half-volley, Steve Davis header and terrific 20-yard strike by Paul Cook had put Burnley in control after 52 minutes.

But Neil Harris started the recovery on the hour, added a second on 78 and Tim Cahill's scrambled effort 10 minutes later will have added a few more lines to Ternent's face. Whatever the outcome of his team's promotion bid, it is a face that deserves to wear a broad smile early next month.

fields.headline: Shearer takes candy from 'babies'
fields.trailText: Newcastle 2 - 2 Leeds
fields.byline: Ian Ross at St James' Park
fields.body:
As Leeds United's season moves ever closer to the point of no return the suspicion grows that they will ultimately be undone not by emotional but by physical fatigue.

David O'Leary refers to them as his "babies" and, rather like infants who have spent too long learning at the knee of their elders, they are now tired, open to distraction and a little bit grumpy.

For O'Leary the aim has always been to gain a place in next season's Champions League but the dream is now fast fading.

Yesterday they squandered a two-goal advantage and, even when the chance of redemption presented itself midway through the second half, it was spurned, Ian Harte driving his penalty wide after Harry Kewell had been upended by Nikos Dabizas.

"No matter how well you play you cannot, as a manager, legislate for defensive mistakes and for missed chances," said O'Leary.

"I have told them in the dressing room that this was definitely two points lost rather than one point gained. I am pleased that over the last 19 months I have been able to raise the profile of this club but I am in this game to win things.

"The praise we have received is fine but we haven't won anything and all along that has been the objective."

For all the improvements, for all the forward thinking, the great charm of St James' Park is that it is essentially a venue lost in time. Up on Tyneside they still gather early to discuss the merits of team selection to the strains of Jimi Hendrix, the Small Faces and, of course, the Animals. It is quaint and all rather reassuring.

The local purists argue that, while the current Newcastle team still embody traditional Geordie values, the need to succeed has, at long last, eclipsed the self-defeating desire to entertain even during dangerous moments.

Winning is all in modern football and, even if Bobby Robson were to slip into retirement this morning, his enormous legacy would be the sense of organisation and discipline that he has brought to a team which collectively now acknowledges that mavericks usually come, at best, second.

Not that Newcastle were particularly well organised throughout yesterday's opening half; Leeds cut them to ribbons with the sort of sublime movement which carried them to the threshold of famous triumph before the fates conspired dramatically to reduce their effectiveness.

For the first time for some weeks Leeds actually played well and, with no one in a black-and-white shirt prepared to drop deep to try to nullify the threat of Harry Kewell, every attack was laden with rich promise.

Although Kieron Dyer struck the foot of a post inside the opening minute, Leeds should have been over the hill, far away and grinning broadly long before Alan Shearer sparked Newcastle's recovery with a fine headed goal from Didier Domi's cross on 24 minutes.

Puncturing the Newcastle defence was so simple that Leeds almost seemed to tire of the process.

They were to score twice in five minutes during this spell of total dominance, Michael Bridges striking first with a fabulous, rising drive from 16-yards after Dabizas had failed to intercept a Jason Wilcox cross.

Wilcox was to score himself shortly afterwards, a curious goal for, while Bridges jumped to meet his curling free-kick, there was apparently no contact and the ball drifted on just inside the far post.

Three minutes into a second half which was too bullish to hold genuine appeal the England captain turned smartly to score from close range after Leeds had failed to clear Aaron Hughes' shot from the edge of the penalty area. So Shearer filched two points from Leeds' back pockets.

webTitle: Royle slaps bubbly ban on upwardly mobile City

fields.headline: Royle slaps bubbly ban on upwardly mobile City
fields.trailText: Man City 2 - 0 Tranmere
fields.body:
Even within seconds of relaying the good news that Manchester City's nearest rivals for the second automatic promotion slot - Ipswich and Barnsley - had both lost, the scoreboard operators just could not resist it. "Season ticket holders. Have you received your play-off postal application?"

Never mind the fact that automatic promotion was now within their grasp; years of disappointment have left their mark on City.

The strange thing is that even their supporters, stereotyped as cocksure scallies with a Liam Gallagher swagger, are no less cautious. While they enjoyed themselves as ever, their nerves were palpable and at no point did they even begin to sing about going up. Their manager must have been proud of them.

"There is a certain amount of cynicism and that's understandable," said Joe Royle. "All they have done is support the club, but all they've had in return is failure."

Finally, however, after three decades of such woeful underachievement that it made them a laughing stock, City appear to be upwardly mobile. Their historical susceptibility to banana skins means that the possibility of a slip-up at Portsmouth today cannot be dismissed, but the strong feeling is that the club are moving irresistibly towards their destiny and that nothing, not even their own famous knack for shooting themselves in the foot, will distract them.

In winning five and drawing one of their last six matches City have made the seamless transition from stooges to straight men, while below them Ipswich and Barnsley have shown no great sign of determination to join Charlton in the Premiership.

The classic City manager, a Malcolm Allison or a John Bond, would be inviting camera crews into the dressing room at Fratton Park today to see the champagne opened. Not so Royle, who said: "There'll be none of that. This club has history of putting its foot in it.

"I expect our game at Portsmouth on Monday to be very tough," he went on. "Their manager Tony Pulis has got an ulterior motive in beating us. He was manager of Gillingham when we beat them in the play-offs last season."

Against Tranmere, goals from cult hero Shaun Goater, on his 100th appearance, and Jeff Whitley were enough to bring out a healthy glow in Royle. "I didn't even kick the Liverpool Echo reporter out, I'm in such a nice mood," joked the manager, who fell out with that newspaper towards the end of his time at Everton.

His opposite number John Aldridge refused to dispute City's first goal, when Goater nicked the ball from Joe Mur phy's fingertips to score from the tightest of angles. Aldridge said: "It is what I would have done as a striker. Goater did nothing wrong. Joe will learn from the experience and become a better goalkeeper because of it."

And the Tranmere manager paid tribute to the City revival. "They've got themselves a great chance now. The club deserve it, Joe deserves it and the fans deserve it. It's a pity for our division if they do go up because it would be great to come back to places like this next season." Sorry, John, but City are going places, whether they like it or not.

webTitle: Rovers hit most of the high notes

fields.headline: Rovers hit most of the high notes
fields.trailText: Bristol Rovers 2 - 0 Bristol City
fields.byline: David Foot at the Memorial stadium
fields.body:
There has always been something surreal about Bristol Rovers. The intimacy between players and fans is exceptional, and on Saturday one pre-match announcement, amid the birthday greetings, wished a supporter well after his haemorrhoids operation.

The manager Ian Holloway gives long, partial and engaging monologues after games, strong on sentimentality and unusual in imagery. Here he reflected: "The trouble with us is that we've had too many players sitting at the piano, not moving it".

Maybe he was simply in an exultant, musical mood. He had just seen his team - only recently "a frightened one" - restate their claim for an automatic promotion place. And the overdue statement was buoyantly made at the expense of tribal rivals.

It was a match strewn with free-kicks and a booking for Rovers' David Hillier after 30 seconds. Then things settled and Holloway's men discovered their exciting, instinctive touch.

First it was Jason Roberts, carrying on the good work of Andy Tillson and Andy Thomson, with a sweet goal in the 53rd minute. Then Mark Walters, who had beavered away on the left wing in the first half, moved into the middle to slide home a Roberts pass.

Virtually nothing was seen of City's attack and both strikers were substituted. The defences were solid, Rovers' more so. Tillson and Marcus Andreasson were tight and reliable, while City's Andrew Jordan continues to grow alongside the experienced Keith Millen.

webTitle: Rotherham cut off by crossed line

fields.headline: Rotherham cut off by crossed line
fields.trailText: Barnet 1 - 0 Rotherham
fields.body:
Guy Branston must be seeing a rage counsellor. In November the Rotherham defender was so incensed at being sent off that he plunged his right arm through the door of the referee's room at Hull, shredded his tendons, and needed 20 stitches. Here, angered by Barnet's controversial winner, he stopped short of a repeat.

"I wanted to do it," he said with a smile. "I should have." He opted instead for a less than quiet word with the referee Lee Cable. The six stitches above Branston's left eye were the legacy of a challenge rather than an attempt to butt his way into the officials' changing area.

What left Branston in a pickle was Mark Arber's 59th-minute goal, which knocked Rotherham off the top and kept Barnet on course for the play-offs. Rotherham were adamant the ball did not cross the line. The referee's assistant, unlikely to see shades of Wembley 1966 at Underhill, thought otherwise.

fields.headline: Rangers flushed with familiar feeling
fields.trailText: St Johnstone 0 - 2 Rangers
fields.body:
Rangers partied last night against St Johnstone, proving the same point they had been making up and down the country all season - that they are not so much champions, rather they are playing in a league of their own.

The old romantics will be delighted that their two goals were scored by a genuine Scottish journeyman, Billy Dodds, but the reality is that the Scottish Premier League crown, their 11th in 12 seasons, was won by the judicious use of a giant cheque book. All that remains is for the club to win the league with a record number of points.

"It was great to get two goals," Dodds said. "It's a great day for me - my first championship, it's brilliant. I said all along that this has all come for me at once and I'm going to enjoy every minute of it."

Rangers' manager Dick Advocaat had promised that he would ring some changes when the title was won, which rather suggested he did not expect Celtic to slip up on Saturday because he put out his most recognised side here.

Not only that, he refused all pre-match interviews, arguing that St Johnstone demanded the same sense of concentration as any other league match. His only concession was to start the match sitting in the stand but that did not last long and after 10 minutes the Dutchman made his way to the dug-out. The celebrations were going to start only after the final whistle had been blown.

The Rangers supporters could afford to go through their entire repertoire of songs and chants as they wished, regardless of anything happening on the field. They took the opportunity gleefully for the whole 90 minutes, including chants of "Kenny must stay" aimed at Celtic's caretaker manager.

The main problem for both sides was the pitch. The skies had opened on Perth before kick-off and a skiddy surface, parts of it with standing water, made it rather less than ideal. It produced the conditions in which the first objective is always not to make a ruinous mistake.

Rangers' passing was always of the higher quality but it could not carry them to the heart of the home defence for almost all of the first half. In fact Saints, with a Kevin O'Halloran shot going over the bar, looked the more likely side to take the lead before class eventually told.

In the 41st minute Jorg Albertz, working away on the left, pushed forward a perfectly weighted ball to Dodds who had made his run towards the near post. The Scotland striker spun round, and from the narrowest of angles hit a vicious shot high into the roof of the net.

The young Saints goalkeeper Stephen Robertson was conclusively beaten by the suddenness of it all - a harsh introduction to the big league for a growing talent.

The irony of the second half was that the louder the Rangers' fans cheered, the more their team seemed content to sit on the lead that Dodds had given them. But the manager's decision to replace Rod Wallace with Seb Rozental gave them a new impetus. The Chilean, after horrendous injury problems, still has something to prove and his vibrancy enlivened the match.

In the 60th minute Rangers went two up with a move which illustrated the quality that runs through their team - started as it was in their own penalty area by Scott Wilson. He picked out Claudio Reyna, whose 40-yard run allowed him to find Rozental on the byline and from his cutback Dodds had the simplest of tasks in turning the ball over the line from two yards.

The game should have died after that but instead exploded when Keiran McAnespie's late challenge on Giovanni van Bronckhorst, which forced the Dutchman to be substituted, led to both sides shaping up to each other.

The Rangers captain Lorenzo Amoruso, who had been booked earlier, was lucky to stay on the pitch in the fracas. Suddenly it was more of a grudge match than an end-of-season piece of entertainment, but nobody or nothing could take the title off Rangers.

fields.headline: Phillips makes wet Wednesday weep
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 0 - 2 Sunderland
fields.body:
As Kevin Phillips added his personal contribution to Sheffield Wednesday's obituary it was as though the grim reality had finally sunk in at Hillsborough.

At the final whistle Gilles de Bilde, the man who goes by the name of Animal in his native Belgium, had been reduced to the role of pussycat. It was a numbing sight, De Bilde down and out in the centre circle, rubbing his reddened eyes and attempting to conceal his crumpled features.

As the Wednesday team departed the scene almost two hours later, his bottom lip was quivering again and those within his vicinity had cause to fear another bout of waterworks. "I cannot remember feeling so low. I'm very emotional," he sighed.

"The manager has told us to get this out of our system, but how? The next few days are going to be so hard."

Perhaps the trauma would not have been so suffocating had their opponents not been spluttering aimlessly along as though already making plans for their summer sabbatical.

After breezing into the top tier without so much as a whiff of trepidation last autumn, Sunderland's descent into turgid predictability has been nothing short of spectacular. Even the most blinkered opponents have long cottoned on to the fact that nullifying the threat of Phillips and Niall Quinn is as good as ensuring some sort of return.

For 86 minutes Wednesday managed as much only for Phillips to strike late on with a devastating one-two, the first an exquisite curling shot from 20 yards and the second a predatory close-range finish, for the 28th and 29th goals of what has already been a remarkable season.

"Sunderland are not the best side, they did not impress me one bit," added De Bilde, employing honesty rather than grape-souring malice. "It's just lucky for them they have Phillips."

Rarely has a truer word been said. While Wednesday, in 18th plaace, remain five points behind Wimbledon with time running out, Sunderland are tentatively eyeing an improbable top-six spot.

"If someone had said that at the start of the season I would have put them in a straitjacket," said Peter Reid.

His opposite number Peter Shreeves, though, knows there is no sanity clause, after watching a team that had been expected to improve on last season's mid-table finish spurn the gift of Wimbledon's defeat.

"While we haven't improved our position it is still not game over," he said. "There are still 12 points left to play for.

"The boys are very disappointed, as you would expect," he added. "The defenders did everything right but you can't legislate for someone like Phillips."

fields.headline: Norwegian Blue faces Euro quandary
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace 0 - 2 Birmingham
fields.body:
Thomas Myhre is on the horns of a dilemma. Now that Birmingham City are virtually assured of a place in the play-offs the big Norwegian goalkeeper would love to stay and help them towards the Premiership. But his country will need him to join up for the European Championship and the further Birmingham progress, the more likely there is to be a conflict of interests.

Myhre's ideal scenario is to be allowed to take part in the play-offs and then meet up with Norway afterwards - always assuming that Birmingham City and Everton can agree an extension to his loan which is due to expire at the end of this week. "It would be disappointing to miss out," he said.

"Although I haven't been here for a long time I've still become a part of the group and hopefully they will want to keep me." The goalkeeper hopes the situation will become clearer when he meets up for Wednesday night's friendly against Belgium in Oslo but he admitted: "At the end of the day it's not up to me. The national team always gets to decide ahead of the club team because that's the rules and I don't want to interfere with that. I'll do whatever they say I've got to do and hopefully they'll sort something out so that I can play all the games."

Losing Myhre would hit Birmingham hard. Saturday saw his third clean sheet in four appearances and it enabled the Blues to leapfrog Huddersfield Town into fifth place. With three games to go, a five-point cushion separates them from seventh-placed Wolverhampton Wanderers. They play Walsall at home today, go to Manchester City on Friday, then their final game is at home to Grimsby Town and perhaps their manager Trevor Francis was being unduly cautious when he said: "I think it will go to the last match."

He added: "You can never take anything for granted in this league. Every week without fail there is a surprise result and you have to make sure it doesn't involve you too often."

Birmingham, though, have the wind in their sails. After hanging in through an injury-plagued autumn they are getting players back fresh and eager and since the new year their record reads: played 20, won 14 and lost only four.

One of those returning players, Paul Furlong, finished off Palace with a close-range shot in the 61st minute. But the home captain Dean Austin had already done the greater damage with a sliced own-goal on the stroke of half-time that would have made Roy Keane green with envy, though Palace are as good as safe now and have little else to play for.

Another player returning was Jon McCarthy, who put in a fine performance on only his second appearance since breaking a leg and said: "That was a big game for us. Other people are losing and that takes a lot of pressure off us. If we win against Walsall, I think we'll be about there."

webTitle: Jinxed Villa fail again to run Foxes to earth

fields.headline: Jinxed Villa fail again to run Foxes to earth
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 2 - 2 Leicester
fields.body:
Throw together two managers who rarely see eye to eye and two teams keen on winding each other up and what do you get? Four goals, a 12-man scrap and an unhealthy dose of petty bickering.

Aston Villa last beat Leicester 13 years ago and twice passed up chances to end that run on Saturday. "If they played against everybody like they play against us, they'd win the Premiership," grumbled Villa's manager John Gregory.

His opposite number Martin O'Neill retorted: "We don't get worked up more for games against Villa. Jinx? They can't beat us, that's the jinx."

The m lée which ensued seconds from the end was indicative of Villa's lack of killer instinct. Even Lee Hendrie's lunge at Robbie Savage, which prompted the handbags, failed to finish the Leicester man off.

Such a finale seemed unlikely after a drab opening half-hour which failed to disturb a flock of pigeons inside the Leicester half. It took Alan Thompson to scatter them, his charge and exchange of passes with Dion Dublin ending in a thunderous shot which ripped past Tim Flowers.

Leicester sent Matt Elliott up front and the man who ousted Villa from the Worthington Cup duly struck again. Stefan Oakes' centre should have been cleared by Gareth Barry but the defender kicked air and Elliott pounced. "They feed off the scraps," said Gregory, referring not to the pigeons but the Foxes.

Paul Merson's header from a Steve Watson cross suggested Villa had learned their lesson before Neil Lennon, profiting from another Elliott knockdown, turned inside Alan Wright to find the top corner.

"If ever there was a day when Aston Villa should have beaten us, it was today," added O'Neill. For once, his opposite number may just have agreed.

fields.headline: Henry's double sting for Hornets
fields.trailText: Watford 2 - 3 Arsenal
fields.body:
Having qualified for the Uefa Cup final on Thursday, Arsenal were almost caught preening themselves yesterday by a Watford side keen to ruffle as many feathers as possible before they fall off their Premiership perch.

Graham Taylor's side retain a mathematical chance of staying up. But it is so slim it only increases one's admiration for the fighting spirit which has been Watford's principal asset all season and enabled them to recover from 3-0 down here.

Arsenal's hard-fought ninth win in a row came courtesy of two goals from Thierry Henry and another laid on by him for Ray Parlour which lifted the north London club on to the shoulder of second-placed Liverpool.

Henry's goals tally for the season now stands at 23. He has scored in each of his last eight games and underlined Arsène Wenger's wisdom in switching the Frenchman from the wing to become a striking replacement for Nicolas Anelka.

An often heated game ended with an incident involving the trouble-prone Patrick Vieira. At first it appeared that the Frenchman had butted Watford's Heidar Helguson. But only mild contact seemed to have been made with the Icelander guilty of some play-acting and Vieira received only a caution.

It was that sort of niggly game, with Watford closing down Arsenal at every opportunity and twice almost scoring in the opening quarter-hour.

David Seaman's miskick almost let in Helguson, who had a fair claim for a penalty as the goalkeeper struggled to rescue the situation. Seven minutes later Steve Palmer set up Tommy Smith for a shot which forced Seaman into a diving save.

An unlikely Watford win looked on the cards. But then Arsenal played their ace. On 18 minutes, when Henry was released by Emmanuel Petit's through pass, the 22-year-old calmly advanced into the Watford area and slipped a smart shot under Alec Chamberlain.

Watford were deflated but not demoralised. On the half-hour they should have equalised when Micah Hyde hit a post. But then Arsenal became the umpteenth side this season to show Watford how to take a chance. Two minutes before half-time Henry's pass released Parlour. He evaded Paul Robinson's lunging tackle, rounded the keeper and slotted home Arsenal's second.

Then Henry picked up the ball about 35 yards out, danced past two yellow shirts, entered the area and, when confronted by three defenders, coolly bent his shot home.

Afterwards Wenger was objective enough to admit that his side, missing the rested Tony Adams, and Nwankwo Kanu away with Nigeria, were luckly to go in at the break 3-0 up.

But soon after Marc Overmars hit a post and more Arsenal goals seemed likely. It was Watford, though, who scored twice, in two minutes.

As Neil Cox's free-kick landed at the far post Seaman held back from a challenge on Helguson and the Watford player stretched out a foot to direct the ball over the line.

Then, on the hour, Martin Keown's defensive header fell to Hyde, whose 16-yard shot was misjudged by Seaman, the ball bouncing over his outstretched arms and into the net. It was the England keeper's third mishap of the day and raised further doubts about his form ahead of Euro 2000.

Seaman partly redeemed himself with a smart block from Helguson and as thunder and lightning bathed Vicarage Road, Overmars cracked a shot against the Watford bar. But it was Arsenal who were happy to hear the final whistle.

webTitle: Europe suddenly a long way off for limp Chelsea

fields.headline: Europe suddenly a long way off for limp Chelsea
fields.trailText: Chelsea 1 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Few would have thought last summer that Chelsea would go within seven minutes of reaching the Champions League semi-finals. There again, fewer still would have foreseen Chelsea struggling to find any route of re-entry into Europe. But the unthinkable must have crossed the minds of many on Saturday.

On this evidence Gianluca Vialli's team will surely fail in the primary objective - one of the top three places offering Champions League qualification. And given their forbidding fixtures against the leading trio, Chelsea will struggle to oust even a frazzled Leeds from the fourth spot guaranteeing Uefa Cup football. That leaves the FA Cup and, suddenly, Stamford Bridge is not making cosy assumptions about the Wembley outcome.

As insurance Chelsea have applied for the InterToto Cup, the last-chance saloon of European football. A far cry, indeed, from the original path to glory envisaged by some only a few months ago when Chelsea were being tipped to exploit Manchester United's Brazilian distraction. Little wonder that Ken Bates's club seem in no hurry to set up new contract talks with Vialli, who has another year left on his current deal.

On the day United cantered to their latest title, hard on a £19m deal for Ruud van Nistelrooy - priced out of Chelsea's reach - it was even more dispiriting that Vialli seemed to see the "gap" between United and the others as a gulf.

In England, said Vialli, United are "at the moment out of everybody's league". One of the reasons is that "they have a very strong base of young, talented English players". And, foreign or British, "they can afford to buy the best". How can Chelsea compete? "We've got to be even smarter."

Smarter at least than Chelsea's manager was here, would say the fans who greeted the final whistle with booing after howling derision at the substitution of Gianfranco Zola rather than the ineffectual Chris Sutton just past the hour.

Didier Deschamps was anonymous, Bernard Lambourde inadequate and Chelsea were again vulnerable at set pieces. Hamilton Ricard will seldom score an easier goal than his equaliser, volleyed in from two yards after Gianluca Festa, unchallenged, headed back Christian Ziege's corner.

Until then Chelsea had dominated. Gustavo Poyet headed home from a corner, Zola curled a shot just wide and Dennis Wise showed up Paul Ince's claims to be a better midfield choice for England.

Ince responded with a forceful second half in which he drove against a post, matching Gabriele Ambrosetti's shot against the woodwork. Tit-for-tat continued as Mark Schwarzer saved superbly from Poyet and Ed de Goey turned over Ricard's point-blank effort.

There again, fewer still would have foreseen Chelsea struggling to find any route of re-entry into Europe. But the unthinkable must have crossed the minds of many on Saturday. On this evidence Gianluca Vialli's team will surely fail in the primary objective - one of the top three places offering Champions League qualification. And given their forbidding fixtures against the leading trio, Chelsea will struggle to oust even a frazzled Leeds from the fourth spot guaranteeing Uefa Cup football. That leaves the FA Cup and, suddenly, Stamford Bridge is not making cosy assumptions about the Wembley outcome. As insurance Chelsea have applied for the InterToto Cup, the last-chance saloon of European football. A far cry, indeed, from the original path to glory envisaged by some only a few months ago when Chelsea were being tipped to exploit Manchester United's Brazilian distraction. Little wonder that Ken Bates's club seem in no hurry to set up new contract talks with Vialli, who has another year left on his current deal. On the day United cantered to their latest title, hard on a £19m deal for Ruud van Nistelrooy - priced out of Chelsea's reach - it was even more dispiriting that Vialli seemed to see the "gap" between United and the others as a gulf. In England, said Vialli, United are "at the moment out of everybody's league". One of the reasons is that "they have a very strong base of young, talented English players". And, foreign or British, "they can afford to buy the best". How can Chelsea compete? "We've got to be even smarter." Smarter at least than Chelsea's manager was here, would say the fans who greeted the final whistle with booing after howling derision at the substitution of Gianfranco Zola rather than the ineffectual Chris Sutton just past the hour. Didier Deschamps was anonymous, Bernard Lambourde inadequate and Chelsea were again vulnerable at set pieces. Hamilton Ricard will seldom score an easier goal than his equaliser, volleyed in from two yards after Gianluca Festa, unchallenged, headed back Christian Ziege's corner. Until then Chelsea had dominated. Gustavo Poyet headed home from a corner, Zola curled a shot just wide and Dennis Wise showed up Paul Ince's claims to be a better midfield choice for England. Ince responded with a forceful second half in which he drove against a post, matching Gabriele Ambrosetti's shot against the woodwork. Tit-for-tat continued as Mark Schwarzer saved superbly from Poyet and Ed de Goey turned over Ricard's point-blank effort.

webTitle: Easter rising has Wolves playing with golden numbers

fields.headline: Easter rising has Wolves playing with golden numbers
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton 2 - 0 Barnsley
fields.body:
Seeing the old gold shirts of Wolves in the Premiership must surely be of more interest to the Molineux regulars than the Premier Gold savings account the club and a local building society have launched. At least any profits from the scheme, though, will be used for strengthening the team.

But, with the combined value of their strike pair Ade Akinbiyi and Michael Branch equating to that of Ruud van Nistelrooy's left kneecap, some serious saving will be in order if Wolves are to remain in the Premiership, if and when they get there. That could still be next season after Branch fashioned and Akinbiyi finished off the manoeuvres to earn the win that keeps Wolves in the chase for a play-off place, three points adrift of sixth-placed Huddersfield.

After languishing in the relegation zone back in September, Wolves could reasonably construe a top-six finish as an unforeseen bonus. The manager Colin Lee, however, does not agree. "I'm not surprised we're still in the race," he said. "I ve got some super players in my dressing room and what would have surprised me is if their heads had dropped."

Barnsley, without a benefactor like Sir Jack Hayward, are even more financially challenged than Wolves; nevertheless a top-six finish would represent a disappointment for Dave Bassett, whose immediate complaint was that he thought "we might have had two penalties - first when Geoff Thomas was hacked down and then when the lads said Keith Curle definitely handled.

"That's kiboshed our chances of automatic promotion," Bassett conceded after watching his side lose for only the second time in 12 games. "Mathematically it's not impossible but, with respect to the teams they are playing, I can't see Manchester City not getting the three points they need from their last three games to stop us."

"And if they fail, then there's always Ipswich. Stranger things have happened but you have to keep a sense of realism. I don't live in fantasy land." Lee and Bassett may find the Premiership, in terms of finances, is just that.

As for immediate player resources, Wolves are trying to extend the loan of the Danish midfielder Allan Nielsen, although Tottenham are likely to recall him for the run-in because of their injury problems.

webTitle: Crazy spirit lost in Olsen tactics

fields.headline: Crazy spirit lost in Olsen tactics
fields.trailText: Tottenham 2 - 0 Wimbledon
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
It is a pertinent question given Wimbledon's fall from grace: what bearing does team spirit have on results?

On Saturday the team formerly known as the Crazy Gang lost their seventh game in a row to equal a club record. Relegation threatens after 14 years in the top flight. And most observers blame the erosion of that special collective will which enabled this little club to punch above its weight for so long.

Hans Segers kept goal for Wimbledon during a large chunk of the Crazy Gang era. Now on Tottenham's coaching staff, he offered this damning assessment after Saturday's game. "I saw them against Liverpool as well, and it's not the Wimbledon I know any more. All the qualities they had are gone.

"The players are down, there's no spirit and I can't see what system they're playing. Spirit and determination was so important to the Wimbledon I played for. That's how the club's survived all these years. When we went out for a game we talked about winning your own personal battles. But now when you look through the team, there's not much there."

But one man believes that team spirit is overrated, that the minutiae of tactics count for more. And in the circumstances his opinion is quite influential. He is the Wimbledon manager, Egil Olsen.

"I have never been in a nation that talks about spirit so much," he said on Saturday. "There is more to this game than confidence and morale. Our biggest problem is conceding too many goals, especially from set plays. And we give the ball away in silly situations."

Olsen comforts himself with the fact that his side still enjoy a five-point cushion from the bottom three - though defeat to second-bottom Bradford next Sunday could make life interesting while Sheffield Wednesday, directly below them still have a game in hand.

The Norwegian is also quick to remind his accusers that Wimbledon were in a slump before he wellied his way into Selhurst Park but he is surely missing the Wimbledon point. Segers sighs knowingly. "You can talk about tactics all you like," he says, "but at the end of the day it's the players themselves, deep in their hearts. Whether they want to win."

The evidence here was pretty clear: Spurs won easily without having to play particularly well thanks to goals from Chris Armstrong, tucking away David Ginola's great cross, and Darren Anderton, deftly converting Steffen Iversen's great pass. Spurs could have scored more; Wimbledon hardly threatened.

The Wimbledon fans' sense of loss was compounded yesterday by speculation that the Crazy Gang's creator Sam Hammam is about to join the Spurs board and bring Carl Cort and Ben Thatcher with him to White Hart Lane.

It was more difficult to believe another report that Glenn Hoddle is about to replace George Graham as manager but, becalmed in mid-table, Spurs are indeed looking to next season.

The club's director of football David Pleat confirmed that at least two high-quality signings would be made this summer, one a striker after Spurs failed with offers for Emile Heskey and Michael Bridges earlier this season.

Pleat also said it was 90% certain that the club would not sell Sol Campbell in the summer even if the England defender failed to extend his contract, which has a year to run. Whether Olsen will be staying with Wimbledon as long is far less certain.
