webTitle: Bennett's rescue service aids Saddlers' spirited journey

fields.headline: Bennett's rescue service aids Saddlers' spirited journey
fields.trailText: Walsall 2 - 1 WBA
fields.body:
There is something impish about Walsall. In a division which many consider above their station they are proving neighbours from hell. Wolves, Birmingham and West Brom might all be sitting prettier if Walsall kept their nose out of such lofty affairs.

Saturday's was particularly lofty, thanks to Albion's nervous state, and Walsall deserved a second win over them for playing the more composed, terrestrial football. It is easier for upstarts to relax. Last season they were tipped to go down from the Second Division. Instead they went up. Now they have leapfrogged West Brom, pushing them below the dotted line. Relegation holds fewer fears for Walsall.

Only Wolves have got a point in Walsall's five derbies so far. In the last, at Birmingham today, the league table may mean less than the local one, which the Saddlers top with 13 points. If only they would buzz off to the Wolverhampton Sunday League, Division Five. That, after all, is topped by the Stirrups.

Walsall's ground is not so much above their station as below the M6, integrated in an out-of-town shopping complex. The manager Ray Graydon has done little shopping but complex Bosman business. With the mien of a favourite uncle, he talked of his players "staying in among this family spirit".

Perhaps it was that which persuaded Tom Bennett to return after a loan spell from Stockport in January. The stadium is overseen by the RAC Control Centre and Bennett provided control and rescue service on Saturday.

He had seven seasons with Wolves, so knows his way about. Patrolling midfield, he dispatched calm and passes to all quarters and duly got Walsall home. He nearly equalised Sean Flynn's early goal with a rocket, brilliantly palmed away by the flying Brian Jensen. After the interval Bennett met a half-cleared corner similarly and the ball flew in off Andy Rammell.

"Rambo can have it," he said later, reflecting the family spirit. "He needs a goal." Rammell, top with 18 last season, had not scored since November.

Bennett could afford to be generous too. His header, direct and unchallenged from another corner, was the winner. "Believe it or not," said Albion's manager Gary Megson, "we work on set pieces." He was not amused.

"I would like to see Albion stay up because of the history of the club," said Bennett. He may not be able to have it both ways. And at present the black humour in the Black Country is coming from Walsall.

webTitle: 'Genius' Di Canio oddly out of the reckoning

fields.headline: 'Genius' Di Canio oddly out of the reckoning
fields.trailText: West Ham 5 - 0 Coventry
fields.body:
Harry Redknapp is unequivocal: Paolo di Canio will be remembered as one of the all-time greats at West Ham. It is a pity his enthusiasm for the most gifted player in the Premiership is not shared by Di Canio's fellow professionals.

The Italian striker has tormented sides up and down the country this season, hapless Coventry being his latest victims, yet he will not be the PFA footballer of the year. Indeed he has not even made the shortlist.

What a shame. For what better way to increase the skill levels of England's youngsters than by putting the man with the widest repertoire of tricks on a pedestal?

The potential influence of Di Canio on the next generation was exemplified by his team-mates, who on Saturday, from goalkeeper to centre-forward, were joining in the showboating, inspired by the maestro. Indeed, with Di Canio, who scored two and had a hand in the other three, in such imperious form it remains a mystery why Italy's national manager Dino Zoff has not paid Upton Park a visit.

"Italy must have a frightening team if Paolo can't get in it. He's a genius," said Redknapp, who is justly delighted to have proved wrong those who criticised his £2m acquisition of Di Canio 16 months ago.

"Italian football is not what it's cracked up to be," said Di Canio. "There is an arrogant attitude of picking players for the national team only from within Serie A. I don't understand why I'm not picked. But I'm 31 and, if I'm not picked now, then I will never be."

Frédéric Kanouté, the French striker on loan from Lyon whom Redknapp is eager to sign permanently, completed West Ham's rout with a header at the far post after Coventry's goalkeeper Magnus Hedman had flapped unsuccessfully at Di Canio's corner. The Italian also set up the Hammers' first, a 25-yarder from Michael Carrick, and the second, a glancing header from Javier Margas. For both players they were first goals for the club. It was that kind of day.

Di Canio added numbers three and four, the first having picked the ball up on the halfway line, driven past David Burrows and fired home from the edge of the area. His second followed a neat interchange with Scott Minto, Di Canio calmly slotting home after deceiving two defenders.

Coventry's misery was compounded by the loss of Colin Hendry with a fractured eye socket. Their manager Gordon Strachan, who has not seen his side win away for more than a year, called Coventry's display "embarrassing".

Burrows gave credit to Di Canio. "I've got sore ankles and a sore groin from chasing him," the full-back said. "West Ham have now got a big star here."

fields.headline: Swans on top
fields.trailText: Swansea City took over at the top by beating Torquay 2-1, their first win in eight games. Goals in each half by Steve Watkin and Jason Price gave the Swans a 2-0 lead, but the visitors struck back strongly; Alex Watson pulled one back, Eifion Williams brought a flying save out of Roger Freestone and then Michael O'Brien struck the woodwork in injury-time.

Goals in each half by Steve Watkin and Jason Price gave the Swans a 2-0 lead, but the visitors struck back strongly; Alex Watson pulled one back, Eifion Williams brought a flying save out of Roger Freestone and then Michael O'Brien struck the woodwork in injury-time.

 Peterborough came back from a goal down at home to Halifax to win 2-1 and draw level on points with third-placed Darlington. Andy Clarke started the move that led to Jon Cullen's equaliser and then curled the winner past the splendid Lee Butler four minutes later.

 Hartlepool dislodged Cheltenham from the play-off zone by beating Mansfield 1-0. Bobby Mimms, the former Tottenham and Blackburn goalkeeper, frustrated the visitors, holding them scoreless for a sixth successive match.

 Shrewsbury gained their second win in 21 games to get off the bottom of the table. They recovered from a goal down at home to Southend with two penalties in nine second-half minutes. Lee Steele scored both after Mark Beard handled and Kevin Maher brought down Luke Rogers.

 Chester fell to last place despite gaining a 1-1 draw at Macclesfield with a Luke Beckett equaliser.

 Brighton drew 0-0 at York to extend their unbeaten run to 11 games. "We'll be up there challenging next season," said their manager Mickey Adams.

fields.headline: Preston poised
fields.trailText: Preston's 1-0 home win over Scunthorpe made automatic promotion almost a certainty for the leaders, who will go up a champions today if they win at Cambridge. Brett Angell scored Saturday's only goal in the 42nd minute to keep his side eight points clear of their nearest rivals.
fields.body:
Preston's 1-0 home win over Scunthorpe made automatic promotion almost a certainty for the leaders, who will go up a champions today if they win at Cambridge. Brett Angell scored Saturday's only goal in the 42nd minute to keep his side eight points clear of their nearest rivals.

 Wigan remain second after Neil Redfearn's 34th-minute penalty gave them a 1-0 home success against Reading. They are two points clear of Bristol Rovers.

 Gillingham moved into fifth place on goal difference, at Millwall's expense, after a 2-0 win over Luton at Priestfield, goals in each half by Andy Hessenthaler and Nicky Southall doing the damage.

 Stoke maintained their hopes of a play-off place thanks to a 1-0 win over Bournemouth with Peter Thorne the scorer in front of a 15,000 crowd at the Britannia stadium.

 Chesterfield were relegated following their 3-0 home defeat by Wrexham, a Carl Connolly hat-trick taking the points for the Welsh side.

 Blackpool look doomed after a last-minute Adrian Littlejohn goal gave 10-man Bury a 3-2 win at Gigg Lane.

 Oxford fell back into the relegation zone after being held to a 1-1 draw at the Manor Ground by Brentford with Cardiff leapfrogging out thanks to a 2-1 victory at Oldham. Goals in each half by Jason Bowen and Paul Brayson clinched the points after Stuart Thom had put the home side ahead.

fields.headline: Bolton in bloom
fields.trailText: Bolton maintained their challenge for a play-off spot with a 3-0 win at Huddersfield, whose place in the top six is now looking precarious.
fields.body:
Bolton maintained their challenge for a play-off spot with a 3-0 win at Huddersfield, whose place in the top six is now looking precarious.

Bo Hansen scored twice for Sam Allardyce's side and the captain Mike Whitlow got the third, his first goal for 2 years, as Bolton moved to within four points of the zone.

"This was a must-win game for us, and the three points were vital to keep us in the pack," said Allardyce. "We are flying at the moment, and that is how you want it at this stage of the season.

"Teams like Huddersfield who have been up there since the start of the season start to feel the pressure now."

 The fight to stay in the division is equally as tight, although Crewe moved closer to safety with a 3-2 win over Stockport County who have gone 19 matches without a victory, the worst sequence in their 117-year history.

Crewe's manager praised Mark Rivers, who got two of the home side's goals, but was critical of his team overall. "We were fortunate Stockport couldn't convert their chances," Dario Gradi said. "We will have to play a lot better if we are to win any of our last three games."

Crewe are now five points clear of the relegation zone and Stockport six, though Walsall edged out of the zone with a 2-1 win over West Brom despite going behind after only 10 minutes.

 Swindon beat Fulham 1-0 at home and Port Vale drew 0-0 at Norwich but both teams still look doomed.

Crewe's manager praised Mark Rivers, who got two of the home side's goals, but was critical of his team overall. "We were fortunate Stockport couldn't convert their chances," Dario Gradi said. webTitle: A shot of bish-Bashir-bosh for Bestie as ITV viewers wonder where it all went wrong

fields.headline: A shot of bish-Bashir-bosh for Bestie as ITV viewers wonder where it all went wrong
fields.trailText: George Best's interview with Martin Bashir - his first since his release from hospital - will have been useful therapy is doubtful.A Helpline number was included at the end of the programme, supposedly illustrating what a serious, caring work of journalism this was. It was not. It was a meretricious piece of trash.
fields.body:
"And now it's time for Tonight With Trevor McDonald, presented by Martin Bashir," trumpeted ITV's continuity announcer. An interesting concept, opening the door to a whole range of new and exciting programmes, such as The Weather Forecast With Robert De Niro (presented by Arnold Grimshaw). In fairness, though, Bashir had got himself a major exclusive this week with his revelation that the soccer legend Georgie Best has become something of a hopeless drunk.

This will have come as a real shock to football followers as most of us were under the impression that, since ending his distinguished Manchester United career with a testimonial at the age of 34, Best had been leading a quiet life as a fitness instructor and lay preacher in a small village just outside Peterborough. The point is George's alcoholism, which has not been the best kept secret in sport, has led to him spending some time in hospital of late, where he has been rather poorly. We wish him well and hope he can find the help he needs to overcome his addiction.

Whether the interview with Bashir - his first since his release from hospital - will have been useful therapy is doubtful. I am sure the process by which Best's cooperation was assured included some sort of indication that it would be, if not for Best then for other alcoholics; and a Helpline number was included at the end of the programme, supposedly illustrating what a serious, caring work of journalism this was.

It was not. It was a meretricious piece of trash, slavishly following a News of the World agenda, and typical, I am afraid, of Bashir, the Man Who Likes To Be There For Rock Bottom. I only hope Best and his people were handsomely rewarded. I suspect they were, which makes one of the programme's more dubious assertions - that Best was "selling autographs for two pounds a time to buy booze" - even more questionable.

It appeared to stem from a complaint by Best's manager, Phil Hughes, that Best had charged someone in a pub £2 for an autograph, which had then shown up on the internet for £26. But as Hughes was portrayed by the programme as not so much a manager, more a drinking crony who had seized the main chance, it seemed a little catchpenny to be taking his quotes and using them as headlines.

Hughes, whom Best met in a bar, was very much the programme's bete noire. Bashir kept pressing him on his "strategy" for keeping Bestie, whom the programme had decided was "just one drink away from death", off the booze. "Will you be drinking in front of him?" asked Bashir. "No," replied Hughes. "A glass of wine, maybe, but I won't be drinking." Gotcha.

Bashir, the uncrowned king of psychobabble, also made sure we knew that Best's mother had died from an alcohol-related disease at the age of 54, "the age George will be next month". Geddit? The age George will be next month. Best and his father felt that the turning of Georgie's life into a sideshow had contributed to Mrs Best's death but, if this programme was not a continuation of that process, I don't know what is. Particularly irritating was Bashir's insistence to Angie Best that George had slapped her around, when all she wished to say was that theirs was the kind of relationship that occasionally involved a full and frank exchange of expletives and crockery.

When Bestie does after-dinner speaking engagements (for which he is paid, incidentally, for one evening what I might expect to receive for writing this column for around six months, making the autograph story even more laughable), he usually tells of the time he was in a hotel room in Birmingham with a Miss World in the bed and a bottle of champagne cooling in a bucket. The waiter, bringing his lobster to the room, asks: "Georgie, where did it all go wrong?" Bashir reminded me of that waiter.

Today's top footballers, of course, have no need to spend their spare time like George hanging around with disreputable types in bars. There is always a television studio in which they can hang around, the latest being the one for Football Fever, the BBC's new Sunday morning football show for young people. Football Fever, presented by Katy Hill of Blue Peter and Matt Smith of BBC Choice, is an unashamed attempt to replicate the success of Soccer AM on Sky, the show which, despite a comparatively small audience, has made stars of the presenters Tim Lovejoy and Helen Chamberlain.

The problem is that Soccer AM, which grew organically out of Sky's all-encompassing football coverage, has been able to relax into its role of interpreting football for the pre-pubescent and now looks at ease with itself, whereas Katy and Matt, springing into action on the back of an extensive promotional campaign, are trying too hard. A show advertising itself as coming from "our funky front room" is one, I should say, unsure of itself.

Football Fever had booked all the right people - Les Ferdinand, David Beckham, Nicky from something called Westlife - but at one point Katy was reduced to asking: "How cool is this?" The answer, I suspect, is similar to the one Louis Armstrong gave when he was asked what swing is. "Lady," he said, "if you have to ask, you ain't got it."

fields.headline: Vialli threatens clear-out
fields.trailText: Chelsea appeared to know their place here and it is not one that will bring Champions League football back next season. With Manchester United in the clubhouse so far as winning the Premiership was concerned Gianluca Vialli's team spent too much of the game dawdling on the fairway when they should have been aiming for the pin.
fields.body:
Chelsea appeared to know their place here and it is not one that will bring Champions League football back next season. With Manchester United in the clubhouse so far as winning the Premiership was concerned Gianluca Vialli's team spent too much of the game dawdling on the fairway when they should have been aiming for the pin.

With this defeat Chelsea's hopes of finishing in the top three have all but disappeared. They remain fifth, four points behind third-placed Arsenal and seven adrift of Liverpool with three matches to play - two against these very teams.

Asked what chance his side now had of making the Champions League Vialli replied: "Being realistic, none." He then added the usual qualification that anything could happen in football, although if it was going to happen for Chelsea it had to happen yesterday.

The lethargic attitude of some of his players prompted even the mild-mannered Vialli to be "a bit pissed off" with some aspects of the performance.

In a scarcely veiled warning for next season he said: "I only want players who want to be part of the future of the club. In the next few games I have to find out who wants to stay, who wants to give his best for the club and make it a success. Who wants to die on the pitch and who doesn't... I'm not threatening anyone but we have done marvellously in Europe but not done well in the league."

The way Dan Petrescu sloped straight off to the dressing room after being replaced by Chris Sutton with 17 minutes remaining suggested that the Romanian, who had scored one goal and set up the other, was more than a little disgruntled. And the contribution of Didier Deschamps before Jody Morris took his place for the second half was half-hearted, to say the least. Marcel Desailly was not even on the bench.

By contrast Dennis Wise, Gianfranco Zola and Tore Andre Flo kept going until the end but Chelsea must be more consistent throughout to make a bigger impact on the championship next season.

This was their opportunity to respond positively to being knocked out of Europe six days earlier but, apart from a few brief periods of urgent, imaginative passing, Chelsea were too inclined to share the relaxed mood of what, for United, was a festive occasion.

By leaving out Jaap Stam and taking off Roy Keane early in the second half Sir Alex Ferguson suggested that, while victory was desirable, it was not the be-all and end-all. Keane, who has a hamstring problem, is unlikely to play again this season.

Ryan Giggs was still at his most watchable, David Beckham's craft shone brightly and Ronny Johnsen's completion of his first match for a year was a reminder of what United's defence had been missing.

The watching Ruud van Nistelrooy, set to complete his £19m move today, said United and Old Trafford were even better than he imagined. "It's even more impressive when you see the ground and especially when you see them play here."

The champions' opening goal, after 10 minutes, was of the cap-and-bells variety. Emerson Thome unwisely passed back to Ed de Goey's weaker left foot and, as the goalkeeper studiously controlled the ball, Dwight Yorke dashed in to challenge. De Goey's kick hit the Tobagonian and bounced back into the net.

United suffered the first of their three league defeats this season 5-0 at Stamford Bridge in October but were never seeking vengeance in kind. Instead their defence paid an indirect tribute to the enduring strength of Stam by conceding two goals which the centre-back might have prevented.

Midway through the first half United froze at the far post as a cross from Flo reached Petrescu, who chested the ball down and drove it past Raimond van der Gouw. Ten minutes before half-time Flo rose imperiously above Mickael Silvestre to nod Bernard Lambourde's centre down to Petrescu, who then set up Zola to bounce a shot into the net.

That should have been Chelsea's cue to deny United space near goal. But within four minutes Ole Gunnar Solskjaer gathered a pass from Giggs near the left-hand corner of the area and turned sharply to drive low into the far corner.

Morris's introduction gave Chelsea better momentum but once Yorke restored United's lead in the 68th minute, turning the ball in after De Goey only parried Beckham's cross-shot, their chances of saving the match steadily disappeared.

United played sublime football until the end, leaving Vialli to reflect: "Perhaps next season we should be knocked out of Europe in the first round and go all the way in the Premiership." If all Europe has to offer Chelsea is the Uefa Cup, he may have a point.

webTitle: Racism link to fights at school

fields.headline: Racism link to fights at school
fields.standfirst:
Race issues in the UK: special report
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Black children who feel subjected to racist treatment by their teachers or classmates were twice as likely to be involved in fights with other pupils, according to a survey of 11- to 16-year-olds.
fields.body:
Black children who feel subjected to racist treatment by their teachers or classmates were twice as likely to be involved in fights with other pupils, according to a survey of 11- to 16-year-olds.

They were also more likely to smoke cigarettes and cannabis and drink alcohol, says the Black Child report.

The research will fuel the debate over whether teachers contribute to high exclusion rates for pupils of Caribbean descent who are 4.5 times more likely to be permanently excluded from schools than white children.

General happiness among black pupils improved marginally since 1997, though nearly one in five still said support offered against racism and bullying was poor.

The report was compiled by the Peoplescience Intelligence Unit, which specialises in ethnic minority research, and was based on 612 questionnaires taken in London, Birmingham, Manchester, Liverpool, Nottingham and Bristol.

fields.headline: Crossed wires at Wapping
fields.trailText: Congratulations to The Register webzine for a wonderful little scoop last week. Thanks to the wonder of email, it got its hands on an internal memo from Alasdair MacLeod, the managing director of News Network, the News International internet division. The memo is a summary of the findings of a staff survey and suggests that all is less than blissful in the wired world of Wapping.
fields.body:
Congratulations to The Register webzine for a wonderful little scoop last week. Thanks to the wonder of email, it got its hands on an internal memo from Alasdair MacLeod, the managing director of News Network, the News International internet division. The memo is a summary of the findings of a staff survey and suggests that all is less than blissful in the wired world of Wapping.

Displaying a fantastic flair for management-speak (lots of stuff about "evangelising the company's vision" and "high quality customer experience"), MacLeod reveals three failings: "Lack of clarity around our vision value proposition", "lack of collective ownership" and "a lack of leadership direction". He promises that in the near future "News Network will take aggressive steps to address your concerns".

Now, it is easy (and tempting) to gloat about such leaks, but, as Tony Hall, News Network's marketing director, says, you can hardly criticise someone for listening to his staff. But this remains a sharp reminder that in the past seven years, News International's activities online have been less than successful at creating a high quality "vision value proposition".

It all started with the acquisition of Delphi, one of the early online services in the US. This didn't work out and was soon sold back to the management. Next came the launch (and extensive marketing) of Line One, an ISP (service provider) and portal in partnership with BT. News International eventually pulled out and United News and Media is now the partner. Incidentally, the talented technical team that was lost eventually went to the BBC, where it set up BBC News Online - the internet equivalent of losing the Beatles from your record label.

Last year, we witnessed the birth of CurrantBun.com, a free ISP based around the Sun. That was so successful that it was quickly rebranded as Bun.com and backed by an enormous TV advertising campaign. But this too seemed to dwindle and, earlier this year, was sold to World Online.

In the meantime, we have seen, with the arrival of News Network, the launch of Footballfc.com, a football site which combines the content of the Sun, the News of the World, the Times and the Sunday Times, but manages to be nowhere as good as any of them individually. We have also seen the launch of FiredUp.com, an auction site.

The greatest success currently seems to be Page3.com, which is fine in a soft-porn kind of way. And there are planned launches for a showbiz site run by Andy Coulson, which should be good, and a recruitment site, Revolver, which should do well. Recently, News International has invested in UpMyStreet.com, although time will tell whether this was an inspired move or just one that seemed like a good idea at the time.

The sum total of this is an enormous amount of money spent (well, enormous by UK net standards) with relatively little to show for it, so far. Meanwhile, we find sites for the Times and Sunday Times, which were reasonably impressive when they launched five years ago, and have their occasionally impressive moments (the budget), but are now clearly in need of a long-awaited revamp.

Where has it gone wrong? Well, the reasons are many - but one is vital: outside the online newspaper arena, the ideas themselves have almost all been "me too"s - an ISP, a free ISP, a football site, an auction site, a recruitment site. All had been done already, normally better.

This is in keeping with a traditional big company "fast follower" strategy of letting others innovate, knowing that, after the innovators have made their costly mistakes, you can either buy your way in to a market or just do it bigger.

However, this simply doesn't work on the net. As Philip Evans and Thomas Wurster warn in their excellent (but clumsily titled) book Blown to Bits: How the New Economics of Information Transform Strategy: "The only sure loser is the 'fast follower', it is better to be early five times than late once." News Network could do much worse than get a poster of that quote made up and put it up on the walls in all their meeting rooms.

Now, only a fool would write News International off from ultimate success in this market, and no doubt in a year's time it is likely that the papers will finally have the sites they deserve. But, it is reassuring to know that even the mighty News International is not having it all its own way. In the meantime, if anyone knows what a "vision value proposition" is, you know where to send your CV.

 Simon Waldman is head of Guardian Unlimited

fields.headline: Strength in numbers
fields.trailText: Ten days ago, along with most of British television, I was at the giant Mip TV market in Cannes. Here in an ugly concrete bunker the world's distributors and producers meet to sell their television wares.
fields.body:
Ten days ago, along with most of British television, I was at the giant Mip TV market in Cannes. Here in an ugly concrete bunker the world's distributors and producers meet to sell their television wares.

Mip reduces television to the level of a huge car-boot sale, a street market on Chablis. Beneath the elegant dinners and parties on the beach there is little or no difference between Mip and Petticoat Lane.

Despite this, a visit to Mip is an important reminder not just of the global nature of our industry but also of what priorities sit outside our very particular television culture. The latest pronouncements of the Broadcasting Standards Commission, or the BBC's views on the future of costume drama, pale into insignificance amid the global selling frenzy on the Croisette at Cannes. This year the world seemed interested in only four subjects: sex, crime, natural disasters and whether the French, the Germans or the Belgians now controlled Channel 5.

My visit to Mip was preceded by a trip to Aberystwyth to address the Celtic Film and Television Festival. Here was an utterly contrasting world, a different planet to the craziness of Cannes. For a start, you can fly direct to France in two hours, but the Aberystwyth train takes five hours. Second, such is the Celtic ability to drink their own distilleries dry that this festival is informally known as the Whiskey Olympics.

Much more important, the delegates at Aberystwyth were passionate about film and television, rather than "product", searching for ways not only to protect but to enhance their cultural identity in the face of the global uniformity on display in Cannes.

In this context, Chris Smith has, quite rightly, recently highlighted the importance of regional broadcasting.

On the other hand, the government has, also quite rightly, been stressing the importance of increasing exports of our television programmes at markets like Mip.

The secretary of state's twin ambitions are not as contradictory as they appear to be. There is no reason why producers cannot serve their audience regionally, nationally and internationally. Indeed, each of these ambitions can feed the other.

In ITV, regionality is one of our defining characteristics, part of our personality, a crucial difference from other broadcasters. Regional producers have a huge pride in serving their communities and deliver a good-quality, diverse service to viewers. They understand that output rooted in these communities and from time to time reflecting those lives back to the nation as a whole is a huge plus for ITV. It puts us in touch with our audience.

Good regional production is not just a cultural but a commercial asset. ITV companies know that a threadbare regional schedule would be commercial suicide because many regional programmes win audiences which are big or bigger than the network average. In Wales for example, HTV's ratings for current affairs, consumer journalism or entertainment would make a scheduler at any London network green with envy. Yet, the television mirror must do more than reflect its own regions. We need to know what the stories are in other parts of these lands. Whether it's the dark landscape of Inspector Rebus's Edinburgh or the lives of gay young men in Manchester, we must explore other people's worlds.

I n an integrated system where regional output is linked to a strong network base, ITV regional production can flow into network programmes. So, the story of the babies who died after heart surgery in Bristol, for example, can start in a region and then graduate onto national television. Good regional production is the first stepping stone which can eventually lead to national and international production.

So, regional output is precious, but in a fiercely competitive multi-channel world it is as vulnerable as any other part of contemporary television. We need to find strategies to support regional talent so that it does not inevitably migrate to London.

Why shouldn't ITV, BBC, C4 and others join together to ensure that talent is not only nurtured but kept in the regions? Co-productions, shared resources so more money goes on screen, joint training initiatives, schemes for new directors and shared commitment to independent producers and even trips to Mip to learn about the international market all spring to mind.

As Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland shape a different political and cultural identity, we need to acknowledge the challenges of Aberystwyth as well as embrace the global commerce of Cannes. They are both important to the future, and they aren't mutually exclusive.

webTitle: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Another war film topped the US box office this weekend. The world war II submarine adventure U-571 surfaced at number one, pushing Rules of Engagement to third place. The movie, which stars Harvey Keitel and Matthew McConaughey took an estimated $20.3m.
fields.body:
Another war film topped the US box office this weekend. The world war II submarine adventure U-571 surfaced at number one, pushing Rules of Engagement to third place. The movie, which stars Harvey Keitel and Matthew McConaughey took an estimated $20.3m.

In the Star Wars Episode 2 steeplechase, Jonathan (The Deep End of the Ocean) Jackson has re-emerged as frontrunner for the coveted Anakin Skywalker role, being cited as "in negotiations" with Lucasfilm on several industry websites. Meanwhile, locals in Sydney, where production of the prequel's sequel begins in two months, are proving rather a pain to producers of the sci-fi saga. According to Aussie film site Dark Horizons, one ex-scaffolder threatened to jump to his death unless Lucas gave him a role, much to the horror of his fellow workmates.

The star of this summer's superhero flick X-Men has been reliving an unfortunate accident he experienced while filming Bryan Singer's movie. The Australian actor Hugh Jackman, who stepped in at the last minute to replace Dougray Scott as Wolverine, described - with difficulty - the day he got his testicles twisted in a harness while shooting a 6-foot fall. "I said the biggest swear word I ever let out," says Jackman, "but nothing happened. Everyone thought I was just really getting into it."

Casting couch

Matthew McConaughey is to play Evel Knievel in a film to be directed by Betty (Doctor Dolittle) Thomas. Says the director, "wait until you see Matty as Evel. The guy is terrific with his pants on, by the way. We pasted pictures of Matthew's head on pictures of Evel's body. The guy is perfect, believe me."

Shekhar Kapur has been discussing the movie he plans to make with his Elizabeth star Cate Blanchett, Bombay Dream. The film is a reworking of the musical Kapur is writing with Andrew Lloyd Webber. Blanchett is to produce, sing and act in the tale of a native woman's struggle to survive in India. Kapur says, "Cate is going to co-produce and star in this film. She can sing and not many people know that about her... I believe we will start work on the project very soon"

webTitle: Big ideas for black British cinema

fields.headline: Big ideas for black British cinema
fields.standfirst:
Forest Whitaker leads charge from film ghetto to multiplexes
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Hollywood star Forest Whitaker is leading a push to get black British film-makers out of the ghetto they have been placed in and into the multiplexes.
fields.body:
The Hollywood star Forest Whitaker is leading a push to get black British film-makers out of the ghetto they have been placed in and into the multiplexes.

The actor and director best known for his roles in the Oscar winner The Crying Game, Platoon and The Color of Money has set up a unit within FilmFour, the pay-TV channel, to bring black and Asian writers and directors through the glass ceiling.

"This is not something I am doing for fun. This is a business opportunity," said Whitaker yesterday. "I am in this to make films.

"The talent is there but the films are not being made, and those that are not being seen."

The unexpected success of the rip-roaring comedy East Is East, which is set to displace Trainspotting as the highest grossing fully-funded British film ever made, proves that black British films can have a mass international audience, according to Whitaker, who has directed such commercial hits as Waiting to Exhale and Hope Floats.

"I am here to make universal stories and build a film community by using the talent that maybe up till now has been frustrated," he said.

A study by the British Film Institute confirmed what black film-makers have known years: that the money men shy away from anything that has "black" elements because they see it as a box office loser.

Leslee Udwin, producer of East Is East, which won the Bafta for the outstanding British film of the year, said she had to fight every step of the way to get her film made. "We were fighting against the idea that it was a small film and a black film, and that it wouldn't do any business. It was hard but we won in the end."

The comedy, about a mixed race family who run a fish and chip shop in Salford, has taken nearly $26m (£16.25m) worldwide so far and got tremendous reviews when it opened in America last week.

Whitaker hopes slowly to change the culture at all levels. He will encourage young directors to make shorts from the internet, and bring writers, directors and producers together to work on projects in his "film lab", which will be tied up with his company, Spirit Dance Entertainment.

But the main focus will be on script development. "The big goal is to make films people want to see," said Whitaker. There had been a lack of ambition for black films, a lack of marketing. "FilmFour really believed in East Is East - and see what happened."

There was plenty of black British talent at all levels, including the directors Isaac Julien, of Young Soul Rebels, and Gurinder Chadha, of Bhaji on the Beach, and actors such as Thandie Newton and Marianne Jean-Baptiste, but "talent has to be allowed to work. Look at Marianne. What has she done since she got that Oscar nomination for Secrets and Lies?"

The BFI report, A Fuller Picture, said the six 1990s "black" films it studied - Babymother, Bhaji on the Beach, The Crying Game, Dancehall Queen, Secrets and Lies and Welcome II the Terrordome - were mostly caught in a "vicious chicken and egg situation". They were seen as high risk because there had not been any real hit black British films, nor were there any big enough black British stars to anchor them.

The report attributed part of the problem to the absence of senior black executives in the industry in Britain, something Whitaker's initiative hopes to correct eventually.

Paul Webster, head of FilmFour, said: "Forest is a very practical inspiration to the community. This isn't simply more film industry tokenism; it's the real deal."

But Whitaker has his work cut out. One depressing table of statistics in the report shows that black British films made less money here than even imported African-American ones. The relatively successful Bhaji on the Beach, made for £1.1m, took £309,715, while Babymother, which was twice as expensive, took only £65,600 and the ultra-low budget Welcome II the Terrordome only £5,000.

"No one wants to lose money," said Whitaker. "But there you can also set up a film to fail if you don't market it and really go over the script to make sure it is right before you go ahead with it."

webTitle: What has two wheels, a roof and seatbelts?

fields.headline: What has two wheels, a roof and seatbelts?
fields.standfirst: Sam Wollaston  takes the new  BMW C1 round the block
fields.trailText: It all goes really well until the dispatch rider asks me if I got it from Fisher-Price. Cheeky bugger. And no, it's not mine. I'm just trying it out for the afternoon, OK?
fields.body:
It all goes really well until the dispatch rider asks me if I got it from Fisher-Price. Cheeky bugger. And no, it's not mine. I'm just trying it out for the afternoon, OK?

I end up telling a lot of people it isn't mine. Dispatch riders are the worst - they look at it with utter contempt. And the fashionable people of London's fashionable Hoxton aren't great either. I take a spin through the area, it being the place to be right now, and me being on - or should that be "in"? - what I had naively imagined was something to be seen on/in. But they look away, embarrassed, or openly pity me.

Others are more charitable. A boy in the back of a people carrier gives me the thumbs up. Some Italian tourists on top of an open topped tour bus video me. A man selling the Big Issue in King's Cross looks genuinely delighted by the spectacle and shouts "Wicked, man".

It's the C1, the world's first bike/car hybrid according to the people at BMW. I don't know about that; it has two wheels right? That, in my book, makes it a bike; cars have four wheels. The C1 is a scooter with a roof - presumably to protect the driver from rocks hurled by disdainful dispatch riders, or Longbridge sympathisers when they spot the little blue and white BMW symbol.

But what's this? Seatbelts; that's not very scootery. Plus a windscreen wiper? And the basic model costs £3,945 - hardly scooter money. On the other hand, it doesn't exactly have the people carrying capabilities of a car; you're not supposed to carry someone on the back so there's only room for one - that's exactly half the number of people as my Vespa carries. This is getting confusing. Maybe the people at BMW were right.

Whatever, I set off from the office in Covent Garden (they've handed over the marketing side of things to a posh PR company for the C1 - we could be talking "lifestyle" product here), do a couple of laps of Trafalgar square and head off up the Mall.

It takes a while to get used to the C1. Everything works well, the brakes are brilliant, but it's quite different to driving a scooter. For a start the centre of gravity is a bit higher so it feels wobblier and on this particular day there's a wicked April gale blowing through London, especially over Waterloo bridge, and I'm being buffeted all over the place. It's also less manoeuvrable so you can't weave like you can on a scooter or small bike. And the extra weight means it's not so quick away from the lights as a 125cc scooter.

When it comes to parking up, the two-lever stand lowering system, though clever, is perhaps a little over- complicated. And you can't squeeze a C1 into the same tiny gaps in bike parks as you can with a scooter. (Crap name too - have they forgotten the C5, Clive Sinclair's ill-fated experiment?).

There are two major pluses though. When an April shower hits you don't get wet (at least not from above). And you feel reasonably safe, much less vulnerable and exposed than on a scooter. The driver is strapped in between shoulder height protective bars, there's an impact absorbing front mudguard and, of course, that rigid aluminium roll-over cage. In a safety video, a crash test dummy comes out a lot better after driving his C1 into a car than doing the same with a conventional bike. This has got to be the main selling point of the thing. In most European countries you don't have to wear a helmet in a C1. Here you do, but that might change.

So would I trade in my Vespa for a C1? I don't think so. Longbridge aside, I think four grand is too much to pay for something with only two wheels and a125cc engine. (The executive model - with mobile phone holder and reading light is £4470, but I never find much time for reading on my bike.) Although the C1 is a very clever design and clearly the future and all that, I have a slight problem with the way it looks. It may have been that Fisher-Price comment that did it.

But if I was someone who drove a car to work, and wanted to get there a bit quicker, but was scared to get on a bike, I might think about one. So long as the route to work didn't go through Hoxton.

fields.headline: Highway patrol
fields.standfirst: It has lasers, satellite links and can see in the dark. Target: traffic cones.  Simon Hacker  gets on the case
fields.trailText: It looks like a mobile home, doesn't even come with metallic paint and costs £1m. But Ford's new Iveco truck (RAV - the Road Assessment Vehicle) has the kind of technology James Bond would die for - and looks set to put quite a few motorway cones out of a job.
fields.body:
It looks like a mobile home, doesn't even come with metallic paint and costs £1m. But Ford's new Iveco truck (RAV - the Road Assessment Vehicle) has the kind of technology James Bond would die for - and looks set to put quite a few motorway cones out of a job.

You want laser guns? This has 22. You want to liaise with HQ via a satellite in space? A GPS link ensures that the RAV's whereabouts are pinpointed down to the last inch.

The plan is that the RAV truck will spend the next five years trundling its way around 6,500 miles of England's motorways and trunk roads, looking for cracks, fissures and things that go bump when they shouldn't. And on the motorway, the RAV can sail along at 70mph, yet still work like a forensic scientist - downloading data from its barrage of lasers and cameras and picking up cracks as small as two millimetres. It can even do its job in the dark.

And while all this information is being collected, the RAV's satellite global positioning system is linked up to pinpoint the exact position of the road defects, so there's no need for the vehicle to keep stopping and marking the side of the road where the tarmac is kaput.

Colin Curry, the RAV driver, arguably now has more power than anyone to reduce road delays. He's proud of his wheels, but not entirely sure they'll guarantee on-road happiness: "I'm very much aware of the value of what I'm driving - particularly when going down a narrow local road. You might say I use a bit more caution than the local road users.

"On the motorway though, it doesn't really matter how slow or fast you're going - drivers will always try to get past you. They all want to be there yesterday, delay or no delay."

fields.headline: Don't worry, that's his job
fields.standfirst: It's not enough for cars to look and feel right - now they have to smell right too. By  Helen Jones
fields.trailText: What does your car smell of? Cheap plastic? Wet dog? Last night's burger? After a few weeks every car takes on the distinctive whiff of its owner and even new cars have a particular smell - but not if you buy an Audi. An Audi should smell of nothing all at.
fields.body:
What does your car smell of? Cheap plastic? Wet dog? Last night's burger? After a few weeks every car takes on the distinctive whiff of its owner and even new cars have a particular smell - but not if you buy an Audi. An Audi should smell of nothing all at.

Heiko Luessmann-Gieger is chief sniffer at Audi's offices in Ingolstadt near Munich. He leads a team of scientists who smell everything that goes into the interior of a new car. "We are aiming for complete neutrality. The perfect car should smell of nothing discernible at all," he says.

In the past, car manufacturers concentrated on the look and feel of their models - the styling, the engine sound, the grip of the steering wheel. Mercedes, for example, employs paint doctors who rub their gloved hands all over the body work looking for blemishes. Ford has an acoustic centre in Cologne that aims to create the perfect "swish" for the windscreen wipers and Nissan uses an "automatic mechanical bottom" - a pair of jean-clad prosthetic legs that sits up and down on a car seat 15,000 times, to ensure that the fabric is durable.

But now manufacturers have to go even further. "It's about creating a total brand experience," says Ralph Ardill, marketing director of branding experts, Imagination. "Cars have to appeal to all the senses so companies are having to think about what their product smells like and how that reflects the brand's values."

Second-hand car dealers know the value of a good smelling motor and invest in scented sprays to produce an "authentic" leather smell. And in Japan, Nissan is experimenting with scents that are intended to make you a better driver. It has developed a concept car that contains a camera focused on the drivers eyelids. "If it spots your eyelids drooping then the car will emit a peppermint spray scent which is designed to pep you up and stimulate you," explains Nissan's spokesman Frank Shepherd.

But Luessmann-Gieger says that adding scents to cars is a bad idea. "You can't add smells to cars because consumers might not like them and even if they did like the scent they might complain when it faded."

His team carries out a whole range of tests to get the neutral scent they are seeking. "We sell to over 100 countries so we have to make sure that the glues and plastics don't smell terrible in really hot climates. We also leave materials underwater for three days to see what they smell like when they are wet."

So how do you sniff an Audi? Luessmann-Gieger and his nose team collect samples of materials from all Audi's suppliers and store them in airtight jars. "We get together and each take a sniff from the jars and then award it marks out of six - from one for no smell to six for unbearable," he explains.

The team, which claims that it can identify the smell of every part of an Audi's interior blindfold, knows which chemicals give off unpleasant odours. "If something smells of bitter almonds for example, I know why and I can go back to the manufacturer and suggest they modify the materials to get rid of it," Luessmann-Gieger says.

The scientists have training sessions with perfumiers to improve their sniffing skills, but some are inevitably more suited to it than others. "Some people just have more sensitive noses than others. We have people who really like particular scents such as leather or PVC and so they tend to concentrate on those areas," he says.

But dedicated PVC sniffers have to make certain sacrifices for their art. They can't smoke, must have high standards of personal hygiene but can't use heavily scented shampoos or deodorants and they mustn't wear aftershave or perfume. Perhaps most trying of all, they have to watch what they eat. "You can't eat garlic, and kebabs are banned because they not only affect your sensitivity, but also that of the people around you," Luessmann-Gieger says.

So is it worth the effort given that within a few weeks owners will stamp their own odour on their Audi? "Absolutely" says Luessmann-Gieger. "If a new car has an unpleasant or intense smell, customers might not buy it in the first place."

webTitle: Me and my motor: Medieval Baebe  Carmen Schneider

fields.headline: Me and my motor: Medieval Baebe  Carmen Schneider
fields.trailText: What do you drive?
fields.body:
What do you drive?

A 1971 Mercedes 300 SEL.

What does that say about you?

That I'm a bit of a show off.

What do you like about it?

I love the sound of the V8 engine bubbling away, but the column gear change can be a bit fiddly at times.

Why did you buy it?

I saw an advert on the internet about chauffeur driven classic Mercs and thought it would be fun to be driven around town before a gig. Then I saw one of the cars was actually for sale and I couldn't resist it.

What kind of driver are you?

I'm an undercover cabbie - I like taking the sneaky back roads.

Any bad habits?

As a passenger giving directions I constantly confuse left and right. It's enough to drive my husband insane.

Any driving test tales?

I failed first time, need I say more?

What was your first car?

A 1972 Mercedes 200D, which cost £140. You can see I got into the habit early. It was a great old banger that needed two batteries to get going in the morning. I used to call it "the whale" because the steering wheel made these funny noises - and if you broke down you were literally beached.

Have you experienced road rage?

Yes, every time I see a black cab.

What's in the boot?

Old newspapers that I keep meaning to take to the recycling station.

Have you ever had sex in a car?

When visiting my now-husband-then-boyfriend in New Zealand, he picked me up from the airport in an "ute" - a utility van. I thought it was hardly ideal for romantic encounters, but as it turns out I couldn't have been more mistaken.

What music do you listen to on the road?

At the moment I'm listening to a tape fellow Baebe Rachel has compiled for my birthday. My favourite tunes on it are by Death in Vegas and Chris Cornell.

What would be your dream car?

A 1950s Mercedes gullwing.

Who would be your dream passenger?

Sam Mendes, I love his plays at the Donmar Warehouse and apart from that an Oscar would go so well with my car.

fields.headline: Yemen slams 'barbaric' Friedkin pic
fields.trailText: Last week, the Arab American Anti-Discrimination Committee censured chart-topping movie Rules of Engagement. This week, the government of Yemen pitched in too. The powers-that-be in the Gulf State have branded the William Friedkin-directed film a "barbaric and racist attack against Arabs and Yemenis" and urged all Arab states to boycott it and its producer, Paramount Pictures.
fields.body:
Last week, the Arab American Anti-Discrimination Committee censured chart-topping movie Rules of Engagement. This week, the government of Yemen pitched in too. The powers-that-be in the Gulf State have branded the William Friedkin-directed film a "barbaric and racist attack against Arabs and Yemenis" and urged all Arab states to boycott it and its producer, Paramount Pictures.

The film, which stars Samuel Jackson and Tommy Lee Jones, depicts an anti-US riot at the country's embassy in Yemen - something which has not actually occurred, insist Yemeni officials, for over 10 years. The movie has incurred Yemen's wrath before actually being screened within several thousand miles of the Red Sea state.

"I think that [the Yemenese government] was aware of our reaction to the movie, says Hussein Ibish, speaking for the Arab-American community. "They probably heard about it through the grapevine. It's a very big movie."

Paramount defended the feature, arguing that it "is not an indictment of any government, culture or people."

Analysts say that such protests were unlikely to hurt the film - on the contrary, they usually help.

webTitle: Parliament 'misled' over UK efforts to end bribery

fields.headline: Parliament 'misled' over UK efforts to end bribery
fields.standfirst: Read the documents
fields.trailText: A Liberal Democrat MP has complained to the speaker of the House of Commons, Betty Boothroyd, that the government has misled parliament over Britain's efforts to wipe out bribery in international business deals.
fields.body:
A Liberal Democrat MP has complained to the speaker of the House of Commons, Betty Boothroyd, that the government has misled parliament over Britain's efforts to wipe out bribery in international business deals.

The complaint came after the minister for trade, Richard Caborn, claimed in a written Commons answer this month that Britain "played a leading role in the negotiations" for an international treaty to outlaw the bribery of foreign officials by commercial companies.

But documents obtained by the Guardian through the US freedom of information act show that behind the scenes the Americans criticised the British for being silent during these talks and had to urge them to do more to get the treaty wrapped up and signed.

The complaint was lodged by Vincent Cable, Lib Dem spokesman on trade and industry, who said : "These documents clearly show that the government has seriously misled parliament. If the government is serious about an ethical foreign policy we have got to be in the lead in stamping out bribery.

"Since these papers were obtained through the US freedom of information act, it reminds us all too clearly why we need such legislation in this country, and why British ministers and civil servants are so terrified about allowing this to happen."

The government has been criticised by other countries and anti-corruption campaigners for dragging its feet over implementing the treaty properly. The suspicion is that, since corruption is so rife, the government does not want to impede UK companies in the race for contracts.

The centrepiece of anti-bribery efforts across the world is a convention promoted by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Governments pledged to make it a criminal offence for their own citizens and companies to slip backhanders to officials of other countries to win contracts.

Britain, the US and other OECD countries pledged in May 1997 to complete the negotiations on this convention by the end of that year.

But by September 1997 the Americans were voicing their unhappiness with the British at a meeting between the US commerce secretary, William Daley, and the then UK trade and industry secretary, Margaret Beckett, in Washington.

Before the meeting, Mr Daley was briefed by his officials as follows: "We must complete these negotiations and have a strong, effective convention open for signature by the end of 1997. We are not aware of any substantive disagreements between our countries in these negotiations. However, the UK has not been active in the talks. We do not know the reason for this reticence."

He told Mrs Beckett that "there had been no sign of strong, active UK support for the convention". He implored Britain to "play a more supportive role and take a stronger position" to champion the convention in negotiating sessions to start in November that year, according to a report of the meeting.

Mr Daley said: "There was no US-UK dispute or disagreements over positions on the issue, but rather a need for the UK to take a forceful, more enthusiastic stance in favour of the convention and to make a 'strong push' in November."

Mrs Beckett was "somewhat surprised", replying that "while it was not like UK representatives to be so reticent, she would ensure that the message gets back to the HMG representatives".

Jeremy Pope, executive director of the anti-corruption campaign Transparency International, said this diplomatic exchange was not an isolated incident. "This comes up all the time between Britain and the US. It is a very hot and live issue."

The US, which outlawed bribery of foreign officials in 1977, has lobbied hard for measures to eradicate kickbacks, partly because it believes that its companies lose out to supposedly less scrupulous foreign competitors.

The treaty to banish the "widespread phenomenon" of bribery in international business transactions was signed in December 1997.

Originally Britain and the other OECD nations had each promised to introduce by early 1998 the legislation needed to enforce the treaty in their own countries. But two years later the British government has produced no such laws.

The DTI yesterday said it was working closely with its American counterparts to suppress bribery. "We are not complacent," an official said. "We are awaiting a decision from the Home Office on new legislation."

webTitle: Early Lucas short gets exclusive online screening

fields.headline: Early Lucas short gets exclusive online screening
fields.trailText: Online short film specialists Atom Films are screening Star Wars chief George Lucas' legendary student film Electronic Labyrinth on their site.
fields.body:
Online short film specialists Atom Films are screening Star Wars chief George Lucas' legendary student film Electronic Labyrinth on their site.

Back in the late 60s, when Lucas was an anti-populist avant-gardist and not a peddler of popcorn to the masses, he made the film which would later evolve into his first feature THX-1138. Atom Films have now bagged the much-discussed but little seen student short.

The plot, writes Ray Greene on the site, "is a primal reworking of themes gleaned equally from Orwell's 1984, Huxley's Brave New World, and the countercultural paranoia of the period." It marked Lucas' first attempt at science fiction. The film used a mixed media approach - overlaying video images and opticals, and techniques "that are startling even today," but which were miraculous and even visionary back in 1967."

The film took first prize in the narrative category at the Third National Student Film Festival, and established Lucas as a film-maker to watch. "It's fair to say that ultimately, the film now known as Electronic Labyrinth changed the course of Hollywood history" continues Mr Greene, "not only by helping to establish one of the towering figures of the modern era, but by transforming the expectations which young short filmmakers came to have of the ultimate impact their works could make Lucas' unexpected achievement was to not only re-invent himself, but to re-invent the possibilities available to independent short filmmakers the world over. Even today, it may be George Lucas' most enduring accomplishment."

Decide for yourself whether such eulogies are justified - you can watch the 15-minute film on Atom Films now.

fields.headline: Red alert over election fever
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: You could say he saw red when he noticed four freshly-erected roadworks signs. But the problem for a Colchester Labour party activist was that he saw yellow; Liberal Democrat yellow to be precise.
fields.body:
You could say he saw red when he noticed four freshly-erected roadworks signs. But the problem for a Colchester Labour party activist was that he saw yellow; Liberal Democrat yellow to be precise.

Now officials have been forced to remove the signs after the Labour man complained that they were giving the Liberal Democrats an unfair advantage. The yellow, he said, was just too similar to the party's local election posters.

The roadsigns, designed to help local people avoid traffic delays while roadworks are carried out in the town, were taken down after Colchester's head of highways, Barry Layzell, admitted the colour did not conform to Department of Transport specifications. His employees had carried out strict tests, comparing Lib Dem yellow to the signs. The signs failed.

Yesterday Colchester's Lib Dem MP, Bob Russell, said the complaint was "completely loopy". He added: "Some poor official was dispatched to my office to get a copy of a brochure so they could check the colour. To suggest the Lib Dems used road safety signs for political propaganda purposes is just dopey. They will be claiming next that all the yellow daffodils planted on the town's roundabouts and in parks should be torn up."

The complaint came ahead of the borough elections on May 4 when the council - which is hung with 25 Lib Dems, 18 Conservatives, 15 Labour members and two Independents - could change its political balance.

Terry Sutton, deputy leader of the council's Lib-Dems, said: "The next thing we know danger signs will have to be removed because they are red - and motorway road signs must be changed because they are blue."

Labour group leader Tim Young said: "The complaint was made by a supporter acting on his own who may have thought it was funny."

fields.headline: Biased, us?
fields.standfirst:
It's BBC-baiting season again. The Tories are crying 'bias' over Question Time, but Michael White has heard it all before
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: I appeared on BBC1's Breakfast News the other morning to discuss the asylum issue with Bruce Anderson, political columnist of the Daily Mail and Spectator.
fields.body:
I appeared on BBC1's Breakfast News the other morning to discuss the asylum issue with Bruce Anderson, political columnist of the Daily Mail and Spectator.

No harm in that, I doubt if the exchange even registered on the telly-bias geiger counter at Conservative Central Office. I offered a liberal perspective plus a few facts, while Beast (as Bruce is affectionately known) offered a rich choice of outraged nouns and adjectives. Flood, bogus, influx, that sort of thing.

Coincidentally, however, the Geiger counter at Tory HQ was jumping all over the place. The Sunday Telegraph had revealed that William Hague had been deeply offended to learn that no Tory representative had been included in the previous week's Edinburgh edition of BBC2's Question Time.

Next day, the Times joined in to report that the Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, has personalised it all by suggesting that the perennial Tory obsession with bias at the Beeb had got a lot worse since Greg Dyke "took over" from John Birt as director-general.

Nonsense or what? I wish it could dismiss it as complete nonsense, but it isn't, even if the usual tired attacks on the Corporation are both longstanding and rarely on target. Do you remember Norman Tebbit flaying Kate Adie (of all people!) for doing her job during the Libyan crisis of 1986?

Alastair Campbell repeated the crass error of judgment over Kosovo. This time the target was - of all people - the equally formidable John Simpson. That's politics. As long ago as 1926, the then DG, John Reith, had to beat off Winston Churchill over his sort-of-balanced reporting of the general strike.

The Mail and Telegraph, on the other hand, usually berate the Beeb for what are essentially cultural reasons: nudity, swearing, atheism and a dumbing down of the Reithian inheritance. I occasionally sympathise with that. If they treated Islam the way they sometimes mock Christianity then Television Centre would long ago have been burned down.

That's part of the trouble, of course. As a publicly-funded institution the BBC has responsibilities, manfully borne most of the time, to respect beleaguered sensibilities, women, minorities, the disabled and - last week - Scots, a very sensitive issue for the BBC.

The decision to field an SNP panelist on Question Time was almost certainly taken from the highest motives (these things are carefully monitored too). The SNP is indeed the Opposition in Scotland, but Question Time is a networked show.

Thus Roseanna Cunningham, MP, is not a household name among the 50m listeners south of the border and Dennis Canavan, the fiery-but-expelled leftwinger on David Dimbleby's Edinburgh team, is not balm to Bournemouth ears.

Beeb-bashing in the Murdoch press is something else: just business. The BBC is a major rival and Murdoch, a bully with a weakness for self-pity ( just like the Sun in fact), thinks it is all unfair, though his own licence fee works out much dearer than Auntie's.

Rupe's whinge is most noticeable in the Sun which shamelessly puffs BSkyB, but evident elsewhere in the empire, including the Times. Last year it launched a campaign which failed to block Dyke's appointment as DG on the grounds that he had given New Labour £50,000.

Unwise perhaps, but more transparent than some political intimacies down the years. Which BBC chairman at a critical juncture had a Tory cabinet member as a brother-in-law?

webTitle: No more news of the screws

fields.headline: No more news of the screws
fields.standfirst: A landmark judgment from the press complaints commission could signal the end of a tabloid staple - the kiss 'n' tell.  Roy Greenslade explains all
fields.trailText: For the regular News of the World reader, the kiss and tell story blurbed on page one and taking up two pages inside was familiar fare. There were the regulation "sexy" pictures of a TV soap star, a couple of lurid headlines and a lot of extremely salacious copy. For the actress featured under the headline "Street star's 8-month marathon of lust", it was deeply humiliating.
fields.body:
For the regular News of the World reader, the kiss and tell story blurbed on page one and taking up two pages inside was familiar fare. There were the regulation "sexy" pictures of a TV soap star, a couple of lurid headlines and a lot of extremely salacious copy. For the actress featured under the headline "Street star's 8-month marathon of lust", it was deeply humiliating.

A former lover, the man she had once been engaged to marry, had been paid a five-figure sum to disgorge the most intimate details of their relationship. She was, like so many celebrities who have suffered similar intrusions into their private lives, devastated. But unlike numerous other victims who walk away, hiding their red faces and accepting their fate, Jacqueline Pirie - who plays Linda Sykes - refused to accept that the paper had a right to publish. The Coronation Street actress, helped by her employers, Granada TV, made a formal complaint to the press complaints commission (PCC).

The outcome has come as a severe shock to the News of the World. In what must rank as a landmark adjudication, the PCC decided that the paper's story had breached clause three of the editors' code of practice, which states: "Everyone is entitled to his or her private and family life, home, health and correspondence."

In other words, the one-sided account by Pirie's ex-fiancé, even though its truth has not been disputed, was considered to have invaded her privacy. At first sight, this seems an extraordinary decision. Surely Lee Atherton, the man who sold his story, has a right to freedom of expression? Regardless of the fact that it was a caddish thing to do, he was talking about his own experiences, after all.

But second sight, when sense and sensibility kick in, suggests otherwise. Freedom brings with it a responsibility not to infringe someone's privacy. By revealing their sexual activities in sordid detail he - and the newspaper - were indeed intruding on her private life.

What the PCC has done (and our courts will surely do often in future since the European Convention of Human Rights has been incorporated into British law) is balance Atherton's right to free speech with Pirie's right to privacy and, in this specific case, come down on her side.

The paper's defence of its story, which ran over two weeks in January, was thin, but it used a ploy that has often proved effective. Aware that it couldn't claim that the story was in the public interest, it chose instead the most common excuse offered by tabloids for such intrusions into the lives of celebrities: that they have previously sought publicity.

The News of the World argued that Pirie had spoken about her relationship with Atherton before, to OK! magazine for instance. She had also been paid by the News of the World for an article and, on a separate occasion, another boyfriend had spoken about her without her complaining. The PCC was having none of this. Each case must be treated on its merits and, to that end, the PCC's concept of "proportionality" is likely to be an excellent guide to deciding whether previous publicity is, or is not, relevant. By measuring the difference between material already in the public domain and the subject matter of any new article, commission members can decide if intrusion is justifiable. In the plainest of terms, does a spread of posed pictures in a magazine, for which the celebrity has been paid a fee, warrant a paper publishing a one-sided account of the person's bedroom habits? Answer in the Pirie case: a resounding no.

To understand the significance of the decision and the growing relevance of proportionality, we should consider two previous cases involving celebrity complainants. In 1996, the PCC rejected a claim by Julia Carling, estranged wife of the then England rugby captain Will Carling, that she was being harassed by the press. Despite being hounded by photographers, it was judged that her privacy had not been invaded.

Why? Because she had given previous interviews about her private life. The PCC noted sniffily at the time: "Persons who put matters involving their private life into the public domain may not be able to claim protection when articles are published without their consent and which seek to comment on, clarify or contrast the impression given by the information provided by the persons concerned." That was unduly harsh. The Pirie ruling runs counter to it, but note that it occurred before the death of Princess Diana. It is proof that times have indeed changed.

On reflection, the other case from that period, in which television presenter Selina Scott complained about a 1995 News of the World story, also had an unsatisfactory conclusion, even though the PCC agreed that her privacy had been violated. The paper had published a kiss-and-tell story in which a man claimed that he and Scott had had an affair 18 years previously. "It was a downright lie," Scott told the PCC. "I have never slept with the man in my life."

The News of the World argued that the man had sworn an affidavit but the commission had no way of testing whether the story was true or false. Instead, it ruled that what had been published - whatever its truthfulness - was an unwarranted breach of privacy without a shred of public interest. Whatever Scott's understandable disappointment that the decision did nothing to nail the lie, the importance of this adjudication, in hindsight, is that it and the Pirie ruling are entirely consistent.

Yet in the four years since the Scott ruling, no other celebrity has taken advantage of the PCC's protection, probably because of the concentration on the controversy about whether the storyteller had lied rather than the nature of his, and the paper's, intrusion.

The Pirie decision is much more clear-cut, and I believe its change of emphasis from the Carling adjudication offers future kiss-and-tell victims a sure-fire remedy. Though it does not, and could not, settle the dispute about what is properly private and what can be deemed to be public, it does offer a guideline. News of the World editor Phil Hall certainly understands the implications, and is contrite about the Pirie story. "I totally accept that it was a mistake," he says. "It shouldn't have happened and I accept that we went too far. We are going to address this kind of problem and we'll be much more careful in future."

Hall has also withdrawn his initial knee-jerk criticism of the PCC decision. He was reflecting the concern among his senior staff about whether the adjudication sets a precedent, outlawing the whole kiss-and-tell genre. It doesn't do that, of course, but it does place yet another hurdle in the way. Even if the form remains, tabloid editors are going to have to think about the content.

I suspect that much of the PCC's dislike of the Pirie story was based on its tastelessness. Without repeating the details, there is no doubt that even by the descending standards of such stories, it was undeniably vulgar. One editor has even described it as "sadistic". A Granada spokeswoman said: "In our experience we'd never seen such a tawdry kiss and tell, going well beyond the bounds of other examples. It was the gratuitous sexual detail that upset her."

Even so, some journalists were surprised that Pirie complained. Would she not attract yet more unwanted tabloid attention? One of Pirie's friends said: "Jacqui was deeply hurt by the piece and very embarrassed that her private life had been splashed all over the paper without her consent or knowledge, and with no shred of public interest. She was concerned that her complaint would antagonise the News of the World, but she felt the degree of intrusion was so extreme that she had to do something. She also felt that if she didn't complain it was quite likely papers would feel she was 'fair game' in future."

It is therefore creditable that Pirie, risking further embarrassment, was prepared to press her complaint. In many ways, it can be seen as a selfless act, more likely to help her fellow TV actors than herself, because she had nothing to gain from her action. Indeed, in my view, if she had gone to law she could have made out a good case for breach of confidence. As Pirie's friend pointed out: "She felt there'd been a trust between her and Lee and that he had betrayed that trust." She might also have considered a breach of copyright action because letters were reproduced too. In such circumstances, the fact that she chose to go to the PCC rather than sue reflects well on her.

The PCC remained silent on one aspect of Pirie's complaint, that the paper didn't contact her before publication. This just isn't good enough. I understand the journalistic convention that papers leave it to the last possible minute to contact people in order to prevent them taking legal action to stop publication. But to publish a scandalous story without any warning is itself a scandal. The PCC must get to grips with this unjust practice as soon as possible.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • The parlous state of the BBC's business and economics unit seems unlikely to improve. Having recently lost Ed Crooks, Chris Giles, Peter Morgan and Denise Mahoney, the unit's attempts to recruit a new economics correspondent ended in failure. "They want someone who looks like Michelle Pfeiffer, thinks like Alan Greenspan and will do a 60-hour week for £40k - and few of those applied," says a BBC insider. Still, Greg Dyke might be able to get closer to his ambition of "covering business like sport" by getting Gary Lineker to knock out the odd think piece on the strong pound or John Motson to deliver a Today package on the euro...

 Though greeted with joy by the public, Lord Alli of Carlton's Crossroads revival campaign has met with a muted response at ITV Network Centre. Asked last week if the surge of motel nostalgia had made it difficult for ITV to say no to the return of Benny and Miss Diane, director of programmes David Liddiment said: "I never find it difficult to say no."

 Channel 4 insiders have let slip the secret to a good working relationship with the fragile genius of Chris Morris. The key is to choose your battles wisely. So instead of protesting about the lack of ad breaks in his Jam series, the channel preferred to tackle Morris about press listings. The crunch came with his pithy description of last week's show, submitted as "Amelia Bullmore [Jam actress] takes it up the arse", a wording we suspect the Radio Times would have failed to find room for. "I wouldn't have minded," says our source, "but that wasn't what it was about at all."

 On a night when Martin Bashir picked up a gong at the RTS journalism awards, most of the Tonight with Trevor McDonald team enjoyed themselves. But reporter Vanessa Collingridge was grumpy, berating a fellow diner for disclosing her past as a weather girl, on the grounds that she's now a serious journalist. Not a claim that would impress those RTS guests loudly proclaiming that Tonight bears more resemblance to Family Affairs than current affairs.

 Former Daily Mail showbiz hackette Rebecca Hardy has been quick to stamp her authority on the Scotsman, where she is acting editor while Tim Luckhurst takes sick leave after only three weeks in the top post. Out through the revolving door at Holyrood Road goes David Black, appointed assistant editor (news) just a couple of weeks ago. Reversing recent recruitment policy, Hardy has promoted Terry Watson and Tom Little - both Scottish, and with newspaper nous. Which is just as well, since Hardy's leader briefings have been described as "intellectually incoherent".
