fields.headline: Advice for the BBC from...
fields.trailText:
Patrick Younge
Deputy commissioning editor for multicultural programmes at Channel 4, and a former executive producer in BBC current affairs
fields.body:
Patrick Younge
Deputy commissioning editor for multicultural programmes at Channel 4, and a former executive producer in BBC current affairs

BBC current affairs has many enemies. Some are external, like ITV, others are internal, like those envious of its ring-fenced income and slots and the executives who compare Panorama's ratings with MacIntyre Undercover, or the Money Programme against Trouble at the Top.

The next head of current affairs has to take the fight to these critics. But before they start they have to address some fundamental questions and some structural problems, not all of current affairs' own making. The department remains overwhelmingly white, especially at producer level and above. A wider range of backgrounds gives you a better range of stories. However, four of the 18 producers made redundant last year were black or Asian, including the woman who produced and directed an RTS award-winning programme.

So the first task for the new boss is to modernise the role of current affairs. I would offer three criteria: programmes have to either be absolutely topical, get a respectable audience or make an impact on the national debate. The BBC consistently manages this on radio, but they're failing to deliver on television.

The highest profile programme to tackle is obviously Panorama. What it really needs is fewer slots. How can any team of journalists be expected to deliver original and penetrating films each week for nearly 40 weeks a year? I'd leave the budget untouched but cut the run by about 20%, down to a maximum of 30 programmes a year, and run it as three blocks of ten shows.

Panorama also needs to look at its agenda and its staffing. The reporting line-up is starting to look tired and a bit dated, and the actual style of reporting feels unchanged from 30 years ago. It needs updating, and soon, if it's going to remain relevant.

Ring-fencing has worked against current affairs, because it's been insulated from having to engage with the audience's changing demands. The new head of current affairs should use this secure staffing base to react quickly to the big breaking stories and news events. Take the closure of Rover at Longbridge. With a bit of ambition current affairs could have pulled together a big live programme within days. That's how they will distinguish themselves from the documentary departments' pretenders to their throne. MacIntyre and Trouble... are great programmes, but they can't handle big breaking stories. These live reactive specials would be unique television events.

Other BBC departments found themselves in a similar position five years ago: documentaries responded with the docu-soap and the constructed reality programmes like Castaway and Living with the Enemy, while science moved to the centre of the schedule by refreshing brands like Tomorrow's World and delivering Walking with Dinosaurs and the Human Body. The current affairs job is a major undertaking for the sucessful candidate, but fortune should favour the brave.

fields.headline: It's the BBC - but not as we know it
fields.standfirst: Can the World Service, with its lingering image of a bygone empire and announcers in dinner jackets, compete with the raw commercialism of the new information networks?  Adam Sweeting  reports
fields.trailText: Few broadcasting institutions seem less typical of the digital era than the BBC World Service. Steeped in the tradition of offering a public service to the polyglot citizens of a once sprawling British empire, and still playing that scratchy old Lillibulero signature tune, the World Service can't help triggering flashbacks to the days when radio broadcasters wore dinner jackets and Britannia ruled the waves. "Like MI5, the cucumber sandwich and the Boat Race, the BBC World Service seems to define the identity of the British, even if it touches precious few British lives," as the Financial Times put it recently.
fields.body:
Few broadcasting institutions seem less typical of the digital era than the BBC World Service. Steeped in the tradition of offering a public service to the polyglot citizens of a once sprawling British empire, and still playing that scratchy old Lillibulero signature tune, the World Service can't help triggering flashbacks to the days when radio broadcasters wore dinner jackets and Britannia ruled the waves. "Like MI5, the cucumber sandwich and the Boat Race, the BBC World Service seems to define the identity of the British, even if it touches precious few British lives," as the Financial Times put it recently.

The World Service built its reputation on being able to reach territories other broadcasters had never heard of, but the explosive spread of new information networks now threatens its existence. While the majority of World Service listeners still have to struggle to tune in on hissing shortwave, CNN has built itself into the Coca-Cola of world media, and prides itself on its "mindshare", or recognisability. Now, CNN Interactive is gearing up to spread its message throughout Europe, Africa and the Middle East via the internet. For anyone who considers themselves a news junkie, cyberspace offers ample opportunities for a fatal overdose. Yahoo! and MSNBC already have their news services on stream, vying with Sky News, ITN, Reuters, Bloomberg and PA's new virtual newsreader, Ananova. Many major newspapers (including this one) are available in comprehensive online versions. Log on to any internet provider, and you're greeted with a splash of news headlines.

Now that news and current affairs have become commodities to be bought and sold by huge media conglomerates such as CNN's owners AOL/Time-Warner, why should listeners still bother to seek out the World Service's faintly eccentric brand? However, the service is acutely aware of the multiple threats to its position, and the internet is at the forefront of its thinking

World Service online offers a 24-hour service in 43 languages, covering all the topics you can get through the crackling ether and with regular World Service items available as ready-to-play audio files. The BBC is busily forging relationships to make its content available through overseas internet service providers, for instance Brazil's Universo Online. The corporation has developed its own multilingual software, enabling PC screens to display Arabic and Urdu, or Mandarin and Cantonese. The World Service can brandish figures to show that in the past year, listeners have increased from 143m to 151m, while usage of the online operation has tripled in the same period.

But can it match the pace and pizzazz of the opposition? World Service boss Mark Byford has his tonic-for-the-troops speech ready. "The World Service is a public service proposition," he declares. "That's why it gets its money through government, to serve audiences, not to make a profit. We believe its values of trustworthiness, accuracy, fair dealing and impartiality, and also the breadth and depth of its international agenda, will still shine through in a multimedia world. We're not saying we want to move from being a radio broadcaster to being a net broadcaster. What we're saying is we want to be the best-known and most respected voice in international broadcasting."

Will it still be the World Service as we know it? "The values and purpose of the service will always be rock solid, cornerstone, fundamental and clear," Byford insists. Chris Westcott, who runs the Service's online operation, argues that the public service remit means that "we don't do things because there is a commercial market there. We're responding to the same kind of market forces as a CNN or an MSNBC, but we're responding in slightly different ways."

Meanwhile, its rivals are scheming relentlessly to steal as much of the World Service's international audience as they can. "Anybody who is producing a news and information service in whatever language is certainly a competitor," warns Mitch Lazar, who's in charge of business development, new media for Turner Broadcasting System Europe.

Lazar was also behind the launch of CNN Mobile last year, a foretaste of emerging technologies which brings CNN content to 41m mobile phone users in 18 countries in SMS, Wap and HDML formats. So far, this is a development that World Service online is only thinking about. CNN has also taken giant steps towards turning itself into an international service, instead of the parochially American institution it used to be. It now has several local-language TV news channels as well as websites in seven languages, while European viewers to its TV service can now count on seeing European anchorpersons, presenting locally tailored content. CNN even offered in-depth coverage of cricket's financial scandals, where once the only sport it seemed to have heard of was American college football. "We've worked very hard to change the perception that we are an American product," says Lazar. "If you watch the TV network today, it's completely different to what you would have seen five years ago."

The World Service's future will depend on how effectively it can continue to make its objective, non-commercial voice heard. "It's key to our position that the unique World Service tone is not eroded," Westcott stresses. "It's often underestimated how sophisticated users of media are. I think there is an increasing wariness about 'you're telling me this, but you're also selling it to me, so why are you telling me?' And of course the BBC doesn't have this problem."

Mitch Lazar takes the oppo site view, funnily enough. "I believe one thing we have in our favour, where the BBC might get bogged down, is that in some cases they are not able to move in a commercialised way as fast as a CNN type of operation. We have different elements driving our business versus the elements driving their business, which are very focused in the UK. We don't have someone who's paying our bills. We have to earn our revenues by various ways of licensing and advertising."

There's plenty of experience and ingenuity lurking in Bush House, but the hard part will be learning how to extract it and exploit it. Westcott hopes he understands how the World Service can promote its distinctive assets.

"Until recently, what we did was make radio programmes," he says. "We can't just take the content from those radio programmes and put it online, it has to be refashioned specifically for that medium. You have to find ways of leveraging the assets of the organisation, its brand and its reputation, across all of the outputs."

The biggest task has been persuading the stately monolith of the BBC to grasp the necessity for change. "The BBC's last new medium was when television arrived at Alexandra Palace in 1947, so the organisation had forgotten how to change. We've got a very large job to explain to people why the future is not going to be the same as the present, and why something they have done successfully for a long time is no longer going to cut it. But I think it's remarkable that we've dealt with it so well, given all the brickbats you see in the press about how the BBC is supposed to be stuck in the 1940s."

The new challenge is to avoid being stuck in the 1990s.

fields.headline: The supplier
fields.trailText:
Paul Woolwich

Director of Twenty Twenty Television, is a former deputy editor of Panorama, editor of Here and Now and executive producer of Channel 5's What's the Story?
fields.body:
Paul Woolwich
Director of Twenty Twenty Television, is a former deputy editor of Panorama, editor of Here and Now and executive producer of Channel 5's What's the Story?

Twenty five years ago, young Turks embarking on a TV career wanted to work in the BBC's current affairs department with the aim of changing the world. Today they would rather be working on Changing Rooms. Current affairs is perceived, often unfairly, as complacent, dated, worthy, dull and uninspired. Much of the output is in the finest traditions of public service broadcasting. But it's still the bastion of Birtism and as such terrified of the word "populist" because it smacks of the worst excesses of the red tops.

Whoever takes over the beleaguered BBC News (the "current affairs" part of the title disappeared years ago) department has a colossal task to restore morale, attract new talent, find new audiences and convince controllers that its output deserves a place in the schedule for reasons other than divine right. But a start could be made by bolstering what's already there.

Inject more money into Panorama immediately. It's scandalous that the BBC's journalistic flagship has had its budget cut year on year: average programme budgets, after deducting overheads, now stand around £40,000 - a pathetic figure compared to other current affairs strands. You can't deliver original journalism for peanuts, and arguably Channel 4's Dispatches is hitting the target more consistently than its White City rival. It's certainly making more headlines.

Don't touch Correspondent, there's nothing else like it on British television, but it needs more funding. Cancel the Money Programme: it no longer serves any useful purpose now that business is covered in a more up-to-date fashion elsewhere in BBC News output. Stop being so snooty about MacIntyre Undercover - exciting, must-watch television - and learn from the fresh way in which it handled stories. Re-invent a populist news magazine à la Here and Now for BBC1. Even up against Coronation Street the show was nudging the 5m mark, and it attracted more young people than any other BBC current affairs series. So why leave a whole area of reportage to Tonight with Trevor McDonald which averages 5m after 10pm and could do with some stiff competition?

In the words of Winston Churchill, BBC current affairs "wants the ocean without its mighty roar". What it needs is to be brave, bold and to make more waves. It also needs someone with a bit of passion at the helm. Then perhaps the ambitious young Turks will be more inclined to help give current affairs a makeover.

fields.headline: Why Ulster got spiked
fields.standfirst: Three men were killed in a British city by British soldiers. It should have been huge, but it hardly got covered at all.  Kevin Toolis  on how the media failed the Troubles
fields.trailText: It could have been that scene from the Hollywood movie where the alert passing cop stumbles upon the nervous getaway driver loitering outside the bank. You know what happens next. The cop holds his gun out and shouts: "Police, freeze, get out of the car."
fields.body:
It could have been that scene from the Hollywood movie where the alert passing cop stumbles upon the nervous getaway driver loitering outside the bank. You know what happens next. The cop holds his gun out and shouts: "Police, freeze, get out of the car."

Except this was Belfast in 1990 and what happened next was a bit more deadly. Without giving any warning, a soldier from the 14th Intelligence Company stuck his 9mm Browning through the open driver's window and blew the suspect's head off; firing eight rounds at near point-blank range. (The driver, it turned out, was unarmed.)

Hearing shots, the driver's fellow robbers rushed out the front door of the bookie shop in the Falls Road that they were in the process of robbing and were promptly shot dead. Both men were wearing balaclavas and carrying highly realistic imitation weapons - a fact of which their killer was almost certainly aware. One robber was finished off, SAS-style, with a few rounds to the head as he lay helpless on the pavement. A fourth member of the gang survived by hiding among the bookie shop customers.

A couple of days later, the Northern Ireland secretary of state Peter Brooke stood up in parliament and said the passing soldiers had chanced upon what they thought was an armed IRA terrorist gang when the robbers wearing their balaclavas jumped out of the getaway car and ran into the bookie shop. They had no option but to engage the gunmen.

It was an important story. Three men, Eddie Hale, John McNeill and Peter Thompson, were dead, killed in a British city by British soldiers. But Ulster was a turn-off, boring, no one cared. There was little sympathy on Fleet Street for a group of foolish west Belfast petty criminals who styled themselves "the hole-in-the-wall gang" and who had crossed paths with an elite British special forces unit. No one on the newsdesk was going to waste money sending someone over for a dead story about dead terrorists.

But then that was nothing new. I had heard that same mantra during my entire reporting career, which began in Belfast in 1983. There were always a dozen reasons why it was never the right moment to go over and do that awkward story. Ireland was dull, dull, dull. No one wanted to know.

Both at the time and in retrospect it was an astonishing response. Ireland's Troubles lasted for nearly 30 years. It was and is the longest-running domestic news story. It brought murder and mayhem onto the streets of the capital city - London - and cost 3,500 lives. A government-sanctioned hit squad on the streets of a British city was not an eight-par page-five filler. It should have been huge, but in fact it hardly got covered at all.

On the other hand it's not so surprising. The Troubles may have taken place in what is legally an integral part of the United Kingdom, yet the reporting record there of British journalism, with very few exceptions, is entirely disgraceful. US television and the press may have stopped the war in Vietnam, but the reverse is true in Ulster where the abdication of journalistic integrity allowed the war to go on unhindered by a free press. As Ireland's Troubles recede into memory it's worth asking why it all went wrong.

If one of the roles of journalism is to inform the public, then 30 years of British journalism in Ulster singularly failed to do so. This failure was most pointedly evident in the reporting of the IRA, the key protagonist. For decades British newspapers, and particularly the Sunday Times and the Daily Mail, parroted the black propaganda myth - originally promoted by the British army - that the IRA were "criminal godfathers", "psychopaths" and bloodthirsty killers. There was little analysis of the political structure of the IRA, its organisation, or the nature of its support base. But then of course psychopaths, ipso facto, cannot be organised. Nor was there any sustained attempt by British reporters to go and ask IRA men why they had joined up. There were notable exceptions, the Guardian's David Beresford and David McKittrick of the Independent disproving the general rule. Of course many of those others who did try would often find that their copy never managed to make it into the paper back home.

By the time I joined the Ulster trail in 1983, the tabloid press had almost entirely abandoned Ulster as a news outpost, leaving just the broadsheets to reluctantly carry copy on our Irish province. The Troubles were reported, most prominently on the BBC, in a piecemeal staccato fashion - one killing at a time with no attempt at dangerous analysis. Everyone in the state bureaucracy of the BBC remembered the row with home secretary Leon Brittan over the controversial documentary programme At the Edge of the Union, which showed Martin McGuinness being nice to his kids. News reports kept to two favourite cliché scripts "tit-for-tat" and "pleas for no retaliation". It made it all sound like a boring but deadly unintelligible board game.

It is said that journalists read everything and believe nothing, but somehow Ulster turned it around. Fleet Street collectively read nothing but then believed everything it was told by government. But when peace broke out, Fleet Street was floundering. Instead of being at the forefront of the story they were miles behind. The revelations that the British government had been secretly negotiating with IRA terrorists for nearly a decade came as a total shock. It is clear that the rapidity of the peace process and the apparent professionalism of the Sinn Fein/ IRA political machine had taken most senior British newspaper executives by surprise. And we are still in the odd situation where both right- and leftwing leader writers are left trailing behind the government's radical agenda on Ireland.

Not every newspaper executive was a government dupe, and someone did send me to Ulster for the "hole-in-the-wall gang" story. No Fleet Street news editor, and certainly no one from the BBC, had questioned Brooke's account or the remarkable coincidences that gave it coherence. Wasn't it odd that the soldiers just happened to be passing when the robbers jumped out of their car? And was it not a bit strange that the robbers would wear their balaclavas running into the bookie shop rather than just pulling them over their heads as they entered the narrow shop doorway?

It did not take much reporting skill - I interviewed the fourth gang member - to find the holes in the official account. Far from being a chance encounter, the gang had been under surveillance by squads of 14th Intelligence Company members as they retrieved their imitation weapons from a hide. Those weapons had almost certainly been "jarked" - bugged and examined - and discovered to be imitation by the undercover soldiers. The gang had been followed to the bookie shop and then ambushed, possibly in the belief that they were IRA men.

Put more simply, the men were killed on the orders of a military command system whose rules of engagement were determined directly by the government. Although we will never find the piece of paper with the words written down, the order ran something like this: "Known or suspected IRA terrorists caught near illegal weapon dumps, or in the act of committing a criminal offence can be summarily executed." And it was an order that was enacted time and time again in Ireland.

In controversial circumstances an inquest jury in 1997 concluded that the men had been killed lawfully.

As in many "shoot to kill" operations in Northern Ireland, the Director of Public Prosecutions concluded that the soldiers should not be prosecuted.

A lot of people might say IRA terrorists, and the petty criminals in the hole-in-the-wall gang, deserved to die. Perhaps they did. But it is usual in democratic societies to have a bit of a debate before we grant the government the right to organise extra-judicial killings with impunity. But there was never that kind of debate in Britain because no one ever told the British people what was going on.

For all the blather by generations of British news editors that Northern Ireland was boring, this obscure example from the Troubles illustrates the obverse: that for the British State the war in Ireland was far too important to allow a democratic press to question the actions of its assassination squads. And so over time it conscripted, cajoled and co-opted the press into seeing the world from pretty much the same viewpoint as the government.

The failure of British journalism in Ulster is one lesson from the Troubles that we should not forget.

 A new edition of Kevin Toolis's book on the IRA, Rebel Hearts: Journeys Within the IRA's Soul, is published by Picador, price £7.99.

There was little sympathy on Fleet Street for a group of foolish west Belfast petty criminals who styled themselves "the hole-in-the-wall gang" and who had crossed paths with an elite British special forces unit. No one on the newsdesk was going to waste money sending someone over for a dead story about dead terrorists. But then that was nothing new. I had heard that same mantra during my entire reporting career, which began in Belfast in 1983. There were always a dozen reasons why it was never the right moment to go over and do that awkward story. Ireland was dull, dull, dull. No one wanted to know. Both at the time and in retrospect it was an astonishing response. Ireland's Troubles lasted for nearly 30 years. It was and is the longest-running domestic news story. It brought murder and mayhem onto the streets of the capital city - London - and cost 3,500 lives. A government-sanctioned hit squad on the streets of a British city was not an eight-par page-five filler. It should have been huge, but in fact it hardly got covered at all. On the other hand it's not so surprising. The Troubles may have taken place in what is legally an integral part of the United Kingdom, yet the reporting record there of British journalism, with very few exceptions, is entirely disgraceful. US television and the press may have stopped the war in Vietnam, but the reverse is true in Ulster where the abdication of journalistic integrity allowed the war to go on unhindered by a free press. As Ireland's Troubles recede into memory it's worth asking why it all went wrong. If one of the roles of journalism is to inform the public, then 30 years of British journalism in Ulster singularly failed to do so. This failure was most pointedly evident in the reporting of the IRA, the key protagonist. For decades British newspapers, and particularly the Sunday Times and the Daily Mail, parroted the black propaganda myth - originally promoted by the British army - that the IRA were "criminal godfathers", "psychopaths" and bloodthirsty killers. There was little analysis of the political structure of the IRA, its organisation, or the nature of its support base. But then of course psychopaths, ipso facto, cannot be organised. Nor was there any sustained attempt by British reporters to go and ask IRA men why they had joined up. There were notable exceptions, the Guardian's David Beresford and David McKittrick of the Independent disproving the general rule. Of course many of those others who did try would often find that their copy never managed to make it into the paper back home. By the time I joined the Ulster trail in 1983, the tabloid press had almost entirely abandoned Ulster as a news outpost, leaving just the broadsheets to reluctantly carry copy on our Irish province. The Troubles were reported, most prominently on the BBC, in a piecemeal staccato fashion - one killing at a time with no attempt at dangerous analysis. Everyone in the state bureaucracy of the BBC remembered the row with home secretary Leon Brittan over the controversial documentary programme At the Edge of the Union, which showed Martin McGuinness being nice to his kids. News reports kept to two favourite cliché scripts "tit-for-tat" and "pleas for no retaliation". It made it all sound like a boring but deadly unintelligible board game. It is said that journalists read everything and believe nothing, but somehow Ulster turned it around. Fleet Street collectively read nothing but then believed everything it was told by government. But when peace broke out, Fleet Street was floundering. Instead of being at the forefront of the story they were miles behind. The revelations that the British government had been secretly negotiating with IRA terrorists for nearly a decade came as a total shock. It is clear that the rapidity of the peace process and the apparent professionalism of the Sinn Fein/ IRA political machine had taken most senior British newspaper executives by surprise. And we are still in the odd situation where both right- and leftwing leader writers are left trailing behind the government's radical agenda on Ireland. Not every newspaper executive was a government dupe, and someone did send me to Ulster for the "hole-in-the-wall gang" story. No Fleet Street news editor, and certainly no one from the BBC, had questioned Brooke's account or the remarkable coincidences that gave it coherence. Wasn't it odd that the soldiers just happened to be passing when the robbers jumped out of their car? And was it not a bit strange that the robbers would wear their balaclavas running into the bookie shop rather than just pulling them over their heads as they entered the narrow shop doorway? It did not take much reporting skill - I interviewed the fourth gang member - to find the holes in the official account. Far from being a chance encounter, the gang had been under surveillance by squads of 14th Intelligence Company members as they retrieved their imitation weapons from a hide. Those weapons had almost certainly been "jarked" - bugged and examined - and discovered to be imitation by the undercover soldiers. The gang had been followed to the bookie shop and then ambushed, possibly in the belief that they were IRA men. Put more simply, the men were killed on the orders of a military command system whose rules of engagement were determined directly by the government. Although we will never find the piece of paper with the words written down, the order ran something like this: "Known or suspected IRA terrorists caught near illegal weapon dumps, or in the act of committing a criminal offence can be summarily executed." And it was an order that was enacted time and time again in Ireland. In controversial circumstances an inquest jury in 1997 concluded that the men had been killed lawfully. As in many "shoot to kill" operations in Northern Ireland, the Director of Public Prosecutions concluded that the soldiers should not be prosecuted. A lot of people might say IRA terrorists, and the petty criminals in the hole-in-the-wall gang, deserved to die. Perhaps they did. But it is usual in democratic societies to have a bit of a debate before we grant the government the right to organise extra-judicial killings with impunity. But there was never that kind of debate in Britain because no one ever told the British people what was going on. For all the blather by generations of British news editors that Northern Ireland was boring, this obscure example from the Troubles illustrates the obverse: that for the British State the war in Ireland was far too important to allow a democratic press to question the actions of its assassination squads. And so over time it conscripted, cajoled and co-opted the press into seeing the world from pretty much the same viewpoint as the government. The failure of British journalism in Ulster is one lesson from the Troubles that we should not forget.  A new edition of Kevin Toolis's book on the IRA, Rebel Hearts: Journeys Within the IRA's Soul, is published by Picador, price £7.99.

fields.headline: The former boss
fields.trailText:
Samir Shah
Managing director of Juniper Television and a former head of BBC TV current affairs
fields.body:
Samir Shah
Managing director of Juniper Television and a former head of BBC TV current affairs

I have had a number of breakfasts recently - many of the candidates for the job of running BBC current affairs have been bending my ear over croissants and cappuccino. There's something surprising about this. Usually the person for such a senior job at the Beeb has already been identified. Of course, fairness and equal opportunities means that it all still has to go through the proper process, but most people know there is - as the euphemism has it - someone who is the "candidate to beat".

This time, it feels different. It seems to be an open field. It reflects a genuine desire to find someone with a vision for current affairs, this most awkward of departments.

It's a far cry from the days when I first arrived in television current affairs at the BBC. The awkward squad of broadcasting were housed in Lime Grove, a street on the wrong side of the tracks. Michael Grade, on a visit, called it a "slum" and thought it should be demolished. But we rather liked it. It did have one over-riding quality that made up for everything else: a sense of purpose. We felt what we did mattered. As one editor - now a very senior figure in the industry - said to me: "You know, between you and me, we could bring down the BBC!" He was joking, just. The top brass - from the DG down - kept a weather eye on us. It might have been pretty stormy at times, but we felt alive.

Do the people now ensconced in what is known not so affectionately as Ceaucescu Towers still feel they matter? They should do. The new director-general, Greg Dyke, like the old one, is a current affairs man. He is not one for the dull and worthy.

As television channels proliferate, BBC1 and BBC2 have had to develop hard-nosed scheduling strategies to compete. Now each and every current affairs programme has to punch its weight in the schedules. There are no hiding places in the schedules any more.

The result appears to be a low-intensity war of attrition. Unlike other factual areas in broadcasting, current affairs cannot offer up a diet of prostitution, sex and children-in-peril stories and opt out of reporting Northern Ireland or South Africa or yet another crisis in the Balkans.

The answers inevitably lie in creating the space for the people that really matter, the programme-makers, to rise to the challenge. The agenda itself may be constrained in scope, but the ways to tell these stories should be as wide and expansive as their collective imagination allows - programmes that range from passionate authored pieces to surprising and unexpected angles on the familiar. And, of course, always the odd programme that threatens to bring down the BBC.

Current affairs is one of the thoroughbreds in the broadcasting stable. And must remain a significant and important part of the mix of programmes in the schedules of a public service broadcaster. From my experience, the new head of the BBC's department will find it is full of people who need the bridle rather than the spur. It's time to cut them loose.

webTitle: Time to put affairs in order

fields.headline: Time to put affairs in order
fields.standfirst: The top job at BBC current affairs is up for grabs. But with Panorama dying on its feet and the Money Programme ready to be retired, who really wants it?  Matt Wells  reports
fields.trailText: When the Sun gets interested in the tribulations of BBC news and current affairs, you know things are serious. "Down the pan-orama!" screamed a memorable headline recently, crowing over the dismal viewing figures of the flagship current affairs programme. Ratings are at an all-time low, the show is failing to make nearly as many waves as it used to, and the current affairs department as a whole is suffering from a lack of fire. Even Newsnight's Rottweiler, Jeremy Paxman, has been rumoured to be facing the muzzle. While high-minded BBC staff may mock, the most-watched current affairs programme on television at the moment is ITV's Tonight With Trevor McDonald.
fields.body:
When the Sun gets interested in the tribulations of BBC news and current affairs, you know things are serious. "Down the pan-orama!" screamed a memorable headline recently, crowing over the dismal viewing figures of the flagship current affairs programme. Ratings are at an all-time low, the show is failing to make nearly as many waves as it used to, and the current affairs department as a whole is suffering from a lack of fire. Even Newsnight's Rottweiler, Jeremy Paxman, has been rumoured to be facing the muzzle. While high-minded BBC staff may mock, the most-watched current affairs programme on television at the moment is ITV's Tonight With Trevor McDonald.

It is not a comfortable situation for the department, which is even more rattled by the fact that the biggest BBC current affairs success recently has been the big-budget investigative show MacIntyre Undercover - made by the corporation's documentaries section. With the position of head of current affairs vacant following the departure of Helen Boaden to the controller's job at Radio 4 and further upheaval coming to news with the merger of the breakfast programmes on News 24 and BBC1, speculation is rife about what will follow the Birtist "mission to explain". One thing is certain: the BBC is certainly not going to go higher brow.

Under John Birt, news and current affairs were split into two distinct departments. But the new regime is said to recognise that the best current affairs is news reactive, so the two departments are now very much part of the same news family, and the new head of current affairs will be expected to work even closer with the news chiefs.

The first task facing the appointee - the BBC is close to making an announcement and the aim is to have someone in place by the end of next month - will be what to do with Panorama. That the flagship analysis programme is in dire straits is not denied - the show recorded a dismal 1.9m viewers recently, scoring a 10% audience share: equal to its worst-ever showing. The BBC may insist that it is the only mass broadcaster committed to long-length current affairs (it recently gave a £300,000 cash boost to the show's annual budget, which sounds good until you learn that MacIntyre swallows that in one episode), but there are many who believe that the genre itself is a thing of the past.

Dabbling with Panorama is a daunting task for even the most courageous of executives. It is the longest-running show of its kind in British television, and despite its scandalously low budget it is still regarded as the pride of the BBC current affairs fleet. Any moves to tinker with it will be regarded with great suspicion both inside and outside the corporation.

Everyone knows that something must be done - one senior journalist on the show remarked recently that it could be dead in five years - but no-one really knows what to do with it. Clearly it needs more cash, and a greater degree of focus. There has been speculation that it could be moved to BBC2, but if anything that would serve only to hasten its demise.

Yet there is clearly an appetite among the British viewing public for current affairs. MacIntyre - the one-man investigative show fronted by Donal MacIntyre - pulled in viewers by the bucketload; ITV's Tonight show is averaging 5m. It is not all that long ago that Panorama could clock up 8m with an agenda-setting story; even Channel 5 takes popular current affairs seriously.

The trick is how to do it. By axing World in Action, ITV demonstrated that it believed that the days of the regular, long-length single-story current affairs shows were numbered. But the commercial channel was by no means the first to recognise that the current affairs shibboleths had to be chal lenged. In many senses, Tonight with Trevor McDonald is the bastard son of Here and Now with Sue Lawley: a BBC creation that was derided at the time but whose demise is now seen as premature. Here and Now got better audiences than Tonight archives, even though it was scheduled in the graveyard slot against Coronation Street. To get 5m for current affairs against the might of the Street should have been regarded as a triumph, yet the snooty BBC elite never gave Here and Now the chance to succeed. It was doomed from the day it was conceived, and like so many BBC ideas, was taken up by ITV and done twice as well. Now the BBC has to play catch-up.

Whoever takes over from Boaden, it is certain that the axe is to fall on that relic of high Birtism, the Money Programme. During the purest period of the ancien regime, the show was seen as the epitome of high-minded, serious journalism. Unfortunately it was often impenetrable and always dull. It fell between two stools - attempting to speak both to the busi ness elite in the City and Sierra man with a couple of utility shares, and inevitably failing on both scores.

Jane Root, the controller of BBC2, has decided this failure can no longer be tolerated. The show will undergo a complete revamp - it may retain its name, which is a strong brand - but will become far more accessible. The transformation will inevitably lead to accusations once again that the BBC is dumbing down, but executives insist that it is perfectly possible to combine intelligence with accessibility.

The shake-up, however, is not just confined to current affairs. News programmes on television got a major make-over last year, with the changes made to the 6pm news the most radical. Next in the firing line are the early morning programmes: Roger Mosey, the head of television news, confirmed last week that the BBC is to launch a new breakfast news show to be broadcast simultaneously on BBC1 and BBC News 24. The move will save £1.5m. A few dozen staff will be axed, but the principal saving is derived simply from producing three hours of programmes instead of six. Work is already under way on developing the new programme, which will be launched in the autumn.

Mosey says news, as well as current affairs, is waking up to the reality of the competitive world. "You can't just say 'sod the audience'. On the 6pm news, we have changed the language a lot, and developed a family of correspondents with whom the viewers have grown familiar. We are also covering a much broader agenda. The idea that there will always be a big political story on every news bulletin is something that's in the past now. People are interested in a far broader range of issues - entrepreneurship, environment, health. It is a recognition that in 2000 we have a different set of priorities. People really don't like sterile, yah-boo politics."

There is nothing wrong with this, says Mosey. "We are proud of being competitive. ITV has completely retreated from prime-time news: we are now dominating the six to seven news hour, and the Nine is the only mid-evening news programme. There is a market for what we are doing as well as the public service argument and we should be more confident about it - even more so about News 24. I just feel that News 24 is something we are very proud of, time after time we are beating Sky News journalistically."

Clearly, BBC news and current affairs has the creative resources to beat the pants off the opposition. At the moment, though, it is the clothing of the BBC, and not of its commercial competitors, which appears threadbare.

webTitle: Forget the party activists. They make no difference

fields.headline: Forget the party activists. They make no difference
fields.standfirst: Canvassers don't knock on doors any more. Just as well
fields.trailText: Who, as your letter box rattles again, are you voting for next month? The Home-Delivered Pizza Party? The Thai TakeAway Party? The Tree-Lopping Alliance? If canvassing counts for anything, they're the only ones worth bothering about.
fields.body:
Who, as your letter box rattles again, are you voting for next month? The Home-Delivered Pizza Party? The Thai TakeAway Party? The Tree-Lopping Alliance? If canvassing counts for anything, they're the only ones worth bothering about.

I live in a traditionally marginal constituency four miles from Westminster - and I'm also, this time round, that prize beyond price: a real floater. A might-go-for-Shagger man because I can't forget the way Ken baited Mrs T and unravelled a London government that worked.

It would be nice, for once, to talk it through with one of those "committed activists" Mr Blair is so worried about. But only the Tarmac Your Drive for Cash in Hand Party comes to call. And that, on reflection, is nothing new. The annual rituals of participative democracy these days habitually pass without doorstep presence or intervention. The spear carriers of allegiance have gone off for a chicken tikka and stayed for the bhuna prawn.

Does that matter? Gordon Brown, preparing to remember the pensioners at last, seems to think so. Stephen Byers, preparing to spread paid paternity leaves among the populace, agrees. The fact that Tory membership is going down to first world war levels is (more) dire news for William Hague. The fact that scores of Labour constituency parties can't be bothered to send delegates to conference this year sends shudders through Millbank.

Heartland 2000 has taken a bypass - and we're continually invited to feel either shame or alarm at such declining involvement. Mr Hague has to go round stirring up something besides apathy, which is unlucky if you're seeking asylum. Tony Blair has cold sweats over Dagenham. They can both feel a big election coming on. They've both got the wind up.

The question nobody asks is how much any of this matters? The one awful truth that party machines never contemplate is the essentially peripheral role of their card-carrying foot soldiers.

Been there: seen that. I spent a couple of happy years long ago as the Guardian s byelection reporter. There's nothing like getting close to the grassroots to help you spot the weeds. Desultory meetings in draughty school halls. Mindless handshaking at dank shopping centres. The unique futility of long canvassing nights.

People - people like you and me, torn from our TV suppers - are such liars. We'll say anything to get rid of the chap on the doorstep. I'd go down a road with Labour one day then come back 24 hours later and lurk with the Tories, then compare notes. It was a dismaying exercise, instructive only for its amazing discrepancies. The great David Butler was right again.

Butler of Nuffield, it may be remembered, was the founding father of British psephology, the researcher who replaced political folklore with hard analysis. Thirty-five years ago he could find only the "possibility" of some "slight effect" for all the alleged effort the two major parties poured into canvassing. The conversion factor itself was negligible. The impact, if any, consisted of reminding identified core reporters that there was a vote on, then digging them out when the crunch came.

Useful? Yes, then and now, for the Liberals, who benefit hugely when voters are reminded they exist. But otherwise utility applies in only a very few close races - a factor marginally more useful than supposed "personal" votes - in a Britain where a clear majority of voters don't know the name of their sitting MP. But most of the toil through the early Butler years - the golden age of participation, with a million devotees out on the streets -was redundant or irrelevant. The last-minute activists would have been better employed moving deck chairs on the Titanic.

That is not, of course, what politicians tell their troops - or themselves. If you're a leader, you have to have somebody to lead. If you're a disciple, you have to believe that the toil you put in makes a difference. Maintaining the illusion of self-importance is mutually necessary. Yet one illusion leads to another.

William Hague, for example, thought he could build a mass party by redefining "core" Conservative values and making them available for a £15 entry fee. Membership, we now see, has gone down. The £15 bit has been quietly dropped. Money matters to the Tories, but the kind of money that matters most is one of those plump personal cheques signed by Lord Ashcroft of Belize. Groundling faith in core values doesn't run to a price tag.

Tony Blair, equally, had a vision: that he could rescue the Labour party from decades of despond by recruiting hundreds of thousands of new, empowered members (who would put the members he had in their place). That worked for a while because there was an aim (regaining power): but it was always going to fade again once the immediate purpose was gone.

So other illusions take hold. One - the Hague illusion - is that making a pitch to your elderly activists can be the foundation of success. If they're motivated to vote, then you can make some gains in Euro or local elections where turnouts are derisory. More from less - which means, in logic, that the feebler central office gets, the greater the prospect of triumph becomes.

And the Blair illusion runs in parallel. Because anxious MPs return to Westminster complaining about disaffected ward meetings and shortages of workers on the ground, the rush is suddenly on to give them something to cheer about.

It's a peculiar mid-term pottiness. Ken Livingstone will be elected mayor of London in a couple of weeks without anything you could call a machine behind him. His elevation is the ultimate destruction of the machine mentality. And yet the reaction of the humiliated machines is to exalt their own roles. Heaven knows what Hague's old bosses at McKinsey's would make of that.

Of course the general election will be different: general elections are different. They don't, however, make the activists any more important; they merely add broader motivation against a background of broadcasting frenzy.

If Mr Blair has an enemy there, it's the assumption that he's won already, that William Hague is a no-hoper. But this is a self-solving problem. Either Hague looks unexpectedly strong - in which case many suburban stumps will be automatically stirred - or no hope rules and victory follows in any case.

Governments do best when they get on with governing. Prime ministers look best when they're not in a flap about their own illusions. If Mr Blair really wants to fire the grassroots, he should concentrate on losing a lot of seats and making parliament a more exciting place to be. But that, I guess, is not the object of this exercise - and meanwhile the sole dish of the week, knocking on my door, is Hawaiian Deep Dish pizza with a free bottle of Coke.

peter.preston@theguardian.com
fields.bodyText: Who, as your letter box rattles again, are you voting for next month? The Home-Delivered Pizza Party? The Thai TakeAway Party? The Tree-Lopping Alliance? If canvassing counts for anything, they're the only ones worth bothering about. I live in a traditionally marginal constituency four miles from Westminster - and I'm also, this time round, that prize beyond price: a real floater. A might-go-for-Shagger man because I can't forget the way Ken baited Mrs T and unravelled a London government that worked. It would be nice, for once, to talk it through with one of those "committed activists" Mr Blair is so worried about. But only the Tarmac Your Drive for Cash in Hand Party comes to call. And that, on reflection, is nothing new. The annual rituals of participative democracy these days habitually pass without doorstep presence or intervention. The spear carriers of allegiance have gone off for a chicken tikka and stayed for the bhuna prawn. Does that matter? Gordon Brown, preparing to remember the pensioners at last, seems to think so. Stephen Byers, preparing to spread paid paternity leaves among the populace, agrees. The fact that Tory membership is going down to first world war levels is (more) dire news for William Hague. The fact that scores of Labour constituency parties can't be bothered to send delegates to conference this year sends shudders through Millbank. Heartland 2000 has taken a bypass - and we're continually invited to feel either shame or alarm at such declining involvement. Mr Hague has to go round stirring up something besides apathy, which is unlucky if you're seeking asylum. Tony Blair has cold sweats over Dagenham. They can both feel a big election coming on. They've both got the wind up. The question nobody asks is how much any of this matters? The one awful truth that party machines never contemplate is the essentially peripheral role of their card-carrying foot soldiers. Been there: seen that. I spent a couple of happy years long ago as the Guardian s byelection reporter. There's nothing like getting close to the grassroots to help you spot the weeds. Desultory meetings in draughty school halls. Mindless handshaking at dank shopping centres. The unique futility of long canvassing nights. People - people like you and me, torn from our TV suppers - are such liars. We'll say anything to get rid of the chap on the doorstep. I'd go down a road with Labour one day then come back 24 hours later and lurk with the Tories, then compare notes. It was a dismaying exercise, instructive only for its amazing discrepancies. The great David Butler was right again. Butler of Nuffield, it may be remembered, was the founding father of British psephology, the researcher who replaced political folklore with hard analysis. Thirty-five years ago he could find only the "possibility" of some "slight effect" for all the alleged effort the two major parties poured into canvassing. The conversion factor itself was negligible. The impact, if any, consisted of reminding identified core reporters that there was a vote on, then digging them out when the crunch came. Useful? Yes, then and now, for the Liberals, who benefit hugely when voters are reminded they exist. But otherwise utility applies in only a very few close races - a factor marginally more useful than supposed "personal" votes - in a Britain where a clear majority of voters don't know the name of their sitting MP. But most of the toil through the early Butler years - the golden age of participation, with a million devotees out on the streets -was redundant or irrelevant. The last-minute activists would have been better employed moving deck chairs on the Titanic. That is not, of course, what politicians tell their troops - or themselves. If you're a leader, you have to have somebody to lead. If you're a disciple, you have to believe that the toil you put in makes a difference. Maintaining the illusion of self-importance is mutually necessary. Yet one illusion leads to another. William Hague, for example, thought he could build a mass party by redefining "core" Conservative values and making them available for a £15 entry fee. Membership, we now see, has gone down. The £15 bit has been quietly dropped. Money matters to the Tories, but the kind of money that matters most is one of those plump personal cheques signed by Lord Ashcroft of Belize. Groundling faith in core values doesn't run to a price tag. Tony Blair, equally, had a vision: that he could rescue the Labour party from decades of despond by recruiting hundreds of thousands of new, empowered members (who would put the members he had in their place). That worked for a while because there was an aim (regaining power): but it was always going to fade again once the immediate purpose was gone. So other illusions take hold. One - the Hague illusion - is that making a pitch to your elderly activists can be the foundation of success. If they're motivated to vote, then you can make some gains in Euro or local elections where turnouts are derisory. More from less - which means, in logic, that the feebler central office gets, the greater the prospect of triumph becomes. And the Blair illusion runs in parallel. Because anxious MPs return to Westminster complaining about disaffected ward meetings and shortages of workers on the ground, the rush is suddenly on to give them something to cheer about. It's a peculiar mid-term pottiness. Ken Livingstone will be elected mayor of London in a couple of weeks without anything you could call a machine behind him. His elevation is the ultimate destruction of the machine mentality. And yet the reaction of the humiliated machines is to exalt their own roles. Heaven knows what Hague's old bosses at McKinsey's would make of that. Of course the general election will be different: general elections are different. They don't, however, make the activists any more important; they merely add broader motivation against a background of broadcasting frenzy. If Mr Blair has an enemy there, it's the assumption that he's won already, that William Hague is a no-hoper. But this is a self-solving problem. Either Hague looks unexpectedly strong - in which case many suburban stumps will be automatically stirred - or no hope rules and victory follows in any case. Governments do best when they get on with governing. Prime ministers look best when they're not in a flap about their own illusions. If Mr Blair really wants to fire the grassroots, he should concentrate on losing a lot of seats and making parliament a more exciting place to be. But that, I guess, is not the object of this exercise - and meanwhile the sole dish of the week, knocking on my door, is Hawaiian Deep Dish pizza with a free bottle of Coke. peter.preston@theguardian.com

CABLE AND WIRELESS TRIANGULAR TOURNAMENT
West Indies, Pakistan, Zimbabwe
fields.body:
CABLE AND WIRELESS TRIANGULAR TOURNAMENT
West Indies, Pakistan, Zimbabwe

Kingston, April 1
Toss: Zimbabwe West Indies 237 for 9 in 50 overs (Campbell 103, Adams 60, Jacobs 32)
Zimbabwe 150 in 41.4 overs (Carlisle 37, Goodwin 52)
West Indies won by 87 runs
Sherwin Campbell (MoM, 1st 100 in 72 ODIs)/Jimmy Adams 140 for 3rd wkt. Ridley Jacobs 25 balls. Zimbabwe were 116 for 2. Adams 7-0-19-3, Ricardo Powell 1.4-0-5-2. Zimbabwe fined 2 overs for slow over-rate.

Kingston, April 2
Toss: West Indies West Indies 280 for 3 in 50 overs (Hinds 116*, Adams 41, Gayle 58)
Zimbabwe 239 for 8 in 50 overs (Carlisle 57, Andy Flower 52, King 3-27)
West Indies won by 41 runs
Wavell Hinds (MoM, HS, 125 balls, 12x4, 1x6)/Chris Gayle (45 balls, 5x4, 1x6) 125 for 4th wkt in 14.3 overs. Andy Whittall 6-0-53-0. Curtly Ambrose 10-1-19-1. The 36th over of Zimbabwe's innings lasted seven balls.

Antigua, April 5
Toss: Zimbabwe Zimbabwe 199 for 9 in 50 overs (Grant Flower 36, Carlisle 30, Guy Whittall 31)
Pakistan 200 for 5 in 47.1 overs (Shahid Afridi 69, Inzamam-ul-Haq 32)
Pakistan won by 5 wickets
MoM Shahid Afridi. West Indies qualify for final.

St Vincent, April 12
Toss: West Indies West Indies 213 for 7 in 50 overs (Hinds 39, Adams 50)
Pakistan 117 in 41.3 overs (Inzamam-ul-Haq 51*, Rose 5-23)
West Indies won by 96 runs
Franklyn Rose (10-1-23-5, MoM) BB. Eight Pakistan batsmen out for single-figures. Curtly Ambrose 8-2-12-1.

Grenada, April 15
Toss: Zimbabwe Zimbabwe 204 for 7 in 50 overs (Johnson 43, Wishart 45, Goodwin 35, Andy Flower 31, Arshad Khan 3-45)
Pakistan 205 for 4 in 43.1 overs (Imran Nazir 105*, Inzamam-ul-Haq 34, Moin Khan 35*)
Pakistan won by 6 wickets
Pakistan qualify for the final. Imran Nazir (MoM) 10x4, 2x6. Moin Khan 36 balls, 5x4, 1x6. Zimbabwe innings 1x7-ball over (the 26th, bowled by Mushtaq Ahmed)

Grenada, April 16
Toss: West Indies West Indies 248 for 6 in 50 overs (Campbell 56, Gayle 42, Powell 50*)
Pakistan 231 in 48.1 overs (Inzamam-ul-Haq 69, Yousuf Youhana 56, King 3-38)
West Indies won by 17 runs
MoM Ricardo Powell (36 balls, 1x4, 2x6). Inzamam-ul-Haq/Yousuf Youhana 123 for the 4th wkt. Pakistan fined one over for slow over-rate

1ST FINAL, Bridgetown, April 19
Toss: Pakistan Pakistan 197 for 8 in 50 overs (Inzamam-ul-Haq 66, Wasim Akram 42
West Indies 180 all out in 49.3 overs (Wallace 47, Hinds 35, Shahid Afridi 3-16)
Pakistan won by 17 runs
Inzamam-ul-Haq 7000 runs in one-day cricket. Wasim Akram (MoM) and Mushtaq Ahmed (11*) put on 53* for 9th wicket. West Indies were 99 for 1, then lost 5 wickets for 24 runs. Shahid Afridi 3.3-0-16-3.

2ND FINAL, Port-of-Spain, April 22
Toss: West Indies West Indies 208 for 8 in 50 overs (Campbell 77, Gayle 33, Wasim Akram 3-34)
Pakistan 148 all out in 45 overs (Younis Khan 31, Adams 3-21)
West Indies won by 60 runs
West Indies 25 runs from first 10 overs, then Sherwin Campbell (MoM) 127 balls, 4x6. Pakistan were 72 for 1. Jimmy Adams 10-0-21-3.

3RD FINAL, Port-of-Spain, April 23
Toss: West Indies West Indies 114 all out in 33.2 overs (Wallace 30, Mushtaq Ahmed 4-22)
Pakistan 116 for 6 in 45.1 overs (Inzamam-ul-Haq 39*, King 4-25)
Pakistan won by 4 wickets
West Indies were 61-0, then lost 5 wickets for 10 runs in 6 overs. Mushtaq Ahmed (MoM) 3 wickets in 5 balls. Pakistan were 73 for 5. Inzamam-ul-Haq: 98 balls, 5x4 saw them home. Pakistan won final 2-1.

Toss: South Africa Australia 240 for 9 in 50 overs (Gilchrist 51, Bevan 31, Martyn 74, Ntini 4-56)

South Africa won by 6 wickets

Australia 145 for 5 in 24.3 overs (Martyn 50, Bevan 39, Kallis 3-40)
Australia won by 5 wickets
Glenn McGrath 10-1-13-2. Adam Gilchrist held an ODI record 6 catches. Australia were 21 for 3, then Damien Martyn (MoM) 32 balls, 10x4.

Johannesburg, April 16
Toss: South Africa Australia 205 in 49.5 overs (Bevan 33, Steve Waugh 51, Harvey 38, Warne 32, Pollock 4-37)
South Africa 209 for 6 in 47.5 overs (Hall 46, Kallis 30, Boucher 55*, Klusener 52*, Brett Lee 3-32)
South Africa won by 6 wickets
South Africa won series 2-1. SA 91 for 2, then 91 for 5. But Mark Boucher (89 balls, 7x4)/Lance Klusener (MoM, MoS, 50 balls, 9x4) 87* for the 7th wkt.

COCA-COLA CUP, SHARJAH
India, Pakistan, South Africa

March 22

South Africa won by 10 wickets
India 42-1, 102-9, then Ajay Jadeja/Javagal Srinath 62 for 10th wkt. Steve Elworthy (MoM, BB ODIs) 10-3-17-3. Gary Kirsten (85 balls, 9x4)/Herschelle Gibbs (93 balls, 9x4, 3x6) 168* for 1st wkt.

March 23

India 149 for 5 in 43.3 overs (Azharuddin 54)
India won by 5 wickets
Pak were 108 for 3. Mohammad Azharuddin (MoM) 7x4.

South Africa 199 for 7 in 44.3 overs (Kallis 35, McKenzie 31, Boje 35*)
South Africa won by 2 wickets
Imran Nazir/Younis Khan 115 for 2nd wkt. MoM Lance Klusener

March 26
Toss: Pakistan Pakistan 272 for 3 in 50 overs (Younis Khan 44, Inzamam-ul-Haq 121*, Yousuf Youhana 56*)
India 174 for 9 in 50 overs (Waqar Younis 5-31)
Pakistan won by 98 runs
Inzamam-ul-Haq (114 balls, 9x4, 5x6)/Yousuf Youhana (64 balls, 5x4, 1x6) 151 for 4th wkt. Inzamam named joint man of the match with Waqar Younis

March 27
Toss: India
India 164 in 48.5 overs (Tendulkar 39, Azharuddin 36, Hayward 4-31)
South Africa 167 for 4 in 42.4 overs (Kirsten 31, Kallis 53*, Cronje 42*)
South Africa won by 6 wickets
MoM Nantie Hayward (BB). India lost last 5 wkts for 10.

March 28
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 168 in 49.2 overs (Yousuf Youhana 65)
South Africa 101 in 26.5 overs (Gibbs 59*, Shoaib Akhtar 3-9)
Pakistan won by 67 runs
Yousuf Youhana 88 balls, 7x4. Shoaib Akhtar (MoM, 4.5-2-9-3) took three in one over; South Africa 74-1, 75-5. Waqar Younis claimed his 300th ODI wicket (Neil McKenzie lbw 1). Herschelle Gibbs (79 balls, 9x4) carried bat; rest of South African team faced combined total of 84 balls.

FINAL, March 31
Toss: Pakistan
Pakistan 263 for 6 in 50 overs (Imran Nazir 69, Shahid Afridi 52, Inzamam-ul-Haq 53)
South Africa 247 in 49 overs (McKenzie 58, Cronje 79, Boucher 57, Waqar Younis 4-62, Arshad Khan 3-51)
Pakistan won by 16 runs
Pakistan's 2nd win v South Africa in 16 ODIs. Imran Nazir (89 balls, 7x4, 2x6)/Shahid Afridi (48 balls, 5x4, 1x6) 123 for 1st wkt. Neil McKenzie/Hansie Cronje (73 balls, 6x4, 3x6) 105 for 3rd wkt. South Africa 198-4, then 199-7 as Waqar Younis (MoM, MoS) took two wickets with consecutive balls. Mark Boucher 49 balls, 3x4, 3x6. Pakistan won the Sharjah tournament for the 12th time

INDIA v SOUTH AFRICA

March 9, Kochi
Toss: South Africa
South Africa 301 for 3 in 50 overs (Kirsten 115, Gibbs 111, Kallis 37*)
India 302 for 7 in 49.4 overs (Ganguly 31, Azharuddin 42, Jadeja 92, Singh 42*)
India won by 3 wickets
Gary Kirsten (9th ODI 100, 123 balls, 12x4)/Herschelle Gibbs (3rd ODI 100, 127 balls, 11x4, 2x6) 235 for 1st wkt. Jacques Kallis 30 balls. Rahul Dravid 2-43 (previously 19 overs and 1 wkt in 116 ODIs). Ajit Agarkar 7-0-55-0. India were 180 for 5, but Ajay Jadeja (MoM, 109 balls, 8x4, 3x6) 92 for 6th wkt with Robin Singh in 11.5 overs. South Africa 199 in 47.2 overs (Cronje 71, Agarkar 3-34, Joshi 4-38)
India 203 for 4 in 47.1 overs (Ganguly 105*)
India won by 6 wickets
Hansie Cronje 86 balls (7x4, 1x6). Sourav Ganguly (MoM, 12th ODI 100) 139 balls, 10x4, 4x6.

Toss: South Africa
India 248 for 8 in 50 overs (Ganguly 56, Dravid 73, Jadeja 31)

Toss: India

MoM Darren Gough. SA were 23-4. Nasser Hussain (12x4)/Nick Knight (7x4, 1x6) 165 for 1st wkt; SA have never conceded more for the 1st wkt in ODIs. Mark Ealham's 6th over, the 32nd of SA's innings, lasted 5 balls; Nicky Boje's 6th, the 27th of England's innings, lasted 7.

Toss: South Africa

England 203 for 9 in 50 overs (Knight 36, Adams 42)
South Africa won by 1 run
England needed 9 off final over, bowled by Jacques Kallis (MoM), but could manage only 7. Darren Gough moved level with Phil DeFreitas with 115 ODI wickets for England; only Ian Botham (145) lies ahead.

January 28, Cape Town (day/night)
Toss: Zimbabwe
Zimbabwe 211 for 7 in 50 overs (Johnson 97)
England 107 in 34.2 overs (Olonga 6-19)
Zimbabwe won by 104 runs
Johnson (5x4, 1x6) made the highest ODI score at Newlands, and the most for Zimbabwe v England. January 30, Kimberley
Toss: Zimbabwe
Zimbabwe 161 for 9 in 50 overs (Streak 35*, Ealham 5-15)
England 162 for 2 in 32.1 overs (Hussain 64, Knight 72*)
England won by 8 wickets
Mark Ealham (MoM) recorded England's best ODI figures (prev. Vic Marks, 5-20 v New Zealand at Wellington in 1983-84), taking 5 wickets in 23 balls as Zimbabwe crashed from 71-1 to 98-7. He also became the first bowler to claim 5 lbws in an ODI innings. Nasser Hussain (77 balls, 7x4, 2x6)/Nick Knight (8x4) 128 for the 1st wkt - the highest for any England wicket v Zimbabwe. Toss: South Africa
South Africa 222 for 7 in 50 overs (Kallis 52, Klusener 65*)
Zimbabwe 223 for 8 in 50 overs (Johnson 35, Andy Flower 59, Guy Whittall 39, Williams 3-38)

Zimbabwe won with a single off the last ball, having failed to score from the previous two. They were 107-6, but Andy Flower (MoM)/Guy Whittall 91 for 7th wkt. Toss: South Africa
South Africa 204 for 7 in 50 overs (Kallis 98*)
Zimbabwe 151 in 46 overs (Johnson 56, Andy Flower 37, Pollock 3-7)
South Africa won by 53 runs
South Africa qualify for final. Jacques Kallis (MoM) hit last ball of South African innings for 6. Shaun Pollock 8-4-7-3.

February 9, Centurion (day/night)
Zimbabwe v England
Match abandoned without a ball bowled
Both sides took one point and finished level in the group on five. But England qualified for the final on the basis of a superior net run-rate (+0.029 to -0.124).

FINAL, February 13, Johannesburg (day/night)
Toss: England
South Africa 149 in 45 overs (Cronje 56, Boucher 36, Caddick 4-19, Gough 3-18)
England 111 in 38 overs (Pollock 5-20)
South Africa won by 38 runs
SA won the Standard Bank Triangular Tournament after being 21-5. Only one other team has won from a worse position in ODI history (India were 17-5 v Zimbabwe at Tunbridge Wells in the 1975 World Cup). Andy Caddick BB. But Shaun Pollock (MoM and MoS) returned the best figures for SA v England, and Mark Boucher equalled the ODI record of 5 catches.

fields.headline: 'Milosevic is trying to provoke a civil war'
fields.standfirst:
Montenegrin president lashes out at Serbia's covert agenda.

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Calling Slobodan Milosevic "evil" and "the worst leader in Serbia's history", the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, told a crowd of supporters here that Yugoslavia's strong man wanted a civil war in Montenegro.
fields.body:
Calling Slobodan Milosevic "evil" and "the worst leader in Serbia's history", the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, told a crowd of supporters here that Yugoslavia's strong man wanted a civil war in Montenegro.

"He knows he cannot mount direct aggression, so he wants to provoke clashes and have us shooting against each other, but we are trying to prevent that," Mr Djukanovic declared.

It was no coincidence that he chose a rare visit to this town on the border with Serbia for some of his toughest language yet in the three-year dispute between the two partners of the moribund Yugoslav federation. The town of Bijelo Polje is on the frontline in several ways.

While railing against international economic sanctions as unfair, Mr Milosevic recently slapped an embargo on virtually all trade with Montenegro. Bored police officers control a checkpoint just north of the town where the traditionally busy road is now almost empty.

Local shopkeepers complain that they have had to make strenuous and expensive efforts to find new supplies from Bosnia, Croatia or further afield.

The town has also become a potential military flash point since the Yugoslav army started to recruit Montenegrins from the pro-Belgrade Socialist People's Party (SNP) into a new paramilitary force, called the Seventh Battalion, headquartered in Bijelo Polje.

"It's a classic security police model of a paramilitary force," Mr Djukanovic said. "We know SNP activists check volunteers for their party loyalty so that they can have party troops who are not trained to defend the state but to overthrow democracy in Montenegro."

Many of the town's residents, half of whom are Muslim, are quietly slipping away to other places because they fear the force's potential for violence.

Vukoman Medojevic, the SNP chairman in Bijelo Polje, admits that the recruits to the Seventh Battalion come from his party's membership. "That's normal, because they support Yugoslavia and the federal army, while Djukanovic's supporters join the police," he says. "But the officers are not party members. The army belongs to the people."

Nevertheless, economic decline remains the main reason why people leave: employment opportunities have plummeted with the general collapse of the Balkan economies.

A picture of Tito, the wartime partisan leader who held Yugoslavia together for 35 years, hangs in the office of Dzemal Crnovrsanin, 51, the manager of a local supermarket. "People used to ask why I bothered to keep a dead man's portrait, but more of them now tell me they understand," he says.

Mr Crnovrsanin blames Serbia for the embargo. "I hope they realise it's useless. It's hurting them hard too. Countries at war often keep trading. Serbia slapped this embargo on, even when we are not at war. Milosevic and the SNP leader are punishing us because they lost the elections."

Despite the embargo, some of his fresh dairy produce, such as yogurt, has labels from Serbia. He admits that goods are smuggled across the border on back roads by pedestrians, or by bribing the Serb customs. But other products have to be driven round via the Serb-run entity in Bosnia.

The embargo was provoked by the Montenegrin govern ment's decision last autumn to bring in the German mark as a second currency alongside the dinar, Mr Medojevic says."If we are one country, we should have one currency. Now it's chaos."

But most Montenegrins favour the change, saying it has reduced instability. Salaries are usually paid in marks and the Yugoslav dinar has quickly become the currency of last resort; the federal army is the only major institution which pays its salaries and expenses in dinars.

The embargo surprised the Montenegrin government, which thought it could pay for its imports from Serbia with the dinars the army distributes. Now about 10% of the country's revenue is in dinars, which cannot be spent.

"We expected them to stop the clearing system but not the traffic in goods," said Dimitrije Vesovic, director of settlement operations at Montenegro's central bank. "It was the worst scenario, since it goes against their interest. If they have lost Kosovo, we thought it would be too much for them to go on to lose Montenegro as a market."

Despite the obstacles, Mr Djukanovic's officials claim to be optimistic that their gradual drive for independence is gathering strength. The next step will be the local elections in June, when they hope the SNP will lose more support, reducing Mr Milosevic's options still further.

fields.headline: Man Utd 3 - 2 Chelsea
fields.trailText:
Man Utd: Van Der Gouw, G. Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre, P. Neville, Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs, Yorke, Solskjaer.
Substitutes: Cruyff, Berg, Sheringham, Fortune, Scholes.
fields.body:
Man Utd: Van Der Gouw, G. Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre, P. Neville, Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs, Yorke, Solskjaer.
Substitutes: Cruyff, Berg, Sheringham, Fortune, Scholes.

Chelsea: De Goey, Lambourde, Leboeuf, Thome, Melchiot, Petrescu, Wise, Deschamps, Ambrosetti, Flo, Zola.
Substitutes: Hogh, Sutton, Morris, Cudicini, Harley.

Referee: S Dunn (Bristol)

No Stam for the champions, but Ronny Johnsen gets a rare outing in his place. Chelsea are missing Desailly as they strive to cement their place in Europe. There will be no presentation of the Premiership trophy at Old Trafford today.

1 min The match gets off to a bizarre start, with Chelsea lining up and applauding the home side onto the pitch, like eleven overgrown mascots in blue. United kick off on a sunny Bank Holiday Monday.
2 On the left of the United area Zola picks up a deep cross from Melchiot. He delivers it back into Flo, who meets the centre with a firm header over the penalty spot. The ball arrows towards the top corner, but somehow Van Der Gouw manages to parry the effort with one hand. The resulting corner is wasted.
5 Chelsea have controlled these early stages, but suddenly Giggs finds a little space on the left touchline and squares to Yorke. His turn surprises Lambourde, who fells the United forward. Beckham steps up, 25 yards out on the left, and drives his shot straight into the wall. Chelsea manage to hack the ball clear. Lambourde looks to have his hands full already.
8 Nicky Butt, Yorke and Keane all combine down the right, sharp passing slicing through the Chelsea defence. De Goey eventually cuts out Keane's cross. United are looking to exact some revenge for the 5-0 drubbing suffered by the champions earlier in the season.
10 GOAL! Man Utd 1- 0 Chelsea Poor old Ed De Goey. Receiving a back-pass with plenty of time to spare, De Goey dawdles and allows Yorke to close him down. As the Dutch keeper kicks clear, Yorke manages to close the gap and the ball ricochets into the net. Even Yorke looks a little embarrassed about that one.
13 Chelsea try and reply immediately through Zola, who finds some space to the left of the United area. His shot across goal is well struck, but Van Der Gouw is equal to the challenge.
16 Giggs is having his own little party on the left. Three times in one move he beat the same man. Eventually, the cross does come over, from Phillip Neville. It falls invitingly for Nicky Butt on the edge of the area. Butt, unfortunately for him, is no Scholes and his shot poses more of a threat for the Goodyear blimp than the Chelsea goal.
18 Chelsea are still looking positive, and Flo seems to fancy his chances against Johnsen, who appears short on match-fitness. The Norwegian latches onto a through-ball from Zola, but his shot clears the crossbar by a metre.
22 GOAL! Man Utd 1 - 1 Chelsea The match comes to life thanks to Dan Petrescu. A throw in from the left is hooked over the area by Flo. At the far post Petrescu challenges for the header, but seems to lose out. Out of nowhere the ball lands at his feet and never one to look a gift horse in the mouth, the Romanian drills the ball past Van Der Gouw from 10 yards.
24 A great ball from Beckham in the centre of the park lands on the toe of Solskjaer's boot from 45 yards. This move goes left to Giggs, who returns the ball to Beckham. His shot from 20 yards out on the left is parried for a corner. The set-piece is wasted, but United are swarming forward every chance they get and it is some sight to behold.
31 Ronny Johnsen loses his rag with Flo on the left and is lucky to escape a booking. The free kick is floated into the United area, causing all kinds of havoc. Van Der Gouw comes, then he doesn't. Lambourde has a dig, and the move is finished of by Deschamps, who hoofs the ball deep into row Q.
33 Man Utd substitution: Berg for Gary Neville.
36 GOAL! Man Utd 1 - 2 Chelsea A superb goal by Chelsea as Flo nods the ball down for Petrescu on the right of the United area. The home side's marking is looking slack and Zola has enough room to get his body shape right to volley home Petrescu's cross, the ball looping over the stranded Van Der Gouw.
38 Solskjaer bundles over Deschamps by the corner flag and is booked for his trouble.
39 GOAL! Man Utd 2 - 2 Chelsea Solskjaer gets himself noticed for all the right reasons. A short pass from Beckham to Solskjaer on the left of the Chelsea area opens up a thousand possibilities. The United forward picks his spot and slots the ball inside De Goey's near post.
43 Giggs has broken through twice, and both times it took an exceptional tackle from Leboeuf to stop the flying Welshman. Solskjaer also tests the Chelsea defence for pace and the men in blue are looking decidedly slow and tired.
45 Another fantastic ball from Beckham on the right, controlled by Phillip Neville in the centre of the area, who lays it off for Solskjaer in the sort of position you would put both your mortgages on him to finish. Well, sell the furniture before the bailiffs call round, because the Baby-Faced Assassin just scooped the ball clean over the bar from 15 yards.
46 A frantic half comes to an end - there are more goals to come in this game, make no mistake.

45 Lambourde crunches into Beckham and Neville in quick succession and gets himself booked. Roy Keane forces a corner, but for once Beckham's delivery is poor.
47 Chelsea break from the clearance through Zola, who finds Flo on the edge of the area in a central position. His shot is straight at Van Der Gouw, who collects comfortably.
48 Man Utd substitution: Scholes for Keane.
50 Chelsea have started this half as brightly as they started the first. In terms of possession they are dominating, but they are finding it difficult to get the ball through to the forwards.
54 A break in the action, as the United physio treats an injury to Nicky Butt. Chelsea are still finding a lot of space as the substitutions appear to have temporarily unbalanced United's shape.
57 Lambourde manages to break two tackles down the left, and squares to Harley, who blazes over from 20 yards. A poor return for all Lambourde's determination.
61 Van Der Gouw takes the Michael - Flo and Zola close down the Dutchman on a back-pass, only for the United keeper to sell Flo an outrageous dummy and clear with ease, much to the delight of the Old Trafford faithful. De Goey must be squirming in his boots.
63 A Phil Neville cross almost puts United in the lead, as Solskjaer rises to meet the centre from the right. His header is powerful but just over the bar.
64 Man Utd substitution: Cruyff for Solskjaer.
67 Henning Berg, after many minutes of toil, is finally getting the better of Flo. Berg displays a lot of strength to hold off the Chelsea striker on the right of the United area. The ball eventually runs out of play. Goal kick.
68 GOAL! Man Utd 3 - 2 Chelsea Ryan Giggs hares down the left, pursued by three Chelsea defenders. Melchiot finally manages to tackle the winger, but the ball rolls kindly to Cruyff, who picks out Beckham on the right of the area with a great curling pass. Beckham's shot is too strong for De Goey to hold, and his parry falls at the feet of Yorke, in front of an empty goal.
72 United push forward yet again, a deep cross to Yorke on the left is met by an overhead kick. The effort is sliced and falls to Cruyff, who scuffs his shot goalwards. De Goey scrambles back and just manages to hold the ball away from the line.
74 Chelsea substitution: Sutton for Petrescu.
76 Chelsea almost benefit from great work on the left by Melchiot, who beats three men before squaring to Flo. His side-footed shot flicks off the head of Berg and onto the crossbar. Chelsea are incensed when referee Dunn awards a goal kick.
79 Phil Neville, deputizing on the right as Beckham moves infield, drives a low cross towards Yorke, who steps over, leaving the ball for Beckham to strike first time. De Goey is frozen to the spot as the shot just misses his right-hand post. So close.
83 Chelsea are allowing United unfettered possession until they approach De Goey's area. Yorke feeds Giggs down the left, who crosses only to find that no-one has bothered to follow his progress upfield.
88 United, and Yorke in particular, looking to add a fourth. Beckham, Yorke, Giggs and finally Scholes, who shoots well over, all combine in a sweeping move that takes in the length of the field.
92 United win their 25th match out of 35 in the Premiership. Full time: Man Utd 3 - 2 Chelsea
