webTitle: How I hit Shane Warne for four

fields.headline: How I hit Shane Warne for four
fields.standfirst: Every Monday throughout the English season wisden.com gets the inside story on one of the week's best performances. This week, Essex batsman Stephen Peters talks us through facing Shane Warne on his Hampshire debut - a B&H match at Chelmsford. Peters made 43, but Hampshire still won.
fields.trailText: Stephen Peters, 21, made a matchwinning century for England in the Under-19 World Cup final in February 1998. He's had a relatively disappointing couple of years for Essex since, but has made a positive start to the 2000 season (two forties in two innings).
fields.body:
Stephen Peters, 21, made a matchwinning century for England in the Under-19 World Cup final in February 1998. He's had a relatively disappointing couple of years for Essex since, but has made a positive start to the 2000 season (two forties in two innings).

Generally I like playing legspin and I'd back myself against most spinners - I enjoyed playing Muralitharan last year - so I was really looking forward to facing Shane Warne. I'd never played against him before and though I wanted Essex to do well, I was also hoping that I would get a chance to face him and get a few runs. Before the game I spoke to Nasser [Hussain] about how best to play Warne, because obviously Nasser has had a lot of experience against him. We talked about what shots to avoid and what shots were quite useful. Nasser said that I should look to play him down to mid-off or long-off and to play with the spin, and also that the sweep wasn't a bad shot to try. Obviously your scoring shots are limited because Warney is such a good bowler.

I am feeling in pretty good nick at the moment (though I've only had a couple of games because the weather has been so bad) so I was quite confident. Unfortunately I only faced a few balls from Warne, and by then we were looking to get after the Hampshire bowling. I looked around the field and couldn't see many spaces so I decided to reverse-sweep him. It certainly isn't a stroke that I have played in first-class cricket before but I thought I'd go for something a little bit cheeky and thankfully it paid off - it went for four.

I won't be playing against Warne in the Championship because Hampshire are in the first division [Essex are in the second], but I look forward to having another go in the one-day stuff. I think he might have been a bit tired in his first game [he finished with figures of 0-44 from ten overs]; but it was clear that he was a quality bowler. There is just that extra edge when he is playing, there were lots more spectators and press at Chelmsford than usual and it all added to the atmosphere. It was just an unfortunate result for us.

Stephen Peters was talking to Tanya Aldred

fields.headline: Cardinal laments Pope's paralysing ailment
fields.standfirst: 'His illness is leading to progressive paralysis, but his spiritual faculties remain intact'
fields.trailText: An admission that the Pope suffers from a progressive paralysis which is making him the prisoner of his body overshadowed a triumphant Easter mass in Rome yesterday.
fields.body:
An admission that the Pope suffers from a progressive paralysis which is making him the prisoner of his body overshadowed a triumphant Easter mass in Rome yesterday.

Cardinal Jean-Marie Lustiger, the archbishop of Paris, who is tipped by some conservatives as the next Pope, broke a Vatican taboo on discussing the pontiff's health by lamenting his illness. The comments were published just as the Pope gave his twice-yearly Urbi et Orbi (to the city and the world) message in 61 languages.

"One knows that his illness is leading to a progressive paralysis, but his spiritual faculties remain intact," the cardinal said. "This man, who used to be an athlete, is becoming more and more a prisoner of his own body."

No response came from the Vatican, which insists that the Pope is fit enough to continue his arduous schedule of jubilee engagements. He suffers from Parkinson's disease and the legacy of operations for falls, a tumour and gunshot wounds.

Cardinal Lustiger's comments to Le Journal du Dimanche were unexpected. A 73-year-old loyalist of Polish Jewish origin, he owes his rise entirely to the Pope.

Public utterances on papal health are viewed as skating dangerously close to plotting the succession - a sin while the Pope is alive. But the cardinal appeared to rule out the possibility of John Paul being the first pope in 700 years to abdicate voluntarily.

"He maintains a spiritual force, an intellectual capacity and a memory which are extraordinary for a man who will be 80 next month," he said.

"He shows evidence of great freedom with respect to his physical limitations. So much so that God will not relieve him of his mission. He accomplishes it faithfully, courageously, like a good servant."

The cardinal's remarks did not douse the euphoria of the 100,000 pilgrims who packed St Peter's Square for the first Easter message of the millennium. Speaking from an altar bedecked with 50,000 flowers from the Netherlands, and resplendent in gold vestments, the Pope urged humanity to defend peace and human rights and rid itself of racism, poverty and xenophobia.

Speaking at the end of a week of hectic engagements, his voice at times quavered, and he gasped for breath. He appeared to tire towards the end.

His Parkinson's disease, which the Vatican does not confirm but no longer denies, is believed to be held in check by the drug Levodopa. Further loss of speech and bodily movements are expected.

fields.headline: Television
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the box on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the box on the net.
fields.body:
1. It's a bank holiday and you're bored. So what are you going to do - watch a little TV?

2. Pressure group White Dot urges you to desist. So angry are they with the medium that they have declared this week International TV-turnoff week.

3. Without the little box in our living rooms, life, they say, would be more fulfilling. Every time you turn it on, you're telling the world you think you're boring and that the people you know are stupid.

4. Millions disagree: every night, soap operas such as Eastenders and Coronation Street pull in audiences in excess of the 5m White Dot claims turned off their TVs in April last year.

5. The jury is still out on this thorny question: it is true that TV brings news and drama to your armchair from across the world...

6. ...But others point out that a lot of that is a) rubbish, b) American and, in any case, may just be a bad influence on the young.

7. Evangelists stress there is plenty you can do if you turn the TV off. Others just object to the irritating station logos you get on a lot of new channels.

8. John Logie Baird, the man who invented television and made its earliest recordings, would turn in his grave.

9. Indeed, TV's not all sex, shooting, soaps and game shows. For the true telly lover, there are also the bits before, in between and after the actual programmes.

10. So what will it be? Kill your television or have a flick around and see what's on?

webTitle: We are on the correct path

fields.headline: We are on the correct path
fields.trailText: A fund manager for a leading investment house explained to us at Christmas that he was shifting into steel and chemicals. His view was that after fund management bonuses were paid in April, technology stocks would dive as managers looked for ways to differentiate their portfolios from those of their peers.
fields.body:
A fund manager for a leading investment house explained to us at Christmas that he was shifting into steel and chemicals. His view was that after fund management bonuses were paid in April, technology stocks would dive as managers looked for ways to differentiate their portfolios from those of their peers.

He described it as a symptom of the short-term way fund managers were incentivised. Although an accurate prediction of events, this neat theory cannot explain the recent decline in the value of technology stocks which has occurred on a global scale.

After recent events one might think that venture capitalists would start to reduce their technology portfolios. But our recent discussions with investors have revealed little evidence of a fall in the amount of capital available for new technology-based businesses.

Our information suggests that what took place in the markets last week was an expected correction rather than a free-fall devaluation of technology stocks. Indeed, some of the investment community seem to have welcomed developments even though their portfolios have taken a battering.

A shake-out seems inevitable. Investors are becoming more informed and recent developments should help to make expectations more realistic. As with any new industry, it takes some time for people to understand it. Many internet businesses are being reappraised, while new strategies based on using limitless capital to grab huge shares of the market are being viewed with scepticism.

Although in the early days of the industry it may have been possible to write a business plan that assumed a significant head start over potential competitors, no-one is letting others take an easy lead anymore.

While working on Rools we have seen a significant shift in the approach of venture capitalists to this market. In particular, there is increasing emphasis on strong business ideas that exploit what the new technology can do in a unique way. There is less interest in business models that simply transfer traditional businesses to the online environment.

Although venture capitalists are still looking to invest in fresh business-to-consumer ideas, business-to-business services are receiving increasing attention. The relative size of these markets makes them attractive - as does the potential for cost savings and efficiency improvements through genuinely new applications of technology.

Investors' love affair with technology is not over. We have simply seen a few plates broken in an argument over businesses that are inherently difficult to value. In the longer term, as the next wave of Internet businesses develop, investors will positively reassess their view of technology stocks.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com, a service that lets teenagers buy online.

webTitle: Close encounter of a third way kind

fields.headline: Close encounter of a third way kind
fields.trailText: If their ardour had taken a firmer hold, Tony Blair might never have set foot inside Downing Street and instead have ended up in Hollywood. The slightly out of focus snap shows the future prime minister with his then girlfriend Mary Harron. She went on to direct the movie American Pyscho, which has just opened in Britain
fields.body:
If their ardour had taken a firmer hold, Tony Blair might never have set foot inside Downing Street and instead have ended up in Hollywood.

The slightly out of focus snap shows the future prime minister with his then girlfriend Mary Harron. She went on to direct the movie American Pyscho, which has just opened in Britain. The film version of Bret Easton Ellis's novel depicts a yuppie who goes on a killing spree.

The picture of Mr Blair, with flowing locks, and Ms Harron was taken while they were undergraduates at St John's College, Oxford, in the early 1970s.

For a time they sought to find their own third way, but their relationship foundered.

Details are scarce but Ms Harron, interviewed by Jon Sopel for his 1995 biography of Mr Blair, remembered the Labour leader with fondness. Even 25 years ago Mr Blair's charm was well-developed. "Even before he became an MP and famous I always thought of Tony as the only 'nice' person that I ever went out with at Oxford," said Ms Harron, now 46.

"He was very good looking in a kind of sweet way, and wasn't at all predatory. He was very different from most of the guys I knew, but I guess I fell for him because he was cute." She also revealed that Mr Blair did not arrive at Oxford with a craving for high office. "He didn't seem terribly ambitious, and certainly wasn't one of those trying to cut a dash in the political arena."

Mr Blair read law at Oxford, and started his course in 1972 after taking a year out between school and university, during which he worked as a barman in Paris. Mr Sopel's book says that Mr Blair's university days saw him date a string of women. Ms Harron is described as "one of the more intellectual students whom he went out with".

Asked yesterday if the prime minister would be going to see American Psycho, a Downing Street spokeswoman said: "I have absolutely no idea."

fields.headline: £20m dome bail-out denied
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the Millennium Dome has denied claims he was seeking a £20m bail-out from the government, but admitted disappointing figures for visitors.
fields.body:
The chief executive of the Millennium Dome has denied claims he was seeking a £20m bail-out from the government, but admitted disappointing figures for visitors.

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau said the New Millennium Experience Company was "assessing the financial situation", but that he was not looking for more money from the national lottery "at the moment".

Mr Gerbeau admitted that visitor numbers over the Easter holiday period were so far not as good as he had hoped, but said the key periods for the dome were the summer and the few months before it closes.

He said he was hopeful 2m visitors would have gone through the gates by the end of April, but conceded that it would be a challenging task to reach his 10m break-even target for the year - downgraded from an initial target of 12m after the dome's shaky start.

Mr Gerbeau said: "Obviously, the Easter period should be booming. It's not at the moment, I am afraid."

He said the influx of tourists to London during the summer and the "last-chance-to-see" message as the dome approached its scheduled closure date at the end of the year would combine to push visitor numbers up towards 10m.

The Sunday Times reported the company was preparing to ask for an extra £20m subsidy from the national lottery, bringing its public backing up to £529m, and may also seek to write off part of its £110m loan.

But Mr Gerbeau told Sky News he was not seeking new public subsidies: "We are assessing the financial situation... but I am not asking for £20m at the moment."

He denied the government was putting pressure on him to force visitor numbers up and save the dome from becoming an embarrassment.

He told Sky News' Sunday with Adam Boulton that Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office minister with special responsibility for the dome, was "very supportive".

Mr Gerbeau said queues at the dome's Body Zone had been cut, from up to 150 minutes when he joined to 15 minutes now, even on busy days.

webTitle: British troops faced a weapons shortage in Kosovo

fields.headline: British troops faced a weapons shortage in Kosovo
fields.trailText:
11.15am: British troops nearly ran out of weapons in Kosovo, according to the latest report to highlight shortcomings in Britain's military intervention in the Serb province last year.
Kosovo: special report
fields.body:
British troops nearly ran out of weapons in Kosovo, according to the latest report to highlight shortcomings in Britain's military intervention in the Serb province last year.

The national audit office (NAO) report - leaked to the BBC's Today programme - said overall the operation was a great success. The NAO praised the operation's financial management, the supply of food and accommodation.

But British troops were said to have suffered a "critical munitions shortage" and, had the air campaign continued, Britain would quickly have run out of weapons, specifically precision guided munitions for the RAF, it said.

This is the latest glitch in the Kosovo campaign that the NAO has detected. It previously reported that Tornado GR-4 warplanes were not deployed in the conflict because their targeting systems were not ready, forcing the RAF to use older GR-1s and Harrier aircraft.

The NAO reviews every British military action and its full report is due to be published next month.

In other criticisms of the Kosovo operation, the latest NAO draft said thousands of essential medicines sent to the army were past their use-by dates by the time they reached troops in Kosovo, commanders' desperate pleas for secure radios were dismissed by the Ministry of Defence as "not relevant", and troops had to borrow guns from other K-For soldiers because many of their own failed to work properly.

The report - a late draft copy - also states that Britain lost 12 unmanned reconnaissance aircraft, the first such admission.

Liberal Democrat foreign affairs and defence spokesman Menzies Campbell said the report, if published in the same form, would be "extremely disturbing". Much of what was in the document confirmed previous fears about the "inadequacy" of communications and shortages of medical staff, he said.

"What it tells you is that if you embark on operations like Kosovo, it's not enough to get there, it's not enough to have high capability, you've got to have the ability to sustain these operations over a long period," Mr Campbell stated.

"These defects are not necessarily all to be laid at the door of the present government. They arise from our failure to address defence properly over the period of the last, say, 15 or 20 years."

Paul Beaver, a defence expert, said the report worried him and echoed long-standing concerns: "If we are going to involve ourselves in expeditionary warfare, peace support operations and the like, we have to be adequately supplied and logistics are number one. It's all very well to have the finest troops in the world, the best-trained troops in the world, the best-trained air force in the world, the most professional etc, you have to be able to re-supply them."

The NAO has lent weight to the leaked debriefing reports which said equipment failures would have made an advance into the province unworkable if the Serbs had put up stiff resistance.

fields.headline: Cash boost for rural policing
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to increase police funding to rural areas after a Home Office-commissioned report found that the current government spending formula failed to take full account of the special costs of policing sparsely populated rural areas.
fields.body:
The government is to increase police funding to rural areas after a Home Office-commissioned report found that the current government spending formula failed to take full account of the special costs of policing sparsely populated rural areas.

The extra cash - which is likely to run into tens of millions - will act as a welcome relief to hard-pressed ministers facing an outcry from middle England over the disappearance of a visible police forces in rural areas. The issue has been highlighted by the life imprisonment of farmer Tony Martin, who was found guilty last week of murdering 16-year-old Fred Barras.

Martin claimed he had acted in self-defence after Barras and an accomplice attempted to burgle his remote Norfolk farmhouse. He is expected to launch an appeal against his conviction this week and at the weekend won the limited support of the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe. She said householders should not be prosecuted if they attack or wound burglars.

"Where there's a dead body on the floor, there would have to be a trial," she said. "But if you go down to what is far more common, which is people who are hitting a burglar over the head, then my view is that it is unacceptable that a person is at risk of prosecution."

The extra funding, likely to be announced in the summer as part of a wider review of the government's standard spending assessments for local councils, will also be trailed in the imminent rural white paper.

Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister and by coincidence an MP for a Norfolk constituency, has already conceded the argument for further cash for rural police forces, saying independent research commissioned by the Home Office was "well made and widely accepted".

The research, by ORH Ltd, was then examined and endorsed by an internal Home Office team last summer including police constables, police authorities and local authorities.

The report found that it took a police officer three times as long to reach the scene of a crime or incident in a rural area than an officer in an urban area.

Mr Clarke has also said that the report's findings have wide support among ministers. The extra cash would help police adopt more visible rural policing strategies.

The government was reluctant to act until the completion of the standard spending assessment. Ministers were also nervous of acting because they feared the move would lead to a cut in police numbers in inner city areas. The Metropolitan police strength is already well down on the level before the last election.

But the government now recognises that the political pressure to act on its own well-documented research is overwhelming. The pressure is likely to increase further when the countryside agency, the government's official rural quango, publishes a report showing rural public services are relatively underfunded.

Home Office ministers also stress that the extra cash will not necessarily lead to higher police numbers since central government is not directly responsible for individual police force numbers.

Tory MPs, especially in the south-west and East Anglia, have been furious that ministers did not act immediately on the ORH report and implement its findings in time for this financial year's funding settlement.

Edward Leigh, the MP for Gainsborough, has claimed that the Lincolnshire police force has been underfunded. "We have the greatest sparsity of any county in England, and the distribution of population is unusually evenly spread. That means much higher costs for delivering any given level of police service."

Mr Leigh also accused the government of delaying the research in 1997 despite an offer from the rural authorities to fund the report. He claims the report's findings could have been implemented two years ago.

Ministers have defended their actions by pointing out that in 1995 3.9% of households in rural areas were burgled compared with 10.3% of those in inner-city areas and 6.3% of those in urban areas.

People living in rural areas were also far less concerned about falling victim to crime than those living in other parts of the country.

Meanwhile, Martin's solicitors said he would appeal against his conviction this week.

Martin is being held in the hospital wing of Bullingdon prison near Bicester, Oxfordshire, and is said to be still in a state of shock.

He is likely to serve his sentence in a segregation unit for his own safety once medical checks have been completed.

Nick Makin, one of the solicitors, said: "There have been threats made to his life and to harm him, for example scalding him with hot water."

fields.bodyText: The government is to increase police funding to rural areas after a Home Office-commissioned report found that the current government spending formula failed to take full account of the special costs of policing sparsely populated rural areas. The extra cash - which is likely to run into tens of millions - will act as a welcome relief to hard-pressed ministers facing an outcry from middle England over the disappearance of a visible police forces in rural areas. The issue has been highlighted by the life imprisonment of farmer Tony Martin, who was found guilty last week of murdering 16-year-old Fred Barras. Martin claimed he had acted in self-defence after Barras and an accomplice attempted to burgle his remote Norfolk farmhouse. He is expected to launch an appeal against his conviction this week and at the weekend won the limited support of the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe. She said householders should not be prosecuted if they attack or wound burglars. "Where there's a dead body on the floor, there would have to be a trial," she said. "But if you go down to what is far more common, which is people who are hitting a burglar over the head, then my view is that it is unacceptable that a person is at risk of prosecution." The extra funding, likely to be announced in the summer as part of a wider review of the government's standard spending assessments for local councils, will also be trailed in the imminent rural white paper. Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister and by coincidence an MP for a Norfolk constituency, has already conceded the argument for further cash for rural police forces, saying independent research commissioned by the Home Office was "well made and widely accepted". The research, by ORH Ltd, was then examined and endorsed by an internal Home Office team last summer including police constables, police authorities and local authorities. The report found that it took a police officer three times as long to reach the scene of a crime or incident in a rural area than an officer in an urban area. Mr Clarke has also said that the report's findings have wide support among ministers. The extra cash would help police adopt more visible rural policing strategies. The government was reluctant to act until the completion of the standard spending assessment. Ministers were also nervous of acting because they feared the move would lead to a cut in police numbers in inner city areas. The Metropolitan police strength is already well down on the level before the last election. But the government now recognises that the political pressure to act on its own well-documented research is overwhelming. The pressure is likely to increase further when the countryside agency, the government's official rural quango, publishes a report showing rural public services are relatively underfunded. Home Office ministers also stress that the extra cash will not necessarily lead to higher police numbers since central government is not directly responsible for individual police force numbers. Tory MPs, especially in the south-west and East Anglia, have been furious that ministers did not act immediately on the ORH report and implement its findings in time for this financial year's funding settlement. "We have the greatest sparsity of any county in England, and the distribution of population is unusually evenly spread. That means much higher costs for delivering any given level of police service." Mr Leigh also accused the government of delaying the research in 1997 despite an offer from the rural authorities to fund the report. He claims the report's findings could have been implemented two years ago. Ministers have defended their actions by pointing out that in 1995 3.9% of households in rural areas were burgled compared with 10.3% of those in inner-city areas and 6.3% of those in urban areas. fields.headline: Tourists taken hostage in Malaysia
fields.trailText: Six heavily armed, masked assailants have taken 21 people, including Americans, Europeans and Malaysians, hostage on a remote resort island in eastern Malaysia, the police said today.
fields.body:
Six heavily armed, masked assailants have taken 21 people, including Americans, Europeans and Malaysians, hostage on a remote resort island in eastern Malaysia, the police said today.

The abductors surprised and captured the group on Sipadan Island on Sunday night, but two captives escaped, Semporna police chief Sulaiman Junaidi said in a telephone interview.

Sipadan is a world-renowned diving island off the north-east coast of Sabah, the Malaysian side of Borneo island, which is shared with Indonesia. Semporna is the port town where divers catch boats for the lush island.

Philippine officials said they were investigating a possible link between the hostage-taking in Malaysia and Filipino rebels who took hostages more than a month ago on a southern Philippine island in the same waters as Sipadan.

Osman Ibrahim, a police spokesman in the Malaysian capital, Kuala Lumpur, said two Americans had escaped and were believed to still be in Sabah. He said most of the tourists were Americans and Europeans.

Officials said the hostages included 10 foreign tourists, four Malaysians from the wildlife department, five Malaysians working at the resort and a cook from the dining hall, as well as a police officer.

Sulaiman said the hostage-takers were believed to be Filipinos. The hostages were said to have been taken onto a boat and are now at sea. Police are currently trying to trace the boat, he said, adding no demands had been made by the hostage-takers.

Colonel Ernesto de Guzman, chief of staff of the Philippine military's southern command, said five to six gunmen in camouflage uniforms and armed with M-16 and M-79 rifles forced themselves into the resort. De Guzman said the gunmen took the victims to a waiting outrigger and sped toward Philippine waters.

"We have dispatched two patrol gunboats to verify or intercept the vessel bearing the hostages if it's heading toward Philippine waters," he added.

He said they were trying to determine whether there was a connection between the Sipadan hostage-taking and a similar incident by Abu Sayyaf rebels on the southern Philippine island of Basilan. Both islands are in the Celebes Sea.

"We are not discounting the possible involvement of Abu Sayyaf rebels, of local pirates and other lawless groups," de Guzman said.

"We are not discounting also the involvement of pirates of other nationalities."

Philippine defence secretary Orlando Mercado said the Philippine and Malaysian navies were now coordinating the hostage rescue. But Mercado emphasised that it had not been definitely established that the hostage-takers were Filipino.

Malaysian deputy prime minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi said a police and military team had been sent to the area. He said that six of the hostage-takers were Filipinos.

"Freeing them is uppermost," Abdullah said. "I think the Philippine government can help in this matter." Chong Kah Kiat, the minister of tourism and environment for Sabah, said he didn't believe the hostage-takers were Malaysians.

"This has never happened here before, so I don't think there are any Malaysians involved," said Chong, concerned that the incident would scare off the 400,000 tourists who visit Sabah beaches and rainforests every year.

Chong said Sipadan was considered one of the top 10 diving spots in the world and that six resorts on the island cater mostly to professional divers.

He said access to the island was restricted to 80 divers at one time, and 40 staff members at the six resorts, to protect the coral reef and wildlife.

Malaysia and Indonesia since 1969 have both claimed sovereignty over the Celebes Sea islands of Sipadan and Ligitan. The south-east Asian neighbours have both filed claims with the international court of justice at The Hague. But there were no early indications that the hostage-takers were involved in the territorial dispute.

fields.headline: Prisons 'failing to end abuse'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: A four year drive to tackle racism and sexual harassment inside Britain's prisons is set to end in failure with more than 80% of staff yet to take part in anti-discrimination training courses, according to a leaked Home Office document.
fields.body:
A four year drive to tackle racism and sexual harassment inside Britain's prisons is set to end in failure with more than 80% of staff yet to take part in anti-discrimination training courses, according to a leaked Home Office document.

The prison service has warned its area managers and directors of high security prisons that a low level or, in some prisons, a complete lack of training in racism and sexism awareness courses is likely to lead to further problems, including embarrassing employment tribunal rulings.

Only last week Martin Narey, the director-general of the prison service, apologised to a black prison officer who an employment tribunal ruled had suffered humiliation and abuse over a 10 year period after he reported an assault by prison staff on a black inmate.

"Cases of harassment and discrimination are politically damaging for the prison service," Paul Wray, the head equal opportunities training, has warned prison managers.

The prison service told every governor in 1996 that equal opportunities training for all staff and managers was to be made mandatory in the wake of damaging industrial tribunal rulings which revealed the extent of racial and sexual harassment in prisons.

The internal Home Office document shows that four years later only about 15% of staff have received any such training at all. "The expectation... was that the whole training programme would be completed by 2000. This will not be achieved," the document says.

It shows that fewer than 10% of all staff - only 3,932 prison officers - have received training in awareness of racial harassment and discrimination - even though the courses last only half a day. Half the prisons have failed to organise any anti-racism training.

Some 7,008 staff have been through courses designed to combat sexual harassment and only 1,337 managers -about one in five - have completed the "equal opportunities for managers" course.

webTitle: US public backs seizure of Elian

fields.headline: US public backs seizure of Elian
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: American public opinion last night appeared to have swung round in support of the government's decision to seize six- year-old Elian Gonzalez at gunpoint from his relatives in Miami.
fields.body:
American public opinion last night appeared to have swung round in support of the government's decision to seize six- year-old Elian Gonzalez at gunpoint from his relatives in Miami.

As the plaintive Easter Day protests organised by the exiled Cuban community subsided, across the water President Fidel Castro declared a single day of "truce" in which he forswore verbal attacks on Washington.

United States immigration officials are now preparing for a fresh round of legal chal lenges before Elian and his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, can leave the country. The next federal appeal court hearing has been fixed for May 11.

Two dramatic images freeze-framed the conflicting emotions of the day: Elian taken at gunpoint from his relatives in Miami, and reunited with his father. In the battle to persuade America of the justice of their cause, both the Cuban exile community and US federal agents raced to get their pictures out to the media.

webTitle: Elian battle drags on despite seizure

fields.headline: Elian battle drags on despite seizure
fields.standfirst:
Dramatic pre-dawn snatch of Cuban six-year-old by federal agents provokes rioting in Little Havana.

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez could face weeks, even months, of further legal battles in the United States before his father is allowed to take him home to Cuba, it emerged yesterday, following the dramatic seizure of the six-year-old Cuban boy by federal agents in Miami.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez could face weeks, even months, of further legal battles in the United States before his father is allowed to take him home to Cuba, it emerged yesterday, following the dramatic seizure of the six-year-old Cuban boy by federal agents in Miami.

On May 11, an appeal court in Atlanta will hear arguments by the boy's Miami relatives that Elian should be allowed to make an asylum claim without his father's permission.

But the court has given no date for its ruling and when it does come, that ruling is likely to be appealed to the US supreme court, a process which could easily last into next year.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez and his son spent their first full day together as a reunited family yesterday, but kept firmly out of the media and public gaze in their "distinguished guest" apartment on the Andrews air force base outside Washington.

They are expected to be moved to the Wye Plantation conference centre in eastern Maryland, a secure site of several phases of talks in the Middle East peace process, later this week.

Meanwhile, the row over the Clinton administration's action in seizing Elian at gunpoint from the home of his Miami relatives in the early hours of Saturday morning continued unabated.

The streets of Miami's Little Havana district returned to something approaching normality yesterday after Saturday's disturbances, as the boy's still-distraught relatives took their case against the US immigration service to Washington. They found some support among the Clinton administration's political opponents but failed in repeated bids to meet up with the father and son.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez said through his lawyer, Gregory Craig, that he did not wish to meet with the Miami family members, or to allow them access to Elian for the moment. "He wants minimal intrusions," Mr Craig said.

"The worst thing that could possibly happen would be to reintroduce the circus atmosphere, the television lights, the cameras and the emotions of Miami into this family reunion, which is so special," Mr Craig told CNN.

There were some signs that the Clinton administration's Republican opponents see Saturday's events as too good an opportunity to miss for attacking the administration.

George W Bush, the party's presidential candidate, said he was "profoundly saddened and troubled" by the seizure, while the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said: "The use of this type of force clearly was not justified."

For the second day running, the Miami relatives gave emotional accounts to the press of the lightning federal raid on Saturday morning, making a stream of allegations against the US government ranging from breach of good faith in earlier negotiations to claims that photographs of the Gonzalez family reunion were faked and doctored. Lawyers for the Gonzalez family dismissed that charge as "absurd".

Administration officials continued to defend their action in a series of media post mortems. Saturday's seizure was "a perfectly legal, properly carried out operation", the US immigration commissioner Doris Meissner said.

Ms Meissner disputed claims by Elian's cousin Marisleysis Gonzalez and his great uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, that the federal agents had threatened to shoot them when they burst into the house at 5am.

"They would not have said anything like that," she told CBS television. "They were in and out in three minutes. Their commands are 'We are here, stand aside'."

Saturday's Associated Press picture of an armed officer preparing to take Elian continued to be a focus of intense argument yesterday, and was brandished by demonstrators in Miami and New York.

"That gun is pointed downwards," Ms Meissner said when she was quizzed about the picture. "The trigger finger is straight ahead. The weapon is to the side."

The immigration commissioner also denied the relatives' allegations that Elian was drugged during his flight from Miami to Washington later on Saturday morning.

Despite the demonstrations by Cuban exiles, a self-selecting survey of more than 400,000 America OnLine internet users showed 60% approval of the US government's action, with 37% disapproval. Some 50% thought that the right amount of force was used, with 43% saying that too much force was used.

Elian, who fled Cuba with his mother in November, was rescued after clinging to an inner tube for two days, the sole survivor of a shipwreck.

webTitle: Heavy air of disbelief descends on Miami faithful

fields.headline: Heavy air of disbelief descends on Miami faithful
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Renaldo Ramos carried a life-size effigy of Jesus Christ, wrapped in a purple velvet cloak, on his aged back to the house in Little Havana where Elian Gonzalez used to live. There he spent a damp-eyed Easter Sunday, squatting at the foot of the serene plastic model.
fields.body:
Renaldo Ramos carried a life-size effigy of Jesus Christ, wrapped in a purple velvet cloak, on his aged back to the house in Little Havana where Elian Gonzalez used to live. There he spent a damp-eyed Easter Sunday, squatting at the foot of the serene plastic model.

"We feel with what they did," he said. "How are you going to put a gun to the head of the kid? At Easter, when all the world is remembering the crucifixion and the resurrection.

"I have brought the holy one here with me so we can pray and have a service. But to tell you the truth, I'm sorry about this, we feel like shit."

The police had tried to stop him hauling his devotional figure to Second Street, to the house where Elian's Miami relatives live. The forces of law and order spent yesterday trying to syphon the passion out of the working-class suburb after a day and night of fitful rioting that followed Saturday's pre-dawn seizure of the little Cuban boy.

But Mr Ramos, who arrived from Cuba 44 years ago, was too smart for the police checkpoints. He carried the effigy, complete with painted stigmata, over a fence and placed it in the front garden of a sympathetic neighbour, where it stood yesterday, silently reflecting the mournful sense of loss infusing a shocked neighbourhood.

Most of the Gonzalez family had followed Elian to Washington, where they were lobbying to see him. They left behind the detritus of a four-month vigil outside their home that was supposed to have kept him from the arms of the US government, Elian's father, Juan Miguel, and the Communist atheists they have always alleged were manipulating him.

A wooden cross with a golden Christ-figure hung from the eaves of the Gonzalez house, near a reproduction of the now iconic photograph of a helmeted border policeman brandishing a gun in the general direction of the terrified child. "Federal Child Abuse", it says above the picture, "Would you let this happen to your child?"

Marta Ramos, who lives two doors down from the Gonzalez house, swept the debris through her front gate with an air of finality.

"I just feel full of sadness," she said, with a voice still hoarse from the pepper spray federal agents had used the previous day. "This is Easter, they should never have done this on Easter. But then they don't believe in God do they - Castro and Clinton?"

Florida's Democratic senator, Bob Graham, had arrived besuited and primed for an on-site television interview, and picked up instantly on the pervasive theme of sacrilege and blasphemy.

"The president had given me a commitment, to me personally, that there would not be a raid at night," he said. "And they should never have done it over the Easter-Passover period. This is a deeply religious period."

A few hours earlier, about 80 Cuban-Americans had gathered for a dawn mass on the beach outside the community's church, Our Lady of Charity. The priest called for prayers for Elian's wellbeing and a murmuring went through the crowd.

Jose Basulto, the leader of an exile activist group, Brothers to the Rescue, appealed for calm - at least temporarily - after the service. "This is a day for prayer, and it should be used for prayer," Mr Basulto said.

Next week, he said, was another matter. A general strike had been called for "Dead Tuesday", another attempt to bring Miami to a halt, and a continuation of tactics that has helped alienate the 800,000-strong Cuban exile community from the rest of the city.

Daniel Ricker, a self- described citizen-activist, arrived in Second Street intending to take the first steps in rebuilding bridges between Miami's three main groups - "Anglos", blacks and Cubans. He called the Elian affair "the most divisive event in this city for decades".

"I want to set up some sort of commission to see how to put Humpty-Dumpty back together again," Mr Ricker said. "When [Hurricane] Andrew happened in 1992, it seemed for a time as if everyone saw themselves as being on one ship. Now it looks like the Titanic."

"The president had given me a commitment, to me personally, that there would not be a raid at night," he said. "And they should never have done it over the Easter-Passover period. The priest called for prayers for Elian's wellbeing and a murmuring went through the crowd. webTitle: That Photograph isn't the full picture

fields.headline: That Photograph isn't the full picture
fields.standfirst:
Most Americans support both the seizure of Elian Gonzalez and the way it was carried out

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The images from Miami that went round the world on Saturday were of fear, chaos, anger and violence. A six-year-old seized at gunpoint in the middle of the night. Distraught relatives shouting defiance at the Clinton administration. Crowds confronting police in the streets of Little Havana. Disturbances in New Jersey and New York.
fields.body:
The images from Miami that went round the world on Saturday were of fear, chaos, anger and violence. A six-year-old seized at gunpoint in the middle of the night. Distraught relatives shouting defiance at the Clinton administration. Crowds confronting police in the streets of Little Havana. Disturbances in New Jersey and New York.

Yesterday, in Washington this time, Elian Gonzalez's Florida relatives relived their anguish yet again, backed by a growing chorus of mainly Republican politicians. A possible general strike looms in Miami.

Placed back to back, as they were on television throughout the Easter weekend, these images play into a view which many Europeans seem to enjoy holding about the United States - that it is a nation inhabited essentially by mad people, who are ready to erupt and over-react in response to issues which could and should be settled more calmly and honestly. Yet the truth about the Elian affair is that it ought to offer some modest reassurance and encouragement.

What is the essence of the situation, the first world war commander Marshal Foch always used to ask his staff officers during the fog of battle. It was a good question then, and it's a good question now. The essence of the Elian situation is not that the situation is out of hand, but that the Clinton administration has enforced the law so that the boy can be reunited with his father - the objective which most people and all precedent supported - in the face of constant opposition and lack of cooperation from the Miami relatives.

Though the seizure operation on Saturday morning clearly involved the assertion of the US state's power, it was not, despite all the shocking aspects of That Photograph, an unlawful or anarchic act. In a perfect world, the seizure would not have been armed. But to ask the Feds to go unarmed into the Little Havana stockade in which Elian had been held for five months was hardly realistic.

In a country which has more guns than people, in a city which has the third most violent crime rate in the nation, in a community which regards the armed overthrow of the Castro government as a sacred cause, you don't take stupid risks when your goal is to bring a child out quickly and alive.

The Florida relatives are obviously, and understandably, outraged by Saturday's seizure, but a clear majority of all Americans, all Floridians, and even all Miamians, think that it is right - not wrong - for Elian to be reunited with his father. Even among the Cuban community in Miami, there are many who think the refusal to release Elian to his father was indefensible. They don't say so in public because they are afraid.

American public opinion supports what the government did on Saturday, even after the event. An unscientific, but very large, internet poll on America OnLine yesterday, in which 400,000 people took part, showed 60% approval of Elian's seizure. Most believed that sufficient force was used in carrying it out. Internet polls are normally biased against government, not towards it.

There will be those -there always are - who will grab the opportunity to attack Bill Clinton and the attorney general, Janet Reno, over the way that the operation was carried out. Anything, absolutely anything, is grist to the mill of the Clinton-haters and the Reno-haters. Yesterday they all piled in, led by Senator Bob Smith of New Hampshire, a man who is so rightwing and so conservative that he couldn't raise even 1% support from his own party in his abortive Republican presidential bid last year.

There is a case to be made that the administration waited too long, was too conciliatory, too cowardly, and that it allowed the Elian issue to balloon out of proportion. But it's a case that should be made with care. There were, and are, court proceedings to take heed of. And as long as Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, remained in Cuba, the decision to return the boy was much more complex, and politically charged than it became once Juan Miguel arrived in the US on April 6. If Janet Reno delayed too long, the delay was a matter of days rather than weeks.

To describe the Elian case as anybody's triumph would be wrong. Too many of the principals in the saga have been too badly damaged to say that - and it is not over yet. Yet there is no getting away from the fact that Saturday was, at one level, Janet Reno's revenge upon the many critics who have mocked and insulted her for eight years, and especially since the catastrophic end of the Waco siege in April 1993.

On Saturday, the St Louis Post-Dispatch published an exclusive story which was inevitably overlooked in the dramas of the day. It reported that a detailed court-ordered re-enactment of the end of the Waco siege had established beyond reasonable doubt that the FBI did not fire shots into the Branch Davidian compound seven years ago - the central charge that the Reno-haters have been making all these years.

One way and another, it would be fair to say that one of the most unjustly maligned politicians in the United States had a good day last Saturday.

martin.kettle@theguardian.com

fields.headline: A tale of two pictures
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Almost as dramatic as the seizure of Elian Gonzalez was the battle of the photographs, wired around the world and jostling for prominence in yesterday's newspapers.
fields.body:
Almost as dramatic as the seizure of Elian Gonzalez was the battle of the photographs, wired around the world and jostling for prominence in yesterday's newspapers.

Less than four hours after US federal agents burst into the Miami home in which Elian had lived for five months, the Associated Press released the photo the Clinton administration must have dreaded - a picture showing an immigration officer carrying a pump-action shotgun as he attempts to seize the six-year-old from the fisherman, Donato Dalrymple, who rescued him last November.

Three hours later came the second picture of the same boy, this one a world away from the first. At Andrews air force base in Maryland, a smiling Elian poses with his father.

The two pictures, which so starkly highlighted the contrasting emotions of Saturday's events, confronted the world's media with the dilemma of which shot to highlight.

British Sunday papers mostly chose the armed seizure photograph taken by AP's Alan Diaz - who is already being spoken of as a certainty for the next Pulitzer Prize news photo awards.

So did yesterday's Miami Herald, the paper that dominates the market in the area where Elian was staying. The Herald showed the armed seizure shot on its front page, with a smaller shot of the reunion below it.

The Fort Lauderdale-based Sun-Sentinel, which has a reputation for being ready to run stories the Cuban-American exiles dislike, kept the gunman off its front page, choosing instead to lead with a shot of a federal agent clutching a crying Elian as she runs from the house.

The New York Times took yet another approach. The big front-page photograph in the US's most prestigious newspaper was the reunion shot. The armed seizure shot was relegated to page 14.

Yesterday's Washington Post took a third way, giving equal prominence to the contrasting images, which were placed side by side at the top of the front page.

fields.headline: Villains not victims
fields.standfirst:
Cuban exiles get a deserved comeuppance

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The two different versions of the same day are reflected in the photographs. Splashed across British front pages yesterday were the dramatic pictures of heavily armed US immigration officers in a pre-dawn raid, removing a clearly terrorised six-year-old, Elian Gonzalez, from the custody of his great uncle in Miami. According to the Sunday Express, it was a "picture that shames America as little Elian is hauled away by the government at gunpoint". But in the US, the pictures which appeared on the front pages of the New York Times and Washington Post were of a smiling and euphoric Elian, finally reunited with his father after a five month protracted separation.
fields.body:
The two different versions of the same day are reflected in the photographs. Splashed across British front pages yesterday were the dramatic pictures of heavily armed US immigration officers in a pre-dawn raid, removing a clearly terrorised six-year-old, Elian Gonzalez, from the custody of his great uncle in Miami. According to the Sunday Express, it was a "picture that shames America as little Elian is hauled away by the government at gunpoint". But in the US, the pictures which appeared on the front pages of the New York Times and Washington Post were of a smiling and euphoric Elian, finally reunited with his father after a five month protracted separation.

In the eyes of many Cuban exiles in Florida, the photographs in the British press portrayed the true picture: an over-weaning federal government, ready to resort to "Gestapo" tactics, battering down a door with weapons at the ready, to snatch the child. Donato Dalrymple, the fisherman who rescued Elian from the Atlantic, the only survivor of a shipwreck that killed his mother and 10 other Cubans trying to flee to the US, was in the house when the immigration officers broke in. He was forced to hand over the boy despite cries of "Help me, help me". Elian's cousin, Marisleysis Gonzalez, purporting to be his surrogate mother, described the officers as "animals".

Yet, in reality, it was the Florida exiles who forced the administration to belatedly adopt its strong-arm tactics. From the moment Elian was released from a US hospital last November into the custody of his great uncle, the exiles have used every resort to keep him in the US and not to return him to his father in Cuba. It is now 14 weeks since US immigration officials rightly ruled the boy should be reunited with his father. They were backed by the attorney general and a US federal court. But still the relatives resisted, using both family law and immigration appeals, but ignoring the legal requirement to hand over the boy once his father arrived in the US, ready to await a final court settlement.

It was not the federal government, but Cuban exiles who have been breaking the law. Much worse was the obscene way in which Elian's interests have been ignored by the exiles - and other political interests - in the hope of scoring a further propaganda victory. Susie Orbach, the psychotherapist, set out in yesterday's Observer the immense difficulties which Elian will face in overcoming his succession of unbearable traumas: the divorce of his parents, loss of his mother, his two days at sea strapped to an inner-tube and, probably even worse, five months as a political pawn in an old ideological war. So much for the exiles' crocodile tears over Elian's removal.

If the federal authorities can be criticised, it is over their delay in removing Elian - explained, but not excused, by Attorney General Janet Reno's political links to Florida and the earlier criticism she received for her pre-emptive strike in the Waco siege in which 24 children died. Too many politicians - among them Al Gore - have been pusillanimous in the face of the exile vote and the crucial role Florida could play in this year's federal elections. The politicians have misread the script: there is widespread public support in the US, possibly even in Florida, for Elian's reunion with his father. Having faced the exiles down, the establishment is in a much better position to pursue a long overdue renegotiation of its relationship with Cuba. The economic blockade, introduced four decades ago, is not going to end this side of the election, but once Castro goes, stand by for change.

fields.headline: Bogus heroes and villains
fields.trailText: My favourite bogus asylum seeker is a six-foot brunette stunna called Stasha. She is half-Serb, half-Croatian, looks like a conservatively dressed Bond girl and speaks the bubblegum posh of your average north London princess.
fields.body:
My favourite bogus asylum seeker is a six-foot brunette stunna called Stasha. She is half-Serb, half-Croatian, looks like a conservatively dressed Bond girl and speaks the bubblegum posh of your average north London princess.

She came to London to study, got refugee status when the war in Croatia broke out, got it revoked shortly afterwards. I met her in the cocktail bar where I whiled away my first 18 months after graduation, mixing martinis for City boys. Stasha was an off-the-books PR girl by day, a bus boy by night. She was brilliant company and she dressed well.

She married a bouncer called Marvin in a registry office in Ealing. It was, of course, a green-card affair. It was also my best-ever wedding. I wept over a perfectly executed reinforcement of the deception, when the registrar fumbled Stasha's complicated foreign surname, and Marvin (who had been well briefed) corrected her. We had the reception in a pub round the corner. Then Marvin had to dash, because his girlfriend didn't know anything about it.

Sadly, the foreign office caught Marvin and Stasha out. They were called in for separate interviews and tested on the colour of each other's toothbrushes. Stasha was booted back to Belgrade. The last time I saw her, she was being interviewed in a wine bar for the 9 o'clock news during the Nato bombing. She was picked out for her looks, eloquence and mild manner.

There are no two ways about it: Stasha was seeking asylum in Britain from nothing worse than the threat of not realising her full potential in the shattered remains of Yugoslavia. She was as bogus as you can get. But this country is less well off without that particular tabloid villain.

Heroes and villains. Which do we regard as which? Readers of the Sun think David Jason should be knighted. Charles Potton of Oxford said: "If it is to be Sir Michael Caine, why not Sir David Jason?" I am inclined to agree. I really, really like A Touch of Frost and I think that people who have two first names should be commended generally.

We're delightfully random in selecting our heroes. One gentle perusal of the tabloids will bear this out. Hooray, currently, to Vinnie Jones, Ant'ny Royle, Stella McCartney, Heather Mills, Des Lynham, Carol Vorderman.

Popular Brit villains, on the other hand are more predictable: apart from bogus asylum seekers, there are love rats and ladies who are no better than they should be.

Boo, then, to James Hewitt, greedy Friends cast members, those two mythical monsters Bridget Jones and the Ladette who are guilty of making us impressionable British ladies drink, which is v v bad, because eventually we'll all be more interested in getting sozzled than having babies; oh, and Ali G (but only because it's fashionable).

And then there's Christine Hamilton who, I think, is trembling on the brink of reinvention as one of the greatest gay icons this country has ever known.

Next Tuesday, the Christine Hamilton Show will hit a small screen near you. (BBC Choice, 11pm - that strange noise must be the sound of a million diaries being cleared.) Actually, I do believe that this promises to be good telly. The idea is that Christine interviews people who have, like her, emerged from what her press release calls Traumas and Stormy Waters.

Confirmed guests so far include James Hewitt, Jonathan Aitken and Kara Noble. A BBC spokesperson explained that, better yet, Christine conducts the interviews from venues that are relevant to the interviewee's personal controversy. "For example, she interviews Jonathan Aitken in the - oh, do you know what, I've forgotten." The Paris Ritz? I hazard. A double whammy of a controversial venue? The BBC spokesperson doesn't think so, no.

For Christine's gay icon potential, consider the evidence: She is one of those residually pink types. She admitted to going through her husband's pockets on a regular basis. She's rumoured to sing I Will Survive over the opening credits.

She's also running a fabulous competition to launch the show. Her web page www.bbc.co.uk/choice/hamilton asks that you "Complete the following sentence in an apt and amusing way, 'It would be my ultimate dream to take Christine Hamilton out for a slap-up meal, to the value of £300 top-whack, because' in no more than 20 words."

A very camp friend of mine recently went to a fancy-dress disco as Christine Hamilton. Ms Hamilton's fluctuating status proves there's an extraordinarily fine line between icon and villain. I suppose this is on account of Britain traditionally championing the underdog. Unless, of course, it's foreign.

webTitle: Papers reveal work on deadlier warhead

fields.headline: Papers reveal work on deadlier warhead
fields.trailText: Britain and the US are collaborating to design a more powerful nuclear warhead, previously secret documents suggest.
fields.body:
Britain and the US are collaborating to design a more powerful nuclear warhead, previously secret documents suggest.

The papers, obtained by Greenpeace, shed light on the multimillion dollar submarine warhead protection programme (SWPP), run by the US department of energy to designs and develop nuclear weapons.

SWPP was given the job of generating a better mechanism for "arming, fusing and firing" the warheads used in the US Trident missiles, according to the papers.

The designs of the Trident missile systems used by the US and Britain are closely related. This work is being carried out by the Sandia National Laboratories in the US, which supplies the mechanisms for Britain's Trident warheads.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: Maintaining control of a website that receives 2.5m hits a day is no easy task, so Tom Hall is grateful that the UK office of Lonely Planet is not responsible for the entire site. "We look after Europe, the Middle East and Africa, and our Australian and US offices are responsible for the rest of the world," he says. "A lot of my job consists of updating and 'tidying' the pages - our site is very interactive and is used by literally millions of travellers as an information board and research post. For that reason, it must be accurate and user-friendly."
fields.body:
Maintaining control of a website that receives 2.5m hits a day is no easy task, so Tom Hall is grateful that the UK office of Lonely Planet is not responsible for the entire site. "We look after Europe, the Middle East and Africa, and our Australian and US offices are responsible for the rest of the world," he says. "A lot of my job consists of updating and 'tidying' the pages - our site is very interactive and is used by literally millions of travellers as an information board and research post. For that reason, it must be accurate and user-friendly."

One of Hall's biggest tasks is to oversee the "thorn tree", an online discussion forum and info-pooling page. "The thorn tree gets roughly 2,200 new posts each day and I have to ensure that all of them are acceptable - not racist or abusive. I learnt HTML on a course and have also taught myself. Now I have what are called 'administrative privileges' which allow me to access the back end of the website and tinker around with it."

The thorn tree takes up a lot of Hall's time, but he believes it provides a valuable service. "I usually check it several times a day - not just to ensure the messages are acceptable but to 'prune' it, deleting old posts or those that have remained unanswered. There's no definite length of time a message can remain. If answers are still being posted three weeks after the question first appeared, I may decide to let it run on.

"One of the aims of the website is to keep travellers properly informed, and one way we do this is with the 'Scoop' section. This is a collection of the latest news stories, or any events that may affect travellers. My colleagues and I scour all the papers for relevant stories, check the facts and then type them up and send them to our Australian office where they are uploaded on to the site."

In addition to administering parts of the site, Hall deals with around 50 emails a day, many of which reappear in the site's Postcards section. "I read each email and if it contains any info about travelling, such as changes to visas or borders, any travel information, or just an interesting experience that may be of use to other travellers, I retype it into the system. There's a template which has the HTML coding set up."

Other emails may relate to the guide-books and these are usually passed to the authors, who may use them for the upgrade page. "Upgrade is intended as a way to keep your guidebook bang up to date," explains Hall. "Upgrades are usually written by the guide's author and include all new information or changes to what was in the original book. I'm involved in administering that part of the site: I have to ensure the writers know their deadlines and have all the relevant information, and when we receive it, I write it in the correct HTML format and upload it on to the web."

A former round-the-world traveller himself, Hall admits that being in constant contact with the travelling community can make him wistful for his backpacking days. "It's a trade-off. I've been doing this job for a year and I really enjoy it - the internet stuff is fascinating. But the adventures and experiences I hear about constantly tempt me to get back on the road."

fields.headline: To whom it may concern...
fields.standfirst: Belinda Coote was awarded £200,000 after being refused a reference.  Kate Hilpern  on the legal options for those who think their employers are ruining their job prospects
fields.trailText: Anecdotal tales abound of insulting sendoffs given to workers when they ask their boss for a reference. "She got into the gene pool when the lifeguard wasn't looking"; "Joanna worked for me for three years. When she was sober, she was rude." Maliciousness on this scale is undoubtedly often apocryphal, but countless amusing and not so amusing examples are recorded on the internet and elsewhere to make anyone considering changing jobs think twice.
fields.body:
Anecdotal tales abound of insulting sendoffs given to workers when they ask their boss for a reference. "She got into the gene pool when the lifeguard wasn't looking"; "Joanna worked for me for three years. When she was sober, she was rude." Maliciousness on this scale is undoubtedly often apocryphal, but countless amusing and not so amusing examples are recorded on the internet and elsewhere to make anyone considering changing jobs think twice.

It is certainly not funny if you suspect that your employer is not going to be honest, measured, or generous when a prospective new boss phones for a reference. And employment law specialists say that in the past few years employers have been giving increasingly vicious responses when asked for their opinion of a staff-member's talents.

"The trend for people to be more honest in the workplace is starting to backfire," says occupational psychologist William Ricks. "Ten or even five years ago, managers became wary of saying anything frank about or to staff, fearing accusations of discrimination. Consequently, there was a trend to send them on courses such as 'How to bring emotion into the office' and 'How to use openness to motivate your team' while remaining politically correct. As a result, we have managers who are clued up on appropriate and inappropriate vocabulary, but who can't wait to give blatantly honest opinions whenever there's a chance."

And what better chance than writing a reference? It is one of those rare opportunities where what's written about an employee can be legally kept from them. Merciless employers say whatever they wish, in the belief that it will never be seen by the employee. Graham Spring hoped for a favourable reference from his employer, Guardian Assurance plc, when he was offered a job with another insurance firm. But his boss instead accused him of being disloyal, being disliked by staff, keeping the best jobs for himself and over-selling to boost his commission. His job offer was promptly withdrawn.

Even when the new data protection act comes into force next year, granting staff access to the majority of their employment records, they still won't be legally entitled to see references without the permission of the writer. In reality, workers often do find out the details of their assessment. "Either they are given a sealed envelope when they leave - which can be unsealed - or the prospective employer lets it slip," says Diane Sinclair, policy adviser to the Institute of Personnel and Development. "Perhaps they'll say, 'We were so thrilled at your boss's comments on your organisational skills that we can't wait for you to join.' Or, they might lament, 'We were shocked to find that you were suspected of stealing so we're withdrawing our offer.'"

By that stage it's a bit late if you think what has been said is unfair or untrue, although you can take legal action. Spring took his former bosses to court and won "substantial undisclosed damages", although the case went to the High Court and took four years to resolve. Belinda Coote, a manager at a London bowling complex, was awarded £200,000 compensation earlier this year when her boss refused to give her a reference after she had won a sex discrimination case against the company. The payout hit the headlines, but only £20,000 was for damage to her feelings, the remainder compensating for loss of earnings over six years.

Many employers who realise they're in the wrong are prepared to offer compensation before it reaches that stage. Michele Brenton, a graduate, received a £25,000 out-of-court settlement from Glamorgan University after a job offer was withdrawn by Monmouth borough council three days before she was due to start work. Council officials said her reference was unsatisfactory but refused to give details. She later discovered that the reference had questioned her "personal attitude and emotional state" and said her work was of a very low standard.

"Employees are queuing up to take legal action," says employment law specialist Laura Smith. "Judging from the number of PAs and secretaries doing so, it seems unfair references may be a particular problem among admin staff." She believes this is because of the high turnover of secretaries, and the fact that the job is far more responsible and multi-skilled than it used to be. "Managers often depend on their support staff far more than they mean to. When they are deserted by them, they may be left feeling foolish, aggrieved or vengeful."

Olga Aikin, an employment law specialist at the Aikin Driver Partnership, says a secretary's best hope of winning a case against an employer over a reference is to prove negligence. "Most people mistakenly assume they can sue for defamation - which is what celebrities sue newspapers for. But this is unlikely because the defence of 'qualified privilege' applies if referees believe the statements they make are true, even though these may be prejudiced and without foundation. Go for negligence, on the other hand, and you get the chance to win your case based on the fact that though they might believe what they said to be true, it isn't."

Employees may also have rights if their employer refuses to provide a reference. "This isn't always the case, but it's worth checking your contract to see if it is company policy to give one, or if your contract states that severance packages include the promise to provide a reference," says Aikin. "Finally, there may be a duty if membership of a regulatory organisation is involved."

Experience shows that your best bet is to put your boss on the spot when you resign, asking there and then if you can have a reference. If you haven't enjoyed your time with the company, be sure to resist the temptation to tell your boss where he can stick his job. When it comes to who should write it, where possible choose someone who you know likes both you and your work - and ask if they would allow you to have a peek. Careers adviser Alice Moore says this is particularly important since "some employers give bad references as a way of keeping treasured staff".

It's not only employers who get into deep water over references. When Sue Bryan, 24, from Hertfordshire, applied for a PA job five years ago, she faked her personal assessment and got caught. "I was fed up of getting rejections and became aware that I didn't have the experience required. I got carried away and concocted this story about how I took the boss's wife under my wing when she was having a nervous breakdown and showed my exceptional life-skills by preventing her from committing suicide. I guess I shouldn't be surprised that I was found out."

Moore claims that although this is an extreme example, admin staff are increasingly likely to fabricate references in today's tight job market. "It's partly for this reason that recruitment firms and employers are now very hot on checking references."

If you must exaggerate a little, save it for the interview, advises Judi James, author of The Office Jungle (HarperCollins, £5.99). "By no means do you have to be totally honest when job seeking, but don't do it in writing. An interview is a fairly false situation so that's your perfect chance. Your employer will no doubt colour the description of your job so I see no problem with colouring your description of you."

So severe are the repercussions of untrue references - whether written by employee or employer - that Aikin reckons we will see more cases reaching court over the next few years. It is a warning that the writer of a reference for an officer in the US Marines might want to ponder. It said, simply, "His men would follow him everywhere. But only out of curiosity."

fields.headline: Thank goodness it's Tuesday
fields.standfirst: It's bank holiday time again and  Dolly Dhingra  considers how workers spend their day off. Maybe they'll even be pleased to return to their desks
fields.trailText: So today is a bank holiday, which means one of two things. Either you are enjoying a lie-in, curled up under the duvet with a cup of coffee and the papers. Or, more likely, in a desperate bid to escape the dull routine of work, you have joined millions of others in a traffic jam on some motorway, heading for the coast.
fields.body:
So today is a bank holiday, which means one of two things. Either you are enjoying a lie-in, curled up under the duvet with a cup of coffee and the papers. Or, more likely, in a desperate bid to escape the dull routine of work, you have joined millions of others in a traffic jam on some motorway, heading for the coast.

Despite the objections of a few killjoys who believe bank holidays interrupt the nation's relentless drive for efficiency, they are fiercely guarded by the workforce. That extra day off which, for once, doesn't eat into one's holiday entitlement seems to send us all a little crazy.

How else to explain the fact that we determinedly head off to exactly the same place as everybody else? For hours on end families sit in cars on motorways stuffing their faces with far too many unhealthy snacks - to be exact, six bags of crisps, three sandwiches, six packets of sweets, two pies, half a dozen chocolate bars, a bag of chips and a kebab, according to a survey carried out by Autoglass.

Those unwilling to risk death by coronary or road-rage prefer instead to injure themselves in the pursuit of DIY. There is nothing like a bank holiday to persuade the non-dextrous to remodel the garden shed into a breakfast room or turn the living room into a lido, or the less ambitious to regrout the bathroom tiles. Home improvement stores reward loyalty by lining up customers in queues and playing tinkling lift music on loop. Rarely can Laurence Llwellyn-Bowen have been responsible for more psychic distress.

But the person really responsible is Queen Victoria. In 1871, the first bank holidays act designated five days off in Scotland and four in the rest of the UK (Christmas day and Good Friday were already traditional days of rest there and didn't need to be included). There are now eight statutory days a year in most of the UK, though this year the government kindly granted everyone an extra day in bed over the millennium weekend.

When the days should fall is a source of heated debate to some. This year, for instance, three bank holidays (Good Friday, Easter Monday and May day) will fall within 10 days, to be followed a few weeks later by the Spring bank holiday. Then nothing until the end of August, followed by a long wait until Christmas.

The May Day holiday commemorates an English tradition of May poles and Morris dancers, but for some it smacks too much of communism and tanks and flags in Red Square. And while the Northern Irish have an extra holiday for St Patrick's day (and another on July 12 to commemorate the Battle of the Boyne), the Scottish, Welsh and English have to celebrate their saints at their desks.

The Bank of England has argued that even these measly eight days threaten the nation's competitiveness, but others are keen to point out that many workers do not have the day off. The Co-operative bank has even argued for a change in name, stressing that for many bank workers, particularly in call centres, a "bank holiday" is no such thing.

These unfortunates can comfort themselves with the thought that while they are sitting inside earning time-and-a-half, the rest of us are probably having a miserable time. Bank holidays could convince the most trenchant atheist of the existence of a malevolent deity, laughingly directing stormclouds to Brighton beach at the very moment when lardy white Brits emerge from their winter woollies to expose inches of naked flesh to the elements.

The met office's prediction of today's weather was characteristically ambivalent: "There's not going to be a heatwave, but neither is it going to be dank and dismal." Which sounds about right. It's important that bank holidays should retain their reputation for crowded, drizzly misery - that's what will get you out of bed tomorrow morning remembering that, actually, you quite like work.
