fields.headline: The bug that didn't bite
fields.standfirst: Planes would fall out of the sky. There would be drought, famine, thousands of deaths and billions wiped off the markets. Only the millennium bug never happened. Was it fixed? Or were we suckered by an opportunistic computer industry? By  Andy Beckett
fields.trailText: Down in neatest Hampshire, just off junction 10 of the M27, where the plush coastal farms meet the executive homes of Fareham, there stands a shrine to the millennium bug.
fields.body:
Down in neatest Hampshire, just off junction 10 of the M27, where the plush coastal farms meet the executive homes of Fareham, there stands a shrine to the millennium bug.

It is a tall medieval barn, in dark brick and black timber, that has been refurbished and occupied by a computer software company. Greenwich Mean Time seems to have done well for itself: it has a car park full of sports cars and, inside, clocks telling the time in Tokyo and Johannesburg. In the company loos, there are brass-effect holders for the toilet roll.

Three years ago, Greenwich Mean Time began selling a £20 box of software called Check 2000. "In less than the time it takes to drink your coffee," its packaging promised, "Check 2000 flags and fixes year 2000 PC problems." It sold over 4 m copies. Versions were distributed in English, French, Italian, Spanish, German, Japanese, and Afrikaans. "We ended up selling more year 2000 checking tools," says Karl Feilder, the firm's founder, in the kind of exaggeratedly calm voice men use when showing off, "than anybody else in the world."

His barn is still full of bug memorabilia. There are newspaper warnings pinned to the walls, Check 2000 posters in the porch, Check 2000 boxes balanced on the office partitions, even scratched Check 2000 discs in service as coffee mats. A prediction from Feilder, given to a Canadian magazine in June 1999, still looms over the visitors' sofas: "In the first couple of days of January 2000, not much is going to happen, and probably the media will write stories about how it was all a hoax. But you'll get this cumulative data error. There certainly will be some companies that go broke, people will be redundant and inevitably some people will die."

Feilder, who is in his mid-30s and wears boots and jeans to work and looks a little like a chunkier, less uptight Michael Portillo, is still sticking to most of this. "There have been a lot of incidents," he says, "but the press have totally lost interest." Besides, he continues, "If those millions of people hadn't checked their PCs, there would have been serious problems." He leans back on one of the squashy sofas in his attic office, arms thrown out contentedly, the barn's roof beams behind him, his employees tapping at their keyboards below. At the end of last year, he says, he was so confident about his company's millennium medicine that he gave the whole Greenwich Mean Time staff 10 days off, and diverted all calls to his mobile phone. He only got 15: "none of them disastrous".

Since January, though, as the weeks have slipped undramatically by, Feilder and his fellow bug experts, many of them both entrepreneurs and advisors to governments, have lost some of their lustre. Their activities have begun to look rather contradictory and self-interested.

First, in the lead-up to 2000, they anticipated worldwide computer chaos, declaring that the new date would baffle the machines, and agreed to speculate on the consequences, in melodramatic detail, for the world's media. Next, they insisted loudly that heavy spending on software and technicians was the only way to avert a catastrophe. Then, as 2000 began, and planes failed to plunge from the sky, they maintained that the crisis had been real, but solved. And now, deep into the year, they are pre dicting that problems may continue after all, and that further vigilance and spending could be needed. Early this month, on the evening after the Stock Exchange's computers had collapsed, Feilder phoned me. "Has anyone asked the question about the millennium bug?", he said.

All this makes Anthony Finkelstein furious. He is professor of software systems engineering at University College London, and perhaps the leading millennium bug sceptic. He speaks with some vigour for an academic: "Being a prophet of doom is a low-risk occupation," he says. "If things go wrong, you are a prophet. If nothing happens, it's because you warned people... [But] the notion that panic is good for people - it's unprofessional. It's patronising. It's contemptible."

In truth, there have been bug incidents. The office for national statistics (ONS) counted 74 British companies, or 7% of its sample, with millennium problems in the first week of January. By the first week of February, 14 firms were still suffering. A weather centre in Aberdeen, a tide gauge in Portsmouth, the payroll of the German Opera - there have been enough odd glitches to fill a few newspaper round-ups. British manufacturing output unexpectedly fell by 0.4% in January, against the trend of recent months. And last December, amid a small shower of pre-millennial computer surprises, a "1900 bug" made an appearance as well. When Bedfordshire social services tried to track down any 100-year-olds in their care, their newly millennium- compatible computers refused to recognise the relevant date of birth.

None of this, however, adds up to global recession, or infrastructure collapse, or accidental nuclear war, as the most heated prophets were anticipating. The ONS has stopped its bug watch, weeks earlier than planned. Action 2000, the Government's millennium-alert agency, has been run down. They barely answer their phones now, and sound awkward when you ask what they still do. The bug has faded to an embarrassing period catchphrase.

Yet countering it, imaginary or otherwise, cost the British government £396m. The world spent between £150bn and £500bn - the variation between all the estimates seems itself to suggest out-of-control budgets. So do the vastly greater sums committed in Britain and Japan and the United States, probably the three countries most entranced by the power of computers, than in equally modern and complex societies such as Italy and France. The Italians and French have not suffered greater problems as a result.

Robin Guenier may be faintly dreading the day. He is a crisp pinstriped man of 63, with careers in computing, aerospace and law behind him, who, from the mid-90s until this January, was probably Britain's noisiest bug alarmist. These days, he plays it down: "It all seems a long time ago," he says, wearily waving his glasses and looking into the middle distance. "I think it's a very boring subject."

In 1997, he felt differently. "I do not want to seem irrational or a prophet of doom," he told the Mail on Sunday that January, "but there is a possibility of riots." He says now that the papers deliberately played up his every hypothetical: "A warning can easily be turned into a prediction_ There were people who were determined to make me into a doom-monger." But then he adds, "If I'd gone around saying, 'We'll probably get through this,' no one would have printed anything."

In fact, attention-seeking infected discussion of the bug from the very beginning. The first widely publicized article about millennium computer anxieties was published by ComputerWorld magazine in 1993. "Doomsday 2000" was by a Canadian called Peter de Jager, who has since diversified into bug videos, bug lectures and a bug cartoon book. "Have you ever been in a car accident?", read his opening sentence.

From there, the fears spread and multiplied. The first British newspaper story was in early 1996; in 1997, there were more than 300; in 1998, more than 2,500. The salaries of computer staff escalated over the same period: by an average of 6% in 1996 and 8% in 1997, according to the National Computing Centre, much steeper rises than earlier in the Nineties.

During the middle of that decade, Guenier had a grey-sounding job reorganising national computing policy for John Major's cabinet office. In early 1996, one of Guenier's subordinates came to him with an exotic-sounding warning. The millennium bug "sounded plausible": Guenier went to America to find out more, and returned as a memo-despatching foreteller of calamity. Very quickly, he says, "The Government regarded me as a guru." How did he actually convince them? He gives a mischevious look. "If you know a bit more about something than anyone else, and you speak with confidence_"

Feilder became interested in the millennium in 1996 too. He was living in South Africa, on the proceeds of a company he had sold to Microsoft the year before, riding motorbikes and trying to be a rock singer. He was bored. He knew from years as a programmer that a lot of computer products were "poor quality" - rushed into use and flawed. "There was bound to be a problem in the year 2000," he says now, smiling on his office sofa, as if it was the most obvious thing in the world. "It was just a question of finding it." That done, he devised "a desktop management product wrapped in the millennium bug" - Check 2000 - and prepared for all the attention.

He had media coaching. He bought memorable suits. And as his software became an international success, he "volunteered my services" to the governments of the countries it sold in. A virtuous circle, shared with Guenier (they are on first-name terms) was set in motion: official briefings, conference speeches, appearances in the press, dark predictions, invitations from everyone to come back again and answer any allegations of exaggeration. Both of them deny personal motives: Feilder maintains he kept advice and commerce separate; Guenier says that"the reason I got involved was that hundreds of thousands of ordinary people could have been affected". Yet their eyes glow when they remember all the meetings.

Finkelstein does not criticise individuals. Instead, he sees the bug panic as a symptom of our immaturity about technology generally. Businesses and the public are increasingly dependent on computers, but still understand little, he says, about how they work. Computer technicians everywhere are busily "empire building", and the bug gave them further justification - plus an ideal cover for any existing problems they had left unsolved. Meanwhile the government, under Major and Tony Blair, applied the lessons of unrelated past panics: "They'd been so badly bitten by mad cow," says Finkelstein, "that they decided that the political risk of over-reaction [to the bug] was less than the risk of under-reaction." And finally, the media saw in the millennium an absolutely delicious opportunity: "The bug wrote itself. It had technology. It had disaster. It had a time horizon. The year 2000 story was too good to check."

There have been some benefits. The Government, the likes of Guenier, and even Finkelstein, all agree that a certain amount of "spring cleaning" has been performed on the computer systems of the world. Perhaps a useful period of hostility towards silicon chips and self-confident computer experts has passed too. A culture of improvisation and exaggeration, however vigorous and growing in importance, has been exposed to plain view.

Down in Hampshire, Feilder is pondering a move out of computing. Greenwich Mean Time has new, non-millennial software to sell, but its staff is down to 50 from a peak of twice that during the bug countdown. On plane trips to its remaining overseas outposts, and in his attic office at weekends, Feilder wonders about going into the music business "like no one's done it before". He already has records by Deep Purple mounted on his walls. His press releases would make interesting reading.

fields.headline: William McHardy
fields.standfirst: Hebrew sholar and overseer of the Revised English Bible
fields.trailText: In 1970, after a 24-year gestation, the New English Bible was published. The Hebrew scholar, William McHardy, who has died aged 88, worked on its Old Testament translation and, from 1961, chaired the panel responsible for the Apocrypha, the most successful part of the project.
fields.body:
In 1970, after a 24-year gestation, the New English Bible was published. The Hebrew scholar, William McHardy, who has died aged 88, worked on its Old Testament translation and, from 1961, chaired the panel responsible for the Apocrypha, the most successful part of the project.

The translators of the Apocrypha (mainly in Greek) did not face so daunting a challenge as did the Old Testament panel. In the mid-20th century, there was a trend in scholarship, lead by McHardy's colleague and Oxford's professor of Semitic philology, Sir Godfrey Driver, to recover the lost meaning of Hebrew words by comparison with related Semitic languages, some of which had only recently been recovered by archeological discovery. It successfully illuminated many obscurities, but could be overplayed; the NEB Old Testament attracted criticism.

Who better then, than McHardy, Regius Professor of Hebrew at Oxford from 1960, to be director of the panel charged with revising the work, published in 1989 as the Revised English Bible? For 15 years, McHardy oversaw the revision. He kept a low profile, always allowing the experts to have their head, but maintained his influence. He was concerned for the readability of the text, and if this sometimes included a Scottish-sounding phrase, then Banffshire-born McHardy would have seen it as a positive contribution.

The REB deserves much wider recognition than it has attained. Its limited impact was partly because it followed so soon after the NEB, and partly because of the popularity of other translations from the same period.

McHardy was born and brought up in Cullen. Childhood polio left him permanently disabled, but the steady progress of his education took him to the local Fordyce Academy, and to Aberdeen University to read divinity.

He took his MA at Edinburgh and his doctorate at St John's College, Oxford. His thesis (never published) was on one Syriac translation of the Book of Ecclesiastes. Syriac is an Aramaic dialect and a major language of one part of the early Christian church. It remained an important aspect of McHardy's expertise, and the subject of some of his few published articles.

Syriac was the focus of his first academic appointments. In 1942, he became research fellow in Syriac and curator of the Mingana collection of manuscripts at the Selly Oak Colleges library in Birmingham. In 1945, he was appointed a lecturer in Aramaic and Syriac at Oxford. He was also, briefly, responsible for the Peshitta Project of the International Organisation for the Study of the Old Testament.

In 1948 he became London University's Samuel Davidson professor of Old Testament studies; 12 years later he became the first lay holder of the Oxford Regius professorship: he worked closely with Driver in the oriental studies faculty, and their collaboration became even closer through their work on the New English Bible.

McHardy also participated in the United Bible Societies' Hebrew Old Testament Text Project, which was chaired by the French scholar, Dominique Barthélemy. A small team of experts analysed some 5,000 difficult passages in the Hebrew Bible and offered advice to those translating the work into other languages. Although the resultant massive volumes appeared under Dr Barthélemy's name, each panellist had to evaluate every competing proposal for the solution of difficulties. The results are a valuable resource.

McHardy remained strongly attached to his birthplace, returning there in 1982, four years after his retirement. He lectured frequently on local history, and is said to have been more proud of the conferment of the title Burgess of the Royal Burgh of Cullen (1975) than of any honour which come his way. He was made a CBE in 1990.

In 1941 he had married Vera Kemp, who died in 1984. Thereafter, although he lived alone, he was cared for by his sisters. He is survived by his daughter, Alison, also an academic historian.

 William Duff McHardy, Hebrew scholar, born May 26 1911; died April 9, 2000

webTitle: Take a leaf out of Conqueror's book

fields.headline: Take a leaf out of Conqueror's book
fields.trailText: The jury is still out on whether Gordon Brown will prove to be Labour's best-ever chancellor. As Nigel Lawson could no doubt testify, opinions of treasury overlords can change and change rapidly, with today's brilliant exponent of economic management becoming tomorrow's scapegoat for failure.
fields.body:
The jury is still out on whether Gordon Brown will prove to be Labour's best-ever chancellor. As Nigel Lawson could no doubt testify, opinions of treasury overlords can change and change rapidly, with today's brilliant exponent of economic management becoming tomorrow's scapegoat for failure.

Certainly, there are the stirrings of an anti-Brown backlash in industry, where the feeling is that the chancellor is spending far too much time fiddling around with marginal tax rates and benefit schemes and too little on the growing imbalances in the economy caused by the over-valued pound.

Most of the arguments for and against Labour's economic strategy have been well rehearsed, and Easter Monday is perhaps not the best time to repeat them. Instead, courtesy of the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, let's see what the economy of England was like when the Domesday Book was compiled more than 900 years ago.

We can do this because the Australian economist Jim McDonald has written a paper for the institute's latest review on the English economy early in the second millennium. Studying the Domesday Book returns for Essex, he found there was a William de Warene, an Aubrey de Ver and a Peter de Valognes but no Gordon le Bruin, which may have been Duke William's loss because the economy of 11th century England was riddled with the sort of structural rigidities that the present chancellor wants to eradicate.

William was a big-picture man. He came over in 1066, stuffed Harold at the Battle of Hastings, culled the Saxon nobility, built a string of castles to defend his kingdom, and parcelled up small bits of land owned by the English to hand out in big chunks to his lords.

They were then left to get on with running them - before McKinsey consultants provided expensive advice - as they saw fit. Had there been an International Monetary Fund in 1086, William would no doubt have told it that his tough early action against the Keynesian Anglo-Saxons had abolished the boom-bust cycle and created a platform for long-term growth. Now it was up to risk-takers and entrepreneurs to make the most of the wealth-making opportunities.

As with Labour in 1997, the economy William inherited was in pretty good shape. According to McDonald, England was one of the wealthiest countries in northern Europe with an economy based on agriculture, wool and fisheries. The administrative infrastructure was sound and there was an effective taxation system.

The Robin Hood tales have given the impression that tax after the conquest was arbitrary, with kings extorting from downtrodden peasantry or feudal lords whatever sums they happened to feel like levying and paying no attention to ability to pay. Modern studies of the Domesday Book have suggested that this image may be entirely false and that the taxation system in the 11th century was economically rational, with assessments closely related to income and resources of the manors.

One economic historian, Graeme Snooks, compares Saxon and Norman systems of taxation favourably to Mrs Thatcher's poll tax debacle, saying that the one was an example of an absolute monarch grappling with the political and economic realities of his time, while the other was irrational and inequitable.

Although the economy of Norman England was feudal and manorial, Snooks says that there was a vigorous market sector and up to 24% of GDP was exported - not that different from the 30% of today.

With a labourer on 2d (0.8p) a day, there was no need for the 11th century equivalent of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to worry about growth in earnings. Snooks says that growth between 1000 and 1200 reached 0.6% - higher than the 0.4% to 0.5% per annum in the first 50 years of the industrial revolution. In the days before mechanisation, this was a pretty creditable performance.

Perfect territory

But, according to McDonald, it could have been a whole lot better. As somone no doubt said at the time, England had some world-class feudal demesnes but a long tail of under-achievers, where productivity was poor, the labour market was inflexible and policies for education and training were straight out of the Dark Ages. Perfect territory for a Gordon le Bruin and his henchman Edward de Balls.

England was not simply a subsistence economy at this time, with feudal lords needing to generate a surplus both to pay taxes and so that they could trade their surplus agricultural produce for tools, military hardware, lead, glass, textiles and fine clothing. But the model McDonald has constructed using data in the Domesday Book found huge disparities across estates in Essex.

The study assumes that 11th century production was characterised by constant returns to scale - that is if one plough team resulted in one unit of output, two plough teams would mean two units of output.

Under McDonald's calculations, estates are measured against those on the frontier of what was possible, given an efficiency measure of 1. Measures ranged from 0.159 for Paglesham, an estate of Robert Corbutio in the hundred of Rochford, to a perfect 1 for 96 estates; 25% of estates had an efficiency measure of 0.435 or less, the median value was 0.625, and 25% had a measure of 0.861 or better. Mean efficiency was 0.643.

This makes it sound as though 11th century production was woefully inefficient. In fact, it compares favourably with other more recent studies of cotton plantations in the American South after the civil war and of Californian fruit growers in the 1970s.

"Statistical tests showed that efficiency values vary significantly with the tenant-in-chief, supporting the idea that such chiefs operated their estates at different efficiency levels according to their entrepreneurial flair," McDonald said.

The results showed that larger estates tended to operate closer to the frontier and those specialising in grazing livestock were also more efficient. But factor markets were poorly developed, there were few opportunities for substitution of capital, labour and land inputs, and the marginal productivity of an extra unit of labour could be zero.

"If the productivity of villeins was higher on one estate than another, there was potential to increase total output by increasing use of villeins on the more productive estate and reducing use on the less productive estate." McDonald estimates that, if input factors had been mobile, an increase in total net output of 40% would have been possible.

So what conclusions can we draw from this? First, some problems never go away. Second, markets were probably better developed in the 11th century than generally believed. Third, if there is not a document in the public records office somewhere saying that the centre-left government of William the Conqueror has eschewed both tax-and-spend policies and laissez-faire in favour of a long-term effort to close England's productivity gap with its main rivals, there should be.

fields.headline: Worm's eye
fields.trailText: We are about due for another of those reports from one or other free market think-tank - it has been at least a fortnight since the last - evoking the "rich tapestry of voluntary provision" that supposedly preceded the establishment of the national health service and touting a revival of such arrangements as the "answer" to the current "crisis" in health economics.
fields.body:
We are about due for another of those reports from one or other free market think-tank - it has been at least a fortnight since the last - evoking the "rich tapestry of voluntary provision" that supposedly preceded the establishment of the national health service and touting a revival of such arrangements as the "answer" to the current "crisis" in health economics.

This "rich tapestry" theory was pretty well unheard of before the mid-1980s, but that may well be because it was an idea whose time could come only when the reality was moving rapidly towards the horizon of living memory.

Happily, by an accident of birth, I am able to make a small contribution of my own to keeping alive the "rich tapestry" of pre-NHS days as it was rather than as it is claimed to have been.

My grandfather, the late Dr RN Curnow, served as medical officer of health for Cornwall from 1939 to 1963. On his retirement, he was interviewed by the Western Morning News and the talk turned to the "service" as it had been on the eve of war.

"I found... that the West Cornwall Hospital at Penzance, a general hospital consisting of about 100 beds providing a wide range of medical and surgical treatment, had a completely untrained and unqualified staff - including even the theatre sister. The matron was the only qualified nurse in the place."

Nor was maternity care much better; every mother at the Redruth Hospital had been infected with puerperal fever and Dr Curnow had to shut the unit entirely to prevent further infection.

Not that the feverish mothers would have got much change out of the county's fever hospitals. "They were shocking. One, I remember well, was a red tin hut in the middle of a field. The caretaker and his wife - both unqualified - were the only staff.

"At another I was horrified on going into the bathroom, to find dirty clothes in the bath and bedpans on a form beside the bath and, at the other end of the form, cups and saucers."

As for the so-called "rich tapestry" of the county ambulance service, horse-drawn vehicles, with the horse borrowed from the local butcher, supplied the main medical transport in Camborne-Redruth with similar arrangements in Falmouth.

The interviewer, writing 24 years later, concluded: "Public health conditions in Cornwall had to be seen to be believed."

Mr grandfather took a modest view of his achievements: "When you come to a service in the condition this one was [in], anything one did was bound to be an improvement.

"I couldn't really go wrong."

No, quite.

fields.headline: Scoot picks up Loot for £200m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, is expected to complete the £200m acquisition of Loot, the classified advertising newspaper, by June.
fields.body:
Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, is expected to complete the £200m acquisition of Loot, the classified advertising newspaper, by June.

Vivendi, Scoot.com's major shareholder with 11.5%, will finance the entire deal in return for further equity in Scoot that could possibly see it increase its shareholding to 22%, sources close to the bid said.

New stock issued to Vivendi would have to be at a premium to the level at which Scoot shares are now trading - 157p last week, less than half the year's high of 374p.

Scoot.com is said to have outmanoeuvred QXL and Freeserve in its negotiations with Loot, a privately owned company, and secured an exclusive negotiating contract.

Robert Bonnier, chief executive of Scoot.com who owns 8.32% of the company, said of the bid yesterday: "I'm not prepared to comment on it."

Scoot.com is keen to snare Loot because that would give it significant revenue acceleration. Mr Bonnier has predicted the company can grow to 2m transactions daily across Europe generating £1.50 per transaction by 2005.

To achieve this sales target Scoot.com would have to grow by129% annually for five years. The acquisition of Loot would propel it towards this target.

Loot was put on the market by founder and owner David Landau after being informed by investment banks what the value of the company's internet operation was worth.

The internet business, said to be Britain's tenth most visited site, could potentially be valued at almost seven times the Loot newspaper operation. Loot's website boasted 153,538 online ads yesterday with total value of the goods it was selling estimated at £405m.

Loot, which counts Lord Saatchi and Lord Rothschild as directors, also has operations in New York, Ireland, India and Pakistan.

On Friday Scoot.com will re launch its service, intending to deliver a more user-friendly interface. This will include an improved search system and users will be able to ask for a quote for a service and make online reservations.

Scoot.com already has a joint venture with Vivendi to expand the online directory's number of subscribers across Europe. Vivendi owns 65% of this business.

Broker SG Cowen has a 12-month share target of 575p for Scoot, based on the joint venture expanding to France in September, and Germany and Italy by December.

Scoot.com is expected to report a loss of £43m this year compared with £20m in 1999.

 The office of fair trading is reported to be ready to meet management of the John Lewis department stores to discuss the group's claim that Dixons is stifling competition in the home computer market.

Earlier this month the OFT appeared to reject John Lewis's claims of anti-competitive behaviour by Dixons and the department store group subsequently threatened legal action.

The allegations centre on Dixons' exclusive deals with suppliers. These mean that many Compaq and Packard Bell computers, two of the leading high street brands, will no longer be sold by John Lewis or other retailers.

webTitle: Lib Dems attack chancellor over 'failing' poverty policy

fields.headline: Lib Dems attack chancellor over 'failing' poverty policy
fields.standfirst: Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's local election campaign suffered a setback yesterday when new research showed Gordon Brown's flagship initiatives to tackle poverty were failing to bridge the gap between rich and poor.
fields.body:
Labour's local election campaign suffered a setback yesterday when new research showed Gordon Brown's flagship initiatives to tackle poverty were failing to bridge the gap between rich and poor.

With just over a week until polling, the Liberal Democrats attempted to win over Labour's traditional supporters by claiming three key measures introduced by the chancellor would never reverse inequalities of wealth. The Lib Dems claimed that:

 The minimum wage, hailed as one of Labour's greatest achievements, has mainly benefited middle income households.

 The working families tax credit, which tops up the pay of the less well off directly through their pay packet, has increased incomes for the less well by a "modest" 1.5%.

 The 10p rate of income tax was "largely irrelevant for the poorest households" because they pay little or no tax.

Steve Webb, Lib Dem social security spokesman, said: "Gordon Brown's fig leaf policies cannot hide the naked truth that Labour is failing to heal the divisions in Britain today."

Labour described the claims as nonsense.

"The working families tax credit is making over 1m families £20 a week on average better off. Along with the minimum wage and the 10p starting rate, this has helped 800,000 more people into work," a spokesman said.

webTitle: West Bank houses burn as peace talks loom

fields.headline: West Bank houses burn as peace talks loom
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli troops razed several houses on a rocky slope in the West Bank yesterday morning, ending an unofficial ban on house demolitions only hours before King Abdullah of Jordan piloted his yacht across the Gulf of Aqaba to urge a just peace for the Palestinians.
fields.body:
Israeli troops razed several houses on a rocky slope in the West Bank yesterday morning, ending an unofficial ban on house demolitions only hours before King Abdullah of Jordan piloted his yacht across the Gulf of Aqaba to urge a just peace for the Palestinians.

The demolitions, the first since last August, were undertaken after a flurry of diplomatic activity intended to prod the peace process back to life when the negotiations resume next week.

King Abdullah joined the chorus of world leaders trying to salvage the talks. Standing at the helm of his yacht, beside his Palestinian wife, Queen Rania, he said he hoped Israel would make peace with the Palestinians in the coming months.

"I am very hopeful that this year will witness a breakthrough that will give hope to the Palestinians and the justice they seek and to the Israeli people the security that they desire," he said.

The four-hour visit to Eilat was Abdullah's first visit to Israel since coming to the throne 14 months ago. The venue, and the brevity of the encounter - which ended an hour earlier than planned - indicates his unease with the high-profile role of his late father, King Hussein, as a peacemaker.

As the demolitions at Issawiyah underlined, the next stage of the negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians, will be especially difficult. Since they are expected to focus on the future status of Jerusalem, settlements and borders, every inch of land becomes contested territory - especially if, like Issawiyah, it lies within easy reach of the holy city.

Three of the homes had been demolished a few days ago, and the villagers had begun work to rebuild them when the soldiers descended before dawn yesterday.

Standing in the wreckage of the six demolished houses,on a slope opposite their original village, the thwarted builders said they were the victims of an Israeli land policy intended to enrich nearby settlements at the expense of Palestinian villages.

"They want to take 3,684 dunams [360 hectares] from our land of Issawiyah, and they want to give it to the settlement of Maale Adumim," said Imam Riyad Issawi, the village preacher. "But inside our village, it is so crowded. We do not have more than 2 sq metres per person."

Issawiyah's outlying fields were expropriated by the Israeli authorities after the 1967 war, leaving the village little room to grow. With the deadline for a Palestinian state looming later this year, local people are trying to reclaim the seized land for fear of losing it for ever when the new borders are drawn. According to the Israeli maps, the rocky hills are to be part of the settlement of Maale Adumim, where urban planners are hoping to build hotels and leisure facilities.

To Yusuf Dari, however, his act of defiance has less to do with politics than sheer necessity. The father of 10, he lives with his family in a one-bedroom house in the original village. Denied a building permit by the Israeli authorities, he said he has no choice but to build.

"There are just not enough houses for everyone in the old village. If we do not do it today, we would have to do it five years from now.

"We have to find a way to breathe somehow."

fields.headline: Vote Frank for car parks
fields.standfirst: Labour desperately needs cheap housing and more green space. It's a shame that no one seems to have told Blair's candidate for London mayor says Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Labour desperately needs cheap housing and more green space. It's a shame that no one seems to have told Blair's candidate for London mayor says Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
Poor old Frank Dobson. Perhaps because he works for London "24 hours a day" (even Stalin, Hitler and Thatcher managed at least four hours' sleep a day) and spends too much time "rolling up his sleeves" (a nervous tic?), he appears unable to see London as the great city it is. Why do I say that? Because he has looked at a megalomaniacal retail and leisure development planned for west London and proclaimed: "This is exactly the type of scheme that I would seek to promote as mayor."

God help London if Dobbo is elected to fulfil that terrible pledge. The development in question, White City, beside the M41, will fill an area the size of almost 40 football pitches with chain stores, supermarkets and a giant car park, rather than parkland and much-needed housing. It will be "one of the largest traffic-generating developments ever proposed for London," according to the Council for the Protection of Rural England.

To date, White City has found favour only with its promoters, the property company Chelsfield and London Underground, with local estate agents who see it as a shot in the arm for house prices, and with fawning architectural writers who wish, presumably, to keep in the good books of Elliot Bernard. Bernard is chairman of both Chelsfield and of the South Bank Centre, where he is promoting a much-needed redevelopment. He is also working with Lord Rothschild to enable James Turrell, the world's greatest light artist, to practise his magic along a significant stretch of the Thames.

All of London's other main mayoral candidates have taken against the £1bn White City project, which is due to be completed in 2002. "The idea that in inner London you create a bloody great magnet for cars is totally opposed to everything we're trying to do in London," says Ken Livingstone. "White City," says Steven Norris, "is an example of how not to do it. It makes massive provision for increasing traffic and provides only a few homes [65 in its 40 acres, according to Dobbo; 42 according to everyone else]." "It's completely out of scale and a threat to local communities," says Susan Kramer.

"The government says it wants 60% of new housing built on brownfield land," points out Richard Bourn, director of the CPRE's London branch. "Instead of badly needed homes, this will provide 4,500 parking spaces. This is not regeneration; it is a recipe for urban degeneration. John Prescott, secretary of state for the environment, transport and the regions, must bow to the wishes of the mayoral candidates and order a public inquiry into the White City development."

Strong words, but wise ones. So what is it that so attracts Dobbo to this decidedly retro shopping, leisure and parking development? Perhaps it is the Ali G factor. Last year the comedian visited Sydenham in south London, where a horrid new Crystal Palace is under construction against the wishes of local people and just about every environmental concern going. The flashy new building, however, is home to a multiplex with a wicked sound system. Or something. Ali G, on a mission to learn about the environment and stuff, found himself more excited by the promise of mega sound systems. Respect.

This was a nice bit of satire. Presumably, however, Dobbo is genuinely thrilled by the idea of a new multiplex (remember the yoof vote, innit), a giant car park and the usual offering of big chain shops such as Sainsbury's and Marks & Spencer. Meanwhile, the inner-city borough where the whole thing will sit, Hammersmith & Fulham, admits to needing 100,000 new homes.

The White City site once housed the long-forgotten 1908 Franco-British exhibition, some of whose buildings have survived and are used as tennis courts and hostels for incontinent pigeons. No one concerned, and certainly not the CPRE, believes that this urban wasteland should be left undeveloped. On the contrary, here is a chance to build a brand-new bit of real city. A chance to redeem the sin of the M41, the motorway that sliced through North Kensington 30 years or so ago, dividing a community so that motorists could drive at 70mph (50mph today) the half mile between the elevated A40(M) or "Westway" and the snarl-ups at Shepherd's Bush roundabout.

This is an opportunity to connect Old Oak Common and Wormwood Scrubs to Shepherd's Bush along what could become a superb new green corridor set about with new homes for everyone, the finest new public buildings imaginable by the world's best architects, as well as entertainment and some useful shops. With a new tram line, improved public transport generally, a lake perhaps, an ice-rink, tennis courts, nurseries_ There's enough land here, and certainly enough money sloshing through London, to make such a new quarter of the capital possible. It would make economic and cultural mincemeat of the half-hearted Millennium Village in the wind-swept Greenwich peninsula.

Instead we have one megastructure - a giant car park bearing a concatenation of whizzy shops, multiplex, bowling alley, "winter garden" and other attractions that those who design and pay for the new-look White City would probably never use themselves. Why do we allow this to happen to our cities? Dobbo gives us that most hackneyed of answers. It's worth plonking down Son of Brent Cross here in London's streaming roar, worth the 64,000 extra car journeys a day it will generate at its peak, worth the aesthetic insult because, in Dobbo's words (check his website), it will "secure over 5,000 new jobs". What sort of jobs? Stacking shelves in superstores? Selling burgers in multiplex cafes? Operating the car park barrier?

The scheme dates from the mid-90s. In its earliest phase it was a crude device; more recently, the architect Ian Ritchie was brought in to do a number on the project, to make it shine in the public eye. This is the same Ian Ritchie who has designed the new Crystal Palace given respect by Ali G. Whether it is the same architect who talked so eloquently about ecologically friendly design in the past, I do not wish to find out. The idea, however, that architects with a good eye can still be brought in to spin an unsupportable development beggars belief. Their talent needs to be harnessed to intelligent new city-making, which is not the same thing as dragging Brent Cross, Thurrock and Bluewater - car-generated schemes all - into the centre of our cities when we are trying to make them more civilised places to live.

It seems doubly sad that Cabe, the government's new Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment, has had nothing to say about White City; nor has the Architecture Foundation chaired by Lord Rogers, whose Urban Task Force report last year took exception to just such developments. London has some of the finest architects in the world. It has staggering amounts of investment money. It needs affordable new homes - not patronising Toy Town stuff - and better public transport. And if it needs more places for the "leisure" we are obsessed with, why not lakes and parks as well as the cinemas and sports venues?

Like its greatest political supporter, the White City development as it stands is a tarted-up anachronism, a Ford Cortina dressed up as a Mondeo. To give the government back a bit of street cred on architectural and urban planning matters, John Prescott needs to call the White City scheme in and encourage the developers to invest their money in a major project that will do Londoners proud and act as a precedent for urban development elsewhere in the country. What he can't afford to do is sleep on it.

webTitle: Don't get emotive on asylum - archbishop

fields.headline: Don't get emotive on asylum - archbishop
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Westminster yesterday stepped into the row over asylum seekers by urging politicians to refrain from using emotive language when dealing with the issue.
fields.body:
The Archbishop of Westminster yesterday stepped into the row over asylum seekers by urging politicians to refrain from using emotive language when dealing with the issue.

Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, leader of Roman Catholics in England and Wales, called on all three major parties to agree not to make refugees a party political football.

The archbishop spoke out after a week in which Conservative leader William Hague announced he would intern all asylum seekers in detention camps until their applications had been reviewed. The proposals were calculated to make the issue part of the Tory campaign in the run-up to the local elections.

Last week senior Tory backbencher Ian Taylor warned that his party's leadership was running the risk of inadvertently unleashing forces of animosity toward ethnic minorities by making asylum a campaign issue.

Talking to GMTV's Sunday Programme yesterday about the use of such phrases as "bogus" and "floods of asylum seekers", the archbishop said: "I am not happy with the use of language that is what I would call emotive, because I think on this particular subject, which is so sensitive, especially for those who are actually coming into this country, that we need to look at the thing very objectively.

"I know there are many people who are seeking asylum who have come from very tragic circumstances, and I would like to think that this is a country that can open its doors a little bit to them, but I do appreciate that it can only be done within certain limits. What can be done with realism and generosity should be done."

He continued: "I would deprecate emotive language to demonise each other. It is something that should be cross-party, that all three parties should concur with, and not try to make political points."

The archbishop's stand was backed by the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes, who earlier this month reported both the Tories and Labour to the Commission for Racial Equality over comments on asylum.

He told the Sunday Programme: "I think it is very significant. He is the most senior figure to have made this sort of call."

The shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe, a Roman Catholic, said: "I agree with the Archbishop of Westminster that we don't want to use emotive language designed to demonise, but that is a world away from the sort of frank discussions which have taken place."

The archbishop's remarks came before he preached an Easter Sunday sermon at Westminster Cathedral in which he urged Roman Catholics not to lose heart in a bustling and secular world.

"If we Christians find that the world around us is becoming so secular, so pagan, so unreligious, it is our duty to do as St Peter told the Christians of the early church, 'Do not be afraid or disturbed at their threats, but enthrone Christ as Lord in your hearts'," he said.

His message was reinforced by the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, who warned in his Easter Day sermon that the seductive values of power, success, fame and money should never blind people to the important things in life.

Dr Carey branded such values as "transitory, paltry things" associated with our "dot.com society" and urged people to look to spiritual values for guidance.

He went on: "Our country and her children must be rooted in these truths of the Easter faith - in the love of God and his personal and passionate commitment for each one of us. If not we shall mistake the temporal for the real world and suffer terribly as a result."

webTitle: Close encounter of a third way kind

fields.headline: Close encounter of a third way kind
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: If their ardour had taken a firmer hold, Tony Blair might never have set foot inside Downing Street and instead have ended up in Hollywood.
fields.body:
If their ardour had taken a firmer hold, Tony Blair might never have set foot inside Downing Street and instead have ended up in Hollywood.

A slightly out of focus photo which shows the future prime minister with his then girlfriend Mary Harron has been discovered. The picture of Mr Blair, with flowing locks, and Ms Harron was taken while they were undergraduates at St John's College, Oxford, in the early 1970s.

She went on to direct the movie American Pyscho, which has just opened in Britain. The film version of Bret Easton Ellis's novel depicts a yuppie who goes on a killing spree.

For a time they sought to find their own third way, but their relationship foundered.

Details are scarce but Ms Harron, interviewed by Jon Sopel for his 1995 biography of Mr Blair, remembered the Labour leader with fondness.

Even 25 years ago Mr Blair's charm was well-developed. "Even before he became an MP and famous I always thought of Tony as the only 'nice' person that I ever went out with at Oxford," said Ms Harron, now 46.

"He was very good looking in a kind of sweet way, and wasn't at all predatory. He was very different from most of the guys I knew, but I guess I fell for him because he was cute."

She also revealed that Mr Blair did not arrive at Oxford with a craving for high office. "He didn't seem terribly ambitious, and certainly wasn't one of those trying to cut a dash in the political arena."

Mr Blair read law at Oxford, and started his course in 1972 after taking a year out between school and university, during which he worked as a barman in Paris.

Mr Sopel's book says that Mr Blair's university days saw him date a string of women.

Ms Harron is described as "one of the more intellectual students whom he went out with".

The future prime minister's love life saw him being hauled up before the college authorities. They suspected Mr Blair had broken rules on how late a woman could stay in a male student's room, prompted by the discovery of a lipstick.

When challenged Mr Blair said "Oh that's mine", and the issue was defused.

Asked yesterday if the prime minister would be going to see American Psycho, a Downing Street spokeswoman said: "I have absolutely no idea."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Batman
fields.body:
Batman

8.30am, Granada Plus

Biff! Bang! Pow! Essential viewing, despite the early morning slot. A psychedelic melange of on-screen cartoon exclamations, gloriously ridiculous effects and great dialogue that's a long way from Kane's original vision, Adam West and Burt Ward are still for many the definitive interpretation of the camp crusaders. First guest star is Frank Gorshin, one of the more helpful crooks in Gotham's rogue's gallery - it's not every criminal whose aim is to commit a crime and leave a clue. Still one of the best shows ever.

Richard Vine

Kes

(Ken Loach, 1969)

8pm, FilmFour

Ken Loach's early feature is bleak but uplifting. David Bradley is a scrawny, soulful, loveable Billy, clipped and clouted by family and teachers, learning life's bitter truths. Sounds grim, but it's beautifully shot by Chris Menges and is very funny. Brian Glover's sports master, shrugging hapless pupils aside in ludicrous imitation of Bobby Charlton, is unforgettable.

Scandal

(Michael Caton-Jones, 1989)

10pm, Living

Political sleaze on the grand, grubby scale: the story of the Profumo affair in 1963, when the war minister's involvement with showgirl Christine Keeler helped bring down a Conservative government. Strong on period detail, restrained on bedroom capers, it's perhaps duller than it should be. But John Hurt as Stephen Ward, who made the introductions and carried the can, and Joanne Whalley-Kilmer as a frail Keeler, are outstanding.

Halloween H20

(Steve Miner, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

Twenty years on from John Carpenter's original Halloween, Jamie Lee Curtis's Laurie, survivor of the encounter with Michael Myers, is now a twitchy, alcoholic single mum with a teenager of her own. It's only a matter of time before Myers returns to his dirty work, and Miner has fun with several false starts before Laurie realises he's not a figment of her imagination.

Paul Howlett

fields.headline: Naughty but nice
fields.standfirst: Terry Johnson's racy drama about the bizarre off-screen antics of the Carry On stars makes its television debut tonight.  Mark Lawson reckons ITV has got its hands on something big
fields.trailText: The novels of the late RF Delderfield (1912-1973) occasionally turn up on jumble sale book tables. Best known is A Horseman Riding By, a Sunday night classic serial of the past. Delderfield called his autobiography For My Own Amusement, but few perhaps now appreciate - his novels scarcely being comic - the scale of the contribution he made to the national laughter.
fields.body:
The novels of the late RF Delderfield (1912-1973) occasionally turn up on jumble sale book tables. Best known is A Horseman Riding By, a Sunday night classic serial of the past. Delderfield called his autobiography For My Own Amusement, but few perhaps now appreciate - his novels scarcely being comic - the scale of the contribution he made to the national laughter.

Delderfield wrote a play called The Bully Boys which, in 1958, was turned into a film by Gerald Rogers. The producer changed the title to Carry On Sergeant. Viewers of the subsequent 28 movies in the series wouldn't realise that the recurring title words hadn't originally been a saucy pun but a piece of army jargon. This was intended as a one-off project, and the little-known actors Kenneth Williams, Kenneth Connor and Charles Hawtrey were retained on a single contract. Yet for 20 years or so these movies would more or less constitute the British film industry.

The words Carry On indicated a sense of momentum, but there came a point in the 70s when there was doubt about how long the jokes and the actors could keep going. This dying of the laughter is the subject of a television drama, Cor Blimey! (tonight, 9pm, ITV), written and directed by Terry Johnson, which catches Sid James, Kenneth Williams and Barbara Windsor off-camera on film sets from the series over 14 years.

The two-hour piece is adapted from Johnson's 1988 National Theatre hit Cleo, Camping, Emanuelle and Dick, a title - derived from a quiz clue about Carry On films - which has been judged either too rude or too subtle for the ITV audience. Johnson is becoming culture's creative middleman between theatre and the screen. He has just put the movie The Graduate on the West End stage, starring Kathleen Turner, and he has written another stage play - Dead Funny - based around the deaths of Frankie Howerd and Benny Hill.

Cor Blimey! - bringing the Carry On movies to television via the stage - is his most complicated mixed-media installation yet, but it succeeds triumphantly. The key decision in theatre-to-screen transfers is the extent of what's known as "opening out". As when extending a building, the risk is that you wreck the architecture. But Johnson understands how differently material needs to be shaped for theatre's rectangle of open air and television's oblong of glass.

On stage, the piece was a farce, its explosions depending on the enclosed space of Sid James's caravan at Pinewood Studios. On television, the external news brought back in speeches - the Carry On stage show in London, James's death on stage in a play in Sunderland, Windsor's attempt at Shakespeare in Chichester - is dramatised, adding to the biographical weight of the depiction.

A film-set moment jokily referred to by Windsor on stage - the diffi culty of redubbing the word "buttocks" as "bottom" for the censor - benefits from the close-up to become a smart visual gag. And a play driven by the affair between James and Windsor gains from an on-camera scene in which, as they struggle to resist each other, they are required to snog in Carry On England. The one serious theatrical miscalculation - the final scene re-appearance of James as a ghost - is sensibly excised for TV. A writer once described self-editing as doing root-canal surgery on yourself. Johnson has the emotional Novocaine to do it.

The biggest risk was that a show which so depended on convincing lookalikes would be exposed on television. An actor who seemed a ringer from Row P might easily appear an impostor from 12 feet in the living room. In fact James (Geoffrey Hutchings), Windsor (Samantha Spiro) and Williams (Adam Godley) are uncannily exact in accent and mannerisms. Oddly - but appropriately - each of the central Carry On trio had a distinctive laugh: James's cackle, Windsor's giggle, Williams' snort. Here, used in almost musical counterpoint, they lead to amazing pairs of tittering, as the Carry On scriptwriter Talbot Rothwell might have put it.

But, impressive though the impressions are, this would merely be Madame Tussaud's broadcasting were it not for the depth and intelligence of Johnson's script. Johnson's own smut is more adult than Rothwell's. There's a running gag about cunnilingus which, 10 years ago, would have had ITV in it up to its neck. Oooh, there I go again.

The real power, however, is in the characterisations. The grim inner life of the publicly grinning comic is a cliche of fiction, but Cor Blimey! is much more complex about the relationship between stars and parts. These actors are not the opposite of their off-screen personae but - more interestingly - a darker and more dangerous version of the same. James suffers the pain and frustration of really being the reckless lecher he plays effortlessly on screen. Williams, master of the bottom gag, is a martyr to anal ailments. Windsor, whose Carry On persona involved not fully understanding the consequences of what she did or said, ignores for as long as possible the fact that her marriage to Ronnie Knight has made her a gangster's moll.

I mentioned here recently the increased use of what might be called website programming: the placing of related shows in the schedules like arrows leading from pages in cyberspace. ITV does the obvious thing of following Johnson's play with Carry On Cleo.

And it's a tribute to the visual illusion and imaginative empathy of Cor Blimey! that it will easily survive this proximity with the original. One of the best stage plays of the 1990s has become one of this year's TV highlights. As Sid, Kenny and Barbara might have put it, ITV has pulled out the big one and forced it down the BBC's throat.

(tonight, 9pm, ITV), written and directed by Terry Johnson, which catches Sid James, Kenneth Williams and Barbara Windsor off-camera on film sets from the series over 14 years. The two-hour piece is adapted from Johnson's 1988 National Theatre hit Cleo, Camping, Emanuelle and Dick, a title - derived from a quiz clue about Carry On films - which has been judged either too rude or too subtle for the ITV audience. Johnson is becoming culture's creative middleman between theatre and the screen. He has just put the movie The Graduate on the West End stage, starring Kathleen Turner, and he has written another stage play - Dead Funny - based around the deaths of Frankie Howerd and Benny Hill. Cor Blimey! - bringing the Carry On movies to television via the stage - is his most complicated mixed-media installation yet, but it succeeds triumphantly. The key decision in theatre-to-screen transfers is the extent of what's known as "opening out". As when extending a building, the risk is that you wreck the architecture. But Johnson understands how differently material needs to be shaped for theatre's rectangle of open air and television's oblong of glass. On stage, the piece was a farce, its explosions depending on the enclosed space of Sid James's caravan at Pinewood Studios. On television, the external news brought back in speeches - the Carry On stage show in London, James's death on stage in a play in Sunderland, Windsor's attempt at Shakespeare in Chichester - is dramatised, adding to the biographical weight of the depiction. A film-set moment jokily referred to by Windsor on stage - the diffi culty of redubbing the word "buttocks" as "bottom" for the censor - benefits from the close-up to become a smart visual gag. And a play driven by the affair between James and Windsor gains from an on-camera scene in which, as they struggle to resist each other, they are required to snog in Carry On England. The one serious theatrical miscalculation - the final scene re-appearance of James as a ghost - is sensibly excised for TV. A writer once described self-editing as doing root-canal surgery on yourself. Johnson has the emotional Novocaine to do it. The biggest risk was that a show which so depended on convincing lookalikes would be exposed on television. An actor who seemed a ringer from Row P might easily appear an impostor from 12 feet in the living room. In fact James (Geoffrey Hutchings), Windsor (Samantha Spiro) and Williams (Adam Godley) are uncannily exact in accent and mannerisms. Oddly - but appropriately - each of the central Carry On trio had a distinctive laugh: James's cackle, Windsor's giggle, Williams' snort. Here, used in almost musical counterpoint, they lead to amazing pairs of tittering, as the Carry On scriptwriter Talbot Rothwell might have put it. But, impressive though the impressions are, this would merely be Madame Tussaud's broadcasting were it not for the depth and intelligence of Johnson's script. Johnson's own smut is more adult than Rothwell's. There's a running gag about cunnilingus which, 10 years ago, would have had ITV in it up to its neck. Oooh, there I go again. The real power, however, is in the characterisations. The grim inner life of the publicly grinning comic is a cliche of fiction, but Cor Blimey! is much more complex about the relationship between stars and parts. These actors are not the opposite of their off-screen personae but - more interestingly - a darker and more dangerous version of the same. James suffers the pain and frustration of really being the reckless lecher he plays effortlessly on screen. Williams, master of the bottom gag, is a martyr to anal ailments. Windsor, whose Carry On persona involved not fully understanding the consequences of what she did or said, ignores for as long as possible the fact that her marriage to Ronnie Knight has made her a gangster's moll. I mentioned here recently the increased use of what might be called website programming: the placing of related shows in the schedules like arrows leading from pages in cyberspace. ITV does the obvious thing of following Johnson's play with Carry On Cleo. And it's a tribute to the visual illusion and imaginative empathy of Cor Blimey! that it will easily survive this proximity with the original. One of the best stage plays of the 1990s has become one of this year's TV highlights. As Sid, Kenny and Barbara might have put it, ITV has pulled out the big one and forced it down the BBC's throat.

fields.headline: Double take
fields.trailText: The actors in Cor Blimey! are doing impressions as a temporary acting exercise. Soon they'll be playing someone we've never heard of. It's a different business spending all your time wanting to be mistaken for someone else. The latest attempt is Alistair McGowan's Big Impression (10pm, BBC1, Wed), the BBC's search for a lookalike for C4's Rory Bremner shows.
fields.body:
The actors in Cor Blimey! are doing impressions as a temporary acting exercise. Soon they'll be playing someone we've never heard of. It's a different business spending all your time wanting to be mistaken for someone else. The latest attempt is Alistair McGowan's Big Impression (10pm, BBC1, Wed), the BBC's search for a lookalike for C4's Rory Bremner shows.

Where Bremner has increasingly concentrated on politics, McGowan turns inwardly, but brilliantly, on TV itself. In the spoof Changing Faces, McGowan's Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen and Ronni Ancona's Carol Smillie enact disastrous cosmetic surgery on a member of the public. In The Royal Family - Queen, Duke, Charles and Camilla lolling on a sofa watching TV - the impressions are thrillingly split-level, combining the mannerisms of the Windsors and the Royles.

McGowan has a remarkable ear. On radio, you couldn't tell the difference. In one revealing aside he shows how Nigel Havers' voice merges the Prince of Wales' accent with Sir Jimmy Savile's speech rhythms. But, as with Bremner and Mike Yarwood before him, you see how much an impressionist is a victim or beneficiary of their physical shape. Bremner and Yarwood - both broad-shouldered men - were always suited to playing the middle-aged. McGowan - thin enough to play both Beckhams if he wanted to - can't bring a visual match to equal the vocal cloning of his Alan Titchmarsh. And his Huw Edwards sounds perfect but looks as if he's been away from the newsdesk for months with amoebic dysentry.

But McGowan's wiriness means he's the first TV impressionist to do sports and pop stars convincingly. His Noel and Liam Gallagher and Gary Lineker could almost go home to their wives without arousing suspicion. The only pity is that, so far, he seems to be leaving another famous figure close to his own physique - Tony Blair - to Bremner. ML

webTitle: The old ones are the best

fields.headline: The old ones are the best
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: Those were the days. At the tiny station of this Sussex branch line, there were at least three full-time staff, all smartly turned out. When a disembarking posh lady objected to the dustiness of her carriage, Perks the station porter (Gregor Fisher) took her complaint seriously. Imagine!
fields.body:
Those were the days. At the tiny station of this Sussex branch line, there were at least three full-time staff, all smartly turned out. When a disembarking posh lady objected to the dustiness of her carriage, Perks the station porter (Gregor Fisher) took her complaint seriously. Imagine!

Along the embankment, Bobbie and Phyl - sunny girls in white pinafore dresses - and their little brother - cute as a button in suit and cap - waved their hankies at the 11.29. And then, from the observation platform of a lovely carriage with a rustic wood finish, a kindly old gent in top hat (Dickie Attenborough), waved back. Why don't Virgin trains have observation platforms, kindly old gents for passengers and wood finishes? Well, why not?

When a Bolshevik refugee turned up at the station, he wasn't asked for his vouchers, his passport or even his train ticket. Instead, Bobby, Phil and little whatshisname took the man home, taught him English, clothed and fed him. Such was England then - decent, humane and not at all suspicious about immigrants. Never such innocence again.

At the end of the 1960s, there were several children's films and TV programmes set in those innocent days when the 20th century wasn't even in its teens. In Trumptonshire, through which Dr Mopp drove in his new- fangled car, and round which Lord Belbroughton steamed in his train, society ran like clockwork. And in Lionel Jeffries's 1970 film version of E Nesbit's 1906 novel The Railway Children, everyone knew their place, was well-spoken and often clean. Perhaps such dramas served a conservative social end: as students revolted, London swung, chains of deference fell away like water and licentiousness and pop music rose like new gods, they instilled in young people a nostalgia for an age when everything was better. A nostalgia, to be sure, for an age that never existed, but which was all the more powerful for that.

Simon Nye's adaptation of The Railway Children (ITV), while inciting a longing for a non-existent English world of innocence and steam, overlaid this with another nostalgia, for a time when Jenny Agutter stood on the tracks in front of the Green Dragon until it stopped, when toothy Sally Thomsett giggled through summer fields, and when Bernard Cribbins was the lovable Perks. Here Agutter was the children's troubled, tired-eyed mother, newly impoverished and forever bursting into the living room to say: "Good news. I've sold another story. Buns for tea!" A clever piece of casting, but hardly as inspired as getting Rab C Nesbitt to pull a porter's uniform over his string vest - a comedy commoner civilised by Sassenachs.

Nye took a few liberties - would Bobbie really have said "OK" and would the station master have told the little boy to "Go tell it to the marines"? - which only made plainer the devotion to creating a meticulously authentic simulation of an inauthentic world.

There were buns for tea, too, in Alice In Wonderland (C4), although the little girl hardly got to eat them. Martin Short's Mad Hatter kept insisting on changing seats before anyone could settle. Delightfully demented, he was backed by the March Hare on a little guitar when he sang. "Auntie's wooden leg," he cooed. "Everyone thinks it's dead." A marvellous adaptation, filled with virtuosic star turns and bafflingly wonderful special effects. The other-worldly white rabbit looked a little pervy in his trim little jacket with no clothes below the waist - as anthropomorphised animals often will.

Who was that grinning puss on the oven? Why, it was Whoopi Goldberg, or at least Whoopi's face grafted somehow onto a cat's body. Ken Dodd was a loony lecturer, and more goofily toothy than Sally Thomsett could ever have managed.

There was even Miranda Richardson as the Queen of Hearts, reprising Her Royal Barminess from Blackadder. I liked it very much when Alice (engagingly played by Tina Majorino, with a full set of furrowed brows) told this crazy queen off: "Stop losing your temper! It's vulgar." This Alice was bent on bringing the social decorum of The Railway Children to this dysfunctional wonderland.

Here, it's true, Richardson's snooty voice was more Gloucestershire equestrian ("Orf with his head!") than absolutist adolescent, but it still made me feel nostalgic for Blackadder's simulation of Elizabethan England, nostalgic for that TV version of a history that never took place.

fields.headline: Rare way to heaven
fields.standfirst: The classic pop-star death is exotic, excessive and drug-fuelled. So pity the poor soul who passes away gardening or cleaning the car, says  Rich Hall
fields.trailText: When musicians kick the bucket, it almost guarantees them mythical status. In particular, there is something about expiration by excess that is always blackly glamorous. So when I imagine musical heaven, I picture a stately mansion whose interior resembles Graceland after a month-long wingding.
fields.body:
When musicians kick the bucket, it almost guarantees them mythical status. In particular, there is something about expiration by excess that is always blackly glamorous. So when I imagine musical heaven, I picture a stately mansion whose interior resembles Graceland after a month-long wingding.

The place is full of smashed TVs, empty bottles and liquor-swollen carpets. Passed out on the plush broken furniture are Jimi Hendrix, Kurt Cobain, Keith Moon and a platoon of other rabble-rousers and tireless over-imbibers. In the corner, Buddy Holly and Jim Croce blithely drink coffee and nibble Pepperidge Farm Cookies. Out behind the mansion is a sun-dappled cabana where Dennis Wilson, Jeff Buckley and a host of other musical drowning victims recline poolside.

Beyond the pool, however, if you bothered to look, you would find a handful of forgotten musical victims. They're the ones no one is ever going to immortalise in song. Their last days on earth weren't accompanied by pills or alcohol. No one plucked them from the wreckage of an aircraft. Nope: they died cleaning the car or maintaining the landscape. In other words, they fought the lawn and the lawn won.

Like Jeff Porcaro. Jeff was the drummer for Toto, but don't hold that against him. He was also one of the most respected session men in the business. Steely Dan, Eddie Van Halen and Boz Scaggs all sought his services. He was gifted, reliable and versatile.

But there was another side to Jeff few knew about. Jeff hated bugs. He hated flies, bees and mosquitoes. One afternoon, while trying to install a barbecue in his backyard, Jeff embarked on one of his bug-killing binges. All he wanted was a pest-free lawn.

But the endless onslaught of bumble bees, the whole brutal regime of pesky winged insects finally became too much for poor Jeff. So he went out and purchased a 10-gallon container of industrial-strength pesticide. Sadly, it became the only drum he never learned to play.

It all got a little out of control and he more or less sprayed himself to death. When he ascended to that great extended solo in the sky, the dozens of fellow musicians who eulogised him, from Mark Knopfler to Jim Keltner, all commented on how extraordinary Jeff's drumming was. Even today one can hear it in his Toto recordings, a charging rhythm both masterful and primal, a rhythm perhaps of a man trying to pound the tyranny of bugs out of his head.

A similar horticulturally related fate befell Merle Watson. Merle, a North Carolinian, is considered one of the greatest finger-picking guitarists ever. Like many musicians, Merle was kind of a night owl and he enjoyed a little late-night open-top cruising. But Merle's speedster of choice was a tractor.

On October 22, 1985, Merle was doing what any musical hellion would be doing at 2am - panelling his basement. He got a splinter imbedded in his arm and decided to visit a neighbour who might help him remove it. Merle - who owned a truck - decided to travel by tractor.

The neighbour "anaesthetised" him with wine and removed the splinter. Merle then headed home. He never made it. The tractor went over an embankment and pinned Merle beneath it, face down in his beloved bluegrass.

If the highway to heaven is full of men who drove too fast, like Eddie Cochrane or Marc Bolan, Merle will be on his tractor, gleefully making sure they can't get by.

Unquestionably, the heavenly vehicle of choice is the Cadillac. A big gold-flaked Sedan de Ville, sitting in front of the mansion in a circular drive, ostentatious as all get-out. Elvis gave them away to his associates like party favours.

Hank Williams died in the back seat of one, rattling around like a drunken Tic-Tac while his driver wended through the mountainous roads of West Virginia, unaware until they arrived at the venue that Hank had expired. But at least people could say, "Well, he died in his Cadillac." Which can't be said for Rex Allen. Rex, sadly, died under his Cadillac. Often called the "Arizona Cowboy", Rex was a yodelling, guitar-slinging, horse-hugging cactusjack whose style was 180 degrees from ol' Hank, though they shared the stage on occasion. And they both owned a string of Caddies.

But while Hank tended to view his as a tavern on wheels, the clean-living Rex was far more interested in grooming his like a prize stallion. One day, while he was inspecting the rear fender for smudges, his driver and female caretaker backed over him. Apparently she didn't realise and sat there blithely listening to his piercing cries. She thought he was just yodelling.

If these descriptions seem indelicate, well, music is an indelicate medium. All the posturing and rampant egoism that make stage performers larger than life can't keep them from choking on a cherry pip or getting run over by their own van.

Lots of people die mundanely, but when it happens to musicians, they get de-mythologised and no one makes a tribute album for them. Which is sad, because Jeff Porcaro and Merle Watson were, in their own way, as vital as Cobain and Elvis, or Jimi or Janis.

But, let's face it, when you're dead, you're dead. Doesn't matter if it was drugs or lawn maintenance. The rule of modern music has always been to live fast, die young and leave a pretty corpse. Or copse.

webTitle: On a working holiday with Jesus at Butlins

fields.headline: On a working holiday with Jesus at Butlins
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Rev Joel Edwards spent Easter this year at Butlins - not having a holiday as such, but praying, talking and taking services for thousands of evangelical Christians.
fields.body:
The Rev Joel Edwards spent Easter this year at Butlins - not having a holiday as such, but praying, talking and taking services for thousands of evangelical Christians.

Eighty-thousand met at holiday camps in Skegness in Lincolnshire and Minehead in Somerset under the enthusiastic eye of the Evangelical Alliance, led by Mr Edwards, who is arguably the most influential black churchman in the country. A million in Britain are affiliated to the alliance, ranging across 30 protestant denominations from Anglicanism to the Salvation Army. No wonder William Hague descended on the Minehead camp last week to try and convince them the Conservative party was on their side.

Mr Edwards was confident in his faith: "There are strong indicators of growth and vitality. Where a church takes the Bible seriously, and takes the person of Jesus Christ seriously and with confidence, where churches are friendly and welcoming to outsiders, and where they are playing a role in the community, those are the hallmarks of our success.

"These are vibrant and encouraging churches. All churches have to face the reality of contemporary culture: adults working under pressure, both parents out at work; we must respond to reality and, where you find churches diversifying to take that into account, you find success.

"You have to fish where the fish are," said Mr Edwards. That might mean midweek services to catch West End shoppers , or it might mean events after school on Friday nights in Wallasey on Merseyside where they were attracting 600 children to leave their computers and television.

It is in the so-called black churches that the liveliest congregations are found. Mr Edwards said: "These churches reflect a significant pocket of the British community and they show all the characteristics of mainstream evangelicalism. Their worship is vibrant and they provide strong positive role models of black leadership.

"But there is no apartheid in this. Black people attend many churches. I think they help white people become less proud and superior and to realise they can learn lessons. They help complementarily."
