Their worship is vibrant and they provide strong positive role models of black leadership. "But there is no apartheid in this. Black people attend many churches. I think they help white people become less proud and superior and to realise they can learn lessons. They help complementarily."

fields.headline: Victory on the home front
fields.standfirst: When Lisa Smith was sued by estate agents, she was told she had no hope of winning.  John Cunningham  on how she proved the doubters wrong
fields.trailText: Almost everyone forgets and forgives the frustrations of selling a house and buying another once the move to the new home is over. But Lisa Smith was different. She was so angry with the estate agents who sold her property, she told them she would pay only half their bill, since they had done only half the job she had asked for.
fields.body:
Almost everyone forgets and forgives the frustrations of selling a house and buying another once the move to the new home is over. But Lisa Smith was different. She was so angry with the estate agents who sold her property, she told them she would pay only half their bill, since they had done only half the job she had asked for.

"The agreement was to sell the house and progress the sale. They did half the original job, which was to sell the house, so I paid them half their original fee," she explained.

The dispute dragged on after she, her husband Paul and their two children settled into their new abode. Paul, who is all for a quiet life, groaned and said: "Pay the bloody bill and shut them up!"

But she was determined to continue the fight. And when the estate agents threatened to go to court to recover the outstanding amount, she retorted: "See you there."

Bairstow Eves East, the estate agency chain owned by the Countrywide Assured Group, went ahead. Earlier this month, represented by the group's in-house barrister, the firm claimed its outstanding commission in the small claims court at Basildon, Essex.

Smith, who works from home looking after the accounting and secretarial side of her husband's double glazing firm, represented herself - and won. Her argument was that, in order to earn its commission, an agency must not only introduce a potential buyer who does purchase the property, but must also progress the sale and keep the client informed about everything that goes on.

The district judge agreed, and said that since moving house is a stressful event, "support and oversight by estate agents must be given. . . It is a responsibility of estate agents to nurse a transaction through to exchange. In this case, I do not think that they did. There were problems in Bairstow Eves' Brentwood office. I feel that service is as important as finding a purchaser."

Smith's experiences will strike a chord with anyone who has bought and sold several houses. Whatever can go wrong usually does, and estate agents (along with solicitors) usually get the blame.

Her tale seems no worse than many, which is why so many homebuyers and sellers will cheer her victory. Everyone who has felt let down by estate agents at some point in an often complicated series of transactions (where chains and chance can play a part) will laud her derring-do. Many might feel emboldened to follow her example.

But they can't just point to her judgment and expect to win. Unlike the rulings of higher courts, the decisions of district judges in small claims cases don't set a legal precedent; each case will depend on its own facts. And Bairstow Eves may still appeal against the decision.

Countrywide's group legal adviser, Sam Themis, who appeared for Bairstow Eves at the hearing, said in a statement: "We are considering our position in respect of an appeal. We consider there is no basis in law for the decision of the district judge."

His view is backed up by a legal academic, who says there is nothing in the 1979 Estate Agents Act (which regulates the professional operation of property selling) about the way an agency should keep in contact with a customer from the time it comes up with a potential buyer to the completion of the deal.

However, the judge clearly accepted that the Smiths had been let down at several points after they entrusted the sale of their home, in the Essex village of Doddinghurst, to Bairstow Eves. Though chuffed about her court victory, Smith remains indignant about the errors she says the agency made, and about its attempts to try to get her to pay up. Since she has never before been involved in court proceedings, she is still surprised at her determination to take on the professionals.

The family decided last spring that they needed a bigger house. She took charge of all the arrangements, and asked Bairstow Eves to act as sole agents after successfully using another branch several years before.

She signed an agreement for a commission of £2,500 but says she verbally agreed with the manager, Alan Benton, for a reduced commission of £2,100 on the asking price of £119,995. He was sympathetic to a couple of special requirements she outlined to him. "I explained, as I was an extremely busy mother working from home, I would expect to have very little personal input, but would expect to be kept well informed of the progression of any sale."

As the Smiths wanted to stay in the same patch of Essex and had a very precise idea of the new house they wanted, Benton agreed that he would keep the sale "low key" to give them plenty of time for their search.

This was crucially important, says Smith, because last summer property in the area was selling quickly, and she did not want to become obligated to a prospective buyer without having secured a new home. However, she says the agency still sent lots of first-time buyers and people who had already sold up.

Her expectations took another knock when she tried to correct a mistake in the details of the house sent to potential buyers. The combined living/dining area was 28ft long, but appeared as 21ft 4ins in the particulars. Three times she rang to get this corrected; three times the firm failed to amend the measurement, which it circulated without her approval - a point, the judge said, which put the agency in the wrong.

By summer the family had found the house they wanted and the process speeded up - along with the incidence of errors, says Smith. A couple, teachers moving to a new school in Essex, made a firm offer for the house. They set a deadline of August 18 - if they could not move in by then, they would have to rent accommodation.

But the Smiths were in the middle of a chain of five house sales, and there was a hold-up: one of the buyers had not received a mortgage offer. Smith says it was she who discovered the obstacle and paid for a courier to take a document from one office to another in Blackpool so the mortgage offer came through, though completion was delayed by about 10 days.

Smith agrees that everything turned out all right in the end, but it was the irritation of not getting enough feedback, plus the odd muddle, which she felt warranted much reduced charges. Craig Job, who took over as office manager while negotiations were in mid-flow last year, said in a statement to the court that he had apologised for the various hiccups and had cut the Smiths' bill as a goodwill gesture.

The moves were completed, summer turned to autumn, and along came more letters from Bairstow Eves demanding payment. Smith had paid £1,050, half the agreed £2,100 commission. The agency said it would accept a total of £1,550 plus VAT, leaving a balance of nearly £800.

In October the Smiths received a letter from the regional manager saying that if the bill was not paid in 10 days, the firm would be entitled to charge its full commission rate and would demand £4,935. In the event, the court claim was for just under £800.

When she decided to fight the court action, Smith says that two firms of solicitors she approached for advice said she had no chance of winning, while two others said they could not take on the case because they did legal work for the estate agents.

That strengthened her resolve. Fortunately, she was used to keeping meticulous records, so the documents, plus dates and times of visits and phone calls, were at hand.

It was a worrying time; but the small claims court was anything but intimidating: no gowns or wigs and a room laid out out more like a tribunal rather than a court. Three hours of statements, questions and the judgment - in her favour.

Appeal or no appeal, she is glad she did it. The £800 does not matter: the family could have paid that off easily enough. What does matter, she says, is that she took a stand in an arena which consumers are loath to enter because they feel they have no chance - until now.

webTitle: Cutting the silk comes at a price

fields.headline: Cutting the silk comes at a price
fields.standfirst: Writ large
fields.trailText: Some poor junior barrister applied to become a QC this year but was turned down. Not very interesting, except that this reject's average yearly earnings were £634,000. How can someone so successful be considered unworthy of silk?
fields.body:
Some poor junior barrister applied to become a QC this year but was turned down. Not very interesting, except that this reject's average yearly earnings were £634,000. How can someone so successful be considered unworthy of silk?

I know that income is not the only criterion for silkdom, but someone who gathers in so much in fees must surely be good. What's wrong with Mr or Ms £634,000? I am consumed with curiosity.

I know that figure because the Lord Chancellor's department has taken to publishing the earnings of applicants for silk. The highest-paid barrister who made it had earned a yearly £570,000. The average for the 78 who became QCs last week was £213,000, whereas the unsuccessful ones only mustered £165,000.

The award of an honorary QC to Nelson Mandela is terrific, but it seems to suggest a change in the criteria for the honour. Until now, these honoraries have gone to people who, though not practising lawyers, have made a significant contribution to the law and legal affairs.

Mr Mandela practised briefly as an attorney a long time ago, starting the first black law firm in South Africa. He has since transcended all superlatives for his contributions to many things - but not especially to the law. If the Lord Chancellor has changed the rules, so be it; I don't mind, except that it might create an unfortunate gateway. I fear that next year we'll be having Bill and Hillary QCs.

The good news is that Mr Mandela will be making the trip to receive his QC in person. Arrangements are under way for the legal costumiers and wig-makers Ede and Ravenscroft to fit him out.

I was away for only 11 days, during which I discovered that the Lord Chancellor had done away with much of the judicial system as we know it. For one thing, he has abolished an entire level of judges.

Before I left there were 500 or so part-time judges known as assistant recorders. No more. Every one of them has been promoted, and is now a recorder (still part-time, but bigger deal), an advancement which used to come after three years of doing a good job as assistant. It's as if they've been told: "We know you only joined the firm the other day as a messenger, but from now on you'll be a vice-president, with your salary multiplied a hundredfold." OK, that's an exaggeration - they'll be getting about £86 a day more - but the principle's the same.

The abolition of assistant recorders is the fault of the Human Rights Act, under which they would not be considered "impartial" judges because their appointments were short term and they could be removed too easily by the Lord Chancellor, a political figure, which meant that they might be perceived as suiting their decisions to his wishes.

It's all very well, but this means that it will no longer be possible to get rid of part-time judges who aren't good at an early stage; they're all going to be recorders, with a security of tenure, which means the bad ones will stay on.

A nother innovation is that the law lords are finally going to get what they've always wanted - some paid help. In future they'll have the services of judicial assistants, clever young lawyers who will spend a year researching, organising and generally taking some of the load off our top judges so they can concentrate on thinking deep thoughts about the law.

The US Supreme Court judges have had such people for ages, called law clerks. Over the years, some of the more enterprising ones have used their time at the court to accumulate salacious information about the judges, either for books of their own, or to pass to journalists and writers.

These law clerks have revealed that some of the most admired judges have been drunks, foul-mouthed, bigoted and stupid. I'm sure that none of these descriptions could possibly apply to our own dear law lords, but it might be best to get the new help to sign some strict confidentiality clauses.

T he World's Most Famous Chambers Ever, being co-founded by Cherie Booth QC, has not yet opened for business. But Matrix (I'm told it's cool to omit the word chambers) is already planning for its most important event - its summer party. Where will it be? Whispers reach me that a certain country house is favourite to host the bash. Matrix at Chequers. It's got a ring to it. The ring of cash registers.

fields.headline: Life is sacred
fields.standfirst:
The spiritual is no longer something to be celebrated in church. It is becoming part of everyday existence

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Easter is that time of the year when the churches swell temporarily with seasonal believers. But every year even this peak audience shrinks across the country by a few more thousand. One of the most extraordinary social revolutions in the 50 years since the second world war has been the decline of institutional religion in western Europe.
fields.body:
Easter is that time of the year when the churches swell temporarily with seasonal believers. But every year even this peak audience shrinks across the country by a few more thousand. One of the most extraordinary social revolutions in the 50 years since the second world war has been the decline of institutional religion in western Europe.

If current rates of decline continue, there will be no Methodists in the UK by the middle of the next century. Each year, 50,000 Catholics in England and Wales give up going to Sunday mass. The declining number of vocations to the priesthood in France, once regarded as the elder daughter of the Catholic church, is leaving parishes empty. Seminaries are closing in Ireland, the country which once exported a surplus of priests to serve all over the world, for lack of candidates. The absence of an institutional faith makes contemporary western Europe, historically and anthropologically, a strange new experiment in human culture.

After all, institutional religion is thriving in virtually every other part of the globe, including America where many still regularly attend church. Every previous society has developed and lived by a religious tradition which explained the place of the individual, the community and the cosmos; it ordered relations between people (particularly over sexual reproduction) and with the environment. Rituals expressed and reinforced the tradition. In many cultures, this tradition was maintained and interpreted by priests who acquired great authority from their position. In 21st-century western Europe, shared beliefs, ritual and religious hierarchies are being swept away.

But the conclusion commonly drawn from the decline of religious institutions - that this is a process of secularisation - is wrong. Polls in the UK consistently indicate that the vast majority of people (more than 70%) say they believe in God. Many admit to praying even if they never go in a church, mosque or synagogue. Many have developed a powerful philosophy of life which incorporates the search for the universal values of truth, love and beauty, but has moved outside the institutional faiths. Millions of people are, individually or in small groups, fumbling towards a new formulation of faith and the signs of it are everywhere.

Look first in language. The radical theologian Don Cupitt points out how in recent decades the word "life" has become hugely popular, loaded with complex philosophical meaning: "get a life that's life, she loved life, there's more to life, I want to get my life back together again, my life has fallen apart, life goes on, I've got a life to live, live dangerously, quality of life, right to life, that's what life is all about, I've only got one life, live life to the full." Many would agree with his conclusion that the focus of contemporary spirituality has shifted from the traditional religious preoccupation with life after death to life before death - the here and now.

Cupitt identifies some of the ways we use the word: life has an imperative - one must keep up and play one's full part in it, one has a responsibility to enjoy and explore it (live life to the full). The best tribute to be paid at a funeral is that the deceased "loved life"; loving life means accepting its vicissitudes. "We are learning to love life disinterestedly," claims Cupitt. Loving life is living in the present, and finding in the moment an intensity and authenticity of experience: "there's more to life than this." Perhaps the fascination with drugs and sex is this quest for an intensity of experience in reaction to the often banal superficiality of consumer materialism. Cupitt concludes that, "We have supposed that what has been happening has been the secularisation of religion, and we have failed to see the much greater event of the sacralisation of life, even though it has already deeply affected all of us."

This new formulation of faith has abandoned the western preoccupation with the intellectual and rational. People are not interested in what you believe but how you live your life. It is the practice not the theory which now concerns us. We are contemptuous of creed-based religions. Their obsession with what people did or did not believe has inspired over the past millennium a history of terrible persecution and violence in which thousands died for the sake of fine points of theological dispute such as transubstantiation. Besides, creed-based religions have lost intellectual credibility because so many of their former truths have been proved wrong by Copernicus and Darwin, leaving them with an absurd hostility to the search for scientific truth.

Contemporary faith now has lost its cosmological ambition, it cannot explain how the universe happened or how and why we emerged from the mud in evolution. It cannot even explain the arbitrary brutality of suffering and death. Its purpose is not to provide explanations; it has been recast as a pragmatic philosophy, something to help us find happiness, reduce our suffering, find peace of mind and meaning in this life. The emphasis has moved to intuition, emotion and empiricism; some would argue that the pendulum has swung too far the other way, and that suspending all critical rationality can lead to a dangerous credulity in which cults and quackery flourish.

The core principle of this faith is individual autonomy - "no one can tell you how to run your life" is the personal mantra. All previous religions have developed hierarchies and figures of authority. Now, everyone is on their own journey. What is lost is bigotry and condemnation, but what is gained is tolerance.

At its best, this radical democratisation of religion offers each individual great opportunity. At its worst, it suggests that everyone is reinventing the wheel because there is no respect for what previous generations have learned - tradition - or for the role of teacher. But this tolerance opens us up to the globalisation of religion; the exclusive claims of the monotheistic faiths become hard, if not impossible, for many people to subscribe to.

A hundred years ago, western Christians' understanding of Hinduism and Buddhism was negligible, the great religious revolution of the 20th century has been a huge growth and understanding of other religious traditions. The dialogue between faiths and the discovery of a commonality of many principles and beliefs is happening all over the world, although it attracts much less publicity than the conflicts between faiths.

The spiritual has moved into daily life and is no longer something separate and apart which properly belongs in the church; the western understanding is of the sacred and secular as being totally distinguishable. Now we are much closer to the Hindu or Confucian practice where the gods are worshipped in the home; potentially, we can now place the sacred in everything implicit and underpinning all of daily life.

Loving life is living in the present, and finding in the moment an intensity and authenticity of experience: "there's more to life than this." Perhaps the fascination with drugs and sex is this quest for an intensity of experience in reaction to the often banal superficiality of consumer materialism. Cupitt concludes that, "We have supposed that what has been happening has been the secularisation of religion, and we have failed to see the much greater event of the sacralisation of life, even though it has already deeply affected all of us." This new formulation of faith has abandoned the western preoccupation with the intellectual and rational. People are not interested in what you believe but how you live your life. It is the practice not the theory which now concerns us. We are contemptuous of creed-based religions. Their obsession with what people did or did not believe has inspired over the past millennium a history of terrible persecution and violence in which thousands died for the sake of fine points of theological dispute such as transubstantiation. Besides, creed-based religions have lost intellectual credibility because so many of their former truths have been proved wrong by Copernicus and Darwin, leaving them with an absurd hostility to the search for scientific truth. Contemporary faith now has lost its cosmological ambition, it cannot explain how the universe happened or how and why we emerged from the mud in evolution. It cannot even explain the arbitrary brutality of suffering and death. Its purpose is not to provide explanations; it has been recast as a pragmatic philosophy, something to help us find happiness, reduce our suffering, find peace of mind and meaning in this life. The emphasis has moved to intuition, emotion and empiricism; some would argue that the pendulum has swung too far the other way, and that suspending all critical rationality can lead to a dangerous credulity in which cults and quackery flourish. The core principle of this faith is individual autonomy - "no one can tell you how to run your life" is the personal mantra. All previous religions have developed hierarchies and figures of authority. Now, everyone is on their own journey. What is lost is bigotry and condemnation, but what is gained is tolerance. At its best, this radical democratisation of religion offers each individual great opportunity. At its worst, it suggests that everyone is reinventing the wheel because there is no respect for what previous generations have learned - tradition - or for the role of teacher. But this tolerance opens us up to the globalisation of religion; the exclusive claims of the monotheistic faiths become hard, if not impossible, for many people to subscribe to. A hundred years ago, western Christians' understanding of Hinduism and Buddhism was negligible, the great religious revolution of the 20th century has been a huge growth and understanding of other religious traditions. The dialogue between faiths and the discovery of a commonality of many principles and beliefs is happening all over the world, although it attracts much less publicity than the conflicts between faiths. The spiritual has moved into daily life and is no longer something separate and apart which properly belongs in the church; the western understanding is of the sacred and secular as being totally distinguishable. Now we are much closer to the Hindu or Confucian practice where the gods are worshipped in the home; potentially, we can now place the sacred in everything implicit and underpinning all of daily life. madeleine.bunting@theguardian.com

webTitle: Case of the week You can't sue me - I'm immune

fields.headline: Case of the week You can't sue me - I'm immune
fields.trailText: You can sue your doctor if he removes the wrong kidney or your solicitor if she messes up your conveyancing. But many people might be surprised to learn that you cannot sue an advocate - barrister or solicitor - who makes a hash of your case in court.
fields.body:
You can sue your doctor if he removes the wrong kidney or your solicitor if she messes up your conveyancing. But many people might be surprised to learn that you cannot sue an advocate - barrister or solicitor - who makes a hash of your case in court.

There is no statute that says you can't. But judges have conferred immunity on advocates in a line of court cases. The reason? Public policy. It would be undesirable, it is said, if cases already decided by one court could in effect be re-litigated in another by suing the advocate. And advocates have an overriding duty to the court which may conflict with their client's interests. Hence they need protection.

The House of Lords last looked at this issue 20 years ago, and decided that advocates' immunity should stand. But a group of test cases now awaiting judgment in the House could change that.

The climate is different now. In the last few years, thanks to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, others who were once immune from being sued have lost that protection. The police, in their crime prevention and investigation role, and local authorities, in their child protection role, were until recently immune. No longer.

After all, the European Convention on Human Rights guarantees a fair hearing in civil claims. But how can you have a fair hearing if your claim is struck out before it even gets off the ground? From next October the convention will be incorporated into our law and its guarantees will be enforceable in our courts.

So it is opportune that the law lords look again at advocates' immunity and how far it should survive in the new human rights era - if at all. As Lord Bingham, the Lord Chief Justice, said in the Court of Appeal, ruling that the claims could go ahead: "The law should be slow to grant its own practitioners a protection denied to members of other professions."

Meanwhile, the Court of Appeal will next month hear an appeal by Mohammed Patel, who alleges he was wrongly convicted because of his barrister's failings in his 1987 trial. The Court of Appeal has ruled that the barrister should come to court to be questioned by both defence and prosecution counsel.

Mr Patel also has a claim pending at Strasbourg after the High Court halted his negligence action against the barrister over the way he handled his case in court.

fields.headline: Oh, you sweet thing
fields.standfirst: It's Easter and we all know what that means ...  Katharine Whitehorn  on women and chocolate
fields.trailText: What is it about chocolate? There's a Chocolate Society, hotels hold Chocolate Weekends where the faithful meet to eat and drool, there are magazines that go on about little else and we in Britain eat more chocolate per person per year than any other nation in the world.
fields.body:
What is it about chocolate? There's a Chocolate Society, hotels hold Chocolate Weekends where the faithful meet to eat and drool, there are magazines that go on about little else and we in Britain eat more chocolate per person per year than any other nation in the world.

Chocolate seems always to be associated with women. Girls are supposed to be a pushover for such sweetness ("What are little girls made of? Sugar and spice and all things nice"). Patronising wine waiters are apt to suggest: "We find the ladies prefer this sweeter wine" to which novelist Mary Stuart once memorably replied: "In matters of wine I am no lady." The adverts that show a man tearing about like James Bond to bring the lady Milk Tray assume she'll be duly grateful when she gets it, but I slightly discount the ads that show a girl eating Cadbury's Flake as if giving a blow job: if some women really do prefer chocolate to sex, you'd surely have to play the scene the other way around and I'd rather not imagine how.

There are all sorts of dark theories to explain our love of chocolate, from a sort of nostalgie pour la boue, a yearning for the primeval mud, or the idea that popping sweets into girlish mouths is a way to infantalise the entire female sex. I think a more potent explanation is that suggested by a book that was wildly popular last year, Chocolat, by Joanne Harris. In it, a woman comes to a French village and opens a sweet shop in direct opposition to an austere and unlikable priest. As in the movie Babette's Feast, the forces of sensuality are shown to be more benign, more kindly and more life-enhancing than the uptight puritanism of respectability. Seen in that light, even the fact that Ann Summers sex shops sell a spreading chocolate with which to coat yourself or your lover seems only a joyous extra, not a perversion.

Chocolate is pleasure, indulgence, sweetness and light; whatever else lets us down, there is always chocolate. Indeed, there is a whole series of greetings cards, featuring for some reason a hippopotamus, with just this message: my favourite has "Things are getting worse" on the outside and "Please send chocolate" within.

There is actually a sound basis for the sense that chocolate makes you feel good. It contains phenylenthylamine, which has a mild antidepressant action, and magnesium, which is good for PMT. Interestingly, Michel Montignac, the man who wrote Dine Out And Lose Weight, positively prescribes small amounts of pure, dark chocolate to reduce an unseemly craving for other foods.

So why do women feel so guilty about it? Is there a special link between females and chocolate? We don't actually eat more of it - teenage boys can apparently eat four bars a day without flinching - but we do seem to feel much more guilt about it. OK, maybe we're highly figure-conscious, but that can't be the only reason: men, after all, wear their swelling bellies with pride. I suspect it's because women are programmed to think that anything that simply pleases us must be suspect, if not downright wrong. It comes into the same category as eating your pudding before your main course, reading a novel in the morning or going to the pictures in the afternoon: surely we should be doing something more useful? Maybe it's just because chocolate is so uncomplicatedly delightful that, deep down, we feel it must be wicked - but I wouldn't swear that doesn't add to its attraction.

Chocolate might actually lose some of its appeal if we did think we ought to eat it. No one, after all, is deeply thrilled by cocoa, dismally associated with slippers, cardigans and a tendency to be in bed by 10.

In the 40s, there was an awful government-inspired drink called namco - national dried milk cocoa. It looked like a mixture of earth and tea, was supposed to be good for you and nearly killed the market stone dead.

Chocolate is addictive, of course, even to the extent that the drug Ecopipam, originally developed to treat cocaine addiction, is being tried out as a cure for craving it. But the guilt itself, it seems, can do us harm. The latest offering from that annual souce of merriment, the British Psychological Society's conference, says guilt weakens your immune system - and in their research, chocolate was right up there in the guilt-inducing stakes with drinking and smoking and sleeping in late, though incredibly, what makes us feel most guilty is watching Neighbours.

There is considerably more sugar in modern chocolate than there used to be, but beyond concern for our figures and teeth, it seems we ought to have a conscience about the way chocolate is produced, too. Cocoa trees are sprayed with fungicide, usually by women since they are small enough to get under the branches, and the stuff contains Lindane, which is banned in Europe because it is implicated in breast cancer.

Happily, the boom in organic chocolate lets you off that guilt trip. So, as the pilots used to say as they soared towards the heavens, chocs away!
All because the lady loves: a few facts for cocoa nuts
* The British are the world's biggest chocolate consumers, eating around 10kg per person per year - a whopping 595,000 tonnes. According to research carried out by Cadbury's last year, adult women buy more than twice as much confectionery as men (67% of the market share) and they eat just over half of what they buy. Men, on the other hand, generally buy confectionery just for themselves.

* Chocolate has a unique property that means it melts at just below body temperature, making for an incredibly sensual experience on impact with your mouth - or any other erogenous zone, for that matter. Casanova was reputed to favour chocolate over champagne for getting women into the sack - yet Cadbury's were surprised to find that their slim, delicate Flake, marketed specifically at women and advertised by a model simulating fellatio with the chocolate bar, appeals almost equally to men.

* Despite claims that chocolate contains a chemical that is produced by the brain when experiencing pangs of love, tests published by the Biscuit, Cake, Chocolate and Confectionery Alliance reveal that the average person would need to eat 4,000 bars of milk chocolate before it would have any aphrodisiac effect.

* According to a Mori survey for Cadbury's Dairy Milk, one in two women would rather spend an evening eating chocolate than having sex, while men would rather eat chocolate than go for a spin in a souped-up sports car.

* You can even argue that chocolate is good for your health. A standard bar provides 21% of the recommended daily intake of calcium and 12% of iron, and according to studies carried out by the University of Westminster, the smell of the stuff boosts the immune system by producing a powerful antibody.

fields.headline:
No: 1621
 The Aurora
fields.trailText: Age: Not officially born until Thursday when the Princess Royal flings a bottle of champagne at her in a naming ceremony which will be televised on the web.
fields.body:
Age: Not officially born until Thursday when the Princess Royal flings a bottle of champagne at her in a naming ceremony which will be televised on the web.

Appearance: 76,000-tonne floating holiday village.

Status: Britain's largest world-class superliner.

Price: She set P&O back £200m.

Surely she's not bigger than the Canberra? You haven't been reading your specs. Aurora has 9,200 square metres of deck space which houses 35 tennis courts, three swimming pools (one with a retractable glass roof), a business centre, a library and computer centre, a gym, shops, five lounges, 12 bars, five restaurants, 10 lifts, a theatre, a cinema, a casino and a concert hall. She carries 2,000 passengers and 815 crew, has 920 cabins, 400 with balconies, and further two-deck luxury penthouse suites with personal butler service.

Economical? She uses enough electricity to power Oxford.

Disgraceful. Aren't the days of swanning round the Caribbean in outsized gin palaces over? On the contrary. The British cruise market is booming. The number of people going on holiday cruises has doubled in the past seven years.

Aurora. That's a funny name. Goddess of the Dawn, actually. In homage to the millennium, the ship's funnel and mast will be lit in the colours of the northern and southern lights, aurora borealis and aurora australis.

Irresistible. How much? A fortnight in the Med will cost you £2,345. Or you could go for the 90-day maiden world voyage, a snip at £48,445.

What's the unique selling point? Personality. According to P&O, Aurora has "contemporary elegance rather than glitter and glitz".

Meaning? An illuminated wake, a 24-hour French bistro, an Egyptian themed restaurant and, in the Champions sports bar, a pair of Henry Cooper's boxing gloves and a signed Arsenal football.

Not to be confused with: Oxford.

Do say : "When's the docu-soap?"

Don't say: "Iceberg ahead."

fields.headline: Ever the diplomat
fields.trailText: Lord Carrington keeps wire-haired dachshunds. Has done "for years and years". He and his wife, Iona, name them after prime ministers. At the moment they're on Arthur Balfour and Harold Wilson ("SHUT UP, Harold," he yells when Harold Wilson barks at the cleaner) and "we've had pretty well everyone else". fields.body:
Lord Carrington keeps wire-haired dachshunds. Has done "for years and years". He and his wife, Iona, name them after prime ministers. At the moment they're on Arthur Balfour and Harold Wilson ("SHUT UP, Harold," he yells when Harold Wilson barks at the cleaner) and "we've had pretty well everyone else". No Ted Heath, though ("Ted's not really the sort of name . . .") and no Tony Blair. "Tone," says Lord Carrington, trying it out, with a little shudder.

Historians might also observe with interest that the former foreign secretary, noted for his special relationship with the Iron Lady, has never had a Margaret Thatcher. Lord Carrington, who is sitting on the sofa in his mews house in Knightsbridge, does a little dance with his feet, a soft-shoe shuffle. "People always ask that," he says. "And it's really very difficult to answer." He gives a surprisingly impish grin. "What can you say, 'No, we don't have bitches.'?"

He conducts this interview in two modes. There's the skittish Carrington, the 80-year-old imp, who says "goody goody" and "Can I go now?" every five minutes like a schoolboy waiting for the bell. He introduces me to Diana, his secretary, an attractive woman 30 years or so his junior, in his office across the courtyard. There's a staircase in the room and I ask what's upstairs. "Filing," she says. He says, suggestively, "What did you think?"

He is the sixth baron in his line; there are paintings of family piles on the walls, including one - Hideous , he says - which is now Wickham Abbey school for girls. He's an old Etonian, an old Grenadier Guard, an old Tory and at times he camps his toffness for all it's worth. "I mean, really, " he says of the Times newspaper devoting half its front page to David Beckham's hair, relishing every scandalised minute. "I mean, really ."

But on the subject of Zimbabwe, the octaves drop, the jowls sag, his eyes become hooded behind his over-sized specs. Peter Carrington was Thatcher's Foreign Secretary in 1980 at the time of the Lancaster House agreement, which ended white rule in Zimbabwe.

Letters in the right-wing press (including the Telegraph, of which he is a director) were last week blaming him for the current catastrophe. Certainly it was Carrington who persuaded Thatcher away from her initial support of the (honorary white) Muzorewa regime to accept Mugabe, the self-proclaimed Marxist whom she had described only a few months before as "no better than the IRA".

"I think her inclination was she would have liked to have agreed to the Muzorewa thing, a satisfactory settlement from the point of view of the whites," says Carrington now. "But it wouldn't have lasted and it wouldn't have stopped the war.

"It is very far-fetched of people to say that what is happening in Zimbabwe, which is truly awful, is due to the Lancaster House agreement. But for that, there wouldn't be a single white farmer on any farm in Zimbabwe, or any white person in Zimbabwe at all. What was happening in 1979 was people being killed, black and white, and the place was in a state of collapse. Do I think there was anything we should have done differently?" He pauses and, taking a folded handkerchief out of his top pocket, he dabs the end of his nose. "No, I don't. Honestly. I was thinking about it and I honestly don't think so because we were very lucky to get an agreement on all sides at all. It was the only solution it was possible to get at that time. And really it started off rather well. For 10 years he stuck to the provisions in the agreement."

So what went wrong? He gives a sigh. "The frailty of the leader," he says. "Surrounded by great style and comfort, he's insulated from the economic catastrophe. And he's determined to stay in power at all costs. Really it is always a great mistake, a leader staying too long. . ." He blinks slowly, or it may have been a wink.

He served under Macmillan and Heath, even Churchill, but it was clearly Thatcher who galvanised him the most. He won't have a word said against her, clasps a knee with both hands and rocks back into the sofa cushions when he talks about her. Never been to Africa before they went to Lusaka, he says, "and brave as a lion". She had two pairs of dark glasses in her handbag. "In case they start throwing acid," she said. "And then when I was travelling about with her, it would be about one in the morning, and I'd say 'I'm off to bed,' and she'd look at me and say, 'Poor Peter, are you tired?' A remarkable woman. Remarkable." His feet dance around the floor. "I don't agree with her about everything, in fact I don't agree with her about a lot of things. But a remarkable woman."

His downfall was her making. He resigned in 1982 at the onset of the Falklands war (after being in the Middle East when Galtieri invaded.) "It wasn't much fun leaving, as you can imagine. She tried to stop me. She was very nice to me . . . But it cleared the air. And it all turned out very well really. The Falklands was a great fillip to this country and, curiously, Margaret Thatcher might not have got a second term but for it." So he could say his resignation paved the way for that? He dabs his nose again and ignores the question. He spends a lot of effort trying to remove himself from the centre of things. "If you're in politics you have to take your ups and your downs. Your downs and your ups. Harold," he says. "Ssssssh."

There were four years at Nato after that, and then directorships and boards and trusts and time with family (three children, six grandchildren, three great grandchildren), lots of gardening, here and at his country estate at Bledlow, just down the road from Chequers.

"I must tell you, I did find it inconveniently close on occasions with Ted Heath and Margaret Thatcher and indeed with Harold Macmillan. You would be pruning roses and the telephone rang and you were sent for. It was only really during Labourgovernments, Harold Wilson and Callaghan and so on, that there was peace and quiet." Tony Blair has not been on the phone. "Why should he? I have nothing to contribute."

He won't be drawn on the subject of New Labour or William Hague's Conservative party. "I'm very much against old gentlemen pontificating. I've seen so many people bore on and on." But when he talks about getting older he says he gets irritated about more things these days. Like what? "Like everything," he says waspishly.

He was particularly irritated by Robin Cook's "ethical foreign policy". "The suggestion that all previous foreign ministers had been unethical - I found that quite ridiculous. And so it was proved. The government very sensibly has pursued a policy of realpolitik in Chechnya and East Timor. You do what you can that's the sensible thing."

He also has things to say about the reform of the House of Lords, where he has sat for 55 years. "I've always been in favour of reform. And the more I think about it the more I believe the only way is to have it elected. I don't think it would be composed of better people than it was but it would have more authority, more credibility as a brake on the House of Commons. This Wakeham thing is just a mishmash. Why three-quarters nominated? Just poodles of the prime minister. They won't represent anybody except themselves."

"Is it good for one to be irritated?" he asks. "At least one minds. I find people are much ruder these days, more inconsiderate. And then, when you say that, you're proved totally wrong. You see the most appalling young man, spiky hair, ring through his nose, then you find him helping an old lady across the road. I think one's got to be terribly careful. OK, you can go, I say. On the way out, he says excitedly: "Who are you going to vote for? Who are you going to vote for?" which is rather confusing for a moment or two. "The sex maniac?" "The baboon? The communist? Or the Lib Dem woman no one's heard of?" Diana, the secretary, says she would have voted for Archer "because he charms everyone".

"He doesn't charm me," huffs Carrington. "No," he whispers, leaning forward. "I've heard the person to go for is the Indian."

"What's he called?" asks Diana.

"Oh, I don't know: Be-le-be-le-be-le," he says.

Lord Carrington, who is sitting on the sofa in his mews house in Knightsbridge, does a little dance with his feet, a soft-shoe shuffle. "People always ask that," he says. "Filing," she says. He says, suggestively, "What did you think?" fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent   Michele Hanson
fields.trailText: What a pleasant surprise. Do Not Resuscitate has at last hit the headlines. About time, too. I moaned on about this problem five years ago when my father died. He was suffering from 85, a hopeless condition with no known cure, especially if you live on the south coast. In those days, this malady started at about 70, but it seems to be spreading. Now Mrs Baker, a lady of only 67, has been considered "inappropriate for resuscitation".
fields.body:
What a pleasant surprise. Do Not Resuscitate has at last hit the headlines. About time, too. I moaned on about this problem five years ago when my father died. He was suffering from 85, a hopeless condition with no known cure, especially if you live on the south coast. In those days, this malady started at about 70, but it seems to be spreading. Now Mrs Baker, a lady of only 67, has been considered "inappropriate for resuscitation".

At least they told us in advance. "We shan't resuscitate if he arrests again," A&E staff said. Why not? "Quality of life," muttered Nurse in a concerned way. "We take his age and record into account." My father recovered that time and the next time, but eventually went in for a third and final time.

"Is he going to die?" I asked. Answers were rather cagey, so my mother plodded in and out of hospital, sitting bleakly by his bedside day after day and watching the little bag of liquid emptying. Eventually it stayed empty.

"He's got no water," she told the nurse. "He's all right," said Nurse, scurrying by. Perhaps she thought it wasn't worth the effort. My father was shortly going to peg out anyway and why prolong the misery?

What a pity they didn't tell us that he was going to lie there curled up and semi-conscious, without water or attention for hours on end, because we may as well have kept him at home and all sat round the bed. Had we been told the Reaper was coming, my father could have waited for him in far more comfortable surroundings. Or perhaps the staff really didn't know what was going on. The day after the empty water bag, they wheeled him off for a scan, but too late. He died on the trolley.

Meanwhile, round the corner in an adjacent ward, my auntie, my father's sister, lay in sodden sheets, her bedsores growing apace. We know because my cousin looked. Luckily my father's last few days were an exception. On every other occasion, a skeleton staff of overworked nurses looked after him like saints. But at the very end there was room for improvement. There obviously still is, if it really is the end. In the meantime, try not to die on the south coast.

fields.headline: Britten at its best?
fields.standfirst: Ever since Cecil B DeMille made his silent version of Carmen, directors have had a hard time filming opera. Has Phyllida Lloyd finally cracked it, asks  Alfred Hickling
fields.trailText: Ever since Cecil B DeMille made his silent version of Carmen, directors have had a hard time filming opera. Has Phyllida Lloyd finally cracked it, asks Alfred Hickling
fields.body:
Benjamin Britten hated television. He never owned a set and, when invited to oversee a broadcast version of his opera Billy Budd in 1965, was horrified by the cable-strewn chaos of the studio.

He was right to distrust the long but unsatisfactory marriage of opera and film. His Owen Wingrave was one of the few operas specifically written for TV, but when it was first broadcast in 1971 it was reckoned to be only a partial success.

Later productions in the opera house confirmed what had been suspected all along: Britten had conceived the opera with an eye to the stage, and had little sympathy for the technicalities of television production.

Now the director Phyllida Lloyd has attempted to better Britten by filming Gloriana, one of Britten's greatest flops when it was first performed. The stony reception this uncompromising portrait of Elizabeth I received at its gala presentation for the coronation of the present Queen meant that it was condemned to the farthest reaches of the repertory for 40 years, until Lloyd's 1994 staging for Opera North. The piece was finally reclaimed, bringing a revelatory performance from Dame Josephine Barstow in the title role.

It was Lloyd's dream to rework the production for TV, and the result can be seen on BBC2 tonight. But capturing a hit stage production on celluloid is an elusive goal that has brought many eminent producers, conductors and film-makers to grief.

Right from the birth of cinema - even before the first talkies - film-makers were drawn to opera. In 1915 the ambitious young producer Samuel Goldfish tempted Geraldine Farrar - then the biggest star at the New York Met - to Hollywood to realise his pet project: an adaptation of Bizet's Carmen to be directed by Goldfish's young protege, Cecil B DeMille, who at that point did not have a successful film to his name.

Farrar's presence lent credibility to a project that established DeMille's characteristic epic style, transformed Goldfish into Goldwyn and taught the soprano a whole new repertoire of realistic, camera-developed acting skills. But as the New York Times critic remarked at the time: "It is a curious commentary on the crazy economy of the theatre that a supreme dramatic soprano should give any of her precious time to a form of entertainment wherein the chief characteristic is complete and abysmal silence."

Still, lack of sound did nothing to deter eager directors, even if successes in the genre were few and far between. Notable exceptions include the Strauss-endorsed, silent Der Rosenkavalier of 1926 and the subsequent version of Offenbach's Tales of Hoffmann made by the British team of Powell, Pressburger and conductor Sir Thomas Beecham.

In the latter part of the century, Joseph Losey's Don Giovanni (1978) used evocative, Palladian locations to complement Kiri Tte Kanawa in a fetching wimple. Placido Domingo and a spectacularly sultry Julia Migenes overcame dodgy dubbing in Francesco Rosi's authentically Andalusian Carmen (1984), while a decade before Ingmar Bergman created what many consider to be the finest example of the breed, with his baroque jewel box of a Magic Flute. So much of the rest, however, is a sorry tale of blunders, such as Pavarotti clowning around oafishly in the 1982 Yes, Giorgio, about which the kindest thing one can say is: No, Giorgio.

If transplanting opera from stage to screen has met with limited success, works composed specifically for film have hardly fared any better. Erich Korngold's Give Us This Night, commissioned by Paramount in 1936, could hardly have fielded a stronger team.

Oscar Hammerstein II provided the screenplay and lyrics, two singers with established popular appeal, Gladys Swarthout and Jan Keipura, were lined up to star, and Korngold himself was that rare commodity - a "serious" composer with a successful sideline in Hollywood scores.

Korngold believed he was on the brink of a new era. "We no longer have to lean on Verdi, Puccini and Mascagni," he declared. "We are now conducting a test which will eventually lead to the writing of entire modern operas for the screen. When that day comes, composers will accept the motion picture as a musical form equal to the opera or the symphony."

We're still waiting. But if cinematic opera never really got off the ground, the challenge was rather more realistically taken up by television. The year that Give Us This Night was commissioned also saw the first ever television opera broadcast, when, a mere 11 days after first going on air, the BBC brought Albert Coates's Pickwick to the 400 or so people in the London area who owned a receiver.

Broadcast opera formed a substantial part of the BBC's early remit. In its first three years of transmission the BBC broadcast 30 operas, including some truly obscure choices such as John Blow's Venus and Adonis, Charles Dibdin's Lionel and Clarissa and Thomas Arne's Thomas and Sally.

The first channel to commission an opera for television was New York's NBC, which, in 1949, invited Gian Carlo Menotti to produce the only TV opera besides Britten's Owen Wingrave to have enjoyed any life beyond its initial showing. Menotti's Amahl and the Night Visitors, a Christmas fantasy about a crippled boy's encounter with the Magi, became a seasonal fixture on most American networks.

It was principally NBC's success with televised opera that prompted the BBC to persuade Benjamin Britten to write Owen Wingrave. The composer finally agreed because the proceeds would help rebuild Snape Maltings concert hall near Aldeburgh, which had burned down in 1969. Writing to his friend and sometime librettist William Plomer after the broadcast, Britten confided: "O what a terrible medium - between ourselves it looked pretty awful. I hope you'll see it on the stage before too long."

Phyllida Lloyd's version of Gloriana, on the other hand, was never conceived with the small screen in mind. The transformation came about through a moment of inspiration while Lloyd was skulking in the wings of the Grand Theatre, Leeds, and observing the darkened chaos backstage.

Her original production implied that Elizabeth's public persona was essentially a theatrical role. Her television version puts on screen the world of singers, stage managers, dressers and technicians as a model of the "staged" Elizabethan court. The result is a kind of real-time documentary of a performance in progress utilising the mobility of the camera to create a dimension of intimacy unavailable from a seat in the auditorium.

As an opera production that actually gains from being televised, Gloriana - A Film (to give it its official title) is a breakthrough. But whether it signals the way forward for further small-screen operas is debatable. Lloyd's is not a universally applicable solution.

Achieved at great expense essentially as a six-year labour of love from Lloyd, Opera North and the production company Illuminations, the film is a glorious one-off. Televised opera may be accessible to all, but it still remains the most expensive noise on air.

fields.headline: Adam Hodgkin
fields.trailText: Need to know
fields.body:
Age: 50, formerly publisher at Oxford University Press.

Who's he? MD and co-founder of xrefer.com, a reference engine on the web.

What's the clever idea? "To put lots of reference books on the web and to do the equivalent of cross-references - we call them xreferences - so the whole collection will be more useful, more browsable (or, in web terms, more sticky) for the user. Cross-references allow you to move within a book to relevant topics. We figured a way of doing this which is not expensive in terms of employing lots of editors nor dependent on artificial intelligence in terms of software."

What's the thinking behind it? "That it's not good enough just to put a book on a web. Reference books are ideally suited to the web, but too often they're dumped there without anyone thinking what the real advantage of that information is. We're trying to mine the nuggets of gold which are the cross-references put into it by the original compilers of the books. We think it is important if a compiler of an entry on Coleridge thought there ought also to be a cross-reference to Wordsworth."

How does it work? "In web terms, it works like a list of hits. You go into an entry, see a cross-reference and can then follow that trail of information/reference across all the books in the collection. Our system has to map all the cross-references in all the books. The effect is analogous to you thumb ing through a book and making a move to a cross-reference, where you see entries and pages. We obviously don't have pages, but we have three levels: search box, hit list, entries. We've had to figure out a different sort of architecture for presenting that information to the user. So basically what you have are entries and a sophisticated network of links between them, which allow you to go in one dimension - which is a cross- reference - within any particular book, or in a second dimension - which is the xreference - jumping across the books. You can navigate the system as you choose."

Possible shortcomings? "We have no pictures. At the moment, we're trying to create something which users will click, click, click all the way through and see lots of information quickly, with seamless navigation. Also, at the moment our collection of books - encyclopaedias, historical dictionaries and so on - results in many inconsistencies of style. But perhaps that diversity is a strength."

What's next? "The potential for expansion is important: we have only 40 titles now but we could have hundreds or thousands of titles. We hope to create an enormous site, and to cover lots of different languages and cultures, not just English or American."

 Interview by Carolyne Ellis

So basically what you have are entries and a sophisticated network of links between them, which allow you to go in one dimension - which is a cross- reference - within any particular book, or in a second dimension - which is the xreference - jumping across the books. You can navigate the system as you choose." Possible shortcomings? "We have no pictures. At the moment, we're trying to create something which users will click, click, click all the way through and see lots of information quickly, with seamless navigation. Also, at the moment our collection of books - encyclopaedias, historical dictionaries and so on - results in many inconsistencies of style. But perhaps that diversity is a strength." What's next? "The potential for expansion is important: we have only 40 titles now but we could have hundreds or thousands of titles. We hope to create an enormous site, and to cover lots of different languages and cultures, not just English or American."  Interview by Carolyne Ellis

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
Steve Outing, 'Stop the presses'

www.mediainfo.com

Newspaper websites are in a period of transition, as more of them move into publishing news throughout the day instead of posting stories at specified times. The idea of editions is counter to the nature of internet publishing: ideally, a news website will publish news without a set schedule, and staff must learn to deal with a constant publishing cycle. On the web, your deadline is now.

An important consideration when transitioning to instant news publishing is writing style. Breaking web news is certainly a new type of journalism. It's somewhat like radio and TV news, yet it's still the written word and thus is perceived as such by the audience. How exactly it should be written and presented is still evolving. Early practitioners are writing the rules as they go.

James Curtis in Revolution
www.revolution.haynet.com

So, what do dotcoms need to do to build brands and not just play a short-term fame game? First, they need a point of difference in the market. This might be attainable by the first-movers which briefly offer something radically new: as Freeserve did with its ISP, egg; first-e and smile did with saving and banking; and Amazon did with books. But this becomes increasingly hard for those who follow them.

If differentiation is hard to do, then dot.coms need to obey the next golden rule: to make themselves desirable. As the internet is still relatively new, online brands are perceived to have a certain trendiness which helps them in the desirability department, but this is not enough in itself and, more importantly, it's not going to last.

Next, they need to score points in another area of the branding textbook: ensure that their consumers know what they do. This sounds basic, but it is often overlooked. The most powerful brands are those that consumers automatically associate with a product, and, even better, a product attribute.

According to a new survey for ICL by Mori, some dot.com brands suffer from woeful brand awareness. Research also suggests that the quirky identities favoured by many dot.coms do not always work. The need for a clear proposition is going to become ever more important.

Already, people are predicting the demise of "surfing" on the internet, as consumers head straight for the brands they know and trust. Given that the internet is an excellent one-to-one medium, community building is held up by many as the best way to build powerful online brands. You can spend all the money on advertising you like, but it won't buy you the loyalty and profitability of a few, very committed customers.

fields.headline: Geeks stole my story
fields.standfirst: Do you know what happens to your work once it's online? Most likely it's been copied and pasted onto another site within minutes, and you'll never know.  Josephine Monroe on why people feel it's acceptable to plagiarise on the net
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, when I was a very junior reporter working with Rick Sky on his pop column in the Mirror, I very occasionally got a "top showbiz exclusive". I told Rick I had a secret source, something I'm sure he doubted but never questioned as everything I brought in eventually stood up. So who was my Hollywood deep throat? Well I can now reveal that it was cable TV. No one else had it in the early 90s and I must have been the sole UK viewer of CNN's Showbiz Today. I taped it every night, watched it before I left for work, and occasionally got the odd page lead on a story I'd pilfered from an uncredited source.
fields.body:
Ten years ago, when I was a very junior reporter working with Rick Sky on his pop column in the Mirror, I very occasionally got a "top showbiz exclusive". I told Rick I had a secret source, something I'm sure he doubted but never questioned as everything I brought in eventually stood up. So who was my Hollywood deep throat? Well I can now reveal that it was cable TV. No one else had it in the early 90s and I must have been the sole UK viewer of CNN's Showbiz Today. I taped it every night, watched it before I left for work, and occasionally got the odd page lead on a story I'd pilfered from an uncredited source.

In a discussion on Radio 4's The Message last week, the psychologist Sandi Mann said that my theft was understandable: "When you see magazines and newspapers on shelves you instinctively know that other people will read them because they're on display. When you see something on a screen and you're on your own, you feel like you're the only person in the world seeing it." And if no one knows your secret source, you might just get away with passing the story off as your own.

Sandi Mann was actually explaining why so many journalists think it's safe to nick, pilfer or purloin news from the internet without ever thinking twice about crediting the source. The newspaper trade magazine Press Gazette recently stung Motorcycle News for taking a bogus story straight from a newsgroup and passing it off as their own. uk.rec.motorcycles were suspicious that the Emap title was lifting stories from their service without crediting them and so laid a trap. Sure enough, their fictitious report about Honda's new range of bikes soon turned up in MCN.

Even though internet penetration rates are significantly higher than cable TV's was 10 years ago, we all still seem to see the internet as our own personal deep throat. Ironically, the worst offenders of plagiarism - those who feel their theft has no consequence - are those who have the most to lose from the practice: journalists who work on the internet seem to think that "no one's really looking" and the reporter who originally broke the story will never find out. Again, the psychologists tell us, this is because they write stories in their bedrooms for a virtual product that - frequently - no one's ever heard of. And often it's just too easy: you don't have to take notes, make a phone call or even do any typing - you just cut and paste.

Cases of journalistic theft on the internet are on the up, and they are hard to prove because automated technology distributes data globally in an instant: when a story appears on hundreds of sites within seconds of breaking, it's not easy to claim that you had it five seconds before the competition. The MCN case proved that content can be passed off as journalism, but increasingly journalism is becoming content, no more than binary data to be recycled with ease and at speed.

The sly and ancient practice of recycling stories is now an endemic cancer at the heart of the medium in which we will all earn our futures. The concept of authored, bylined journalism on the net is an increasingly hard one to grasp.

"A lot of the big sites take a newsfeed from PA," says Lisa Hulme, joint managing director of the internet PR agency, big-mouths.com. "We place stories on the PA website because we know that they will appear on Yahoo, Excite and several other portals instantaneously and get read by hundreds of thousands of people within hours. Information is circulated at lightning speed on the internet." HTML coding tricks mean these PA newsfeeds look as if they are content generated by Excite and Yahoo themselves - right colours, right logos etc - with only a small credit for the original source. A well as these big search engines using the same content, further aggregation of content by services such as moreover.com and newsnow.co.uk recycles stories even further. Moreover and newsnow spider, or check, thousands of sites every minute - with or without the website operator's consent - and collate headlines into a kind of macro newsfeed. These newsfeeds - essentially just a series of headlines linking to the source sites - are then used by other sites making them look like their own branded, constantly updated news service.

The combination of theft and internet technology make it very hard to establish ownership over content. But in the quest to gain more traffic and sell advertising, few seem to mind: "Everyone's very happy to be spidered by us," says Nick Gilbert, one of the founders of newsnow.co.uk. "Some sites even create special messages saying 'as used by newsnow', they're so happy for us to syndicate their content. Our syndication service is a real way of getting people to visit a site."

Syndication used to mean a split between the originator of the story and the syndication agency. On the internet however, syndication is not a profit driver but a traffic driver. And with everyone apparently desperate - according to Gilbert - to syndicate their content in such a way and equally desperate to carry the "enhanced" content of a newsfeed, websites are often sporting links to rivals' offerings without realising: the medium that was supposed to speak with a million voices seems to have very little to say for itself that's original. The internet promised diversity but has delivered - in journalistic terms - homogeneity.

Trying to build a reputation for first-class journalism in a medium dominated by porn, unmonitored chat rooms and newsfeeds isn't easy. And when a story you've worked on for weeks appears within minutes on another site without your byline, it's hardly an incentive for excellence. But internet journalists owe it to themselves and their future careers to be more honourable: plagiarism plays into the hands of those who see journalism as just another form of content and who see no reason to pay for our contacts and skill when so much content is available for nada.

For the past year I have been establishing an alternative media portal for people working in TV and publishing. My site is not the only site occupying, in net jargon, the media space and the competition for a limited market has meant accusations of plagiarism are made fairly regularly between me and my competitors. I know from my stat logs that my competitors visit my site on a daily basis and it's not often that an exclusive stays exclusive for long. You can watermark content by inserting invisible bits of html code that you can use to unmask the cut and paste merchants, but it's fairly easy to remove those watermarks and that only trips up the amateurs. Ten years ago it took 36 hours for me to recycle and remodel CNN's scoops for my own ends, but now that the ability to cut and paste has replaced nous and contacts as core journalistic skills, stories are replicated within minutes.

A decade on from my days stealthily peddling journalism that was not my own and printed under someone else's byline, I find myself employing a team of trained and tenacious journalists producing some of the most original and rigorous journalism on the web. Holding on to a sense of authorship over our content, sorry, journalism, in a medium where newsgathering is done by computers and people with meaningless titles like "content producer" is one of the greatest challenges facing independent web publishers. We might get a little sidetracked as we chase the almighty advertising dollar, but we ignore the value of traditional reporting at our peril.

 Josephine Monroe is co-founder of the-bullet

webTitle: Happy-clappy way to satisfy hunger for truth

fields.headline: Happy-clappy way to satisfy hunger for truth
fields.standfirst:
About 2,500 people are attracted each Sunday to the services at a church in west London which follows the Alpha line
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: There is a church just a short step from Harrods in west London that appears to have found the Holy Grail. Every Sunday it plays host to more than 2,500 people, most from within a four-mile radius encompassing some of the most expensive housing and prosperous families in the country. Many are young professionals.
fields.body:
There is a church just a short step from Harrods in west London that appears to have found the Holy Grail. Every Sunday it plays host to more than 2,500 people, most from within a four-mile radius encompassing some of the most expensive housing and prosperous families in the country. Many are young professionals.

Services are conducted by Holy Trinity's curate, Nicky Gumbel, a former barrister who has achieved almost cult status in some church circles. The Alpha courses developed by Mr Gumbel and his vicar, Sandy Millar, and designed to attract non-churchgoers, have had an astonishing worldwide success - running in 15,000 churches of many denominations in 108 countries.

Alpha organisers claim that 3.5m British adults, 6% of the population, have either taken the course or know someone who has. The courses are said to run in 122 out of Britain's 158 prisons, and in 120 of its 170 universities. One famous attender has been Jonathan Aitken. This autumn, in their most ambitious venture yet, Alpha-ites are inviting the whole nation to turn up to their local church to attend a 30-minute video lecture by Mr Gumbel: Christianity: Boring, Untrue, Irrelevant? Naturally, the talk seeks to prove the contrary.

Any church can run its own Alpha course, providing it sticks to the outline developed by Holy Trinity. Two-day courses are run for vicars to learn how to organise meetings or how adapt them to varying groups, such as undergraduates or mothers and toddlers.

Mr Millar, 63, said: "I think there is a hunger for the truth among the younger generation.

"My generation did not go to church to ask questions. Now there is a generation that wants to participate and question; they want to know about the meaning and purpose of life, and what happens when they die."

As the Church of England strives for improved attendances and wider commitment from adherents, the Alpha courses are a rare success. Another is the growing commitment to evangelism among ethnic minority communities.

Some fear evangelism will overreach itself as it dabbles in US-style political involvement, such as against lowering the age of consent and repeal of section 28. But it is in evangelist churches that worshippers in hundreds and even thousands can be counted on Sundays. Derisively labelled "happy-clappy", services spread their message with the help of exuberant hymns accompanied by guitars, swaying and even dancing in the aisles.

Increasingly the evangelicals' innovative approach, and the direct answers they provide to spiritual questions, leads churchmen and women to believe that they are witnessing the way the church will have to develop.

The evangelicals were first to meet in supermarkets, having tapped school clubs, television and even the internet - just as John Wesley was 250 years ago, when he broke with the Anglican establishment to preach around the country in the open air and form a movement that became the Methodists.

Prayer meetings in supermarket car parks are already happening. There is a religious television channel. Soon there may be cyber churches, with the curious logging on in search of spiritual answers.

Peter Brierley is author of a survey suggesting church attendance may fall to 0.5% of the population from 7.5% within 40 years. He suggests: "If time is short, and you can attend a service by just pressing a few buttons, then people will do that."

Youth for Christ is an evangelical organisation with 50,000 members in 50 centres across the country. On the Pensnett estate of Dudley in the Black Country, it has moved six young workers into two houses to befriend youngsters and discuss their problems, without pushing religion at all.

Steve Rollason, the estate's community beat police officer, told the project's coordinator: "There can be little doubt that the workers (whose arrival at one time was openly discussed as being DSS spies and police informers) are now playing a valuable role in liaising... a role where traditionally both police and parents have failed to communicate."

Roy Crowne, Youth for Christ's national director and a member of the Evangelical Alliance's national executive, said: "Kids want to experience something first, and then work out why they feel good about it. In a postmodern age spirituality is on the agenda. It is a supernatural encounter with Christ they are looking for - and the church has always backed away from that."

Even in London, bedevilled by infighting, alleged covens of gay clergy, and opposition to women priests, a revival has taken root. Whereas in the 1970s London churches were the most poorly attended in the country, now they are among the best with up to 10% of the capital's population going to church on Sundays.

Richard Chartres, Bishop of London, said: "Our critics are behind the times. Congregations have increased by 4.5% over five years. The number of our ordinands is up - we have 100 priests in training.

"The fact that there are so many people coming to church every week, given the number of other attractions in their lives, is a miracle, especially as every organisation in the country, from political parties to trade unions, is experiencing a decline."

The Rev Keith Sinclair's church stands next to Villa Park soccer stadium on a council estate in Aston, Birmingham. He sees the future in collaboration with other religions; each faces the same problems, he says, and the local mosques consult him about dealing with the authorities.

"If you become obsessed with numbers, you are on the slippery slope. What matters is the health of the church and its community. Churches are doing a brilliant job, but maybe people are making other choices. We need to find a language to engage with them."

When Aston Villa scheduled a cup tie on a Sunday morning last season, Mr Sinclair had his church bells rung to remind football spectators that others had different considerations at that time of day. "We got quite a lot of sympathy," he chuckles, "including from the fans. And the club certainly haven't tried it again."

fields.headline: Peugeot fears grow
fields.trailText: Sources close to French car maker Peugeot warned yesterday that the continued strength of the pound was threatening jobs at its plants in the West Midlands.
fields.body:
Sources close to French car maker Peugeot warned yesterday that the continued strength of the pound was threatening jobs at its plants in the West Midlands.

The Observer newspaper quoted a senior figure as saying that jobs were at risk at its plants in the Coventry area because the high value of sterling was making UK investment decisions "hard to predict".

Urging the government to state once and for all whether it would or would not join the single European currency, the source said: "Two-thirds of our production is for export. It's a big concern not just now but for the future, because the high level of the pound against the euro makes future investment difficult."
