webTitle: Dour Dye says greed is investors' enemy

fields.headline: Dour Dye says greed is investors' enemy
fields.trailText: Greed is the new enemy of the stock market. At least it is according to Tony Dye, the long-standing bear who found his own fortune by trading in stocks and shares.
fields.body:
Greed is the new enemy of the stock market. At least it is according to Tony Dye, the long-standing bear who found his own fortune by trading in stocks and shares.

Now retired from investment house Phillips & Drew, Mr Dye claimed yesterday that "pure greed or envy of new riches acquired by friends already playing the market suck more and more people into the share-buying spree".

Mr Dye warned four years ago that many shares were overvalued - only to watch the market embark on a meteoric rise fuelled by a frenzy for technology stocks. His former firm, which invests billions on behalf of pension funds, provided a poor return to investors as a result of his views.

Even after the recent market slide, Mr Dye remains convinced that the shares indexes have further to fall and disputes the existence of a new economy.

He calculates that stock markets are now valued at twice their historic average of about $8 trillion. "Either the 'new era' is worth that amount or we are witnessing an $8 trillion bubble."

His advice for investors is to form a view about whether they buy the new-economy story or believe a bubble is waiting to burst. "If you are worried, as I am, that there is a bubble, a cautious approach to the market is correct route to follow." This means picking companies which pay dividends, have sound assets and a long history.

His concession to those who do believe in the new economy is to adopt a high degree of selectivity to "sort the wheat from the storm of chaff" among the dot.com stocks.

One thing he is certain about is that, whichever story investors believe, there is rocky ride ahead. High volatility, he says, will characterise the stock market until one of the stories is proved to be true.

fields.headline: Ian Murray
fields.standfirst: Master reporter, punster, medical correspondent
fields.trailText: Ian Murray, who has died of liver cancer aged 59, was a master of the reporting trade, a story-spotter as much as a story-teller. He could ferret out a ripping yarn in turgid official prose or bland agency copy; he could find a sensitive insight, or a quirky look at life. He was a marvellous reporter.
fields.body:
Ian Murray, who has died of liver cancer aged 59, was a master of the reporting trade, a story-spotter as much as a story-teller. He could ferret out a ripping yarn in turgid official prose or bland agency copy; he could find a sensitive insight, or a quirky look at life. He was a marvellous reporter.

He was always determined to be a journalist, an ambition which alarmed his parents, both distinguished medical practitioners. They had sent him to Haileybury, the school which specialised in turning out servants of Empire, and the Indian Empire in particular. That tickled Ian, but he was never tempted by public service.

Instead, he plunged into the rough end, training on the Croydon Advertiser before moving to the News of the World, reporting sleazy court cases, writing features on the comparative merits of holiday camps, and covering the 1966 Aberfan disaster. He moved on to the pre-Rupert Murdoch Sun - the short-lived and much-lamented broadsheet; then, 30 years ago, gravitated to his natural home, the Times.

Some of its empire-era languor remained. Ian revelled in the authority of the title, and in gently pricking the pomposity of the institution. He served on the labour staff during the industrial mayhem of the early 1970s, and on the newsdesk. For a year, he also took an executive editorial job on the new London commercial radio station, LBC, but quickly bounced back to the Times.

In 1977, his longest-held ambition was realised when he was appointed to the Paris office, serving as deputy to the crusty bureau chief, Charles Hargrove. Ian was a born foreign correspondent, working the diplomatic circuit; his patch included chunks of former French territory in West Africa.

In the early 1980s, he became the Times man in Brussels, a news reporter's gulag. But Ian treated the Euro-babble with splendid contempt - and hewed story after story from the European Economic Community word-face. In Strasbourg, where the European Parliament held its monthly jamboree, British correspondents were once dismayed to be confronted by nine potential stories on one day. Most of us settled for sending over a couple of the best, Ian filed the lot.

He was a generous colleague and splendid companion; his penchant for lamentable puns - he could not see a cloth cap without muttering, "flat hattery will get you nowhere" - masked a love of language and letters. He would, when least expected, recite chunks of Shakespeare, and had an ear for Chaucerian speech.

From Brussels, Ian went on to distinguished service in Jerusalem and Bonn. In the 1990s, as editors - and accountants - wearied of foreign coverage, he was hauled back to London to the newsroom once more. Wapping was not to Ian's taste, but, as a craftsman, he plunged back into home reporting, became local government correspondent, and, in 1997, medical correspondent.

To that role he applied all his experience, his eye for a good story, and his scrupulous regard for the truth. As illness consumed him, he did not deviate an inch from his standards, working until a few days before his death. He wrote of his own predicament, describing the experimental treatment he was undergoing without any self-pity. He was a true reporter.

Ian is survived by his wife, Carol, and by a daughter and son.

 Ian Murray, journalist, born June 15 1940; died April 15 2000.

fields.headline: Lila Kedrova
fields.standfirst: Oscar winner for Zorba the Greek, stage star in London and Paris: an always-young actress with a gift for tragic romance
fields.trailText: Lila Kedrova was rumoured to be 80 when she died - she had chosen her own birth date when all paper evidence was abandoned as her family fled Russia after the Revolution: she liked to say that this allowed her to be any age she wanted. And her preferred age was 16, the age of the soubrette.
fields.body:
Lila Kedrova was rumoured to be 80 when she died - she had chosen her own birth date when all paper evidence was abandoned as her family fled Russia after the Revolution: she liked to say that this allowed her to be any age she wanted. And her preferred age was 16, the age of the soubrette.

That was her gift: she played tragic soubrettes, foolish but not silly young women aged 38 and 66 and 71, still willing to believe that romance will blossom even as they recount, broken-voiced, how romance has failed them in the past.

Kedrova was 45 when director Michael Cacoyannis phoned from Crete to invite her to take over the role of Mme Hortense in Zorba the Greek, after Simone Signoret walked out on him a week into shooting. His Hollywood producers advised him to buy the biggest replacement name around, but he knew that Kedrova - whom he called Little Monster for her persistence - had yearned for the role, even though she was 20 years too young to be the consumptive whore.

He asked in French if she could speak English. "Oui," she lied, flew forthwith from Paris to Crete, caught flu, hid in bed and learned her lines for the first scene. The whole crew, protective of her, coached her: in snagged crochet gloves, she gave the truest performance in that phoney film: her Hortense abandoned herself as totally as an adolescent to hope. Sentiment made her brave. She won an Oscar.

In 1984, by which time she was the right age and rather more - "smeary-faced, shimmery, out of a Toulouse-Lautrec canvas" wrote Frank Rich - she won a Tony for Hortense again, once more opposite Anthony Quinn, in the Broadway musical version.

Lila, short for Elizabeth, was born in whatever was the Russian equivalent of a theatre trunk. Her father was a singer, director of the Kedroff Quartet, her mother in the Petrograd Opera. Lila Kedrova studied piano (encouraged by Shostakovich, for whom she claimed she turned pages of score), her education broken by the family flight first to Germany, then Paris - at the beginning of the Stalin terror, a stranger on the street told her father he was on the list to be purged.

The Kedroffs were Bohemian refugees; Lila went barefoot; Lila was acquainted with Stravinsky and Prokofiev; Lila ran off with the gypsies and pretended to be an orphan to join the circus, pulling a "big, old, friendly" bear around the ring on a chain.

At 14, she joined the emigré Moscow Arts Theatre, a Stanislavsky-style touring company; learnt discipline singing in cafe-concert, ("Quick-quick, I change dress, make up, all"); and studied at drama school under actor-director Pierre Valide, whom she married.

In the 50s, he directed her initial stage successes, including The Rose Tattoo. She was in A View from The Bridge, A Taste of Honey, and a drug addict in Razzia sur la Chnouf, for which she won the French critics' best performance award in 1955, when it was made into a film.

She reluctantly took roles in European and Hollywood films - including Hitchcock's Torn Curtain, and A High Wind in Jamaica - but hated to leave the stage even for a holiday. After Zorba, she could have patented the character on the movie cameo role circuit of the time, but she did not: her best performance was in Polanski's 1976 The Tenant.

Onstage, she took the part she had always been meant to play, Lyuba Ranevskaya in Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard, in London in 1967: her Ranevskaya's sense of loss at parting with the estate was overcome by excitement at rejoining her lover and frittering away the money in Paris. (During the production she had met her second husband, Canadian stage director Richard Howard.)

The next year, she was Frau Schroeder, Sally Bowles's Berlin landlady in the London production of Cabaret, a widow romanced by a Jewish greengrocer: this time love did not make her brave. "What would you do?", she half-growled, half whispered, and - parting pragmatically with hope - "It'll all go on, if we're here or not. So who cares. So what?" But when she played Gigi's aunt at the Fortune in 1976, she seemed, for all the wisdom, younger than teenage Gigi; she was perfectly wistful as Madame Armfeld in A Little Night Music at Chichester in 1989.

Kedrova remained with Howard, based in Canada and Paris, until her death. She leaves no other family.

fields.headline: Rabah Bitat
fields.standfirst: One of the founders of Algerian independence
fields.trailText: The French remember All Saints Day 1954 in Algeria as  La Toussaint Sanglante, the Bloody All Saints Day, announcing the most savage of colonial wars. That day, November 1, marked the real beginning of the Algerian war of independence, when a series of revolts became a true revolution.
fields.body:
The French remember All Saints Day 1954 in Algeria as La Toussaint Sanglante, the Bloody All Saints Day, announcing the most savage of colonial wars. That day, November 1, marked the real beginning of the Algerian war of independence, when a series of revolts became a true revolution.

Six young men in Algeria, and their three Cairo-based associates, planned this insurrection at a meeting in June 1954. The so-called six historiques are considered to be the founders of independence, and Rabah Bitat, who has died in a Paris hospital aged 74, was one of them.

Bitat had been in the movement from his earliest years. Born in the village of Aïn Kerma, in the eastern department of Constantine, he came from a very poor family, but had been one of a handful of Algerian children to attend school. At the age of 13, when his parents were unable to buy the books he needed, he left school and worked first in a tobacco factory and then for a civil engineering firm.

At 16, he joined the Messali Hadj Party of the Algerian People, which worked for independence and for the confiscation of French settlers' land. Although it was among the most radical of nationalist parties, most Messali members did not envisage violence. But the events of May 1945 convinced Bitat that a violent revolution was necessary.

The French had organised a second world war victory parade in Sétif, a market town which was not far from Constantine. The army encountered Algerians protesting about bad economic conditions, and shots were fired. The troubles spread and the French army took its revenge after 100 Europeans had been killed. Although estimates vary greatly, it is believed that nearly 10,000 Algerians were killed.

For Bitat, the time for legal action was over; it was time to begin attacks on French farmers and military posts. The future lay in organisation, effectively in the Organisation Secrète that Bitat and four associates formed, breaking away from Messali. Algeria was divided into zones and each leader was made responsible for a zone. Bitat's was south of Algiers.

This was in February 1947, and for the next seven years the emphasis was on training and indoctrination. At first the methods of the French Resistance were a model, but later news of what was happening to the French army in Indo-China filtered through and tactics changed.

In 1950, Bitat was identified as involved in a conspiracy to seize arms and was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment in absentia. Under false names, he travelled to France, making contact with underground organisations.

The November 1 1954 attacks were not regarded as important by the French military at the time. Bitat, based in Blida, south of Algiers, was forced to take refuge in the hills. There were few casualties on either side, although Bitat's greatest triumph was the number of telephone lines that were cut. But in December, more than 600 people attended the funeral of a local nationalist in Blida, a tribute to Bitat's organisation and to its effect on public opinion.

On March 25 1955, as Bitat left a cafe in Algiers, he was denounced by a fellow Algerian, and arrested because he was carrying a revolver. Once identified, he was interrogated and tortured for 12 days; twice he tried to commit suicide.

He was sentenced to life imprisonment, and became a witness to the terrible conditions that existed in the Algerian prisons and to the boredom that dominated life in them. When General de Gaulle began his negotiations with Algerian leaders, he showed his good intentions by having Bitat and fellow prisoners moved to more comfortable surroundings. In May 1961, they were transferred from prison to living under police supervision.

Bitat was released in April 1962 and returned to Algiers to join Ben Bella's first government. But he was soon in opposition. In April 1963, he denounced attempts to come to an economic agreement with France. Algeria, he claimed, should only befriend socialist countries. He resigned, and finding himself in danger, fled to France.

He returned later, supporting the coup d'état against Ben Bella in 1965, and held ministerial offices under President Boumédienne. He then became a member of the Algerian Assembly until 1992. In 1999, he emerged from retirement to support the candidature of Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who was elected president with the aim of reconciling the Algerian people.

In 1962, Bitat married Zohra Drif, a heroine of the Battle of Algiers, who had been sentenced to 20 years' imprisonment in 1958, for planting a bomb in a bar opposite French army headquarters.

They had two sons and a daughter.

fields.headline: Skychefs strike resolved
fields.trailText: Britain's longest-running industrial dispute has been resolved with the offer of job reinstatement or compensation running into several thousand pounds for 270 sacked strikers at Skychefs.
fields.body:
Britain's longest-running industrial dispute has been resolved with the offer of job reinstatement or compensation running into several thousand pounds for 270 sacked strikers at Skychefs.

The workers, who provide in-flight catering services for 14 airlines operating from Heathrow airport, were sacked in November 1998 when they went on a legal one-day strike over changes to shift patterns.

Resolution of the dispute comes on the eve of the intro duction of new workers' rights in the Employment Relations Act which would have made the sackings illegal.

The act, which comes into force today, bars employers from sacking staff during the first eight weeks of a legally called strike. Since their dismissal 17 months ago, the Skychefs strikers, most of whom are women of Asian background, have picketed the company's kitchens and airlines which use the services of LSG Skychefs, part of German national carrier Lufthansa.

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.trailText: What is fiscal policy?
fields.body:
What is fiscal policy?

It is the impact the government's tax and spending plans has on the economy. If the government takes more money out of the economy in taxes than it spends, then the fiscal stance is restrictive. If it spends more than it earns, other things being equal, fiscal policy will boost the economy. If the Bank of England believes the government's tax and spending decisions are adding more fuel to an overheated economy it will put the brakes on with higher borrowing costs.

If the government is running a surplus is the fiscal stance tight?

It is not that simple. The fiscal position is affected by what economists call the automatic stabilisers. When growth is above trend, as it is in the UK at the moment, taxes rise and unemployment payments fall which tends to shift the government's finances into the black. But analysts and the Bank are more interested in the non-automatic bits of fiscal policy: structural changes to tax and spending patterns and the impact of the government's decisions on its finances.

How is that judged?

According to the Treasury, the absolute fiscal stance is given by the change in its predictions for the size of the public sector's surplus or deficit from one year to the next. Gordon Brown is predicting that the public sector's surplus will fall between the 1999-2000 fiscal year and 2000-01, which means policy is loosening.

However, the Treasury prefers to concentrate on the relative fiscal stance - how its forecasts for the balance between spending and revenues compares to the predictions it made in the previous year's budget. As the government will be running a bigger surplus than it originally planned, the Treasury argues that the fiscal stance has tightened.

webTitle: Indian agency chief may quit in protest

fields.headline: Indian agency chief may quit in protest
fields.trailText: The head of the Brazilian government's department for Indian rights is expected to resign today in protest at the violence used by military police against Indians during the country's 500th anniversary celebrations.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The head of the Brazilian government's department for Indian rights is expected to resign today in protest at the violence used by military police against Indians during the country's 500th anniversary celebrations.

Several people were hurt on Saturday when police threw teargas canisters and charged at 3,000 Indians and their sympathisers marching to Porto Seguro, where President Fernando Cardoso launched a week of official festivities.

Carlos Mares, president of the national Indian agency, said that he could no longer be part of a government that used force against the organised indigenous movement.

"It was pure aggression," he said. "The intention was not to dissolve the march but to hurt people. The last time I saw such truculence was during the [military] dictatorship."

The Indians, representatives of many of Brazil's 227 remaining tribes, were marching to Porto Seguro to hand a document to Mr Cardoso, Mr Mares said.

fields.headline: Computer games linked to violence
fields.trailText: Violent video games step up aggressive behaviour in young males, according to both laboratory and real life studies, two US psychologists claim today.
fields.body:
Violent video games step up aggressive behaviour in young males, according to both laboratory and real life studies, two US psychologists claim today.

Their research, published a year after the Columbine high school massacre, is certain to provoke controversy - and concern about the long-term effects of graphic slaughter at fingertip control.

"One study reveals that young men who are habitually aggressive may be especially vulnerable to the aggression-enhancing effects of repeated exposure to violent games," they said. "The other study reveals that even brief exposure to violent video games can temporarily increase aggressive behaviour in all types of participants."

On April 20 1999, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold murdered 12 students and a teacher and wounded 23 others before shooting themselves at the Columbine high school in Littleton, Colorado.

They were known to enjoy Doom, a video game licensed by the US military to train soldiers to kill. In a classroom project the pair made a videotape of their own version, in which they dressed in trenchcoats, carried guns and killed school athletes.

They did it again, in the school, with real guns less than a year later. One researcher described Harris, 18, and Klebold, 17, as "playing out their game in God mode".

There is disputed evidence suggesting that cinema and television violence encourages aggressive behaviour.

A US judge recently threw out a case brought against 25 video game companies after a boy of 14 with a gun killed three students in a prayer group at a Kentucky high school. The judge said: "Tragedies such as this simply defy rational explanation, and courts should not pretend otherwise."

But Craig Anderson, of the University of Missouri-Columbia, and Karen Dill, of Lenoir-Rhyne College in Iowa, report in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology today that video games might indeed have damaging effects. In one study they questioned 227 college students about their aggressive attitudes, and asked them to report on their own aggressive behaviour - deliquency, vandalism and so on - in the past. They also asked the students about their video game playing habits.

"We found that students who reported playing more violent video games in junior and high school engaged in more aggressive behaviour," Dr Anderson said.

The two scientists then got 210 students to play either Wolfenstein 3D, a violent game, or Myst, a non-violent one. Afterwards the students "punished" their opponents with a noise blast of varying intensity. The ones who played the violent games spent longer "punishing" each other than those who had played the non-violent game.

Dr Anderson said: "In the short run, playing a violent video game appears to affect aggression by priming aggressive thoughts.

"Longer-term effects are likely to be longer lasting as well, as the player learns and practises new, aggression-related scripts that can become more and more accessible for use when real life conflict situations arise."

A spokesman for the British Psychological Society was not convinced: "There have been a number of attempts over here to set up experiments like these, and they have got absolutely nowhere. There is a world of difference between pressing a noisy buzzer for longer and shooting at your classmates in a college."

But Dr Dill argued that the laboratory experiment did reflect real experience: "It is important not to train a generation of people to be disrespectful, or to not value life or the humanity of other people."

fields.headline: Impressions of Monet
fields.standfirst: Artist's own collection yields rich harvest for exhibition
fields.trailText: The Claude Monet industry, which has dominated painting exhibitions throughout the world for at least a decade, is about to produce its trump card: a display of the entire collection held by the Paris Académie des Beaux Arts, including works dating back to his adolescence.
fields.body:
The Claude Monet industry, which has dominated painting exhibitions throughout the world for at least a decade, is about to produce its trump card: a display of the entire collection held by the Paris Académie des Beaux Arts, including works dating back to his adolescence.

After rival sell-out shows in London, Paris, North America and Rome in recent months, which drew on private and public collections, the exhibition opening at the Marmottan museum in Paris on Thursday will ensure that just about all he drew or painted in 86 years until his death in 1926 will have been put on view.

Several benefactors have donated works, but most of the paintings are from Monet's personal collection at Giverny, west of Paris, donated by his younger son, Michel.

The popularity of the Giverny house, studio and gardens, now one of the country's biggest tourist attractions, encouraged the Marmottan's curators to empty out their reserves, which include 23 drawings finished before Monet was 20. Among more than 100 paintings on show until the end of December are classics like Waterloo Bridge, Gare Saint-Lazare and Promenade près d'Argenteuil.

webTitle: New economy weighs heavily on real world

fields.headline: New economy weighs heavily on real world
fields.trailText: As the economy becomes more detached from obvious human need, and more people depend for livelihood on inessential work, it becomes harder to demonstrate the necessity for this or that occupation.
fields.body:
As the economy becomes more detached from obvious human need, and more people depend for livelihood on inessential work, it becomes harder to demonstrate the necessity for this or that occupation.

An appeal to the market as arbiter of last resort is a thin justification for labour in a world of so much suffering and want.

The economy of fantasy depends upon collusion by its participants that theirs is indeed the most vital work of the world. Hence the heroics of labour which the privileged have seized in their arduous calling: high-paid workaholics, helots of the advanced market economy, driven to work longer hours than were ever imposed by factory masters in Victorian England.

This explains the urgency of documents, blueprints, reports, plans, schedules and printouts which must be on somebody's desk by yesterday, the unblinking stare of banks of screens before which the burned-out eyes of insomniac whizz-kids monitor minusucule shifts in the value of currencies. And the perpetual birdsong of mobile phones in public places - more imperious even than the factory-hooters which once sounded over the streets of Bolton and Halifax.

People serving abstractions such as futures, derivatives, and other invisibles must shout louder to advertise their indispensability; and despite handsome material rewards, they are always complaining of lack of recognition of their dedication and self-sacrifice.

The importance of display, the burnishing of images and appearances, presentations and makeovers have loosened our purchase on reality.

Our material needs are wafted in from a distant elsewhere; we are self-provisioning in virtually nothing.

We must convince ourselves of the value of our functionless activity. The high-octane busy-ness of executives who are head-hunted for their vision, and then dismissed within months because of falling profits, with the meagre consolation of a six-figure bonus.

The self-importance of celebrities talking on television about the tragedy of their year-long marriage, or the purposeless mobility of intercontinetal travellers attending conferences in sound-proofed hotel suites close to airports, whose fluttering diaries are chock-full until September at the earliest.

Behind the business jargon which is now applied to every human activity - targets and outcomes, productivity and best practice - can be detected high anxiety, doubts over its human purposes, the question not to be asked: what is it all for?

We have never been so busy. We find ourselves doing several things at once - shopping, eating and phoning; watching television, reading and helping with the chilldren's homework; travelling, listening to music, working at the lap-top; making love, planning tomorrow's schedule and recalling pornographic images taken off the internet.

Our leisure time is even more colonised than our work - so much fun to be packed into the inelastic hours at our disposal!

The economy has long ceased to serve humanity; and in recent years even the pretence that it does so has been abandoned.

The "performance" of the economy is now the highest priority. Bulletins appear daily on its health, whether it is ailing, robust or recovering, whether markets are nervous, volatile or steady. The economy has been anthropomorphised, and human beings diminished, disposable as the trash we become if we cease to be marketable.

Stress, bullying, harassment, discrimination are significant features of this economy. Older consolations of work-place solidarity have vanished in favour of a more intensely competitive insecurity: desks are cleared, pay-offs settled, services dispensed with in the twinkling of an eye.

This new economy is unpredictable, and we respond to its arbitrariness in much the same way as the serving classes formerly curtsied and touched their forelock to more material masters of flesh and blood.

The greatest growth in employment is in leisure and entertainment: a pub chain "creates" 5000 jobs; retail outlets promise work for thousands; fast food companies provide career opportunities.

These are spoken of as "real jobs", unlike the archaic manufacture of expendables such as shoes, steel, cups, clothes and ships.

The promised liberation of the "knowledge-based economy" remains elusive. We think we are tooling up for the new millennium, but most of us are learning to know our place in the have-a-nice-day service sector.

People who do possess skills and knowledge find these being degraded. Those in the "caring professions" see their abilities eroded by industrial disciplines - doctors spend more time on paperwork, teachers merely "facilitate education", while social workers are busy avoiding blame for any violence their clients may commit.

Working with people is a debased ill-paid alternative to flying high in the economy of fantasy.

This economy sounds light and insubstantial, but that is an illusion. It weighs oppressively upon the damged resource-base of the earth, and equally upon those who perform the despised labour we have jettisoned: the factory workers, harvesters of our daily bread in Asia and Africa, the servitors of global wealth who are pressed into the maintenance of the precarious and unquiet well-being of the rich.

 Jeremy Seabrook is a writer.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bloodbath as hostages freed
fields.body:
Bloodbath as hostages freed

An operation to free dozens of hostages held by Islamic guerrillas in the Philippines ended in the death of as many as 20 captors.

Government forces backed by artillery, helicopter gunships and navy gunboats launched their assault on Saturday to rescue the hostages, many of them children, who had been held for 35 days by the fundamentalist Abu Sayyaf guerrillas in a hideout on Basilan island in the south. Reuters, Zamboanga

Suharto assets to be seized

The Indonesian authorities plan to seize the assets of the ailing former president Suharto, who is accused of corruptly amassing a fortune.

A spokesman for the attorney general's office said that investigators were listing Mr Suharto's assets, but would not say when they would be seized. Reuters, Jakarta

Killings 'marked Columbine date'

A boy of 15 accused of stabbing five pupils and a school employee in Ottawa, Canada, last week planned the alleged attacks to coincide with the first anniversary of the high school massacre at Columbine, Colorado, the police say. AP, Ottawa

Iranian papers closed down

Iran's special press court closed three pro-reform newspapers without warning yesterday, journalists said: the biggest blow yet to the new independent press.

Journalists said the editors of Asr-e Azadegan, Fath and Iran-e Farda were told to stop publication immediately. Reuters, Tehran

Actor hanged during play

An Italian died during a re-enactment of Christ's passion, probably because the noose he wore for the role of Judas was too tight.

In the performance in the town of Camerata Nuova, Renato di Paolo, 23, jumped from about 30cm and lay still with the noose round his neck while the play went on. An actor raised the alarm after noticing that he looked too rigid. Reuters, Rome

webTitle: British ministries divided on American missile shield

fields.headline: British ministries divided on American missile shield
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence appear to be at odds in their assessments of US proposals to create a new anti-ballistic-missile system.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence appear to be at odds in their assessments of US proposals to create a new anti-ballistic-missile system.

On the agenda of the talks which begin in New York today on the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, Washington's scheme for a national missile defence (NMD) system is one of the most contentious issues.

The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain will tell the conference that the American plan, which is meant to protect the US from attacks by "rogue" states such as North Korea, "raises complex and difficult issues".

The Foreign Office is concerned about the plan.The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, is more enthusiastic, saying that the government is "in a very good position and strong role as far as fetching and carrying [between the US and Russia] is concerned".

Not least of the Foreign Office's concerns is the fact that part of the proposed system would be built in Britain, but Britain would not necessarily be under its protective umbrella.

The plan involves upgrading the US radar station at Fylingdales on the North Yorkshire moors. The US satellite communications station at Menwith Hill, near Harrogate, also in North Yorkshire, also plays a key role.

Mr Hoon described Menwith Hill as part of a global system able to detect missiles launches throughout the world.

"Clearly, if you've got such a system in place, then that system could be used as part of [the US's] national missile defence. But it is a step we have yet to take," he said.

On the Fylingdales upgrade he said: "The position remains that unless and until the Americans take a decision to deploy NMD we are not required to take a decision as to what assistance we might give, and that remains the position."

For his part, Mr Hain will say tonight that the issue has to be addressed by the US and Russia "through calm, measured dialogue".

"Despite obvious differences, we hope they can reach an agreement," he will say. "We have made clear to both sides that we continue to value the [present] anti-ballistic-missile treaty and wish to see it preserved."

He will be able to argue at the New York conference that Britain under the Labour government has taken unprecedented steps towards greater transparency in nuclear weapons policy.

The 1998 strategic defence review said Britain would maintain a stockpile of less than 200 operationally available nuclear warheads.

This compares with a maximum of 300 warheads announced by the previous Tory government, and is fewer than those held by the other four members of the official nuclear club.

But review also said that the Trident system had to be capable of a "sub-strategic" role: the clear implication being that the government would be prepared to use nuclear weapons against non-nuclear states.

It said: "The credibility of deterrence depends . . . on retaining an option for a limited strike that would not automatically lead to a full-scale nuclear exchange."

The review also committed the government to include British nuclear weapons in international negotiations towards "mutual, balanced, and verifiable" reductions, but only when it was "satisfied with [the] progress towards our goal of the global elimination of nuclear weapons".

Such language enables the government to argue that Britain's nuclear weapons should be protected for the foreseeable future from any arms reduction negotiations.

Meanwhile, more than 270 MPs have signed six separate Commons motions urging the government to have nothing to do with Washington's new anti-ballistic-missile project.

Britain will also come under pressure to explain its plans for a successor to Trident and to detail the research it is undertaking with the US.

Documents leaked recently from the Aldermaston atomic weapons factory refer to a plan "to safeguard UK options and capabilities for a future nuclear weapon by December 2000".

But earlier this month the defence procurement minister, Baroness Symons, denied that a "new nuclear weapon system" was being developed at Aldermaston.

Nevertheless, she added that the factory "maintains a capability to produce a successor to Trident should this be required by the government.

"That decision is still some way off."

Such language enables the government to argue that Britain's nuclear weapons should be protected for the foreseeable future from any arms reduction negotiations. Meanwhile, more than 270 MPs have signed six separate Commons motions urging the government to have nothing to do with Washington's new anti-ballistic-missile project. Britain will also come under pressure to explain its plans for a successor to Trident and to detail the research it is undertaking with the US. Documents leaked recently from the Aldermaston atomic weapons factory refer to a plan "to safeguard UK options and capabilities for a future nuclear weapon by December 2000". But earlier this month the defence procurement minister, Baroness Symons, denied that a "new nuclear weapon system" was being developed at Aldermaston. Nevertheless, she added that the factory "maintains a capability to produce a successor to Trident should this be required by the government. "That decision is still some way off."

fields.headline: Bleak prospects for nuclear talks
fields.standfirst: As negotiations begin, the risks are great but ambitions small
fields.trailText: The commitment of nuclear powers to disarmament faces a severe test at an international conference beginning in New York today to review the 30-year-old non-proliferation treaty.
fields.body:
The commitment of nuclear powers to disarmament faces a severe test at an international conference beginning in New York today to review the 30-year-old non-proliferation treaty.

At the last treaty review conference five years ago the nuclear powers, including Britain, committed themselves to "the determined pursuit . . . of systematic and progressive efforts to reduce nuclear weapons globally, with the ultimate goal of eliminating those weapons".

That high-minded objective received a setback when India and Pakistan conducted nuclear tests.

The mood in New York as ministers gather is not optimistic. The US has not helped by threatening to go off in pursuit of a new missile programme. The talks are also being held against a background of indifference in the post-cold-war age.

The mood is beginning to change, however. The first stirrings of unease began four years ago when India and Pakistan, neither of which has signed the NPT treaty, tested nuclear weapons.

Worrying

Just as worrying is the the attitude of the US. Last year congress voted against the comprehensive test ban treaty, the Republicans insisting that the US should not permit any international constraints on its ability to test and modernise its nuclear forces.

The prospects for a concrete conclusion to the NPT discussions in four weeks' time look remote. Those in the nuclear club, while urging other countries not to join, show little sign of being flexible.

Nato's "strategic concept", announced at its 50th anniversary summit in Washington last year, stated that "the circumstances in which any use of nuclear weapons might have to be contemplated [by the allies] are . . . extremely remote". But it added: "Nuclear weapons make a unique contribution . . . They demonstrate [to enemies] that aggression of any kind is not a rational option."

Nato continues to reject a "no first use" commitment, and one of Vladimir Putin's first initiatives on becoming president of Russia was to abandon Moscow's "no first use" policy. Against the background of deteriorating conventional forces, he also suggested that Russia would in future rely on a lower nuclear threshold.

The Russian parliament's recent ratification of the Start II arms reduction treaty, which commits each of the two powers to cut its nuclear warheads from 6,000 to 3,500 by 2007, will put further pressure on the US congress to follow suit.

"The Russians will go into the non-proliferation treaty review conference looking like good guys. The spotlight will be on us," a US diplomat said.

The US and Russia are preparing to begin talks on Start III. The Russians want to cut the number of each side's long range nuclear warheads to 1,500. The US does not want to go below 2,000 or 2,500.

But the New York conference also takes place under the shadow of US plans for a national missile defence system (NMD). The project will be "the ghost at the wedding", said Rebecca Johnson, director of the Acronym Institute, a respected London disarmament thinktank. A decision to go ahead with NMD would require an amendment to the anti-ballistic missile treaty signed by Washington and Moscow in 1972, which enshrines the traditional concept of deterrence and "mutual assured destruction".

Moscow opposes any change to the ABM treaty, despite Washington's insistence that its anti-ballistic missile project is designed to protect the US from "rogue" states such as North Korea, Iran, Iraq and Libya. But analysts suggest that the US is seeking "absolute security". They argue that the project reflects a dangerous shift from long-held assumptions about deterrence towards a belief in the "limited use" of nuclear weapons, shared by other countries, not least Pakistan.

Violation

"There is a move towards the concept of a 'normalisation' of nuclear weapons, towards reintegrating them into general weapons arsenals," Ms Johnson warned.

Some observers believe that Nato's strategic concept opens the way to it using nuclear weapons against biological and chemical weapons, in violation of the "negative security assurances" given by the nuclear powers in 1995.

The British American Security Information Council argues that Nato's existing "nuclear sharing" arrangements in time of war - whereby European non-nuclear states could gain access to US nuclear bombs - clearly breach the NPT.

The nuclear powers will come under pressure from two groups fed up with what they regard as hypocritical preaching: the "New Agenda" countries, including Japan, Canada, Egypt, Brazil and South Africa, and the Non-Aligned Movement. But those at the opening meeting are not preparing for some huge step forward. At best they hope for a form of words on which they can agree. The nuclear risk is huge, but the ambitions in New York are small.

fields.headline: Split opposition tests a monarch
fields.trailText: From the day he was born in Claridges hotel in war-time London, Crown Prince Alexander has been raised as the quintessential English gentleman.
fields.body:
From the day he was born in Claridges hotel in war-time London, Crown Prince Alexander has been raised as the quintessential English gentleman.

Alexander Karadjordjevic has rarely visited his homeland, and speaks halting Serbo-Croat, but he is the man many hope will unite the forces to eject Slobodan Milosevic, Europe's last "dictator king".

With the help of the internet the former British army captain has tried to enhance his role as unifier of Yugoslavia's notoriously fractious opposition.

This weekend he held talks in Greece bringing together Serbian dissident emigres, politicians, clerics, trade unions, youth activists and journalists. The aim was to bridge the divisions that have helped keep Yugoslavia's isolated opposition disunited and Mr Milosevic in power.

"Our quarrel is with the regime, not amongst ourselves," the exiled crown prince said in an interview at the close of the Athens talks.

"And the issue in Serbia today is democracy, reconciliation and the country's reintegration into Europe. My contribution is to gather people from all areas who might not ordinarily meet. Here we have been able to express views without the bad breath of the regime breathing on us."

Alexander - who lives and works within walking distance of Claridges - said he hoped the various groups would re turn with renewed impetus to unite against Mr Milosevic before the local elections.

"We are all very concerned that this dreadful man is firing up another round of negative nationalism in Montenegro . . . that we could be headed for another civil war. We must get rid of him," he said,

Polls show that only 25% of the Serbian population favours the restoration of the monarchy. But opposition leaders said they hoped that dissidents would accept the Athens declaration, proposing that Prince Alexander should oversee a council of "wise men", in collaboration with the church, to arbiter differences between them.

"The crown prince is a very reasonable man, he has shown that he stands above politics by not taking sides. So why not get him to moderate in cases that we, the opposition, cannot resolve?" said Zoran Djindjic, heads of the Democratic party.

Alexander openly admits that he would like to follow in the footsteps of his distant cousin King Juan Carlos I, who oversaw Spain's peaceful transition to democracy.

"I don't want to ram the monarchy down their throats, to give them food they don't like," he said with a smile.

"The biggest gift I can give the nation is democracy, to walk down the streets and see people being happy. That's a real monarchy. That would be fantastic."

webTitle: Sri Lankan army rocked as Tigers win stronghold

fields.headline: Sri Lankan army rocked as Tigers win stronghold
fields.trailText: The Sri Lankan army suffered a major reversal yesterday when heavy fighting against the rebel Tamil Tigers on the Jaffna peninsula left hundreds dead and wounded.
fields.body:
The Sri Lankan army suffered a major reversal yesterday when heavy fighting against the rebel Tamil Tigers on the Jaffna peninsula left hundreds dead and wounded.

It was forced to withdraw from its strategic Elephant Pass base, which controls the narrow causeway from the mainland to the peninsula. More than 15,000 troops holding the garrison were ordered to move north.

The government said 79 soldiers were killed and more than 400 wounded in the heavy artillery and mortar exchanges.

"We have relocated from the area, I would not say we have lost it," a military spokesman, Brigadier Pallitha Fernando, said.

"We have had reversals in the past but we will start from here again."

The Tigers are jubilant about capturing the base, which gives them a firm foothold on the peninsula, the centre of their mini-state until five years ago.

The rebel radio station said their fighters had hoisted the flag of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and recovered a large stock of weapons.

"The fall of this crucial base at the gate of Jaffna will facilitate the LTTE to gain its strategic goal of liberating Jaffna," a press release issued by the Tigers said.

The peninsula is highly symbolic for both sides. It was the Tamil Tigers' stronghold for five years, the birthplace of their leader Velupillai Prabakharan, and the homeland they claim for the minority Tamil community.

The army scored a huge propaganda victory retaking Jaffna town in 1995. The Tigers, who have consistently vowed to recapture the area, launched the latest stage in their offensive at the end of last month. An attempt on the Elephant Pass base was expected, and it was well fortified.

The army's sudden collapse has been attributed to poor leadership, exhaustion and poor morale. Although the army is more than 120,000 strong, most young men join for the wages of £70 a month rather than through patriotic pride.

The Tigers on the other hand are keenly motivated, and have the advantage of knowing the terrain, the culture and the language.

They are now in a better position than at any time in the past five years to take the whole of the 2,500 sq km (965 sq miles) peninsula, and analysts believe they will eventually try to capture Jaffna town. Although the rebel numbers are small, there are known to be many infiltrators and sympathisers on the peninsula.

Further successes would also help to strengthen the Tigers' hand in proposed peace talks, which are being arranged by the Norwegian government.

webTitle: Trams are the best way to beat the jams

fields.headline: Trams are the best way to beat the jams
fields.trailText: Jean Shaoul (Analysis, April 19) in considering London underground alone, falls into the same trap as the mayoral candidates.The underground only carries a small part of London's traffic. The 1998 transport white paper calls for an integrated approach, which uniquely is possible in London, where deregulation and competition have not been introduced. Expanding the underground, as demonstrated by the Jubilee line extension, is an expensive way to increase the capacity of London's transport system.
fields.body:
Jean Shaoul (Analysis, April 19) in considering London underground alone, falls into the same trap as the mayoral candidates.The underground only carries a small part of London's traffic. The 1998 transport white paper calls for an integrated approach, which uniquely is possible in London, where deregulation and competition have not been introduced. Expanding the underground, as demonstrated by the Jubilee line extension, is an expensive way to increase the capacity of London's transport system.

Most journeys in London are made by road: on foot, cycle, bus, taxi and car. The cost of expanding the passenger capacity of the road network could be relatively small, if investments attracted car commuters to release space they wastefully occupy. About 70% of car trips are under five miles. Surveys have shown that these can be made faster by bike. The cost would be small to create a bike network to give all Londoners a real choice on direct and safe routes. The cost of converting trunk bus routes to tram operation is also small. For the cost of the Jubilee line extension, a 300-mile tram network could be built.

Prof Lewis Lesley
John Moores University

 Jean Shaoul is wrong to say that the London underground has been a publicly owned public service since the 1930s. From its creation in 1933 until 1947 (a period often thought of as a golden age) LT was a privately owned monopoly. LT was nationalised in 1948, and comparing the period since then with 1933 to 1947, it is not easy to conclude public ownership has served Londoners well.

Also relevant is that from 1935 on, a huge programme of modernisation and expansion of the network was initiated, funded by £40m raised by loan stock guaranteed by the government - in other words, a form of bonds. The stock was due to be repaid by 1955, but that obligation was overtaken by nationalisation, so we can never know how the obligation to repay or refinance bonds would have affected services. It is, however, correct that the underground has never generated a return on capital investment that would satisfy the private sector since the advent of mechanised street transport at the turn of the century.

AJ Robertson
Bromley, Kent

fields.headline: Feast and famine
fields.trailText: Elliott Entis of Aqua Bounty claims rejecting GM fish would be a "terrible mistake" and miss a chance to save the world from starvation ('Feed the world' opportunity seen for GM salmon, April 22). The truly terrible mistake is to imagine that starvation can be solved by technology of any kind. The real villain is the system of world trade. For our award-winning BBC documentary Sex, Drugs And Dinner, with Alexei Sayle, we filmed in the Dominican Republic, a typical poor country, but not one of the poorest. Here the markets were full of food - what was lacking was the money to buy it with.
fields.body:
Elliott Entis of Aqua Bounty claims rejecting GM fish would be a "terrible mistake" and miss a chance to save the world from starvation ('Feed the world' opportunity seen for GM salmon, April 22). The truly terrible mistake is to imagine that starvation can be solved by technology of any kind. The real villain is the system of world trade. For our award-winning BBC documentary Sex, Drugs And Dinner, with Alexei Sayle, we filmed in the Dominican Republic, a typical poor country, but not one of the poorest. Here the markets were full of food - what was lacking was the money to buy it with.

A large proportion of third world countries have a failing agricultural system, unable to provide jobs or income in the face of impossible economic odds. We filmed coffee farmers, for example, who could only sell coffee at less than it cost to grow - unless they were lucky enough to find a Fair Trade buyer such as Cafe Direct. Then, as now, the poorest countries were exporting food to the rich, in a desperate and generally doomed attempt to earn dollars to keep afloat. Britain imports lentils from Ethiopia and mangos from the Sudan - even as the west continues to send in food aid.

Charles Harris
Paradise Grove Films charlie@harris.u-net.com

 The famine in Africa is being blamed on drought coupled with misgovernment. But these are only triggers. The underlying cause is increase in numbers of people, exceeding the capacity of land resources to support them. There is an ethically acceptable set of measures for reducing rates of population growth: improvement in the education and status of women, coupled with making family planning services available to all. Until greater efforts are made to check rates of population growth, famines will inexorably become more frequent and severe.

Anthony Young
Norwich

fields.headline: Chinese wall
fields.trailText: With the government confounding us with so many examples of its ethical foreign policy, the consequences of Britain's decision not to co-sponsor a US resolution in Geneva condemning China's human rights abuses has been overshadowed. China has succeeded yet again - for the ninth time in 10 years - in blocking the resolution with a no-action motion (Britain 'soft on Chinese abuses', April 14). During the time of Tony Blair's "quiet dialogue" China's iron fist has tightened its grip, with increases in the death penalty, imprisonment and torture, and a systematic raping of Tibet. While "quietly" talking human rights, Blair has in fact been actively negotiating the sale of the very weapons used by China to torture and oppress. It is horrifyingly clear by their silence where the British government stands.

webTitle: Miracles touch most in modern America

fields.headline: Miracles touch most in modern America
fields.trailText: Neither Easter Monday nor Good Friday is a public holiday in the US, but do not be fooled by that show of cool 21st century American secularism.
fields.body:
Neither Easter Monday nor Good Friday is a public holiday in the US, but do not be fooled by that show of cool 21st century American secularism.

Fundamental religious belief is every bit as strong among contemporary Americans as it was among the first settlers who crossed the Atlantic to seek religious freedom nearly four centuries ago.

Forget the man-made American economic miracle: according to a Newsweek poll published yesterday to mark Easter, an astonishing 84% of Americans believed that God performed real miracles.

Among Christians - who amount to about 160m of the US's 260m official residents - the proportion who believed in miracles was 90%. And the majority of non-Christians agreed with them.

Almost as big a proportion believed that the miracles described in the Bible were true: 79% of all those surveyed and 85% of Christians thought they actually took place.

Evangelical Protestants were the most likely to believe in the Bible's literal truth: 96% of them said they did.

But even the most sceptical denomination - the Roman Catholics - showed 77% support for the scriptures' literal truth.

The findings of the poll were very nearly as gratifying to the Devil they were to God.

Exactly three quarters said they believed that Satan or the Devil existed, and four fifths of Christians said they believed in the Devil.

According to the responses, a remarkably large proportion of Americans - 48% - say they have personally experienced or witnessed an event which they consider to have been miraculous. The figure for evangelical Protestants was 71%, for Catholics 38%.

The findings of the poll were very nearly as gratifying to the Devil they were to God. Exactly three quarters said they believed that Satan or the Devil existed, and four fifths of Christians said they believed in the Devil. According to the responses, a remarkably large proportion of Americans - 48% - say they have personally experienced or witnessed an event which they consider to have been miraculous. The figure for evangelical Protestants was 71%, for Catholics 38%.

fields.headline: Ethical policy is just talk
fields.body:
Hugo Young (Comment, April 18) is properly critical of Blair's spurious ethical foreign policy, but misses the point in one important respect. Russia is hurt by criticism over Chechnya - Putin is no Milosevic - but rebuffing him is by no means a sure way of forcing "concessions". Moscow's concessions over the last decade - giving up political influence in eastern Europe, the break-up of the USSR, signing up to arms control - have been met with a refusal to allow Russia more than a token voice in European affairs. Nato intervention in Yugoslavia and western rhetoric over Chechnya - seen by virtually the entire Moscow establishment as a case of double standards - is matched only by growing alarm over US defence policy; this has convinced Putin that realpolitik still dominates international relations, something for which Britain and the west bear as much responsibility as Russia, if not more. Blair is implicitly acknowledging this and bowing to the demands of the logic which will dominate relations with Russia during the Putin presidency.

Derek Averre
University of Birmingham
D.L.Averre@bham.ac.uk

 The prime minister believes the best way to register concerns and get results is dialogue not isolation. However, Iraq is being bombed daily by the US and UK for "humanitarian purposes" and dialogue has not only been ruled out, but there are plans to prevent senior figures from travelling. The aim has been widely stated "to keep Iraq in its box".

Serbia, too, has been bombed, embargoed and left to rot. Results "by dialogue not isolation"?

Felicity Arbuthnot
London

fields.headline: Give them all more money
fields.trailText: While there may be good reasons for paying extra for outstanding teaching (Leader, April 22), the crisis in education will not be solved until the government decides to fund pay increases for "merely" satisfactory teachers (ie the vast majority) which are higher than average earnings. For too long teachers, in common with other public sector workers, have been paid increases well below the average for the rest of us, and as a consequence they are seriously underpaid as well as undervalued.
fields.body:
While there may be good reasons for paying extra for outstanding teaching (Leader, April 22), the crisis in education will not be solved until the government decides to fund pay increases for "merely" satisfactory teachers (ie the vast majority) which are higher than average earnings. For too long teachers, in common with other public sector workers, have been paid increases well below the average for the rest of us, and as a consequence they are seriously underpaid as well as undervalued.

This, together with the additional demands placed on them by governments obsessed with league tables, is a major factor in persuading too many of our bright graduates there is no future in teaching for them. Your comparisons with Manchester United and the media are spurious; there are relatively few people involved in such activities whereas in teaching what is needed is not a few high flyers but a large number of good, competent, enthusiastic professionals.

John Carpenter
Morpeth, Northumberland

 So Manchester United are a good example of a team benefiting from performance pay? What about the other Premier teams who also pay their better players more highly yet end up getting relegated?

Rick Canning
Hinton St George, Somerset rcan@rcan.freeserve.co.uk

 I very much doubt performance related pay will improve recruitment into the teaching profession. People who choose to become teachers are unlikely to be strongly motivated by money in the first place and the sort of incentive that the government is offering is not going to impress those high flyers who want to make a killing. Study after study of PRP in the private sector has shown that it doesn' t affect performance one way or the other.

Furthermore, research suggests that criteria for establishing "excellent" performance are notoriously hard to set and tend to focus people narrowly on targets that will get them rewards. Employees often feel that standards are inequitable or arbitrary; this is precisely the point that many teachers have argued. Surely the way to attract young people back into teaching in schools is by reducing class sizes and the stress of the monitoring of standards. This is a far better reward for the dedication and efforts of all our teachers, and their students, than the route you suggest,

Amanda Rose
University of Westminster ARose52646@aol.com

 There are good reasons to doubt that PRP will improve practice. Time-servers will go through the motions ostentatiously and massage the results. The world of PRP is likely to be paradise for them. Conversely, the empty formulae of PRP are part of the same suppression of initiative, insight and creativity that deters any talented graduate from going into teaching in the first place.

The question for the unions is whether they can secure a rethink from the government, one which goes beyond fiddling with the parameters of a misconceived scheme, whilst avoiding the pitfalls of staffroom favouritism. If they can't, then calls for industrial action can't sensibly be ruled out. There's a limit to how much nonsense we can swallow in education.

Nigel Blake
Open University n.p.blake@open.ac.uk

 Why is the Guardian so unwilling to listen to teachers? That's who the delegates at the conferences actually are - real teachers from real schools. Yet these teachers are constantly derided as "extreme" or "out of touch". When the vast majority of teachers oppose the latest in a long line of market-driven schemes, maybe its time for the government (and the Guardian) to actually listen to what teachers are saying.

Clive Searle
Manchester
C.Searle@tesco.net

webTitle: Police step in as farm invasions continue

fields.headline: Police step in as farm invasions continue
fields.standfirst:
Tension eases in Zimbabwe after weekend of mixed signals

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe took a cautious step back towards political stability yesterday as a number of white farmers returned to their homesteads, opposition rallies passed off peacefully and police intervened to pacify squatters in some areas.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe took a cautious step back towards political stability yesterday as a number of white farmers returned to their homesteads, opposition rallies passed off peacefully and police intervened to pacify squatters in some areas.

In a weekend of mixed signals, a handful of farm occupations were overshadowed by deals between self-styled war veterans and farmers that allowed squatters to stay on land in return for peace and the promise that farmers would not harbour activists for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change.

Tension eased after a southern African summit at Victoria Falls on Friday appeared to come up with a formula for defusing the crisis. Leaders from South Africa, Mozambique, Zambia and Namibia apparently persuaded the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, to stop endorsing the farm occupations and hold elections while pushing Britain to fulfil its commitment to help fund land redistribution.

Delegates from the British and Zimbabwean governments are to meet in London on Thursday to discuss the issue, with both Britain and the US expected to help fund the purchase of white-owned land for distribution to black peasant farmers.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said the money would be given on condition that peace prevailed and that the land went to the poor.

"The starting point for our discussions will be the offer we made in 1998 to help fund a programme of land reform," he said. "But it has to be a programme that is within the rule of law and helps the rural poor. And the occupations have to stop."

The MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, welcomed the prospect of a land redistribution programme but warned that the international community should not use the apparent breakthrough to condone Mr Mugabe's tactics.

He told a rally on Saturday: "We need an orderly and fair distribution of land. We have no problem with that. But if they are endorsing Mugabe's lawlessness then we have a serious problem."

Hopes that the Easter weekend would pass peacefully were boosted when white farmers returned to the Macheke area, where the farmer David Stevens was killed the previous weekend. Elsewhere police moved on to some farms to prevent squatters causing damage to property or hurting the owners. Previously they simply looked on as the attacks took place, claiming that the occupations were a political matter.

On Saturday opposition rallies of several hundred people were held around the capital, Harare, without incident, in contrast to just a few weeks ago when MDC demonstrators were attacked by supporters of Zanu-PF, the ruling party.

But the situation remained volatile. On Saturday night there was a bomb attack on an opposition newspaper, the Daily News, in Harare. No one was hurt but the blast followed a death threat to the editor.

Meanwhile, sporadic land occupations continued. War veterans armed with guns and clubs invaded another white-owned farm yesterday, trapping the farm manager and two young women.

The Forresters farm in the Mvurwi area, about 60 miles north of Harare, was occupied by about 200 veterans, a member of a local farm support group said.

The group later reported that the crowd on the farm, one of the world's biggest tobacco operations, had swelled to about 700 and included labourers from nearby farms.

It said the farm manager Duncan Hamilton, briefly detained outside the farmhouse, had been sent inside to join the women. Journalists who tried to approach were turned back by the squatters and told not to return. Police put up roadblocks but took no further action.

On Saturday another white farmer north-east of Harare reported that 60 people armed with chains and wooden planks had occupied his property and assaulted him and a colleague.

Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party also stepped up its anti-white, anti-foreign rhetoric. In a full- page advertisement in yesterday's Standard newspaper the party told Zimbabweans: "Don't throw away that power [won through independence] by surrendering it to unrepentant racial and foreign interests with your hands open in the air." It was referring to the raised open palm, the symbol of the MDC.

fields.headline: Selling the pound short
fields.standfirst: Buying euros could help save Dagenham
fields.trailText: There are many factors behind the threatened closure of Ford's car plant at Dagenham. Most of them, like world overproduction and poor labour relations, are outside the power of government to change. But there is one vital factor which governments can influence: the value of the currency. Practically everyone, including most members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, believe the pound is seriously overvalued by anything up to 25%. It is one of the reasons why BMW's Longbridge plant is losing money, it is why the coal industry is demanding more subsidies to avoid yet more closures, why farming is doing so badly and why most of manufacturing is doing the only thing it can to survive: switch supplies abroad.
fields.body:
There are many factors behind the threatened closure of Ford's car plant at Dagenham. Most of them, like world overproduction and poor labour relations, are outside the power of government to change. But there is one vital factor which governments can influence: the value of the currency. Practically everyone, including most members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, believe the pound is seriously overvalued by anything up to 25%. It is one of the reasons why BMW's Longbridge plant is losing money, it is why the coal industry is demanding more subsidies to avoid yet more closures, why farming is doing so badly and why most of manufacturing is doing the only thing it can to survive: switch supplies abroad.

If the chancellor had tightened the fiscal stance in the budget (by cutting spending or, more appropriately raising taxes), the Bank would not have come under such pressure to raise interest rates - thereby risking an even more overvalued pound. But even if he is reluctant to raise interest rates there is something else the chancellor can do to bring down the pound - he can use some of the unexpected £19bn windfall profits he has just made (from selling off the radio spectrum for the next generation of mobile phones) to intervene on the foreign exchanges by selling pounds and buying foreign currencies, particularly euros.

The last time there was intervention (on Black Wednesday when Norman Lamont was chancellor) it was disastrous. But that was because he was trying to stop an overvalued currency from falling, a silly and impractical thing to do. It is quite different when you are intervening to stop an overvalued currency from going even higher - because underlying economics are in your favour. The money raised from selling euros could be used to buy long-term gilt-edged stock. This would plug any surge in the money supply caused by buying euros and give a boost to gilts at a time when shortage of demand has been depressing yields and holding down annuities (on which pensions are based). There is not much downside risk from this strategy and if Mr Brown's diagnosis is correct, that the problem is a weak euro rather than strong pound, then buying them now could be a very profitable activity when the euro recovers. Time, maybe, for Mr Brown to put his not inconsiderable money where his mouth is.

fields.headline: Spoilt for choice
fields.standfirst: Not as new as it sounds, but getting worse
fields.trailText: It was bound to happen. The ultimate goal of the consumer society - free and unfettered choice - is proving more challenging than advocates were ready to acknowledge. The plethora of choices in modern society, according to a survey by Abbey National, is adding to the stress of life. This is not as new a problem as the survey suggests. The 14th-century French moral philosopher, Jean Buridan, created the celebrated allegory of Buridan's ass, which died of starvation when, placed between two equally attractive piles of hay, it was unable to decide which to turn to. But earlier generations, as the chirpy 19th-century proverb suggests, had an easier time when "you pays your money and you takes your choice".
fields.body:
It was bound to happen. The ultimate goal of the consumer society - free and unfettered choice - is proving more challenging than advocates were ready to acknowledge. The plethora of choices in modern society, according to a survey by Abbey National, is adding to the stress of life. This is not as new a problem as the survey suggests. The 14th-century French moral philosopher, Jean Buridan, created the celebrated allegory of Buridan's ass, which died of starvation when, placed between two equally attractive piles of hay, it was unable to decide which to turn to. But earlier generations, as the chirpy 19th-century proverb suggests, had an easier time when "you pays your money and you takes your choice".

Just a generation ago, life was simpler. Compare the 40,000 items in a modern supermarket with the old style of shopping described by a 70-year-old: "In my day we just had roast on Sunday, bubble and squeak on Monday, shepherd's pie on Tuesday and fish on Friday - every day you knew what you were going to eat". According to the survey, almost 50% of women and 20% of men have trouble deciding what to eat each evening. It does not stop there. A modern coffee bar - with its 11 types of coffee, four added toppings, three types of milk and sugar, plus choice of decaffeinated or extra cream - has 6,000 different permutations of coffee. A similar over supply of choices faces car buyers (over 1,600 makes and models), book buyers (200,000 volumes in the modern high street bookshop), or television viewer (180 TV channels).

Psychologists acknowledge increases in choice do not necessarily lead to an increase in feelings of well being: you can be overloaded with choice, making informed decisions impossible. Even so, it is an improvement on an earlier age when, as Samuel Johnson noted: Liberty is, to the lowest rank of every nation, little more than a choice of working or starving.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Call to curb powers of world firms
fields.body:
Call to curb powers of world firms

Trade rules are widely disliked by the public who believe governments should have greater powers to ban imports which may damage health and the environment, an opinion poll reveals.

The poll, the first on the World Trade Organisation's powers to police trade, shows that government policy is out of line with public opinion, according to the Ecologist magazine which commissioned the poll from Mori.

Multinational companies are widely disliked and the public want their powers curbed, the magazine concludes. Examples of where the WTO had overruled local environment and health objections had clearly upset public opinion.

The report says: "There is clearly strong public support for the principle of government protection - at least against the interests of multi-national companies."

The poll found "large majorities oppose some of the key principles of WTO, and the current global economic system".

The poll was conducted among a representative sample of 982 adults.
Paul Brown

When your home is your fortune

The average British home could be worth £1m by 2040, according to a new survey.

Research commissioned by BT Internet has revealed that the cost of the average home is expected to escalate from £79,393 within 40 years.

The research, conducted by Future Foundation, was based on a range of sources including the retail price index and the labour force survey. Calculations were based on average 6.6% annual growth rates of the last 20 years.

Non-homeowners were advised to look to saving their monthly income as the next most likely route to making a million.

On current average earnings of about £20,000 gross per annum it would take 50 years to amass £1m, but this ignores tax and spending.

The Future Foundation study says today's millionaires are up to nine times poorer than their 1970s predecessors with £9.2m today buying what £1m would have bought in 1970.

Paris: the Southport of the south?

The tree-lined boulevards of Paris may have been inspired by a northern seaside town, according to Quentin Hughes, a retired architectural historian.

He believes Napoleon III was so taken by the design of Lord Street in Southport that he used it as his inspiration to remodel parts of the French capital.

Professor Hughes has found proof Napoleon III rented a house, South Lawn, that looked out over Lord Street. Prof Hughes said: "Southport has been known as the Paris of the north, but it is time Paris was known as the Southport of the south."
