webTitle: Shoppers dislike being spoilt for choice

fields.headline: Shoppers dislike being spoilt for choice
fields.standfirst: Consumers bewildered by thousands of brands
fields.trailText: Researchers have confirmed the suspicions of shoppers trawling shopping centres this bank holiday - modern living has left many lost in a bewildering snowstorm of choice.
fields.body:
Researchers have confirmed the suspicions of shoppers trawling shopping centres this bank holiday - modern living has left many lost in a bewildering snowstorm of choice.

A consumer group, The Future Foundation, says its research, carried out in conjunction with Abbey National, shows an American-style revolution in British consumerism has failed to enrich our lives but has caused confusion and anxiety as people struggle with the mind-boggling array of options available.

Far from variety being the spice of life the once straightforward chore of grocery shopping has been complicated hugely over the past 20 years.

Two decades ago the typical supermarket was stocked with 5,000 different lines, but it now boasts 40,000 separate products, including 400 brands of shampoo and nearly 100 different types of toothbrush. While 20 years ago buying water may have seemed absurd, Sainsbury's Leeds store now boasts a staggering 101 lines.

This trend has also been reflected in the vogue for high street coffee shops. They offer up to 6,000 permutations of coffee, milk, topping and sugar - if you bought one a day it would take nearly 17 years to try them all.

Michael Willmott, founder of The Future Foundation, initiated the survey of 1,000 adults to find out what irritates people most about modern living and his findings suggested the consumer explosion is a big factor complicating our already busy and complex lives. Mr Willmott said: "Individual choice can be very empowering but, as this new research demonstrates, it brings hassles too.

"Consumers are feeling overwhelmed and it is starting to have a negative effect on people, making them feel anxious and stressed about making the right choice.

"But our research shows that consumers are finding their own solutions to cope with this situation. Choosing well-known brands is one, but some people are starting to employ less obvious strategies like buying only organic products or shopping only on a Friday when the supermarket shelves are emptier.

"In this way they are consciously limiting the products available to them.

"But some are unable to cope. One man interviewed during our survey went out to buy his mother a mobile phone but was so confused by the number of different makes and tariffs available he bought her an electric whisk instead."

Two mothers in their 40s surveyed said: "We have to get different sorts of cereal for everyone and it is the same with coffee and shampoo."

A 70-year-old woman said: "In my day we just had roast on Sunday, bubble and squeak rissoles on Monday, shepherd's pie on Tuesday and fish on Friday - every day you knew what you were going to eat."

Guy Fielding, a psychologist from Oxford University, claims product saturation was reached more than 25 years ago.

He said the British public have been encouraged to adopt an American attitude to consumerism to accommodate this choice revolution.

"Many British people used to deride the Americans asking why they needed so much consumer choice," he said. "But now with the number of possibilities expanding in Britain we too are expected to be active and informed choosers where once our product consumption was marked by familiarity.

"The increase in choice has not necessarily lead to a similar increase in feelings of well-being. You can be over-loaded with choice, making informed decisions impossible.

"In such circumstances people select products at random and feel as though their ability to choose has be taken away. Then they are left with a nag ging feeling that their choice has not been the best one."

Responding to the report, a spokesman for Sainsbury's said: "As a supermarket we simply respond to consumer demand, nothing stays on the shelf unless the customer wants it. We think that it is fantastic that the public can be offered so much variety."

Supermarkets 40,000 lines

Books Average bookshop has more than 200,000 titles

Cars 1,600 models

Eating out Food from 150 regions in London restaurants

Radio Nearly 250 stations

Coffee 6000 permutations of coffee, milk, topping, sugar and size

Sandwiches Average sandwich shop has 50 types

Music Average record shop has over 1000 titles on offer

Holiday 150 tour operators, thousands of destinations

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Third of callers misdialled
fields.body:
Third of callers misdialled

A third of callers using new 020 codes for London misdialled yesterday morning, although the figure settled down to 20% by mid-afternoon. Callers using old codes for London, Portsmouth, Southampton, Coventry, Cardiff and Northern Ireland heard a voice recording of the correct code.

Man accused of girl's murder

A 23-year-old man was last night charged with the murder of Carol Sanderson, 16, who was found strangled in a park in south-east London. Christopher Levey of Crystal Palace, south-east London, will appear at Croydon magistrates court today.

Comeback for Penny Black

The Royal Mail is to reprint the Penny Black, the first ever postage stamp, at the Stamp Show 2000 next month - 160 years after it was first issued. First class stamps will go up by 1p to 27p on Thursday, the first rise in nearly four years.

Compensation for Posh bags

Spice Girl Victoria Beckham will receive compensation thought to be £100,000 after her baggage went missing at Heathrow airport, British Airways has confirmed.

One winner of £9m jackpot

One ticket won Saturday night's £8,890,009 National Lottery jackpot Winning numbers were 26, 31, 35, 43, 48 and 49. The bonus number was 38.

One ticket won the £250,000 top prize in the Thunderball game, matching numbers 2, 4, 5, 16 and 29 and Thunderball 8.

fields.headline: House rules
fields.standfirst:
There are several ways to restructure the Lords, but Tony Blair seems to be in no great hurry. Meanwhile, the peers are up to their old tricks

Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: There are almost as many ways to assess Tony Blair's half-reform of the House of Lords as there are hereditary peers who have survived their expulsion and lived on to speak and cast their hereditary votes into the 21st century. That number is usually taken as 92, 75 of them elected by their peers (literally so in this case), party by party, plus senior office-holders. They survived under the deal which Lord Cranborne, heir to the ancient Cecil titles, did with Tony Blair behind William Hague's back. It cost him his shadow cabinet job.
fields.body:
There are almost as many ways to assess Tony Blair's half-reform of the House of Lords as there are hereditary peers who have survived their expulsion and lived on to speak and cast their hereditary votes into the 21st century. That number is usually taken as 92, 75 of them elected by their peers (literally so in this case), party by party, plus senior office-holders. They survived under the deal which Lord Cranborne, heir to the ancient Cecil titles, did with Tony Blair behind William Hague's back. It cost him his shadow cabinet job.

But that calculation omits the startling spectacle of ancient hereditaries such as Lord Cranborne himself being sent back to the Lords by Mr Blair as a life peer, along with a clutch of other re-appointed ex-hereditaries, including five Labour life peers with such exotic names as Anthony Fitzhardinge Gueterbock.

No wonder that, give or take Lord Michael Ashcroft of Belize and the occasional gay, Asian entrepreneur like Lord Waheed Alli, the tone of the old place has not changed much at all. Most of the regulars have survived Blair's butchery. The Lords may still be a mish-mash, but after almost a century of talk his government has finally broken the dominance of inherited political power over the gorgeous, Pugin-designed, gilded fantasy that is Britain's upper house.

The survivors are a remnant. Instead of there being 750 or so hereditaries (400 of them taking the Tory whip) out of 1,100 peers in the old Lords, 650 have gone. Of the remaining 665 or so, no party has a majority, much as Labour's 1997 manifesto promised will be the case hereafter.

There are 232 Tories facing 181 Labour; the 54 Lib Dems and 116 crossbenchers between them arbitrate controversial votes like section 28 or the right to jury trial, usually in favour of tradition. There are still 26 bishops and six assorted law lords.

Ethnic minorities and faiths can expect a few more seats to make the old place more representative of New Britain. At present only 105 of the 665 are women. But it is going to take time - to the fury of dangerous radicals such as, well, Lord Hattersley, who dislikes the place but took the peerage that was an ex-cabinet member's due.

Labour's 1992 manifesto spoke boldly of creating an elected second chamber, plain and simple. "Regionally based" was the talk at the time. In 1997 Labour spoke of a two-stage reform, hereditaries out first, then a fairer appointments system and a "wide-ranging review" on how best to make the Lords "more democratic and more representative." The word election was not mentioned. So it should come as little surprise that as the expected 2001 election looms for MPs at the other end of the building, ministers should feel in no rush to do stage two.

In January, Lord Wakeham's royal commission produced a cautious document which Lord Wakeham, a natural fixer, said would please no one too much but would be a workable basis for progress. He acknowledged the Commons's supremacy and gave the Lords (he ducked a change of title to senate) broadly similar powers to check the executive branch.

The trouble is the balance between appointment and election in Wakeham's 550-plus chamber. Wakeham made no secret of his own scepticism. Busy men and women of suitable quality would not want to stand for election. Wakeham came up with three options, two of them blatantly non-starters:  the minimalist version: 65 regional members be elected on the same day as a general election, allocated from lists drawn up by parties in proportion to the votes cast for each party in the 12 British regions;  the maximalist version: 65 regional peers directly elected by voters using the "partially open" regional list (you can vote for a party or a person) on Euro-election day and serve for three four-year terms; 195 elected members in all; There was also Model B placed in the middle and clearly what the Blairites will settle for if they can.  the compromise: 87 regional members elected by thirds at each European election, using the Euro-election method of "closed" party lists (you can only pick a party).

Naturally Mr Blair has not said that 87 peers/senators will have an elected mandate; they are about as much as he will stomach. Old right and old left combine with Blairite control freakery to assert the supremacy of what is currently a very pliable Commons. But that is the message which the constitutional enthusiasts in the Lib Dems and Charter 88 are getting from his ministers, notably Baroness Jay, whose unbending manner the Opposition does not love.

The official position remains that Lady Jay wants to convene a cross-party committee to thrash out a consensus, but that the opposition parties are being tiresome. Another try will be made after Easter, but the government will probably shelve the committee until after the coming general election when its manifesto will promise early action to end the temporary "stage one" arrangements. Ministers are keen to act before the 92 elected hereditaries can tweak the government's tail by staging a byelection after one of their number dies. Meanwhile the half-reformed peers are claiming fresh legitimacy and have defeated the government 10 times since Christmas.

As for the new independent appointments commission, peers teased each other last week as to who would appoint the appointers. Many peers do not love New Labour (even New Labour peers rebel) and more defeats are promised before polling day. It is the political equivalent of Viagra.

Michael White is our political editor

michael.white@theguardian.com

webTitle: Two die after fall on climb

fields.headline: Two die after fall on climb
fields.trailText: Two climbers died yesterday after they fell 400ft into a gully while scaling a mountain in the Scottish Highlands.
fields.body:
Two climbers died yesterday after they fell 400ft into a gully while scaling a mountain in the Scottish Highlands.

The two men, who were roped together, were near the summit of Buachaille Etive Mor in Glencoe when they are believed to have slipped. A naval helicopter was scrambled from HMS Gannet in Prestwick, Ayrshire, after another group of climbers heard the men's shouts and alerted Glencoe mountain rescue by mobile phone at about 4.30pm.

The climbers, who were not named, were found dead in Crowberry Gully.

It was not known last night whether they had dislodged rocks while descending, or whether they had been hit by rocks dislodged by climbers above them.

The two other members of their party continued their ascent, unaware that their companions had died. John Grieve, of Glencoe mountain rescue team, said: "Their fellow climbers were made aware [of what had happened] when they reached the road at the other side of the summit."

The men's bodies were airlifted off the mountain, he said.

A total of 60,000 walkers and climbers were in the area at the weekend, where conditions for rock and ice climbs were described as good.

fields.headline: RA reaps Monet effect
fields.trailText: The Royal Academy's decision to hold Britain's first 24-hour art show helped to make it one of the most popular tourist attractions, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The Royal Academy's decision to hold Britain's first 24-hour art show helped to make it one of the most popular tourist attractions, it was announced yesterday.

With the aid of the rush to view the Monet exhibition, the gallery entered the English Tourism Council's top 10 tourist attractions of 1999 in eighth place with 1.39m visitors against 912,714 in 1998.

Alton Towers theme park in Staffordshire remained the top attraction. Madame Tussaud's waxworks museum was next.

In its first full year of charging an entrance fee for the whole building Westminster Abbey attracted 1.27m and was the 11th most popular attraction.

Blackpool Pleasure beach remained the top free attraction with an estimated 7.2m visits, followed by the British Museum (5.46m) . "The UK's established attractions are still very popular, but there is no room for complacency," said ETC chief executive, Mary Lynch.

The top 10 attractions charging admission in 1999 were: Alton Towers, Staffordshire, with 2.65m visits; Madame Tussaud's, London, 2.64m; Tower of London, 2.4m; Natural History Museum, London, 1.7m; Legoland, Windsor, Berkshire, 1.6m; Chessington World of Adventures, 1.55m; Science Museum, London, 1.48m; Royal Academy, London, 1.39m; Canterbury Cathedral, 1.35m; Windsor Castle, 1.28m.

webTitle: Incensed police seek to bar parole for triple murderer

fields.headline: Incensed police seek to bar parole for triple murderer
fields.standfirst: 'Life should mean life' for killer of officers, says federation
fields.trailText: The Police Federation yesterday urged prison authorities to stop parole being granted to Harry Roberts, the armed robber jailed for the murder of three police officers who were shot dead 34 years ago.
fields.body:
The Police Federation yesterday urged prison authorities to stop parole being granted to Harry Roberts, the armed robber jailed for the murder of three police officers who were shot dead 34 years ago.

The federation was reacting to the news that Roberts, 64, was moved from Ashwell prison in Leicestershire to Sudbury open prison in Derbyshire earlier this month in preparation for possible release.

Yesterday a Prison Service spokeswoman said: "He will undergo interview by parole board, where it will be decided whether he is eligible for release. It could be within a couple of years. There is no time limit on how this progresses."

Fred Broughton, chairman of the federation, said that it was imperative that police officers should have the protection of the law. "Life must mean life for Harry Roberts."

Roberts was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1966 for the triple murder in Shepherd's Bush, west London.

He and the other members of his gang, John Duddy and John Witney, both now dead, had been stopped by the CID officers while on their way to an armed robbery. As DC David Wombwell, 25, and Sgt Christopher Head, 30, walked up to question the men, Roberts pulled out a 9mm Luger pistol and shot DC Wombwell, and then Sgt Head. When the third officer, PC Ge offrey Fox, 41, tried to drive off to get help, he was shot through the windscreen by Duddy.

Within a week police had arrested Duddy and Witney, but Roberts, then aged 29, caused what was at the time the biggest manhunt in the Metropolitan police's history. He was caught three months after the shootings, living in a camouflage den made out of plastic bags and branches near Bishop's Stortford, Hertfordshire.

The gang was jailed at the Old Bailey in December 1966, where the trial judge recommended Roberts serve at least 30 years in jail.

His possible release outraged officers of all ranks, according to Norman Brennan, a serving officer who heads the police pressure group Protect the Protectors. "It is an utter disgrace that this is even being considered," he said. "What justification can there be?"

PC Fox's son Paul, who lives in Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire, said: "It is very hard to come to terms with the idea that this man will be released."

DC Wombwell's mother Daphne, 78, who lives in Suffolk, said: "I'm horrified. He will only go out and harm someone else. He's a violent man. I was at the trial and sat two feet away from him. He showed no remorse at all."

Duddy died in prison in 1981, aged 51, and Witney, who was freed in 1991, died at his home in Bristol last August, aged 69.

webTitle: BBC invests in new-look money show

fields.headline: BBC invests in new-look money show
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is poised to replace the high-minded Money Programme with a more "accessible" alternative. Jane Root, the controller of BBC2, is examining the current affairs output on her channel and is deeply unhappy with the financial analysis programme.
fields.body:
The BBC is poised to replace the high-minded Money Programme with a more "accessible" alternative. Jane Root, the controller of BBC2, is examining the current affairs output on her channel and is deeply unhappy with the financial analysis programme.

In a separate move Roger Mosey, the head of television news, is leading plans to merge the breakfast news shows on BBC1 and BBC News 24.

Executives insist that the new-look Money Programme - first broadcast in 1966 - will not be "dumbed down", but will present business stories in a more comprehensible way. The programme will be completely overhauled to rid it of its stuffy image, gained after a relaunch under the last director general, John Birt.

While Money Programme investigations occasionally make the headlines, it is not a "must-watch" among the business community, and fails to attract the wider audiences that turn to business shows such as Trouble at the Top or Working Lunch.

The programme claims to reach 60m viewers on BBC2 and BBC World channels. It is billed as the corporation's flagship business and economics programme and since 1997 has been presented by Maya Even.

Mr Mosey told editorial staff on BBC Breakfast News and BBC News 24 last week of the plans to merge the two programmes. There will be 33 job losses, including 28 journalists.

Development of the new programme is well under way and it is believed it will bring back sofas to the breakfast television slot in a drive to popularise its least-watched news and current affairs shows.

The new show will be presented by Jeremy Bowen, the BBC's Middle East correspondent, and its Breakfast News presenter Sophie Raworth. Moira Stuart is to return to daily newscasting after being axed from the six o'clock news, presenting regular bulletins within the new programme.

A new set is being designed by Martin Lambie Nairn, responsible for the look of BBC news studios. Bowen and Raworth will not sit behind a desk, but will be in a maroon and cream-coloured studio that has a "contemporary feel".

It is understood that sofas are under consideration, echoing the BBC's first attempt at breakfast television - Frank Bough and Selina Scott lolled on leather sofas when Breakfast Time was launched in 1983.

"The exact furniture arrangements have not yet been worked out," a senior news executive said yesterday.

The programme will be transmitted simultaneously on BBC1 and BBC News 24 from 6am to 9am. It will run seven days a week, but the weekend shows will only be broadcast on News 24.

The BBC is determined to put up a stronger rival to the breakfast output on Sky News and GMTV - which gets 1.5m viewers. The BBC1 programme struggles to achieve 1m.

fields.headline: Blair in Ford crisis talks
fields.standfirst: Fear of motor industry collapse prompts PM's intervention
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has held secret crisis talks with the global head of the carmaker Ford amid fears of a meltdown in the British car industry, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has held secret crisis talks with the global head of the carmaker Ford amid fears of a meltdown in the British car industry, it was revealed last night.

The prime minister met Jack Nasser, head of Ford global operations, at Downing Street and urged him not to end car production at Dagenham.

The government fears ending assembly of cars at the Essex plant will anger unions and spark a wave of strikes that could provoke Ford into even more drastic cuts in its operations throughout Britain.

Downing Street officials have met car union leaders separately to discuss the proposed closures. They are said to have impressed on the unions the seriousness of the position and the need for the workforce to do everything possible to boost production.

Ford is reported to be announcing its restructuring in the next few weeks, including the ending of car production at Dagenham, with the loss of 3,000 jobs.

The prime minister, desperate to avoid a repeat of the political fallout from BMW's decision to pull out of the Rover plant at Longbridge, has also been in frequent telephone contact with Nick Scheele, the chairman of Ford Europe.

Mr Blair is said to be anxious to ensure that there is no rerun of the BMW fiasco at Longbridge, when the German manufacturer kept ministers in the dark over its plans to close not just the plant, but most of its mass car production facility. More than 19,000 jobs are threatened in the West Midlands.

The prime minister, who met the Detroit-based Ford boss two weeks ago, is not in a position to offer the manufacturers short-term subsidies because of strict EU subsidy rules.

He also can do nothing in the short term about the high level of sterling, one of the central reasons for closures cited by the British-based car makers.

Ford has focused on reduc ing its European car production capacity after the company reported losses of £72m on its overseas operations in the first three months of the year.

Managers at Dagenham have repeatedly criticised productivity levels, citing high levels of absenteeism and unofficial strikes. Ford managers down the years have claimed that productivity levels are higher at the company's plant in Cologne, where the next generation of Ford Fiestas seems destined to be built.

Mr Scheele met British union leaders last week and told them no decisions had been taken about Dagenham's future. Union sources said he had assured them they would be fully consulted in the event of any job losses.

But car assembly at Dagenham has been gradually run down in the past couple of years and a decision to end it next month when Ford announces its major European restructuring would come as no surprise, given worldwide overcapacity.

Closing down the car assembly line would mean the loss of just under 3,000 jobs but up to 300 of those workers could be transferred to Ford's highly successful engine building operation, which is expected to remain open.

In the meantime, unions are not ruling out strike action. Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU, said: "Ford has given us a number of pledges over the future of Dagenham. They have committed themselves to car assembly at the plant and we expect them to honour that commitment in full. If the car assembly line is closed or run down we will be very hostile to that outcome."

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB union, said: "If these reports of a closure are true then it would be a catastrophe for Dagenham and for UK car production. However, we still believe there is something to play for. Ministers must fight to the death to protect car production and jobs at the Dagenham plant."

The Department of Trade and Industry said: "Ford has made it clear to the government that its present review is looking at the problems of overproduction and excess capacity across its operations throughout Europe.

"This review is not centred on issues which solely affect the UK. We expect an announcement from Ford about the outcome of the review within the next few weeks."

webTitle: PM backs national rules on adoption

fields.headline: PM backs national rules on adoption
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will this week step up his drive to improve the adoption system when he urges specialists to adopt a national framework of adoption rules.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will this week step up his drive to improve the adoption system when he urges specialists to adopt a national framework of adoption rules.

Ministers have been frustrated by the slowness of some local authority social services departments, the inconsistency of rules and the tendency of some children to become institutionalised in care homes.

The Local Government Association responded to Downing Street pressure by setting up an adoption task force, which recommends local authorities to use innovative approaches such as the internet, through secure encrypted sites, to match children with prospective adoptive parents.

The LGA also aims to encourage the formation of more local authority adoption consortiums, which give authorities a wider region in which to seek matches while enabling children to stay in a familiar area and in contact with friends.

Acknowledging that the performance of councils is patchy, the task force will produce a best practice leaflet so that lessons from those with an excellent adoption record can be learned by others.

Councils claim that the recruitment crisis in social work is leaving too many parents who want to adopt waiting too long to be assessed for registration.

They also fear that the pressure to speed up adoption could, if pushed too far, result in more failed placements, a pattern found in the 1980s during a similar initiative.

Mr Blair will propose a national register of children seeking adoption and couples eager to adopt. At present there are 1,267 applicant adopters and 2,400 children, many in care homes, seeking adoption.

The prime minister, in an interview for the women's magazine Red, underlined the well trailed government shake-up of the system by saying: "I want to make it easier for children to be placed quickly. The most important thing is that children are in a loving family rather than a care home, however well it is run."

Ministers believe social services departments are delaying processing applications by setting over-complex rules.
